        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>The American composer <a href=\"http://philipglass.com/\">Philip Glass</a>, 80 this month, has been one of the dominant, boundary-crossing influences of the past half century. He first won a worldwide following in the 1970s with <em>Koyaanisqatsi</em>, <em>Einstein on the Beach </em>and <em>Satyagraha</em>, and has collaborated with Allen Ginsberg, Robert Wilson, Doris Lessing, Martin Scorsese, Ravi Shankar, David Bowie, Paul Simon and many more. Glass\u2019s birthday will be marked with a production by Scottish Opera of his opera <a href=\"https://www.scottishopera.org.uk/our-operas/16-17/the-trial\"><em>The Trial</em></a><em> </em>and a <a href=\"https://www.barbican.org.uk/music/series.asp?ID=1697\">Philip Glass at 80</a> weekend at the Barbican.</p> <p><strong>It seems that no one \u2013 not you, or Steve Reich, or John Adams \u2013 likes being called a minimalist. What do we call you if not that?</strong><br />Let\u2019s talk about this. The problem is no one is doing minimalism now. It\u2019s music we wrote in the 1970s. It\u2019s over 30 years out of date. It\u2019s a crazy idea to use a description made up by journalists and editors to cover all kinds of music. It\u2019s more confusing than descriptive. What do I really do? Listen to me. I\u2019ve written 26 operas, 20 ballets, I don\u2019t know how many film scores. I write theatre music. I write concert and symphonies too. I\u2019m working on a new film score right now. Then I\u2019ll start a new stage piece. My problem is people don\u2019t believe I write symphonies. But I\u2019m <a href=\"http://www.carnegiehall.org/Calendar/2017/1/31/0730/PM/Bruckner-Orchestra-Linz/\">premiering Symphony No 11 </a>in a couple of weeks. These are all different forms of music. Maybe I do too many things.</p> <p><strong>But it\u2019s the description that sticks: Philip Glass, the great American minimalist\u2026</strong><br />If people called me an American opera composer it would have the virtue of being what I actually do. This is reality. God forbid we should be accurate. I\u2019m not making this stuff up. Would it be easier to say I\u2019m an Icelandic composer who writes serial music? Would that be helpful? [Silence, then laughter.] I\u2019m a theatre composer.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"f5a40bf39d6a41ac35a1efab698a9077c5805e74\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/f5a40bf39d6a41ac35a1efab698a9077c5805e74/452_0_1383_1569/881.jpg\" alt=\"Philip Glass in Linz, Austria earlier this month for rehearsals of his Symphony No 11.\" width=\"881\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Philip Glass in Linz, Austria earlier this month for rehearsals of his Symphony No 11.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Werner Kerschbaummayr/ AFP/ Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>A lot of people want to hear my music of the 1970s and 1980s. And do you know what I do? I play it. I talk to Paul Simon or anyone like that and it\u2019s the same. I say, \u201cwhat do you play live, Paul?\u201d and he says \u201cI play my new songs and I play my hits\u201d. And it\u2019s true. If you go to hear Paul Simon, you want to hear Bridge Over Troubled Water. The new work, by the way, is beautiful, but it\u2019s not why you buy the ticket. You want to hear the old ones. It\u2019s the same for me when I play with my ensemble [the Philip Glass Ensemble]. We\u2019ve been together 40 years. We play the familiar stuff, the highlights.</p> <p><strong>So you\u2019re saying, then, you play\u2026 minimalism</strong>!<br />Well, yes, I admit I am part of the confusion. We\u2019ve reworked a piece from 1971. And, guess what, it\u2019s minimalist! OK OK OK, I\u2019m just as bad as the journalists [more laughs].</p> <p><strong>Growing up in Baltimore, Maryland, you stoked your own musical curiosity by listening to unsold stock in your father\u2019s record store. Was there one really striking discovery?</strong><br />Not one, though I listened to everything \u2013 what we called \u201chillbilly\u201d and Buddy Holly and R&amp;B, as well as Beethoven quartets and things that were quite modern then \u2013 Shostakovich and Bart\u00f3k. But as far as records in the shop were concerned, there was always lots of contemporary music \u2013 <a href=\"http://www.charlesives.org/\">Charles Ives</a>, the great American composer. And the <a href=\"http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b086t9mw\">Second Viennese school</a> \u2013 Berg, Webern and, to a lesser extent, Schoenberg. I sent off for his book on basic harmony \u2013 couldn\u2019t find it in the Baltimore bookstores \u2013 and followed it to the letter. It was very traditional!</p> <p>But look, I was devouring a whole range of repertoire at that stage. I was studying music at the Peabody Institute. As a nine- or 10-year-old I was taking part in Bach masses in church performances. At high school they wanted to put on shows, so what did they do? Gilbert and Sullivan! I played flute in the orchestra. I got to understand how theatre works: the musicians in the pit, the timing, the getting singers on and off stage. It\u2019s not a bad way to learn your craft. It gave me a good solid background. When, years later, I came to write opera, I felt comfortable about all that.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>The people who don\u2019t want your music don\u2019t change their minds. You outlive them, if you\u2019re lucky</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p><strong>You went off to the University of Chicago, prodigiously early at 15, then to the Juilliard school in New York. But the big break was when you went to Europe. You\u2019ve said you had two angels sitting on your shoulder, your two great teachers, Nadia Boulanger and Ravi Shankar.</strong><br />I\u2019ve always said one taught through fear, one through love. Nadia Boulanger was the great guru in Paris. She was tremendously fierce. She taught me Bach, Beethoven, Mozart \u2013 every tool of western art music \u2013 with an iron rod. It was, in essence, about understanding technique. Then there was <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/ravi-shankar\">Ravi Shankar</a>, a master of Indian concert music. I met him in 1964. So I had two of the greatest exponents of different traditions at the same time. I was about 25 and Ravi was almost 20 years older. I was like a student. I stayed close to him for a long time. We collaborated. I spoke with him just days before he died.</p> <p><strong>Your long immersion in Indian music and philosophy, trying to go beyond cultural tourism, has shaped your outlook, practical and aesthetic\u2026</strong><br />That time in India, which included long stays as well as many shorter ones, visiting frequently from the late 60s until 2001, opened a door to the world of global music. Until then I\u2019d been immersed in European art music. In Kerala I encountered <a href=\"http://www.kathakali.net/\">kathakali</a>, the classical Indian dance theatre which had an influence on my own operas, such as <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/nov/25/how-we-made-satyagraha\"><em>Satyagraha</em></a>. Back then, hearing anything beyond western music wasn\u2019t easy. You couldn\u2019t find records, except a few specialist discs of music collected by anthropologists. If you wanted to hear Balinese music you pretty much had to go to Bali. It\u2019s hard to believe that now.</p> <p><strong>Do you feel you have done what you set out to achieve as a young man? Or does it only make sense now, looking back?</strong><br />I decided early on I wouldn\u2019t be a music teacher or an academic. So as soon as I got back from my studies in Europe in 1967 I formed my ensemble \u2013 seven musicians playing keyboards and a variety of woodwinds, amplified and fed through a mixer\u2026 I felt I had no choice but to be a performer. By then my flute playing had dropped off but I\u2019d sharpened up my keyboard skills. The point of the ensemble was to play the music I\u2019d written. We rehearsed in my house, we played my music! That was the deal. (We did make exceptions and play other stuff, when we rehearsed elsewhere.) And I could sense the response of the audience. Those audiences were tiny at first of course. Sometimes just 20 or so people. And then we got more successful, but it was a long, long time before we made any money. That took another 10 or 15 years.</p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/video/2016/oct/13/watch-a-clip-from-philip-glass-einstein-on-the-beach\"            data-short-url=\"https://gu.com/p/56ztz\"                    data-show-ads=\"true\"            data-video-id=\"2793309\"            data-video-name=\"Watch a clip from Philip Glass's Einstein on the Beach\"            data-video-provider=\"guardian.co.uk\"            > <video data-media-id=\"gu-video-57fb71d4e4b06538ee91e188\" class=\"gu-video\" controls=\"controls\" poster=\"\"> <source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/mainwebsite/2016/10/10/161010EinsteinOnTheBeach_KP-29666704_desk.mp4\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/HLS/2016/10/10/161010EinsteinOnTheBeach_KP-29666704.m3u8\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/webM/2016/10/10/161010EinsteinOnTheBeach_KP-29666704_WebM.webm\"/> </video> <figcaption><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/video/2016/oct/13/watch-a-clip-from-philip-glass-einstein-on-the-beach\">Watch a clip from Philip Glass\u2019s Einstein on the Beach</a></figcaption> </figure>   <p><strong><em>Einstein on the Beach</em> was a massive hit in 1976 yet you still had to drive a taxi and work as a plumber.</strong><br />Yes, after <em>Einstein on the Beach </em>I went back to driving a New York cab. I didn\u2019t mind that. It was interesting work. I didn\u2019t have an agent. I ran all the business side of it and the box office myself. I enjoyed it. I grew up in the music business. I was happy to do it. But it took at lot of time and work. In 1979 when we did our first Carnegie Hall concert we had to pay for it, and sell the tickets! Eventually I formed a publishing company and had people doing it for me. I didn\u2019t do it for them!</p> <p><strong>Have the old divisions between musical styles \u2013 a source of surprisingly bitter contention in the last decades of the 20th century \u2013 now healed? Do people now accept your chosen path of tonal harmony, melody, repetitive structures?</strong><br />No no no no no. Those divisions never healed. Those people just died! The people who don\u2019t want you don\u2019t change their minds. You outlive them, if you\u2019re lucky. They\u2019re all dead now, the older guys. The battle was never won or lost. The army just went away. What can I tell you? Isn\u2019t that the truth? It\u2019s biology. Nothing more than that. They\u2019ve just gone away\u2026 and we carry on playing.</p> <ul> <li><a href=\"https://www.scottishopera.org.uk/our-operas/16-17/the-trial\">Philip Glass\u2019s The Trial</a> is at the Theatre Royal, Glasgow (24-28 Jan) and King\u2019s theatre, Edinburgh (3-4 Feb).</li> <li><a href=\"https://www.barbican.org.uk/music/series.asp?id=1697\">Philip Glass at 80</a> at the Barbican, London, 27-29 Jan, will feature UK premieres of his <a href=\"http://www.bbc.co.uk/events/edw2mb\">Concerto for Two Pianos</a> for the Lab\u00e8que sisters (part of the BBC Symphony Orchestra\u2019s Total Immersion day, 28 Jan) and Glass\u2019s score for the film <a href=\"https://www.barbican.org.uk/music/event-detail.asp?ID=19155\">Visitors</a> (29 Jan).</li> <li>Radio 3 will broadcast a <a href=\"http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b08c2lwr\">Glass all-nighter</a>, 29 Jan, 1am-7am, featuring a complete broadcast of his Music in Twelve Parts.<br /></li> </ul>",

          "body": "<p>It\u2019s 11.30pm, time to roll down the blinds of your mind and slip into the\u00a0black sponge of sleep. Now it\u2019s 12.30am, and my mind is on alert, hyper-aware, posing questions to a\u00a0vacant audience: pit-pat, tit-tat, the cogs are turning when they should be grinding down. 1.30am: nope, still awake.\u00a02.30, 3.30, and so on, and so on\u2026 until the sweet chirps of the morning birds, which have now become a doom-laden fanfare, heralding a day stretching ahead for a body and mind deprived of sleep and restoration.\u00a0To the uninitiated, welcome to insomnia.</p> <p>I\u2019ve had this condition for 12 years, and people find it baffling: \u201cYou just close your eyes and go to sleep, right?\u201d If only. The rage, oh the rage! The partner whose snoring is a nightly middle-finger to your restless mind. The colleague who complains, \u201cI\u2019m so tired, I only got six hours\u2019 sleep last night.\u201d Six hours! That\u2019s a\u00a0holiday for an insomniac. The person who says proudly, \u201cI\u00a0could sleep on a rock \u2013 my head hits the pillow and I\u2019m out.\u201d The endless articles about how sleep is so important, and being deprived of it will lead to early death.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2017/apr/22/what-im-really-thinking-school-trip-teacher\">What I\u2019m really thinking: the school-trip teacher</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Hypnotists, therapists, camomile tea, drugs, pillows doused in lavender oil: I\u2019ve tried them all, but still sleep eludes me. So, as I\u00a0stagger around like a zombie, desperate for my next coffee break, at least I\u2019m in good company. What I\u2019ve learned is that sleep is elusive if studied and scrutinised. The more you try, the less you get. It\u2019s a paradox I\u2019ve yet to solve. Maybe the key is not even to bother.           "body": "<p>The history of Jean-Paul Sartre\u2019s refusal of the 1964 Nobel prize for literature (<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/oct/20/bob-dylan-website-acknowledges-nobel-prize-win-after-five-day-wait\">Silence broken on Dylan\u2019s Nobel \u2013 after five days</a>, 21 October) is complicated. Sartre did in fact get wind of his imminent Nobelling from an article in <em>Le Figaro litt\u00e9raire</em> shortly before the Swedish Academy was to announce it, and wrote immediately to the Nobel committee to ask them to revoke their choice. His letter was misaddressed and failed to reach the committee on time, and the rest is history, up to a point. In 1966 the critic Max-Pol Fouchet argued that Sartre, who refused all honours, declined the Nobel in defence of \u201cthe solitude of the revolutionary writer\u201d, in denunciation of \u201cworldly and external self-importance\u201d. Sartre set this out movingly in his funeral oration for the Italian communist leader and revolutionary writer Palmiro Togliatti, who died on 21 August 1964, a few months before the Nobel episode.<br /><strong>Bruce Ross-Smith</strong><br /><em>Oxford</em></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/oct/24/another-side-of-bob-dylans-doctorate\">Another side of Bob Dylan\u2019s doctorate | Letters</a> </p> </aside>  <p>\u2022 Alfred Nobel made his fortune from arms and explosives. In Masters of War, Dylan sang about \u201cYou that build all the guns / You that build the death planes / You that build all the bombs.\u201d The song\u2019s final verse includes the lines \u201cAnd I hope that you die / And your death\u2019ll come soon.\u201d I hope Dylan stands alongside Sartre in refusing this tainted award (<a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/oct/21/bob-dylan-unacknowledges-nobel-prize-literature-win-removed-website\">Dylan thinks twice about Nobel acknowledgment</a>, 21 October).<br tabindex=\"-1\" /><strong tabindex=\"-1\">Andy Ashenhurst</strong><br tabindex=\"-1\" /><em tabindex=\"-1\">Canterbury</em></p> <p>\u2022 Before making fools of themselves by awarding the Nobel prize for literature to Bob Dylan, the Nobel committee should have taken into account the experience of St Andrews University, which in 2004 made the songster a Doctor of Music for \u201chis outstanding contribution to musical and literary culture\u201d.</p> <p>Arriving with his entourage 50 minutes into a 90-minute ceremony, Dylan sat glassy-eyed on the stage, yawning occasionally as the speaker burbled on about how his music \u201cmoved everything on to a place it never expected to go and left the deepest imprint on human consciousness\u201d, even comparing him to Pablo Picasso. After which, ignoring the university choir and its rendition of Blowin\u2019 in the Wind, and without a word of thanks or farewell, the new doctor and his train left the building.<br /><strong>Harry Watson</strong><br /><em>Edinburgh </em></p> <p><strong><em>\u2022 Join the debate \u2013 email </em></strong><strong><em><a href=\"mailto:guardian.letters@theguardian.com\">guardian.letters@theguardian.com</a></em></strong></p> <p>\u2022 The second letter was amended on 25 October 2016.           "body": "<p>If you are wearing a piece of gold jewellery, take a good, hard look at it and consider this: you are likely to be wearing the celestial debris of a cataclysmic stellar collision, a collision so devastating that it literally shook the universe. That\u2019s the conclusion from Monday\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/oct/16/astronomers-witness-neutron-stars-collide-global-rapid-response-event-ligo\">announcement</a> of gravitational wave signal GW170817.</p> \n<p>It is another reminder that we are intimately connected to the cosmos around us. At heart, astronomy is not really about remote and abstracted realms, instead it informs us about our own origins and the origins of those things we value.</p> \n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> \n <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/oct/16/astronomers-witness-neutron-stars-collide-global-rapid-response-event-ligo\">New frontier for science as astronomers witness neutron stars colliding</a> </p> \n</aside> \n<p>Astronomically, the origin of gold has been a puzzle for decades. The recognition that stars shine because they fuse one chemical element into another was made in the 1920s. It suggested that stars are the chemical factories that build almost everything in the chemist\u2019s periodic table, but the details were elusive. </p> \n<p>Astronomers have since established that the simplest elements \u2013 hydrogen and helium \u2013 were made during the origin of the universe in the fireball of the big bang. The rest of the naturally occurring elements come in various quantities from dying, exploding or colliding stars. </p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> \n <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"a428d86e-805b-4c4d-997a-e687036ed6e2\" data-atom-type=\"media\"> \n  <div> \n   <iframe frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/MVqy5WlO7pY?showinfo=0&amp;rel=0\"></iframe> \n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>Monday\u2019s announcement confirms <a href=\"https://www.popsci.com/science/article/2013-07/colliding-dead-stars-created-earths-gold\">research from 2013</a> that shows that a significant fraction of the gold and other heavy elements could come from the collision of two super-dense celestial objects known as neutron stars. The resulting explosion is known as a kilonova.</p> \n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> \n <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/jun/22/hunt-is-on-gravity-waves-spacewatch\">The hunt is on for gravity waves</a> </p> \n</aside> \n<p>A neutron star is the burned-out core of a once-giant star that exploded long ago. This particular pair was initially separated by 200 miles, but spiralled towards each other so rapidly that they met 100 seconds later. Situated about 130m light years from Earth, each neutron star was around 12 miles (19km) in diameter and contained a mass about half a million times that of the Earth.</p> \n<p>The final moments of their spiral and the actual collision itself generated the gravitational waves. These were detected at 1:41pm UK time on 17 August by two identical detectors in the US (Washington state and Louisiana), and a third detector in Pisa, Italy. It triggered a worldwide alert for other astronomers to try to find the event with traditional telescopes.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"e7ec7fd2b5e997c34c76d4673bcee616c55a2014\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/e7ec7fd2b5e997c34c76d4673bcee616c55a2014/0_0_2133_1600/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Sky localisations of gravitational-wave signals detected by Ligo\" width=\"1000\" height=\"750\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> \n  <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Sky localisations of gravitational-wave signals detected by Ligo beginning in 2015 (GW150914, LVT151012, GW151226, GW170104), and, more recently, by the LIGO-Virgo network (GW170814, GW170817).</span> \n  <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: LIGO/Virgo/Nasa/Leo Singer (Milky Way image: Axel Mellinger)</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>At the time of the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/live/2016/feb/11/gravitational-wave-announcement-latest-physics-einstein-ligo-black-holes-live\">first gravitational wave detection in February 2016</a> there was talk about how this was the equivalent of a new sense for astronomers. Being ripples in the fabric of space, gravitational waves were said to be rather like the cosmological equivalent of sound. It would be like going from silent movies to talkies. This is now coming true because at almost the same time that the gravitational waves were discovered, Nasa\u2019s Fermi observatory registered a short burst of gamma rays. </p> \n<p>Such short gamma ray bursts have been known about for years. Analysis suggested that they were the result of a collision between two neutron stars but clinching evidence has always eluded astronomers. Until now.</p> \n<p>The gravitational wave signal shows clearly that they were neutron stars not their larger cousins, black holes. Follow-up observations taken with ground-based telescopes captured the flash of the explosion and showed astronomers the chemical fingerprint of the atoms in the debris, including significant quantities of gold.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e8Yt7O7BLuc\"> \n <iframe width=\"460\" height=\"259\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/e8Yt7O7BLuc?wmode=opaque&amp;feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> \n <figcaption>\n  The left panel is a visualisation of the matter of the neutron stars, the right panel shows how space-time is distorted near the collisions.\n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>This mixture of gravitational waves and traditional observations is the opening of the astronomical flood gates. Such coordinated observations are going to become the norm for astronomers. And as they do, expect more wonders and more links to be found between us and the wider cosmos.</p> \n<p><em><a href=\"http://www.stuartclark.com/\">Stuart Clark</a> is the author of <a href=\"http://www.amazon.co.uk/The-Unknown-Universe-About-Chapters/dp/1781855749/ref=tmm_hrd_title_0\">The Unknown Universe</a> (Head of Zeus).</em></p>",
          "headline": "Monday's gravitational wave observation is astronomical alchemy"

        "isHosted": false,

        "pillarName": "News",
        "sectionId": "science",
        "sectionName": "Science",
        "type": "article",
        "webPublicationDate": "2017-10-16T14:00:11Z",
        "webTitle": "Monday's gravitational wave observation is astronomical alchemy",
        "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2017/oct/16/mondays-gravitational-wave-observation-is-astronomical-alchemy"
      },
      {
        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/commentisfree/2016/feb/12/einstein-gravitational-waves-physics",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>The <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/feb/11/gravitational-waves-discovery-hailed-as-breakthrough-of-the-century\" title=\"\">discovery of gravitational waves</a> has been hailed as yet another vindication of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/alberteinstein\" title=\"\">Albert Einstein</a>\u2019s theory of general relativity, unveiled a century ago. Indeed it is: among the theory\u2019s predictions was that violent events in the universe involving immense masses \u2013 such as the collision and merging of two black holes \u2013 could set the fabric of spacetime ringing, the ripples spreading across the cosmos and stretching or squeezing space as they pass.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/feb/12/gravitational-waves-answer-biggest-question-albert-einstein\">Gravitational waves may help us answer the biggest question of all | Simon Jenkins</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Experiments at the Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory facilities in Washington and Louisiana have detected these distortions, and it\u2019s a tremendous, exhilarating moment for science. But it\u2019s been barely noted what a deeply strange, perhaps unprecedented situation this is too. The initial detection event happened last September, in the centenary year of the publication of Einstein\u2019s theory. Yet <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/life-and-physics/2015/nov/25/video-100-years-of-einsteins-general-relativity\" title=\"\">the theory of general relativity</a> itself is a great rarity in science: for this was not an idea motivated by any need to explain observations, but the result of Albert Einstein simply sitting down and thinking. It isn\u2019t easy to find another example of such a rich, fertile theory conjured, as it were, out of nothing.</p> <p>No one was demanding a new theory of gravity in 1915. We already had one \u2013 devised by <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/isaac-newton\" title=\"\">Isaac Newton</a> more than two centuries earlier \u2013 and it seemed to work fine. Sure, there were a few little puzzles, such as the <a href=\"http://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/26408/what-did-general-relativity-clarify-about-mercury\" title=\"\">anomalous motion of the planet Mercury</a>. But these weren\u2019t in any sense the stimulus for the new theory (even though it explained them). No, it arose because Einstein saw the world differently.</p> <p>It began in 1907, when Einstein was 28 and still working as a patent clerk. \u201cI was sitting in the patent office in Bern,\u201d he later wrote, \u201cwhen all of a sudden a thought occurred to me: if a person falls freely, he won\u2019t feel his own weight. I was startled. This simple thought made a deep impression on me. It impelled me toward a theory of gravitation.\u201d This, Einstein attested, was \u201cthe happiest thought of my life\u201d.</p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/video/2016/feb/11/gravitational-waves-discovery-changes-everything-video\"            data-short-url=\"http://gu.com/p/4gjbp\"                    data-show-ads=\"true\"            data-video-id=\"2454865\"            data-video-name=\"Why discovering gravitational waves changes everything \u2013 video\"            data-video-provider=\"guardian.co.uk\"            > <video data-media-id=\"gu-video-56bcb63fe4b0d007e4723bec\" class=\"gu-video\" controls=\"controls\" poster=\"\"> <source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/mainwebsite/2016/02/11/160211GravWaves5_desk.mp4\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/small/2016/02/11/160211GravWaves5_small.3gp\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/large/2016/02/11/160211GravWaves5_large.3gp\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/HLS/2016/02/11/160211GravWaves5.m3u8\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/webM/2016/02/11/160211GravWaves5_synd_768k_vp8.webm\"/> </video> <figcaption><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/video/2016/feb/11/gravitational-waves-discovery-changes-everything-video\">Why discovering gravitational waves changes everything \u2013 video</a></figcaption> </figure>   <p>This is what set Einstein apart: what seems trivially obvious to most people struck him as profound. Using a complex form of calculus called <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scalar%E2%80%93tensor_theory\" title=\"\">tensor theory</a>, he spent eight years working on a new concept of gravity. The theory of general relativity showed that masses warp space and that in a gravitational field time slows down. It also predicted neutron stars and black holes, although they weren\u2019t accepted for many decades.</p> <p>Many physicists regard general relativity as a theory of exemplary beauty. But it\u2019s difficult too. Its <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Einstein_field_equations\" title=\"\">10 equations</a> can be written down concisely using tensor notation, but in full they\u2019d take up many pages. The difficulty of solving the equations is one reason why, after being first vindicated in 1919 by observations of \u201cbent\u201d starlight during a solar eclipse, the theory languished for decades.</p> <p>Almost all science stems from a need to explain what we see: to solve empirical puzzles. But not general relativity. Are there any other cases where significant new scientific ideas have arisen without any observations demanding explanation? <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/life-and-physics/2015/may/06/string-theory-and-black-holes\" title=\"\">String theory</a>, which attempts to unite general relativity with quantum theory, is juggling with scales and energies well beyond anything experimentally accessible, but still there\u2019s a clear motive: to reconcile two mutually incompatible ideas. Quantum theory itself is startlingly accurate with its predictions but current research into its underlying principles is motivated largely just because it appears so bizarre. It works but scientists want to\u00a0know why.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--supporting\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/feb/12/gravitational-waves-explained\">Explain it to me like I'm a kid: scientists try to make sense of gravitational waves</a> </p> </aside>  <p>By contrast, Einstein seemed to invent general relativity simply because he wanted to \u2013 because he saw questions where others didn\u2019t.</p> <p>A more pertinent question, perhaps, is whether any young scientist could do that today. Einstein\u2019s \u201cmiraculous year\u201d of 1905, in which he not only deduced special relativity but also kick-started quantum theory and published several other ground-breaking papers, was an unrivalled creative burst. Yet any scientist\u2019s early career is often their most productive time, as it was with <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/hawking\" title=\"\">Stephen Hawking</a>. Today, however, it\u2019s instead likely to be the most constrained and fraught.</p> <p>Young scientists now need more than ever to publish lots and quickly, to get grants and tenure, to justify the \u201cimpact\u201d of their work, and to carve out a niche for themselves, often in a highly specialised area. There is scant opportunity to just sit at a desk and ponder big questions.</p> <p>A century ago, general relativity had no obvious \u201cimpact\u201d, even though the GPS systems in today\u2019s smartphones rely on it. It didn\u2019t even have a clear goal, except intellectually. If Einstein\u2019s project had relied on a grant application today, it would surely be rejected; probably no young scientist could afford the luxury of contemplating it in the first place. It\u2019s not clear there is a space for Einsteins in modern science any longer.</p>",

          "body": "<p>One of my favourite books is <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Education_of_Henry_Adams\" title=\"\"><em>The Education of Henry Adams</em></a> (published in 1918). It\u2019s an extended meditation, written in old age by a scion of one of Boston\u2019s elite families, on how the world had changed in his lifetime, and how his formal education had not prepared him for the events through which he had lived. This education had been grounded in the classics, history and literature, and had rendered him incapable, he said, of dealing with the impact of science and technology.</p> <p>Re-reading Adams recently left me with the thought that there is now an opening for a similar book, <em>The Education of Mark Zuckerberg</em>. It would have an analogous theme, namely how the hero\u2019s education rendered him incapable of understanding the world into which he was born. For although he was supposed to be majoring in psychology at Harvard, the young Zuckerberg mostly took computer science classes until he started Facebook and dropped out. And it turns out that this half-baked education has left him bewildered and rudderless in a culturally complex and politically polarised world.</p> <p>What is intriguing about the Facebook founder is his astonishing blend of high intelligence, naivety and hubris. In February, when it finally began to dawn on him that the election of Donald Trump might tell us something significant and disturbing about the state of the US society, he wrote a <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/notes/mark-zuckerberg/building-global-community/10103508221158471/\" title=\"\">lengthy epistle</a> to his 86 million disciples.</p> <p>\u201cToday,\u201d it began, \u201cI want to focus on the most important question of all: are we building the world we all want?\u201d Ponder that for a moment: note the imperial, hubristic \u201cwe\u201d and the implicit assumption that it is possible to build a single world that everyone wants. It comes straight out of the Ladybird book of democracy. The epistle continues in the same vein. \u201cProgress now requires humanity coming together, not just as cities or nations, but also as a global community.\u201d And of course Facebook would provide just such a community: after all, it already has more than 2\u00a0billion users, which is significantly more people than there are in China.</p> <p>When it began to dawn on people that the powerful ad-targeting machine that Zuckerberg and his associates had built might also have been used to nudge voters towards Trump and away from Clinton, Zuckerberg\u2019s response was a mixture of denial and incredulity. Then, as the evidence mounted that his machine had indeed been \u201cweaponised\u201d by political actors to send so-called \u201cdark posts\u201d to individual users, he pivoted rapidly from incredulity to scepticism and then \u2013 as the evidence became incontrovertible \u2013 to technocratic determination to \u201csolve\u201d the problem. In between, he took consolation from the fact that since everyone was now angry with Facebook, the company must be doing something right. \u201c<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/zuck/posts/10104067130714241\" title=\"\">Trump says Facebook is against him,</a>\u201d he wrote. \u201cLiberals say we helped Trump. Both sides are upset about ideas and content they don\u2019t like. That\u2019s what running a platform for all ideas looks\u00a0like.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/oct/05/smartphone-addiction-silicon-valley-dystopia\">'Our minds can be hijacked': the tech insiders who fear a smartphone dystopia</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Given the ineptitude of his response to the crisis, Zuckerberg makes Theresa May look like Einstein. And therein lies a puzzle. For we know that the lad isn\u2019t stupid. Why then is he apparently behaving like an idiot? The answer is that he cannot come clean about the root of the problem, because to do so would reveal the unpalatable truth that it\u2019s a product of Facebook\u2019s business model.</p> <p>Facebook, like Google, is an extractive company, rather like ExxonMobil or Glencore. It \u201cmines\u201d, refines, aggregates and sells its users\u2019 personal information and data trails to advertisers, who then use it to target ads at said users. This data is clearly valuable. At the moment, for example, the company earns nearly <a href=\"http://uk.businessinsider.com/facebook-almost-20-per-user-us-and-canada-q4-2017-2\" title=\"\">$20 per user per year</a> (in the US and Canada, anyway) by monetising their data. The downside \u2013 from society\u2019s point of view \u2013 is that the targeted system that delivers these revenues is easily manipulated by political actors \u2013 as we saw from the way <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/oct/02/facebook-says-up-to-10m-people-saw-ads-bought-by-russian-agency\" title=\"\">Russian interests used it</a> in the 2016 election.</p> <p>Given the largesse that flows from this golden goose, you can see why Zuckerberg is reluctant to do or say anything that might threaten it. That\u2019s why there\u2019s no discussion about alternative business models that might enable the company to survive without undermining democratic processes. One could, for example, imagine an honest business model \u2013 in which people paid an annual subscription for a service that did not rely on targeting people on the basis of the <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2016/08/19/98-personal-data-points-that-facebook-uses-to-target-ads-to-you/?utm_term=.2e7f280c9278\" title=\"\">98\u00a0data-points</a> that the company holds on every user. All it would need is for Facebook users to fork out $20 a year for the pleasure of sharing LOLcats with one another.</p> <p>What\u2019s the likelihood of that happening? You know the answer. Which is why Zuck will continue to keep mum about the sordid reality underpinning his money machine.</p>",

          "body": "<p>Prague has long been home to opulent coffeehouses, where everyone from Kafka to Einstein gathered to debate the burning issues of the day. Fast forward to the 21st century and the tradition of the coffeehouse as radical hub continues in the form of Paraleln\u00ed Polis\u2019s Bitcoin Coffee in the suburb of Hole\u0161ovice. </p> <p>Founded by anarchic ethical hacker collective <a href=\"http://www.ztohoven.com/?lang=en\">Ztohoven</a>, the cavernous ground floor space is fitted with the industrial light fittings and paper honeycomb furniture found in hip cafes, but there\u2019s a difference \u2013 the only form of payment accepted is the cryptocurrency Bitcoin. Barista Al\u017eb\u011bta Svobodov\u00e1 even has a chip implanted in her wrist so she\u2019s never without her virtual wallet. \u201cWe want to introduce Bitcoin to people from the street,\u201d she explains. \u201cThe cafe is a tool to do that.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"6fe3d6a1c6e23006edb914a0336fad950730e45b\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/6fe3d6a1c6e23006edb914a0336fad950730e45b/0_0_960_960/500.jpg\" alt=\"Bitcoin Coffee, Prague. Expect to find all the usual espresso-based brews, as well as cutting-edge filter preparation methods, such as V60 and Aeropress on offer at the free-standing bar \u2013 intended to embody the open exchange of ideas in the digital age that Paraleln\u00ed Polis espouses.</p> <p>\u2022 <a href=\"https://www.paralelnipolis.cz/koncepty/bitcoin-coffee-en/\"><em>paralelnipolis.cz</em></a></p>",

          "body": "<p>\u2018Researchers say you might as well be your own therapist,\u201d <a href=\"https://qz.com/1057345/researchers-say-you-might-as-well-be-your-own-therapist\">the website Quartz proclaimed recently</a>, in light of <a href=\"https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10488-016-0783-9\">a new study</a> that found a vanishingly small difference between seeing a cognitive behavioural therapist and just doing various self-help exercises on your own. Naturally, this sort of thing is liable to make therapists angry. (The correct response is to nod compassionately and ask: \u201cNow, <em>why </em>do you think that makes you so angry?\u201d) As Mark Brown <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/aug/23/therapist-self-help-therapy\">noted in this paper</a>, we should be wary of any finding that seems to suggest governments could save money by telling people to sort themselves out. But the self-help route has another limitation worth bearing in mind: what makes you so confident you even know what your problems really are?</p> <p>Typically, self-help works like this: you\u2019re troubled by some issue \u2013 procrastination, commitment-phobia, depression \u2013 so you seek a\u00a0book to fix it, just as you\u2019d seek a\u00a0spanner or screwdriver if the legs on your kitchen table started wobbling. But minds aren\u2019t like wobbly tables. There\u2019s no reason to\u00a0assume \u2013 actually, <a href=\"https://aeon.co/essays/every-school-of-psychology-has-its-own-theory-of-the-unconscious\">there\u2019s much reason to doubt</a> \u2013 that we\u2019re in touch with our deepest anxieties and hang-ups. Rather than productivity techniques, maybe you need to face the fact that your job provides no meaning. Maybe accusing yourself of \u201ccommitment-phobia\u201d is\u00a0how you rationalise the subconscious awareness that your partner doesn\u2019t love you. Maybe your depression is best understood not as the result of \u201cautomatic thoughts\u201d, but as a sign that you\u2019re living life to serve your parents\u2019 agenda, instead of your own.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2017/jul/28/stabbing-children-disease-ridden-needles-science-common-sense\">Common sense isn't always that sensible</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Or maybe not: probably, some problems are exactly what they seem. But the question is so personal that the best book in the world can\u2019t help but miss the mark, whereas another human at least stands a chance of hitting it. And if CBT is truly no better than self-help, maybe the right conclusion isn\u2019t that therapists don\u2019t matter, but that CBT isn\u2019t necessarily <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/jan/07/therapy-wars-revenge-of-freud-cognitive-behavioural-therapy\">the apogee of therapy</a>?</p> <p>Crucially, the point isn\u2019t that therapists are wiser, thus better placed to tell you what your problems are. Rather, a good therapist will throw up roadblocks to your attempts to swiftly define the problem before hurrying on to fix it. This is the kernel of good sense in the cliche of the Freudian shrink who does nothing but rephrase his patient\u2019s comments as questions: he\u2019s refusing them the comfortable option of a one-size-fits-all solution, stubbornly forcing them toward self-understanding. Therapy isn\u2019t the only way to do this: journaling, meditation, even <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/aug/10/not-self-help-great-advice-life-james-hollis-what-matters-most-jung\">some books</a> are among the others. What they all share is that they throw you back on yourself, blocking the easy but inauthentic alternative of using someone else\u2019s secondhand answer. As Albert Einstein is often quoted as saying, <a href=\"https://quoteinvestigator.com/2014/05/22/solve/\">though he didn\u2019t really say it</a>: \u201cIf I\u00a0had only one hour to save the world, I would spend 55 minutes defining the problem.\u201d</p> <p>Plus, when it comes to psychology, there\u2019s a\u00a0bonus: half the time, a problem truly understood stops being a problem at all.</p> <p><a href=\"mailto:oliver.burkeman@theguardian.com\">oliver.burkeman@theguardian.com</a></p>",

          "body": "<p>It is a century and more since the modern age began. Dadaism started in 1916. Other movements and ideas that still shape our lives have either had or soon will have centenaries, from Einstein\u2019s general theory of relativity (published in 1916) to the Russian revolution (1917). Where have we got to, after all those revolutions? Is art (and even science) in the 21st century any more than a retread of the innovations of the early 20th? Does the violence of modern history leave us with any hope?<br tabindex=\"-1\"></p> \n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> \n <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/sep/10/out-of-south-africa-how-politics-animated-the-art-of-william-kentridge\">Out of South Africa: how politics animated the art of William Kentridge</a> </p> \n</aside> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/sep/10/out-of-south-africa-how-politics-animated-the-art-of-william-kentridge\"> William Kentridge</a>\u2019s melancholy carnival of an exhibition is the most convincing attempt I have seen by an artist of this century to meditate on the history of the last. It is a dazzling cinematic montage of modern times that chews on everything from relativity to Leon Trotsky to the fantastic early films of Georges M\u00e9li\u00e8s. In a series of unapologetically epic and trenchantly emotional installations, Kentridge puts himself \u2013 and his country South Africa \u2013 into a grandiose history of life, the universe and everything, reinventing the shattered perspectives of early 20th-century modernism in an original, funny and profound way.</p> \n<p> History is a mad machine, propelling us ever forward. In Kentridge\u2019s awe-inspiring installation The Refusal of Time, a kind of huge perpetual motion machine \u2013 lovingly crafted out of wood \u2013 cranks its shafts and pumps its pistons while around it films are projected and speakers blare speech and music. But this no mere futurist chaos; there is method to Kentridge\u2019s madness. At the heart of this great speculation is the theory of relativity, which takes as its starting point the fact that light has a constant speed of 299,792,458 metres per second. If the speed of light is constant, explains the voice coming from the agitprop-style loudspeakers, it follows that time cannot be a stable quantity. This insight led to Einstein\u2019s most mind-boggling thoughts, and they inspires Kentridge to imagine human history as a film we can rerun, a sorrow that can be stopped.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"41474688a920483c6f63ce79f40bbdd41184dd07\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/41474688a920483c6f63ce79f40bbdd41184dd07/0_0_4000_2610/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The Refusal of Time is on show at the Whitechapel Gallery, London.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"653\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> \n  <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Refusal of Time is at the Whitechapel Gallery, London.</span> \n  <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Doug Peters/PA</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p> At the other end of the exhibition, after climbing a staircase decorated with a portrait drawn in black tape whose image fragments as you ascend, another crazy machine rattles away. This time it\u2019s a propaganda speaker built from flea-market finds that leads you into a bureaucratic office where Trotsky is lamenting the collapse of democracy in the Soviet Union. A Bolshevik commissar and his secretary change into dancing cyborgs, half-human and half-camera, in a sequence that is both a homage to the avant-garde film of revolutionary Russia and an image of a society becoming dehumanised.</p> \n<p> Kentridge\u2019s love of film is joyous, but shadowed. He re-creates M\u00e9li\u00e8s\u2019s early special-effects classic <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_FrdVdKlxUk\">A Voyage to the Moon</a> in what seems a simple celebration of the power of the camera to make magic. But then the film-maker \u2013 Kentridge \u2013 magically invents a dream lover, only for this mysterious woman to vanish like a ghost when he tries to touch her. Art can give and it can take away. It is a touching portrait of the artist as a lonely man.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"bee1c7464f15220d10914d33390556c260ebe27f\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/bee1c7464f15220d10914d33390556c260ebe27f/0_0_7092_5100/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Second Hand Reading, 2013.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"719\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> \n  <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Kentridge\u2019s Second-Hand Reading, 2013.</span> \n  <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Illustration: William Kentridge/Marian Goodman Gallery, Goodman Galler/Lia Rumma Gallery</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p> At least he\u2019s got his drawing. A brilliant graphic talent links together the diverse elements of Kentridge\u2019s highly theatrical aesthetic. His firm, expressive sketches appear and disappear on all the screens here as he animates his drawings, creating and destroying their vivid imagery. Instead of exhibiting drawings, he shows us the process of drawing as an endless stream of designs and doodles. In one film he draws his own portrait \u2013 it comes to life and walks away. </p> \n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> \n <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/aug/29/eyes-on-the-prize-the-must-see-art-and-design-of-autumn-2016\">Eyes on the prize: the must-see art and design of autumn 2016</a> </p> \n</aside> \n<p> Once again, time slows and gets lost. The 20th century began with a belief in progress, but by its midpoint was marked forever as the age of Holocaust. What can we cherish from that age? The dazzling modernist effects in Kentridge\u2019s film installations capture what was best about the early 20th-century avant garde: its acceptance of the complexity of time and space. But things look even more complex now.</p> \n<p> Kentridge has created a tragicomic version of cubism. <a href=\"http://www.barglow.com/angel_of_history.htm\">The angel of history</a>, said the Marxist Walter Benjamin, is pulled forward but keeps looking backward. Kentridge, though, imagines a utopia where time flows in both directions. We can step in and out of it. Perhaps art is that utopia: a place where people can be made to disappear without anyone getting hurt.</p>",

          "body": "<p>We are creatures of light and air. Life\u2019s a gas, in every sense. We are\u00a0oxygen, hydrogen and\u00a0nitrogen, packed together with the carbon that photosynthesising life has plucked, one molecule at a time, from the atmosphere in the form of carbon dioxide. At cremation, our bodies bake down to a handful of minerals. When Hamlet beseeched his too, too solid flesh to melt, thaw and resolve itself into a dew, he got it about right: the Prince of Denmark would have been about 70% water, which is itself an atmospheric vapour. And he certainly could have been blown away.</p> <p>Harry Truman \u2013 \u201cnot that Harry Truman\u201d, as Sam Kean says in this bright and breezy book \u2013 was blown away by Mount St Helens. Truman was the defiant man who dismissed the warnings of volcanologists and refused to leave the high slopes of America\u2019s most violent modern volcano before it erupted in May 1980. Kean reconstructs his death because, as a chemist, he knows the temperatures at which water, viscera and bones could vaporise as a black cloud of intense heat, 100 storeys high and 10 miles wide, came roaring down the mountain at 350mph: \u201cTruman\u2019s clothes would have flared and disappeared, and then Truman himself would have sublimed in the scientific sense \u2013 transformed from solid to spirit almost instantly. And with a final hiss, he would have risen up into the air.\u201d</p> <p>As Kean says, there\u2019s a chance that your last breath contained just the tiniest whiff of the late Harry Truman, just as it quite possibly contains a remnant of the air exhaled by Julius Caesar as he cried \u201cEt tu, Brute,\u201d and expired. The atmosphere is vast, but so is the number of atoms and molecules inhaled with each breath: the number of lungfuls in the air and atoms in each lungful run to the billion trillions and more or less match. So each inhalation is also likely to incorporate the last wheeze of a dying tyrannosaurus 70m years ago; and the breath exhaled by Marc Bolan of T Rex as he sang \u201cLife\u2019s a\u00a0Gas\u201d, or by Joey Ramone of the Ramones (who wrote a different song of the same title).</p> <p>Our planet is for the moment an ideal home, solar-powered, air-conditioned, fitted with hot and cold running water and underfloor central heating, but it is the atmosphere that provides the currency with which life pays its way. This book starts with a blood-soaked toga and the conceit of Caesar\u2019s last gasp, but it does truly have an epic story to tell, and Kean takes us at a canter right through the entire 4.5bn year saga, from the moment of planetary assembly, mostly from interstellar gas molecules, to the chaotic challenge of planetary weather, the sorry comedy of\u00a0flying saucers at Roswell and the even more mournful tale of humanoid survivors from spaceship Earth \u2013 should there be any \u2013 in search of another habitable planet a\u00a0dozen light years away.</p> <p>Earth\u2019s first atmosphere during the Hadean period can hardly have been promising: the steamy magmatic exhalations would have been at pressures high enough to crush a human skull, but they cooled to condense into sea. Earth was also hit by another space object big enough to tilt it off its axis, and give it a companion moon: the same collision, says Kean \u201cnot only ejected our atmosphere, it\u00a0may well have boiled our frickin\u2019 oceans\u201d.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"b00f548b8dea369bb4d202c2ba81d7c17ae49396\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/b00f548b8dea369bb4d202c2ba81d7c17ae49396/0_307_4928_2957/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Lake Nyos, Cameroon.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Lake Nyos, Cameroon.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Alamy</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Let\u2019s get this bit out of the way: at times, Kean takes his admirable conversational tone in directions not always familiar to those brought up\u00a0on\u00a0the measured language of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2009/feb/07/evolution-of-birds-from-dinosaurs\" title=\"\">Thomas Henry Huxley</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/jun/09/is-richard-dawkins-destroying-his-reputation\" title=\"\">Richard Dawkins</a> or\u00a0<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jul/01/nigel-calder\" title=\"\">Nigel Calder</a>. So in an aside, the aforementioned Harry Truman \u201cwoke up in the snow in his tighty-whities\u201d; the chemist <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/nov/03/fritz-haber-fertiliser-ammonia-centenary\" title=\"\">Fritz Haber </a>\u201cdeveloped one helluva crush\u201d on the\u00a0Kaiser; Humphry Davy tried \u201cchugging a bottle of wine as fast as possible\u201d; Alfred Nobel spilt some \u201cnitro onto a pile of kieselguhr like a\u00a0klutz\u201d and so on.</p> <p>More awkwardly, the whole story \u2013 serious science all the way \u2013 is told in measurements of miles, pounds and Fahrenheit, rather than the metric units now universal in science.</p> <p>Inevitably, some of it is familiar: who could talk about oxygen without invoking Joseph Priestley, or Lavoisier; nitrogen without mentioning Haber, or nitrous oxide without Davy? The numbers, too, are numbing: we don\u2019t think in septillions but that\u2019s the traffic in oxygen molecules consumed by a human in 24 hours in the course of powering muscle movement. The poisonous gas hydrogen sulphide, for instance, makes up a vanishingly small component of the air, but you gulp 60m molecules every four seconds. You never think about the noble gases, but every four seconds you breathe in \u2013 and breathe out \u2013 20 quadrillion molecules of helium and 100 quintillion of argon.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>Albert Einstein makes an appearance as a fridge designer</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>The narrative embraces not just the nature of air but the breathtaking qualities of some of its gases, and their connection with human history, so there are enjoyable detours into the story of guano that \u2013 before the Haber-Bosch process \u2013 supplied the nitrogen that fuelled 20th-century food supply; and into the grim <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2000/aug/20/theobserver1\" title=\"\">deaths at Lake Nyos, Cameroon</a>, which in 1986 foamed like soda water, with deadly levels of carbon dioxide that killed 1,746 people. \u201cSurvivors remember an eerie stillness for days afterward. There weren\u2019t even flies around to snack on the dead bodies.\u201d</p> <p>This airy adventure bobs along with the first balloonists; the atmospheric link between the collapse of the Tay Bridge and the fame of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/feb/18/rare-poem-worst-poet-auction\" title=\"\">William McGonagall</a>, that enduring disaster of a poet; the improbable spontaneous combustion of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/feb/27/bleak-house-plot\" title=\"\">Mr Krook in Dickens\u2019s</a> <em>Bleak House</em>; the vacuum pumps and steam machinery of Newcomen and Watt and the explosive value of gunpowder, nitroglycerin and dynamite (all of which release gases, very suddenly, and with great force). We meet Joseph Pujol, aka Le P\u00e9tomane, the Parisian performer of evocative farts. Albert Einstein makes an appearance as a fridge designer; the nuclear force locked in atomic matter pops up even more forcefully with the atmospheric weapons tests in the Pacific. The overarching story is instructive,\u00a0told lightly and with pace.</p> <p>Kean thoughtfully packs even more digressions into his endnotes. My favourite nominates the 832\u00b0F temperature at which brimstone (hell has a lake of it, according to the Revelation of St John the Divine 21:8) remains liquid; and then takes the temperature of heaven (Isaiah 30:26 seems to say the sun shines sevenfold as the light of seven days). Temperature increases as the\u00a0fourth power of sunlight, so with\u00a049\u00a0suns heaven would enjoy a temperature of 1,000\u00b0F and therefore be hotter than hell. It\u2019s a helluva read. And it\u2019s a gas.</p> <p>\u2022 <em>Caesar\u2019s Last Breath</em> is published by Doubleday. Free UK p&amp;p over \u00a310, online orders only. Phone orders min p&amp;p of \u00a31.99.</p>",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/books/2015/jun/12/five-reasons-we-should-celebrate-albert-einstein",

          "body": "<h2><strong>1. His science</strong></h2> <p>Einstein was, first and foremost, a scientist. In 1905 and again in 1916, he <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/2011/may/07/scientists-prove-einstein-right\">radically revised our understanding of the universe</a>. He was a pictorial thinker who came up with a new, intuitive sense of what reality looked like. Physics at the start of the 20th century was a rather settled endeavour, not seemingly in need of radical revision. We thought light was a wave and that duration, length and mass were objective facts of the world. We thought that space was a flat, Euclidean entity, unaffected by the distribution of matter and energy within it. Einstein, a mere patent clerk when <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/apr/05/einstein-equation-emc2-special-relativity-alok-jha\">he first began suggesting differently</a>, showed us that light must be thought of as a particle when it is emitted or absorbed, that matter is composed of atoms, that space is malleable, undulating with the distribution of the stuff within it, that how long or massive an object is or the time order of closely occurring events is not a fact of the world, but merely a fact of our point of view. He showed that these perspectival truths were well-behaved when they were placed in a four-dimensional conceptual framework. Seeing may be believing, but what we should believe about the universe, Einstein demonstrated, requires seeing it from a reference frame beyond that of the human senses.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/alexs-adventures-in-numberland/2015/may/04/einsteins-election-riddle-are-you-in-the-two-per-cent-that-can-solve-it\">Einstein's election riddle: are you in the two per cent that can solve it?</a> </p> </aside>  <h2><strong>2. His politics</strong></h2> <p>Einstein joked to his dear friend Max Born that he had a version of the Midas touch: everything he said turned to newsprint. Einstein\u2019s science made <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/picture/2014/mar/14/albert-einstein-tongue-photography\">him a worldwide celebrity</a>, a status others might have enjoyed, but which Einstein despised. He was no shrinking violet, yet he detested the shallowness and meaningless absurdity that came with his universal adoration. But he realised that it could be handy. He was given a cultural megaphone and he decided that its best use was to amplify the concerns of those whose voices were least heard. Whether it was his own Jewish brethren suffering the insults of antisemitism, African-Americans suffering systematic racism, the poor kept down by structural barriers to advancement, or political dissidents in the Soviet Union who were being repressed, Einstein was unabashedly vocal in trying to change the institutions that led to inequality and injustice. His standing provided him with a unique place to speak for those who were silenced and he made great use of it in the name of universal human dignity.</p> <h2><strong>3. His immodesty</strong></h2> <p>Einstein never lacked confidence. Strengthened by his convictions, he was impervious to the power of those with superior social or professional standing, and resolute in his willingness to state his beliefs publicly. As social psychologists have shown since the <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2009/mar/07/social-psychology-group-mentality\">famous experiments of Solomon Asch and Stanley Milgram</a>, humans are greatly influenced by the opinions of those around us, especially those who occupy positions of authority. We can shy away from reasonable and ethical beliefs, if we sense that we are in the minority for holding those views. But Einstein stands as an example of intellectual commitment. His revolutionary physical theories and his advocacy for peace at times of war and for better treatment of those in need were often unpopular. Einstein was investigated by the FBI for his views, and he received death threats from Nazi sympathisers. He was threatened with the <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/2005/jan/05/science.schools\">loss of his position at the Institute for Advanced Study</a> for his vocal support for his beliefs and causes. Yet he steadfastly refused to give in to fashion, expedience or groupthink. It is a cliche to say someone has the \u201ccourage of his convictions\u201d, but <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/dec/05/albert-einstein-archive-genius-doubts-and-loves\">Einstein is a figure of great courage</a> in publicly expounding views he thought correct and morally necessary when such positions were dangerously unpopular.</p> <h2><strong>4. His modesty</strong></h2> <p>Einstein was flummoxed by his public reception. In one famous incident, he was accompanying Charlie Chaplin to the opening of his film <em>City Lights</em> when they were mobbed by thousands of fans. \u201cWhat does it mean?\u201d Einstein asked Chaplin, who replied: \u201cNothing.\u201d We have a cognitive bias that leads us to be more apt to believe the praise we receive and to explain away criticism. We are the focus of our lives and with the contemporary cults of individuality and celebrity, too many people eagerly welcome the spotlight and take it as a sign of their superiority. But Einstein did not seek mass adoration or personal aggrandisement. He was not present to receive his Nobel prize. <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/feb/16/israel.india\">He refused the presidency of Israel</a>. He was willing to step into the public eye when it suited his causes, but he was not one to seek fame for the sake of fame.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/jun/21/even-albert-einstein-needed-more-than-curiosity-to-become-a-great-physicist\">Even Albert Einstein needed more than curiosity to become a great physicist | Letters</a> </p> </aside>  <h2><strong>5. His meaning as a cultural symbol of modernity</strong></h2> <p>I often ask audiences: \u201cWhen I say the name Albert Einstein, what is the first thing that comes to mind?\u201d Regardless of the demographic or the country in which I ask this, inevitably the response is \u201cthe hair\u201d. Here is a man who changed the way the way we see reality, who stared down hatred and stood up for justice, yet despite all of this, the thing we immediately think of is that mane of unkempt, wild white hair. That may seem shallow of us, but I think it is a good thing. What does Einstein\u2019s hair signify? It was a political statement \u2013 he refused to conform to social standards of personal appearance. He was unapologetic in his individuality and unashamed of being different. Growing up a Jew in Wilhelmine Germany, where he was sent to a Catholic school, he was always aware of being an outsider and became not only comfortable with his distance from the mainstream, but took it as a mark of pride. On the one hand, Einstein is the very icon of the genius, someone whose innate intelligence made him radically unlike the masses. But in allowing his hair to become the spectacle it was, he became a symbol that said that special people can come from anywhere, can look like anyone. His physics appeared at a time when the regular order <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/blog/2012/jul/17/henri-poincare-einstein-picasso\">was being challenged by modernist movements</a> in mathematics, science, art, religion, governmental and economic structures, even the very sense of what it was to be a human was being reconsidered from its core. Einstein, with his wild hair, signalled that human advancement comes not from the conformity the authorities demand, but from difference \u2013 and that all of us at various times in our lives feel a sense of alienation. Einstein gives us pride in ourselves as individuals who can make a difference; we can revel in free thought, but there is no need in doing so to reject our shared humanity.</p> <p>\u2022 Steven Gimbel\u2019s <em>Einstein: His Space and Times</em> is published by Yale. Free UK p&amp;p over \u00a310, online orders only.           "body": "<p>It is an extraordinary story, ripe for the telling: a glamorous Hollywood leading lady is at the summit of the film industry, yet treated as a sexual trophy and repeatedly undervalued intellectually. But her scientific knowhow leads to a breakthrough in military technology and opens up the way for contemporary communications methods, such as Bluetooth and wifi.</p> <p>The remarkable life of the Austrian-born Hedy Lamarr \u2013 considered the most beautiful woman in the world by her Hollywood peers in the 1940s and 50s \u2013 is now the subject of a documentary, co-produced by the actress Susan Sarandon, which receives its British premiere in London on Wednesday as part of the <a href=\"http://ukjewishfilm.org/\">Jewish Film Festival</a>.</p> <p><a href=\"http://ukjewishfilm.org/film/bombshell-the-hedy-lamarr-story/\"><em>Bombshell: the Hedy Lamarr Story</em> </a>follows the career of the young Hedwig Kiesler from her childhood in pre-war Vienna, on to her escape, disguised as a maid, from a rich first husband. Using news footage and interviews with Lamarr\u2019s children from her six marriages, the first-time director Alexandra Dean traces Lamarr\u2019s journey to London and later to Los Angeles, where she becomes a star after appearing with Charles Boyer in the film <em>Algiers</em>. But at the centre of the new documentary is her little-known life as a successful inventor.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"8ec48adff71fe1f9cc79d176332518871ffd18e8\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8ec48adff71fe1f9cc79d176332518871ffd18e8/0_146_2602_1560/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Hedy Lamarr as Delilah in the Cecil B DeMille\u2019s 1949 biblical blockbuster.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Hedy Lamarr as Delilah in the Cecil B DeMille\u2019s 1949 biblical blockbuster.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Allstar</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The film tells Lamarr\u2019s story largely through previously unheard tapes of an interview she gave to <em>Forbes</em> magazine in 1990, 10 years before her death in Florida. By then a recluse, she explains her interest in technology to the journalist. \u201cInventions are easy for me to do,\u201d Lamarr says. \u201cI suppose I just came from a different planet.\u201d</p> <p>Lamarr is best remembered for her sultry role as the duplicitous Delilah in Cecil B DeMille\u2019s 1949 biblical blockbuster, in which she appeared opposite Victor Mature as Samson.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/gallery/2014/jul/15/celebrity-patents-prince-neil-young-albert-einstein\">From Prince's keytar to Bing Crosby's sash window: celebrity patents in pictures</a> </p> </aside>  <p>But her acting started on stage in Austria, after she had attended a renowned Berlin acting school headed by the director Max Reinhardt. The daughter of a Viennese bank director with a love of technology, Lamarr grew up in an artistic Jewish quarter of the city. By the age of 19 she had won a film role that brought her life-long notoriety, appearing nude in an unprecedented simulated sex scene in the 1933 Czech film <em>Ecstasy</em>, a performance denounced by the pope.</p> <p>Until now, Lamarr\u2019s part in the development of what she called \u201cfrequency hopping\u201d, a way to avoid the German jamming of radio signals, has remained an obscure bit of Hollywood trivia. However, as the Los Angeles film industry is shaken by accusations of in-built sexism in the wake of revelations about producer Harvey Weinstein\u2019s sexual abuses, Sarandon and the German film actress Diane Kruger, a fan of Lamarr who appears in the documentary, believe her hidden scientific talent will finally be recognised.</p> <p>Dean told <em>Vanity Fair</em> this year that Lamarr opens the tapes by saying: \u201cI wanted to sell my story \u2026 because it\u2019s so unbelievable. It was the opposite of what people think.\u201d Lamarr also complains about Hollywood\u2019s obsession with appearances, which she found dull: \u201cThe brains of people are more interesting than the looks, I think.\u201d</p> <p>Nevertheless, her roles repeatedly showcased her beauty and offered limited scope for acting. George Sanders, one of her co-stars, once said that Lamarr was \u201cso beautiful that everybody would stop talking when she came into a room\u201d.</p> <p>Her interest in radio communications seems to have been rekindled by the introduction in America of remote control systems for playing music, and by her concern about the German jamming techniques that prevented the use of radio-controlled torpedoes.</p> <p>She worked on her invention of an early form of \u201cspread spectrum\u201d telecommunications \u2013 in which a signal is transmitted on a much broader bandwidth than the original \u2013 together with her Hollywood neighbour, the avantgarde composer George Antheil, through the summer of 1940.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"8a34b8c924f042e45f68bb20689e50a75a077c04\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8a34b8c924f042e45f68bb20689e50a75a077c04/0_66_3000_1800/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Susan Sarandon co-produced the documentary, Bombshell: the Hedy Lamarr Story.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Susan Sarandon co-produced the documentary, <em>Bombshell: the Hedy Lamarr Story.</em></span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Noam Galai/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Their joint design employed a mechanism rather like the rolls used inside a pianola, or self-playing piano, to synchronise changes between 88 frequencies \u2013 the standard number of piano keys. The duo submitted a patent to the National Inventors Council on 10 June 1941, and it was granted a year later.</p> <p>While the idea was not entirely new, with German engineers winning patents for related work in 1939 and 1940, the United States navy classified the patent as \u201ctop secret\u201d. It took time, however, for the military to recognise how useful Lamarr and Antheil\u2019s bulky invention might become.</p> <p>After the war, in 1957, engineers at Sylvania Electronic Systems Division adopted it, and the navy began to use it to help transmit the underwater positions of enemy submarines revealed by sonar.</p> <p>In 1998, more than 50 years after their invention, the pair were honoured with an Electronic Frontier Foundation award.</p> <p>The actress, who once commented that her face was her \u201cmisfortune\u201d and \u201ca mask I cannot remove\u201d, may now gain some posthumous recognition as an inventor, but her most lasting legacy is still likely to be the striking features of Disney\u2019s Snow White, a cartoon character modelled on Lamarr.</p> <h2>LAMARR\u2019S LIFE</h2> <p><strong>Born</strong> Hedwig Eva Maria Kiesler, in Vienna, Austria, on 9 November 1913.</p> <p><strong>Family</strong> Married six times including to Friedrich Mandl, an arms dealer, but fled her loveless marriage to be a Hollywood actress.</p> <p><strong>Film career</strong> Big break was a lead role in Gustav Machaty\u2019s <em>Ecstasy</em>, where she became the (probably) first Hollywood star to simulate a female orgasm on screen. The film sparked outrage and was attacked by Pope Pius XI. After leaving her husband she changed her name to Hedy Lamarr, and starred in the Hollywood film, <em>Algiers</em>. Other films included <em>Boom Town</em>, <em>My Favourite Spy</em> and <em>Samson and Delilah,</em> the highest grossing film of 1949.</p> <p><em>Algiers</em> (1938) was her first American film.</p> <p><strong>Inventions</strong> In 1942 Lamarr and her business partner, composer George Antheil, awarded a patent for a \u201csecret communication system\u201d for radio-guided torpedoes. Later, it became a constituent of GPS, wifi and Bluetooth. She also developed \u201dbouillon\u201d cubes to transform water into a Coke, and a \u201cskin-tautening technique based on the principles of the accordion\u201d.</p>",
