approved by the Council of Australian Governments. Coag will hold an energy meeting on Friday. </p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/feb/15/south-australian-blackout-caused-by-demand-and-generator-failures-market-operator-says\">South Australian blackout blamed on thermal and wind generator failures, plus high demand</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Among the reforms that will be put to state and territory energy ministers at Coag is a proposal to \u201cunpack\u201d the energy price and set different price signals within the market, similar to those used in telecommunications markets.</p> <p>\u201cWe have got to make these changes and we don\u2019t want to waste this crisis \u2026 we want to move this stuff forward,\u201d Zibelman said.</p> <p>\u201cWe need to come up with an actionable plan with details, bring them back to Coag, so they have the confidence to know that what we\u2019ve come up with is something that people will invest in and it\u2019s driving value to consumers.\u201d</p> <p>Zibelman said expecting existing energy markets to cope with a changing power environment that included greater reliance on renewable energy was unrealistic. </p> <p>Between 2008 and 2017, she said, coal-produced energy in grid had dropped 14% from 27,000 MWh to 23,000 MWh and wind had increased 263% from 1,100 MWh in 2008 to 4,000 MWh.         "fields": {
          "body": "<p>In 1501, desperate for Leonardo to paint her portrait, the immensely rich Isabella d\u2019Este employed a friar to act as go-between. The friar met Leonardo in Florence but found his lifestyle \u201cirregular and uncertain\u201d and couldn\u2019t pin him down. \u201cMathematical experiments have absorbed his thoughts so entirely that he cannot bear the sight of a paintbrush,\u201d Isabella was told. With promises he\u2019d get round to it eventually, Leonardo kept her dangling for another three years. Pushy to the end, she changed tack and asked him for a painting of Jesus instead. Even then, he didn\u2019t come up with the goods.</p> <p>The story encapsulates contrasting versions of Leonardo that have been in\u00a0play ever since <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jul/28/in-praise-of-giorgio-vasari\" title=\"\">Vasari</a> extolled him in his <em>Lives of the Artists</em>. On the one hand, the lofty genius who wouldn\u2019t kowtow to affluent patrons; on the other, the feckless fantasist who failed to fulfil his commissions. On the one hand, the Renaissance Man to whom maths and science were as important as painting; on the other, the artist who \u201cleft posterity the poorer\u201d (<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/may/16/kenneth-clark-arrogant-snob-saviour-art\" title=\"\">Kenneth Clark</a>\u2019s phrase) by pursuing hobbies \u2013 engineering, architecture, pageantry, military strategy, cartography, etc \u2013 on which his talents were wasted. He achieved so much. But did multitasking prevent him achieving more?</p> <p>Walter Isaacson has no doubt about the answer. The subjects of his previous books \u2013 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2007/jun/10/biography.features\" title=\"\">Albert Einstein</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2004/jul/10/featuresreviews.guardianreview10\" title=\"\">Benjamin Franklin</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/oct/20/the-innovators-walter-isaacson-review-inventors-hackers-geniuses-geeks-digital-revolution-internet\" title=\"\">Ada Lovelace and Steve Jobs</a>, among others \u2013 were all blue-sky thinkers, with the ability \u201cto make connections across the disciplines\u201d and \u201cto marry observation and imagination\u201d. His life of Leonardo (rather cheekily subtitled \u201cThe Biography\u201d, as\u00a0if there were no others) doesn\u2019t neglect the paintings. But it\u2019s more fascinated by the notebooks, with their\u00a07,200 pages of sketches and ideas. Isaacson\u2019s premise is that Leonardo\u2019s scientific interests nourished his art \u2013 that only through the work he put into\u00a0dissecting corpses and studying muscles was he capable of painting the Mona Lisa\u2019s smile.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"28d6ac1e8a1ed086a7eb65fe4df90cabe9d12809\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/28d6ac1e8a1ed086a7eb65fe4df90cabe9d12809/0_0_3440_5118/672.jpg\" alt=\"The Mona Lisa.\" width=\"672\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The <em>Mona Lisa</em>.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: History Archive/REX Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Gay, vegetarian, flamboyant in dress (with a preference for pink), erratic in his work habits and astute when it came to self-promotion, Leonardo would have felt at home among the hipsters of today. Being illegitimate was no great stigma: it meant he grew up with two mothers (which Freud thought explained a lot). It also saved him from becoming a notary, a profession closed to sons born out of wedlock. His lack of a formal education was no handicap, either. Self-taught, he derided \u201cpuffed up\u201d scholars who relied on received ideas: \u201cHe who can go to the fountain does not go to the water-jar.\u201d Experience was what counted, he said \u2013 that and a relentless curiosity.</p> <p>At 14, he was apprenticed to the workshop of Andrea del Verrocchio, who was (so Vasari claimed) \u201castonished\u201d by his talent and with whom he collaborated before producing at least two early masterpieces, <em>The Annunciation</em> and (his first non-religious effort, and one to rank with the <em>Mona Lisa</em>) <em>Ginevra de\u2019 Benci</em>. A charge of sodomy, involving a 17-year-old, might have halted his progress by landing him in prison or worse. But one of the four young men with whom he was accused had connections with the Medici family and the case was dropped.</p> <p>His attitude to sex was ambivalent: \u201cWhoever does not curb lustful desires puts himself on the level of beasts,\u201d he wrote, with conventional piety, but he also acknowledged that the penis \u201cpossesses a life and an intelligence separate from the man\u201d. His companion of many years \u2013 servant, pupil and the subject of many drawings \u2013 was the rascally Salai, who came to him at the age of 10. At some point they probably became lovers. Later, in his mid-50s, Leonardo adopted another young man, Francesco Melzi, whom he loved as a son.</p> <p>Not surprisingly, his depictions of men are more erotic than those of women. He described the act of coitus as \u201crepulsive\u201d; only the beauty of human faces redeemed the ugliness of genitalia. His lack of desire for women is perhaps what makes his paintings of them so tender and attentive: by objectifying less (and leaving their clothes on), he sees more. Some of his men look feminine, too. The angel in <em>Virgin of the Rocks</em> \u2013 intended to be Gabriel or Uriel \u2013 is often mistaken for a woman. A later drawing of an angel, either by Leonardo or by someone in his studio, showed a figure with breasts and an erect penis. Androgyny appealed to him. His men lack the muscularity of Michelangelo\u2019s nudes, which he dismissed as looking like \u201ca sack of walnuts rather than a human figure\u201d.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/may/20/leonardo-da-vinci-orphan-mother-caterina\">Tuscan archives yield up secrets of Leonardo\u2019s mystery mother</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The rise of Michelangelo (20-odd years his junior) may have been a factor in his preference for Milan: having spent much of his 30s and 40s there, he returned in his mid-50s. It was a bigger city than Florence and was well stocked with intellectuals and scientists (less so with artists). Later he moved to Rome and later still, leaving Italy for the first time, to France. But it was Milan that encouraged the odd mixture of the practical and the fantastical that went into his inventions \u2013 his schemes for flying machines, giant crossbows, scythed chariots, needle grinders, screw jacks and so on. As Isaacson sees it, his inventions and ideas occupy an important place in the history of science and technology, anticipating the discoveries of Galileo and Newton. He contributed to medical knowledge too: by dissecting the body of a 100-year-old man, he came up with the first description of arteriosclerosis as an outcome of the ageing process. Even his wackiest ideas (such as the plan to protect Venice with a team of underwater divers wearing breathing apparatus) had potential, though it was several more centuries before scuba gear came along.</p> <p>Anatomy was his abiding specialism. Other artists might aspire to get the measure of man but he went about it literally, computing the right proportions (\u201cfrom the top of the ear to the top of the head is equal to the distance from the bottom of the chin to the duct of the eye\u201d, etc). This kind of perfectionism underlaid his reluctance to complete his paintings, notably <em>The Last Supper</em>, to which he\u2019d sometimes add just a couple of brush strokes before knocking off for the day (serious artists occasionally \u201caccomplish most when they work least\u201d, he told the impatient duke who\u2019d commissioned it), and the <em>Mona Lisa</em>, with which he fiddled on and off for 15 years and which was still in his studio when he died.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>He described the act of coitus as \u2018repulsive\u2019; only the beauty of human faces redeemed the ugliness of genitalia</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Like almost everyone who has written about it, Isaacson is reverential towards the <em>Mona Lisa</em>, though not as much as<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2004/jan/24/featuresreviews.guardianreview13\" title=\"\"> Walter Pater</a> (\u201chers is the head upon which all the ends of the world are come\u201d) and not without using it to underline one of his main themes \u2013 Leonardo\u2019s sfumato technique, whereby lines are blurred and boundaries (like those between art and science) disappear. More illuminating is his account of the recent controversies over two other paintings attributed to Leonardo, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/nov/30/leonardo-da-vinci-experts-painting-la-bella-principessa\" title=\"\"><em>La Bella Principessa</em></a> and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/nov/20/artistic-license-experts-doubt-leonardo-da-vinci-painted-450m-salvator-mundi\" title=\"\"><em>Salvator Mundi</em></a>: through carbon dating and digital magnification, experts have assessed the key evidence (palm prints, left-handed brush strokes, stitching holes), but whether they\u2019re the genuine article remains a matter of dispute.</p> <p>Five hundred years on, you\u2019d have thought that everything it\u2019s possible to know about Leonardo would now be known, but authentication of his work remains an issue and surprises still keep turning up \u2013 a <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2016/dec/13/leonardo-da-vinci-lost-drawing-tajan\" title=\"\">lost drawing of Saint Sebastian</a> in 2016 and new details about the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/may/20/leonardo-da-vinci-orphan-mother-caterina\" title=\"\">identity of his mother</a> Caterina only this year. Isaacson doesn\u2019t claim to make any fresh discoveries, but his book is intelligently organised, simply written and beautifully illustrated, and it ends with a kind of mental gymnastics programme that suggests how we can learn from Leonardo (Be curious, Think visually, Go down rabbit holes, Indulge fantasy, Respect facts, etc).</p> <p>Leonardo\u2019s notebooks are full of similar exhortations: \u201cGet a master of hydraulics to tell you how to repair a lock \u2026 Observe the goose\u2019s foot \u2026 Describe the tongue of the woodpecker.\u201d In\u00a0his thirst for knowledge, he was like a small child endlessly asking \u201cWhy?\u201d His last drawings were turbulent images of water and wind. You can read them as metaphors for apocalypse and death (he\u2019d had a stroke by then). Or as the culmination of a lifelong drive to find connections between natural phenomena \u2013 to link the curve of waves to a curl of human hair. Either way, Isaacson\u2019s claim that no other figure in history \u201cwas as creative in so many different fields\u201d doesn\u2019t seem far-fetched.</p> <p>\u2022 <em>Leonardo da Vinci: The Biography</em> is published by Simon and Schuster. To order a copy for \u00a325.50 (RRP \u00a330) go to <a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/leonardo-da-vinci-524734.html?utm_source=editoriallink&amp;utm_medium=merch&amp;utm_campaign=article\" title=\"\">bookshop.theguardian.com</a> or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&amp;p over \u00a310, online orders only. Phone orders min p&amp;p of \u00a31.99.</p>",

          "body": "<p>Last week a stranger stopped me in town, approaching with the swagger of a young man comfortable in his own skin. I didn\u2019t realise I knew him until he called me Miss.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2017/jun/24/secret-teacher-school-echo-chamber-leftwing-views-labour\">Secret Teacher: my school is an echo-chamber for leftwing views</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Looking closely, I saw the eyes of a boy who\u2019d spent many an hour face-planting desks during GCSE lessons. A boy who\u2019d often refused to scribble his name, let alone write an essay on the ambiguities of responsibility in Macbeth. He\u2019d never seen the point.</p> <p> But I discovered that this ex-student of mine is thriving. With a steady job, a vocation, and a good salary, he\u2019s found more self-worth than he\u2019d ever hoped to find in school. Despite most teachers telling him he \u201cwouldn\u2019t amount to anything without GCSEs\u201d, he\u2019s unrecognisably happy and healthy. Proving the system wrong, he wanted me to be proud of him. </p> <p>And I am. But I feel guilty, too. School was hell for him. I remember the fists through walls, broken knuckles, the fights. He was frustrated. I\u2019d told him he needed an English GCSE to move on to grander things. I perpetuated the myth that without GCSEs he would fail. </p> <p>But now I think I was wrong. There are plenty of people who, despite the threat of lifelong failure, go on to do great things. <a href=\"http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/a-level-results-2016-ucas-richard-branson-message-virgin-founder-grades-not-everything-a7197721.html\">Richard Branson</a> is usually trotted out as the go-to example, but some report even Einstein left secondary school with <a href=\"http://metro.co.uk/2016/08/25/15-people-who-did-amazing-things-without-amazing-exam-results-5940967/\">no formal qualifications</a>. </p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>The nature of study often turns subjects of joy into exercises of misery</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Qualifications have their place, of course, but some students see GCSEs as the gateway to conform, not be informed. Put simply, these courses don\u2019t always feel relevant. These subjects are learned to pass exams, not gain a living knowledge. With their academic frames so distant from real-life experience, GCSEs aren\u2019t useful, creative, productive or fun. </p> <p>To make matters worse, GCSE failure lands squarely on the shoulders of students and teachers. The complaints of \u201cWhat\u2019s the point?\u201d are ignored and aren\u2019t treated as symptomatic of a systemic problem. Rather, the students themselves are considered a problem \u2013 the bad eggs preventing schools from improving those all-important performance statistics marking out \u201csuccess\u201d.</p> <p>So what\u2019s the answer? As Niace finds, to <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"http://www.learningandwork.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Engaging-learners-in-GCSE-maths-and-English.pdf\">make English and maths engaging</a>, \u201clearners need to see the purpose and relevance of what they are learning\u201d. So I believe we must make these subjects meaningful in a real-world context (even the most disengaged have shown to be hardworking during <a href=\"https://www.academia.edu/2002722/Stahl_and_Dale_2012_Creating_Positive_Spaces_of_Learning_DJers_and_MCers_Identity_Work_with_New_Literacies?auto=download\">tasks meaningful to them</a>). Who, for the love of Pythagoras, draws triangles just to calculate their hypotenuse? Instead, why not learn the great man through productive activity, like the construction of buildings or designing of video games? Learning is much more effective when <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"http://dera.ioe.ac.uk/2152/1/Removing%20barriers%20to%20literacy.pdf\">students focus on topics they actually find interesting</a>.</p> <p>With the <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/review-of-vocational-education-the-wolf-report\">Wolf report</a> back in 2011, I thought there may be a shift for English and maths to focus on \u201cemployment outcomes rather than an accrual of qualifications\u201d. Yet we\u2019re seeing none of this. Attempts at making learning relevant are but token offerings, while work experience placements become solely the remit of independent schools or those with resources to support them.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2017/jun/10/secret-teacher-evidence-free-schools-results\">Secret Teacher: we need evidence on free schools, not blind faith</a> </p> </aside>  <p>So if the government isn\u2019t going to step up, perhaps we can find ways to form links between businesses and schools. Industry knows we need more<a href=\"http://www.builders.org.uk/news/encouraging-home-grown-talent-vital-in-post-brexit-britain/\"> home-grown workers with the right skills</a>. So let\u2019s bring the resources of business to the world of education, a sector struggling under the pressure of budget cuts and greater class sizes. Let\u2019s think about building mentoring programmes offering aspirational role models, find ways to offer varied learning contexts through more work placements, and make school-based education relevant and purposeful. This wouldn\u2019t just benefit the disaffected, but all students who crave more independence. </p> <p>No child should be asking, \u2018What\u2019s the point?\u2019 \u2013 much less be stamped as a troublemaker or failure. They should be empowered to find meaning and the self-worth to excel.<br /></p> <p><strong>Follow us on Twitter via <a href=\"https://twitter.com/GuardianTeach\">@GuardianTeach</a>, like us on <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/GuardianTeacherNetwork/\">Facebook</a>, and join the <a href=\"https://profile.theguardian.com/agree/GTNF?returnUrl=https://teachers.theguardian.com/Registration.aspx\">Guardian Teacher Network</a> for lesson resources and the latest articles direct to your inbox</strong></p> <p><strong>Looking for a teaching job? Or perhaps you need to recruit school staff? <a href=\"https://jobs.theguardian.com/jobs/schools/?INTCMP=gdnwb_copts_editorial_jobs_SchoolsArticle_\">Take a look at Guardian Jobs</a>, the education specialist</strong></p>",

          "body": "<p>The maximum human lifespan could far exceed previous predictions, according to work that challenges the idea that humans are approaching a hard limit on longevity.</p> <p>The latest research comes in response to a recent <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/oct/05/human-lifespan-has-hit-its-natural-limit-research-suggests\">high-profile paper</a> that concluded \u201cmaximum longevity has hit a ceiling of 114.9 years\u201d \u2013 a claim that prompted extraordinary levels of criticism from the scientific community. Now five separate research teams have launched critiques of the work in a series of papers in the journal Nature.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/oct/05/human-lifespan-has-hit-its-natural-limit-research-suggests\">Human lifespan has hit its natural limit, research suggests</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Together they present the case that there is no compelling evidence that we are approaching an upper limit on our mortality \u2013 or at the very least, that such a limit may be considerably higher than 115 years.</p> <p>Prof Jim Vaupel, a specialist in ageing at the Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research in Germany and one of the authors, said: \u201cThe evidence points towards no looming limit. At present the balance of the evidence suggests that if there is a limit it is above 120, perhaps much above \u2013 and perhaps there is not a limit at all.\u201d</p> <p>The dispute between Jan Vijg, the geneticist at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York who authored the original paper, and the critics, has become unusually heated, with both sides stepping beyond the typically restrained bounds of scientific discourse.<br /></p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s the worst piece of research I\u2019ve ever read in Nature magazine,\u201d said Vaupel. \u201cI was outraged that a journal I highly respect would publish such a travesty.\u201d</p> <p>Vijg is equally strident, implying that his critics are, to some extent, simply upset at being confronted with their own mortality.</p> <p>The original study used the <a href=\"http://www.supercentenarians.org/\">International Database on Longevity</a>, which compiles lists of the age of the oldest person to die in a given year. It found the maximum reported age of death increased rapidly between the 1970s and early 1990s, but then appeared to plateau in the mid-1990s at 114.9 years.</p> <p>The latest papers argue that this conclusion is wrong and offer a host of more optimistic interpretations. Prof Siegfried Hekimi from McGill University in Montreal said: \u201cYou can show the data are compatible with many different trajectories and not at all an ongoing plateau.\u201d</p> <p>Under one such scenario, lifespans would be predicted to climb steadily upwards, such that the oldest person alive by the year 2,300 would be expected to be 150 years old. \u201cThe increase in average lifespan will not suddenly crash into a 115-year limit,\u201d he said.</p> <p>Hemiki said there was annoyance about the levels of media attention the Vijg paper received, because \u201cpeople like a number\u201d, despite the fact that \u201cthe data were strikingly unconvincing\u201d.</p> <p>One complaint was that Vijg\u2019s analysis partitioned the data into two time periods \u2013 before and after 1995 \u2013 on the back of a visual inspection that appeared to show a levelling off around this year. When the two underlying trends were calculated, the period after 1995 had a flat gradient, appearing to confirm the hypothesis.</p> <p>\u201cThat\u2019s something you shouldn\u2019t do in statistics,\u201d said Hekimi. \u201cIt\u2019s circular.\u201d</p> <p>Another problem is that when any data series is segmented, there may appear to be temporary plateaus or even declines, despite an overall upward trend \u2013 as seen in <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_jump_world_record_progression\">long-jump records, for instance</a>.</p> <p>Another of the critiques notes that the headline result \u2013 the flat gradient after 1995 \u2013 is based on just 12 data points and could simply reflect the inclusion of Jeanne Calment, a French woman who died in 1997 at the record-breaking age of 122 years. If this datapoint was shifted forward a few years to 2004, the apparent plateau vanished.</p> <p>Vijg counters that a dataset focused on the oldest people on Earth is always going to be small. \u201cWhen you look at these super-old people, there are not many of them. That\u2019s kind of the point, isn\u2019t it?\u201d</p> <p>Maarten Rozing of the University of Copenhagen said there was little to suggest the existence of a \u201cbiological clock\u201d programmed to limit the length of life. \u201cWe now know not only that the idea of such a clock is highly implausible, but also that ageing is proving to be more amenable to change than used to be supposed,\u201d he said.</p> <p>Vijg said he accepts \u201cabsolutely nothing\u201d in the latest criticisms, dismissing them as statistical nitpicking by those who \u201chadn\u2019t read his paper properly\u201d.<br /></p> <p>He compared the suggestion that there was no lifespan limit in sight to Zeno\u2019s paradox, where an arrow is shot at a tree and first travels half the distance and, from the halfway point, half the distance again, in an apparently unending journey.</p> <p>\u201cThey try to come up with intricate models to show that mortality is actually decreasing with very old age,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s worse than science fiction.\u201d</p>",

          "body": "<p>Last week\u2019s GCSE maths results \u2013 the first of the new and more challenging syllabus \u2013 show that boys have pulled <a href=\"https://www.tes.com/news/school-news/breaking-news/gcse-results-2017-six-key-points\">further ahead</a> of girls; 16.5% of male candidates were awarded at least an A grade this year, compared with 14.7% of female candidates.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2015/nov/17/how-teachers-help-students-maths-anxiety\">The fear of all sums: how teachers can help students with maths anxiety</a> </p> </aside>  <p>What does this mean for the uptake of A-level maths among girls? At present, <a href=\"http://furthermaths.org.uk/files/FMSP-Girls-in-Maths.pdf\">65% of boys</a> who get As in GCSE maths choose to take it at A-level, while <a href=\"http://furthermaths.org.uk/files/FMSP-Girls-in-Maths.pdf\">only 43% of girls</a> do so. Of all students, <a href=\"http://furthermaths.org.uk/encouraging-girls-maths\">39% of maths candidates, and just 27% of further maths candidates</a>, are female. Students are often unaware that top universities require double maths (maths and further maths) at A-level for maths, physics, computer science or engineering degrees, so this has negative consequences for their participation in Stem courses and careers. </p> <p>As a maths teacher at a large sixth form college, I\u2019m concerned by the disproportion of female students in the department. I spoke to three groups of girls in year 12 about their experiences; one not studying maths, those studying single maths, and those studying double maths. Based on their feedback, I have the following suggestions for encouraging more girls to take the subject at A-level.</p> <h2>Don\u2019t perpetuate the idea of a \u2018maths brain\u2019</h2> <p>One student who does not study maths said that she didn\u2019t \u201chave a maths brain\u201d and was \u201cnot actually very good\u201d. This was echoed by many who hadn\u2019t taken A-level maths, despite getting A*s at GCSE. Curiosity, persistence and hard-work are the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/jul/25/no-such-thing-as-a-gifted-child-einstein-iq\">attributes of high performers</a> , according to research by Deborah Eyre. Teachers need to praise these characteristics and avoid language that implies \u201cnatural ability\u201d. Many teachers are <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2017/jan/09/growth-mindset-practical-strategies-classroom\">aware of this</a> but the students\u2019 feedback suggests this hasn\u2019t transferred effectively to the classroom, where success is often tied to speed.</p> <h2>Use competition with caution</h2> <p>Typically, girls respond less well to competition. Those I spoke to were demoralised by competition within lessons and in comparing test results. As such, teachers using competition in the classroom should design collaborative competitions where students have clear (and changing) group roles. We should avoid focusing on speed, applauding good teamwork instead.</p> <p>Students in all groups felt their test results defined their \u2018rank\u2019 in the class. Teachers must explain that only a narrow selection of mathematical skills are examined. It is important students know that tests provide an opportunity for them to showcase understanding of these skills, but don\u2019t define their potential as a mathematician.</p> <h2>Interact with us, encourage us \u2013 but don\u2019t patronise us</h2> <p>\u201cI always felt that [the teacher] was a little bit tired of the girls or something. I don\u2019t know, maybe she didn\u2019t like us.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2015/feb/10/chinese-teaching-primary-maths\">Why are we blindly following the Chinese approach to teaching maths?</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Students who are not studying maths described top set classes at secondary school full of \u201cloud and confident\u201d boys who didn\u2019t fear shouting out an incorrect answer, who had \u201cbanter\u201d with the teachers and who were \u201calways\u201d chosen to demonstrate work. One student mentioned two apparently-able boys in her class: \u201cIf you were stuck, you could go to them and they\u2019d explain it.\u201d This is a familiar social norm, but teachers must also offer female students positive experiences of explaining their work.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/dec/10/generation-z-latest-data-teens\">Generation Z</a> is under pressure to look and act a certain way \u2013 a problem amplified by social media. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/aug/23/girls-and-social-media-you-are-expected-to-live-up-to-an-impossible-standard\">Girls are often more affected</a> , reducing their confidence in the classroom. Male students also struggle with low confidence, of course, but maths teachers <a href=\"https://www.tes.com/news/school-news/breaking-news/teachers-underrate-girls-maths\">underestimate girls\u2019 performance relative to boys of the same level</a>, according to researchers in the US. </p> <p>To address these issues, teachers can keep track of the number of one-to-one interactions with each student. A <a href=\"https://www.miniwebtool.com/random-picker\">random name selector</a> would ensure all students have the opportunity to participate in whole-class discussions.</p> <h2>Inspire us</h2> <p>Many in the double maths group said they found the subject to be uninspiring until year 10. Teachers need to get girls interested in maths before choosing their GCSEs and younger students should encounter a variety of challenging maths problems. Classrooms are full of students with a range of tastes in mathematics and it\u2019s hard to predict which concepts will engage students\u2019 curiosities, so let\u2019s bring what we find beautiful about mathematics into the classroom.</p> <h2>Show us examples of women doing mathematics</h2> <p>\u201cWhen I think of a mathematician, I don\u2019t think of a woman,\u201d said one student in the single maths group. Students also discussed \u201chating the feeling of panic\u201d when stuck on a maths problem.</p> <p>Stereotype threat, outlined in <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2010/sep/10/gender-gap-myth-cordelia-fine\">Fine\u2019s \u2018Delusions of Gender\u2019</a>, \u201ccan do more than impair performance \u2013 it can also reduce interest in cross-gender activities\u201d. It\u2019s exacerbated by imagery that confirms the stereotype, so the examples of mathematicians that we use (at all levels) should be 50% female.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2016/oct/15/secret-teacher-pupils-forced-maths-never-use\">Secret Teacher: pupils are force-fed maths they'll never use again</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The words of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/aug/13/interview-maryam-mirzakhani-fields-medal-winner-mathematician\">Maryam Mirzakhani</a>, the first female Fields medallist, could be valuable to share: \u201cOf course, the most rewarding part is the \u2018aha\u2019 moment, the excitement of discovery and enjoyment of understanding something new \u2013 the feeling of being on top of a hill and having a clear view. But most of the time, doing mathematics for me is like being on a long hike with no trail and no end in sight.\u201d</p> <p>Gendered classroom practices have negative implications for students of all genders: a more inclusive classroom would benefit everyone.<br /></p> <p><em>Grace Geilinger is a maths teacher at Brighton, Hove &amp; Sussex Sixth Form College. </em></p> <p><strong>Follow us on Twitter via <a href=\"https://twitter.com/GuardianTeach\">@GuardianTeach</a>, like us on <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/GuardianTeacherNetwork/\">Facebook</a>, and join the <a href=\"https://profile.theguardian.com/agree/GTNF?returnUrl=https://teachers.theguardian.com/Registration.aspx\">Guardian Teacher Network</a> the latest articles direct to your inbox</strong></p> <p><strong>Looking for a teaching job?           "body": "<p>China says it has launched the world\u2019s first quantum satellite, a project Beijing hopes will enable it to build a coveted \u201chack-proof\u201d communications system with potentially significant military and commercial applications.</p> <p>Xinhua, Beijing\u2019s official news service, said Micius, a 600kg satellite that is nicknamed after an ancient Chinese philosopher, <a href=\"http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-08/16/c_135603521.htm\">\u201croared into the dark sky\u201d</a> over the Gobi desert at 1.40am local time on Tuesday, carried by a Long March-2D rocket. </p> <p>\u201cThe satellite\u2019s two-year mission will be to develop \u2018hack-proof\u2019 quantum communications, allowing users to send messages securely and at speeds faster than light,\u201d <a href=\"http://english.cri.cn/12394/2016/08/16/4202s937644.htm\">Xinhua reported</a>.</p> <p>The Quantum Experiments at Space Scale, or Quess, satellite programme is part of <a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/30/world/asia/china-unveils-ambitious-plan-to-explore-space.html?_r=0\">an ambitious space programme</a> that has accelerated since Xi Jinping became Communist party chief in late 2012. </p> <p>\u201cThere\u2019s been a race to produce a quantum satellite, and it is very likely that China is going to win that race,\u201d Nicolas Gisin, a professor and quantum physicist at the University of Geneva, <a href=\"http://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-latest-leap-forward-isnt-just-greatits-quantum-1471269555\">told the Wall Street Journal</a>. \u201cIt shows again China\u2019s ability to commit to large and ambitious projects and to realise them.\u201d </p> <p>The satellite will be tasked with sending secure messages between Beijing and Urumqi, the capital of Xinjiang, a sprawling region of deserts and snow-capped mountains in China\u2019s extreme west. </p> <p>Highly complex attempts to build such a \u201chack-proof\u201d communications network are based on the scientific principle of entanglement. </p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/aug/11/chinese-satellite-test-einstein-spookiest-claim\">Chinese satellite will test 'spooky' Einstein claim</a> </p> </aside>  <p>According to <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/aug/11/chinese-satellite-test-einstein-spookiest-claim\">this theory</a>, two particles become \u201centangled\u201d when they interact. However, any subsequent interaction impacts on both particles. \u201cIt is hence impossible to wiretap, intercept or crack the information transmitted through it,\u201d <a href=\"http://english.gov.cn/news/top_news/2016/08/16/content_281475418520259.htm\">Xinhua reported</a> after Tuesday\u2019s launch. </p> <p><a href=\"http://www.nature.com/news/china-s-quantum-space-pioneer-we-need-to-explore-the-unknown-1.19166\">Speaking to Nature magazine</a> earlier this year, the Chinese physicist in charge of the project, Pan Jianwei, said the launch would push the boundaries of scientific knowledge. \u201c[But] if you want to explore new physics, you must push the limit.\u201d </p> <p>\u201cI think China has an obligation not just to do something for ourselves \u2013 many other countries have been to the moon, have done manned spaceflight \u2013 but to explore something unknown,\u201d added Pan, from the Chinese Academy of Sciences.</p> <p>After Tuesday\u2019s launch Pan told Xinhua the mission marked \u201ca transition in China\u2019s role ... from a follower in classic information technology (IT) development to one of the leaders guiding future IT achievements\u201d. </p> <p>Beijing\u2019s official news agency said there were \u201cenormous prospects\u201d for the use of such technology in fields including defence, military and finance.</p>",

          "body": "<p>The definite article in the subtitle of Walter Isaacson\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/leonardo-da-vinci-524594.html\" title=\"\"><strong>Leonardo da Vinci: The Biography</strong></a> (Simon &amp; Schuster \u00a325.50) says it all \u2013 but why should the bestselling biographer of Benjamin Franklin, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2007/jun/10/biography.features\" title=\"\">Einstein</a> and <a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/steve-jobs-6.html\" title=\"\">Steve Jobs</a> pretend to false modesty? Isaacson is uniquely well-equipped to write the definitive account of a universal man who was a painter and a musician, a scientific theorist and an engineer, a designer of military hardware and a theatrical impresario, and he makes Leonardo\u2019s technological contraptions \u2013 a hoist, a perpetual-motion machine, a needle-grinder \u2013 seem every bit as fantastical as the effeminate saints and enigmatic sibyls he painted.</p> <p>Isaacson marvels at the infinite curiosity of a thinker who set himself to \u201cdescribe the tongue of the woodpecker\u201d, yet refuses to babble about genius as a supernatural gift. His Leonardo is a human being with foibles and frailties, whose great mind ultimately goes into a \u201ctailspin\u201d in his late drawings of an apocalyptic deluge: the intelligence that wondered at the miracle of creation took an almost crazed delight in the spectacle of destruction.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/oct/23/leonardo-da-vinci-biography-by-walter-isaacson-review\">Leonardo da Vinci: The Biography review \u2013 portrait of an easily distracted genius</a> </p> </aside>  <p>James Hamilton\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/gainsborough-502476.html\" title=\"\"><strong>Gainsborough: A Portrait</strong></a> (Weidenfeld &amp; Nicolson \u00a325) presents the painter of the Georgian aristocracy as a riotously ungenteel character \u2013 a rake whose hell-raising habits prompt Hamilton to call him \u201cJerry Lee Lewis with a paintbrush\u201d. Barbara Ehrlich White\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/renoir-519899.html\" title=\"\"><strong>Renoir: An Intimate Biography</strong></a> (Thames &amp; Hudson \u00a324.95) is equally startling. Renoir\u2019s creamy nudes encourage us to think of him as an unabashed hedonist; White, however, emphasises his grim battle with rheumatoid paralysis, which left him scarcely able to manipulate a brush. Art served as Renoir\u2019s medicine, the only alleviation of his pain, and he emerges here as a brave stoic rather than a sweet-toothed connoisseur of female flesh.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/surreal-life-of-leonora-carrington.html\" title=\"\"><strong>The Surreal Life of Leonora Carrington</strong></a> (Virago \u00a320) is a funny, touching account of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/apr/09/the-surreal-life-of-leonora-carrington-joanna-moorhead-review\" title=\"\">Joanna Moorhead</a>\u2019s unexpected friendship with the wildly imaginative painter and writer who happened to be her long-lost cousin. Carrington, a renegade debutante, scorned stuffy England and fled to Mexico with Max Ernst; incongruously nicknamed Prim by her family, she began life as a rebellious child, enchanted and alarmed Bu\u00f1uel with her sensual antics, and aged into a hawk-eyed, fiendishly witty sorceress who mocked death and defied it to take her. She is lucky to have found such a memorialist.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"1875e5b548116c8c8ecb2a11697156d3cc8b70d5\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/1875e5b548116c8c8ecb2a11697156d3cc8b70d5/144_167_1358_815/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Leonora Carrington in her studio in Mexico City in 2010, the year before her death.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Leonora Carrington in her studio in Mexico City in 2010, the year before her death.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Virago</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>In <a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/ravilious-co.html\" title=\"\"><strong>Ravilious and Co: The Pattern of Friendship</strong></a> (Thames &amp; Hudson \u00a324.95), Andy Friend has a more sedate but socially ominous story to tell. The watercolours and wood engravings of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/apr/05/ravilious-dulwich-picture-gallery-review-watercolours\" title=\"\">Eric Ravilious</a> and a circle of friends including <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/jun/14/rachel-cooke-shelf-life-edward-bawden-scrapbooks-wondrous-almanac-one-mans-sensibility\" title=\"\">Edward Bawden</a> helped to establish a \u201cgraphic identity\u201d for Britain in the 1930s. Their homespun provincial anecdotes pastoralised the country: a foreign observer remarked that genteel leisure was the main preoccupation of what was once a hard-working industrial nation. This villagey vision of the country has renewed relevance now that Great Britain is contracting into Little England, literally insulated from the modern world.</p> <p>A similarly enticing rural idyll recurs often in Martin Salisbury\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/illustrated-dust-jacket-1920-1970.html\" title=\"\"><strong>The Illustrated Dust Jacket 1920-1970</strong></a> (Thames &amp; Hudson \u00a324.95). Vistas of somnolent valleys are wrapped around National Trust guides; on the covers for books about the English counties edited by <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/news/2014/may/18/observer-archive-john-betjeman-giant-of-age-verse-rooted-past\" title=\"\">John Betjeman</a>; <a href=\"http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/john-piper-1774\" title=\"\">John Piper</a> relishes wistful Gothic decay. A series on country pubs has designs in blushing, bibulous hues that aimed, according to marketers in the 1930s, \u201cto seize the beholder in a chromatic embrace and give him a mental shake\u201d. The selection also includes a balefully modernist jacket for <em>Metropolis</em>, the book of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/mar/15/metropolis-fritz-lang-philip-french-classic-dvd\" title=\"\">Fritz Lang\u2019s science-fiction film</a>, plus some lush art deco extravaganzas that improbably package novels by Ernest Hemingway. It\u2019s all wickedly but irresistibly nostalgic.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>As the novelist Bergotte dies, Proust muses about a 'little patch of yellow wall' in a Vermeer view of Delft</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p><a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/paintings-in-proust.html\" title=\"\"><strong>Paintings in Proust</strong></a> by Eric Karpeles (Thames &amp; Hudson \u00a325) is a visual accompaniment to Proust\u2019s labyrinthine mnemonic novel <em>In Search of Lost Time</em> \u2013 indispensable for the addict, but also enticing for the casual browser, since Proust\u2019s mind contained a multi-cameral gallery of pictures, which he cited as sources for his characters and landscapes. His narrator notices women in the street who have stepped out of \u201cthe new and perishable universe\u201d created by Renoir; as the novelist Bergotte dies, he muses about a \u201clittle patch of yellow wall\u201d in a Vermeer view of Delft, a symbol of aesthetic perfection and a memento of the imperfect world he is leaving. Proust\u2019s verbal images aspired to the condition of painting, and here their wish is granted.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"fcba09acb53b4fdc514df8f5aff9ea45b26e6174\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/fcba09acb53b4fdc514df8f5aff9ea45b26e6174/447_0_2066_2582/800.jpg\" alt=\"Sergei Eisenstein\" width=\"800\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Sergei Eisenstein: a tour of the director\u2019s sketchbooks exposes often erotic scenarios he did not dare include in his films.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Ronald Grant</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Naum Kleiman\u2019s <strong>Eisenstein on Paper</strong> (Thames &amp; Hudson \u00a360) does some cerebral spying on the great Soviet film director. The tour of Eisenstein\u2019s sketchbooks deciphers what he called his \u201cvisuastenography\u201d, and exposes scenarios he did not dare to include in his films. The graphic escapades are often erotic. In a Mexican arena the horned bull seems to be humping the matador; Nijinsky is sketched while performing his notorious act of frottage in the ballet <em>Afternoon of a Faun</em>. If you have ever wondered why Shakespeare doesn\u2019t let us look inside the room where Macbeth kills Duncan, you should \u2013 if you\u2019re not easily shocked \u2013 take a peep at Eisenstein\u2019s imagined version of the forbidden scene. Here we see into the darkness punctuating the lighted images that flash across the cinema screen 24 times a second, as if we had penetrated the shuttered recess of Eisenstein\u2019s subconscious.</p> <p><strong>The Artist Project</strong> (Phaidon \u00a349.95) sets 100 contemporary artists loose in New York\u2019s Metropolitan Museum of Art to locate works that have a particular resonance for them. \u201cThe goddam Metropolitan Museum!\u201d sighs one participant, depressed by the surfeit of masterpieces. Some of the players opt to spend their time venerating <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/jan/03/velazquez-vanishing-man-laura-cumming-john-snare\" title=\"\">Velasquez</a> or Rembrandt; more intrepid explorers track down obscure treasures, among them a murky totem from Mali and a slit gong from Vanuatu, a fragment of the pharaoh Akhenaten\u2019s sinuous sculpted mouth and some armour worn by the Holy Roman Emperor Ferdinand I. A Vietnamese exile selects a Eug\u00e8ne Atget photograph of a messy Parisian kitchen, as a homesick reminder that cooking is synonymous with culture. The choices made and the commentaries that explain them are endlessly fascinating: here is the voluminous proof of Proust\u2019s belief that art multiplies reality, enabling us to see the world from inside someone else\u2019s head.</p> <p><em>\u2022 </em>To order any of the titles above for a special price, click on their titles, go to <a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/\" title=\"\">guardianbookshop.com</a> or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&amp;p over \u00a310, online orders only. Phone orders min p&amp;p of \u00a31.99</p>",

          "body": "<p>It has been a good year for British brains, which make up half the recipients of Nobel prizes in 2016 to date (the economics prize <a href=\"https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/about/prize_announcements/index.html\">will be announced</a> on Monday, while the literature prize comes later in the year). </p> <p>British trio David Thouless, Duncan Haldane and Michael Kosterlitz received the 2016 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/oct/04/david-thouless-duncan-haldane-and-michael-kosterlitz-win-nobel-prize-in-physics\">physics prize</a>, while Sir Fraser Stoddart <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/oct/05/nobel-prize-chemistry-2016-jean-pierre-sauvage-jean-pierre-sauvage-bernard-feringa-nano-machines\">shared in the chemistry prize</a>, helping to boost the number of awards the UK has received in these categories to 23 and 24 respectively.<br /></p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/video/2016/oct/04/duncan-haldane-calls-nobel-prize-win-a-gratifying-recognition-video\"            data-short-url=\"https://gu.com/p/56xne\"                    data-show-ads=\"true\"            data-video-id=\"2776667\"            data-video-name=\"Duncan Haldane calls Nobel prize win a gratifying recognition \u2013 video\"            data-video-provider=\"Reuters\"            > <video data-media-id=\"gu-video-57f3e9f5e4b005191a20eb71\" class=\"gu-video\" controls=\"controls\" poster=\"\"> <source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/mainwebsite/2016/10/04/04102016nobel_desk.mp4\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/HLS/2016/10/04/04102016nobel.m3u8\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/webM/2016/10/04/04102016nobel_WebM.webm\"/> </video> <figcaption><a recognition</a></figcaption> </figure>   <p>The highest proportion of UK winners is in the field of physiology or medicine, among them the Scottish-born John Macleod (1923) for his joint <a href=\"http://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1923/\">discovery of insulin</a> and his fellow Scotsman Sir Alexander Fleming (1945), who shared the prize with two others after he <a href=\"http://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1945/fleming-facts.html\">accidentally discovered penicillin</a>.<br /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/oct/06/brexit-not-good-news-for-british-science-warn-new-nobel-laureates\">Brexit 'not good news for British science' warn new Nobel laureates</a> </p> </aside>  <p>A total of 98 Britons are now on the list of Nobel prize winners, a tally second only to the US, which has had 258 Nobel laureates to date. <br /></p> <p>Indeed, such is the success of the US that it has had more Nobel prize winners than any other country in every category other than literature.<br /></p> <p>Germany has had 80 Nobel laureates, with 24 awards in both chemistry and physics. The most famous German winner is, of course, <a href=\"http://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1921/einstein-facts.html\">Albert Einstein</a>, who was awarded in 1921 \u201cfor his services to theoretical physics, and especially for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect\u201d.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2016/10/saturday_data_nobel/giv-1406tLrLbWSommL0/\" data-alt=\"nobel prize winners\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2016/10/saturday_data_nobel/giv-1406tLrLbWSommL0/\">nobel prize winners</a> </figure>",

          "body": "<p>Scientists have taken a major step towards building a global quantum internet by beaming \u201centangled\u201d particles of light from a satellite to ground stations more than 700 miles apart.</p> <p>The feat paves the way for a new kind of internet which draws on the curious ability for subatomic particles to be connected to one another despite being far apart and even on opposite sides of the planet.<br /></p> <p>Researchers believe that by linking particles together in this way, encrypted information could be sent from place to place across a quantum network with no danger of it being decrypted and read by others, as can be done on the existing internet.<br /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/dec/15/secure-quantum-internet-photons-computers\">Plans for a secure quantum internet take a leap forward</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Jian-Wei Pan, who led the research at the University of Science and Technology in Hefei in China, said the demonstration was a moment he had been dreaming of since 2003. \u201cMany people thought it was a crazy idea, because it was very challenging,\u201d he said.<br /></p> <p>The work obliterates the previous world record for sending pairs of photons that are connected to one another by a strange rule of quantum physics first spotted by Einstein. Until now, the farthest researchers had ever sent entangled photons stood at a mere 65 miles, less than one tenth of the distance achieved in the satellite experiment.<br /></p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s a first step, and a major step, toward creating a global quantum network,\u201d said Pan. \u201cAll the previous methods are limited to about 100km so can only work within a city.\u201d</p> <p>The experiment relied on the world\u2019s first quantum-enabled spacecraft: <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/aug/16/china-launches-quantum-satellite-for-hack-proof-communications\">a Chinese satellite called Micius</a>. As it soared over China, the satellite created pairs of photons with properties that were linked through quantum entanglement. It then beamed these simultaneously to ground stations in Delingha, Lijiang and Nanshan. Each pair of particles travelled up to 1,240 miles before they reached their destinations. Details of the study are published in <a href=\"http://science.sciencemag.org/cgi/doi/10.1126/science.aan3211\">Science</a>.</p> <p>Pan said that the kind of cryptography used to keep data safe today relies on complex mathematics which can often be defeated by hackers. \u201cIf a future quantum network is established, the security is ensured by the laws of physics, which are unconditionally secure,\u201d he said. \u201cIt will be beneficial for all human beings.\u201d<br /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/mar/06/quantum-computing-explained-particle-mechanics\">Quantum computing explained: harnessing particle physics to work faster</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Martin Stevens, a physicist at the National Institute of Standards and Technology in Boulder, Colorado, said he was impressed with the work. \u201cThese types of experiments are not easy to do, even within the controlled confines of a laboratory environment. Doing them between two remote ground locations and a satellite flying overhead at a speed of thousands of kilometres per hour is mind-bogglingly difficult.\u201d</p> <p>In 2015, Stevens sent entangled photons down a 65 mile length of optical fibre. That is good enough for quantum communications between neighbouring towns, but it cannot work for much greater distances, because the signal is gradually lost the more optic fibre it travels down. The advantage of using a satellite is that the particles of light travel through space for much of their journey.<br /></p> <p>Anton Zeilinger at the Vienna Centre for Quantum Science also praised the work. \u201cIt\u2019s an important step towards a worldwide quantum network. If you envisage a quantum network, the question is how to cover large distances and that cannot be done with glass fibres on the ground. You have to go into space, because in glass fibres you lose the signal. It\u2019s very important to show that it works with satellites, so I\u2019m very excited by this.\u201d<br /></p> <p>Zeilinger is working with Pan on an intercontinental quantum network and hopes to have results to report before the end of the year.<br /></p>",

It has been proof that the nation is committed to the principle that everyone should have access to the arts wherever they live in the UK.</p> <p>The gallery is the home of the world-famous <a href=\"http://thenewartgallerywalsall.org.uk/collections-library/\" title=\"\">Garman Ryan Collection</a> \u2013 365 works gifted by Kathleen Garman to the people of Walsall in 1973.         "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/books/2016/jan/15/sci-fi-general-relativity-einstein-planet-of-the-apes",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>A century after Albert Einstein formulated general relativity, the theory holds a profoundly strange place in modern life. On one hand, it underwrites all the marvels of technology today, from smartphones to space probes. We wouldn\u2019t be <a href=\"https://twitter.com/messenger2011\">tweeting from orbit around Mercury</a> without the physics Einstein published in 1915. On the other hand, while a fair number of people can tell you what special relativity\u2019s E=MC<sup>2</sup> stands for, a vanishingly small number can claim to really understand the universe as Einstein\u2019s famous equation reveals it to us.</p> <p>The popular understanding of relativity comes almost entirely from science fiction. A crew of astronauts crash land on a planet populated by apes, where humans are mutes kept as cattle. But it\u2019s only when <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XvuM3DjvYf0\">Charlton Heston screams \u201cYou maniacs, you blew it up!\u201d at Lady Liberty</a> that the other moon boot drops: we\u2019re on Earth after a nuclear apocalypse, transported into the future as a result of time dilation, an effect of relativity predicted by Einstein\u2019s theory.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--supporting\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/life-and-physics/2015/nov/25/video-100-years-of-einsteins-general-relativity\">Video: 100 years of Einstein's General Relativity</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Pierre Boulle\u2019s 1963 novel La Plan\u00e8te des Singes, via its Hollywood movie adaptation, arguably remains the most famous illustration of relativity in sci-fi. But Boulle\u2019s story is less about science than it is about humanity, with time dilation simply providing what the critic <a href=\"http://www.depauw.edu/sfs/backissues/14/suvin14art.htm\">Darko Suvin describes as the \u201cnovum\u201d</a>, the pivotal idea around which any sci-fi metaphor is constructed. Boulle exploits relativity to transport his readers into the future \u2013 but only to show us the folly of the present.</p> <p>For most of the 20th century, SF went out of its way to dodge relativity. The postulation of warp engines, hyperdrives and other varieties of faster-than-light (FTL) transportation is less a scientific idea than a dramatic device. In space opera novels such as Frank Herbert\u2019s Dune or CJ Cherryh\u2019s Alliance-Union series, FTL is first and foremost a way to play out human political dramas that would be impossible if it took eight centuries to travel between locations. We want stories told on a human scale, but on the scale of a relative universe, human stories don\u2019t even register.</p> <p><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/news/2001/aug/06/guardianobituaries\">Poul Anderson</a>\u2019s Tau Zero won the Hugo award for best novel in 1971 for it\u2019s hard-edged take on relativity and space travel. Fifty colonists travel from Earth on a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bussard_ramjet\">Bussard ramjet</a>-powered spacecraft. An onboard malfunction causes the ship to continue accelerating endlessly, taking ship and crew far beyond the limits of light-speed, flying between galaxy superclusters with all they know left billions of years in the past.</p> <p>From its title \u2013 a reference to <a href=\"http://mathworld.wolfram.com/LorentzTransformation.html\">the Lorentz equations that underpin relativity</a> \u2013 to Anderson\u2019s frequent authorial interventions explaining the science of relativity, Tau Zero dedicates itself to showing us a relativistic model of the universe. And yet the result is still much like a fairy tale transposed to space; a galactic Hansel and Gretel, of men and women lost in a star-strewn wilderness. However hard we try, we can only conceive of the weirdness of relativity through the mundanity of stories already known.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"bcbc619e1d86542913487abc03e2ccb8895603c8\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/bcbc619e1d86542913487abc03e2ccb8895603c8/0_114_2700_1620/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Planet of the Apes (1968)\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">It\u2019s all relative \u2026 Planet of the Apes (1968), adapted from Pierre Boulle\u2019s 1963 novel, is one of the most famous illustrations of the concept of time dilation.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: 20th Century Fox/Sportsphoto Ltd/Allstar</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Conjuring stories on the scale of a relativistic universe is among the greatest challenges in modern SF writing. <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/jul/13/alastair-reynolds-science-fiction\">Alastair Reynolds</a> pushes the possibilities of sub-light empire-building to their limits in House of Suns, where human civilisations rise and fall in cycles of a few millennia without breaking Einstein\u2019s laws of physics. Vernor Vinge\u2019s A Fire Upon the Deep incorporates the tricky question of consciousness into relativity, describing a galaxy in which the speed of thought increases the further life travels away from the \u201cunthinking depths\u201d of the galactic core.</p> <p>In Shikasta, the wide-ranging imagination of <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/books/dorislessing\">Doris Lessing</a> took the union of consciousness and physics to its ultimate conclusion, in a universe where travel between worlds is achieved by the passage through higher planes of existence that we would probably recognise as forms of heaven or nirvana. It\u2019s one of SF\u2019s strange conundrums, that the further it projects hard scientific fact into our future, the more it arrives back at a vision that echoes the myths of spirituality and religion.</p> <p>\u201cReality becomes illusory and observer-oriented when you study general relativity. Or Buddhism. Or get drafted,\u201d jokes William Mandella in <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2011/apr/14/back-to-the-hugos-joe-haldeman\">The Forever War</a>. Joe Haldeman\u2019s SF classic makes a beautiful literary device of time dilation and relativity, as its protagonist is sent on multiple tours of duty in a war against aliens that explicitly echoes Haldeman\u2019s own experiences in the Vietnam war. Every time Mandella returns home he is further forward in human history, and further isolated from the world he knew.</p> <p>It\u2019s the illusory, observer-oriented nature of reality that the theory of relativity brings us crashing up against. As we live them, the moments of our lives seem solidly real. But look at them through the lens of spacetime and they will be, in the words of Roy Batty, the replicant from Blade Runner whose inception date was 8 January 2016, \u201c<a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/mar/14/why-blade-runner-is-timeless\">lost in time, like tears in rain</a>\u201d. A century after Einstein\u2019s equations revealed a universe that humanity can never truly perceive, sci-fi has only just begun to let us see, however imperfectly, through eyes that can.<br /></p>",

          "body": "<p>A fictional mill town is the setting for new school drama <a href=\"http://www.channel4.com/programmes/ackley-bridge\"><strong>Ackley Bridge</strong></a> (Channel 4). Two schools, one predominantly Asian, one mainly white, have been merged to form Ackley Bridge College. Desegregating Yorkshire, it could have been called, if it was a documentary. (In fact, it was: you may recall Newsnight\u2019s series on <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/news/2015/nov/05/integrated-school-waterford-academy-oldham\">a similar real-life merger in Oldham</a>.)</p> <p>The new school has a new logo (a blue hand holding an orange hand; someone must have told the designer that the point of the new academy was to unite Iggle Piggle with Donald Trump). And a new sponsor, local mattress mogul Sadiq Nawaz, who takes a close interest in the day-to-day running of the place, and an even closer one in headteacher Miss Carter. Well, that\u2019s what Mr Carter thinks. Actually, Miss Carter\u2019s husband, the PE teacher, is called Mr Bell. \u201cEnd!\u201d shouts a kid, inevitably, but still amusingly.</p> <p>Things at the new school don\u2019t start brilliantly. Neighbours and best mates (but for how much longer?) Missy and Nasreen soon find themselves on different sides of a divide \u2013 a racial one \u2013 that quickly appears. Football teams pick themselves according to skin colour. Everyone might be in the same school now, but it doesn\u2019t look any more integrated.</p> <p>A kid called Jordan Wilson, also known (by himself) as Abdullah bin Kevin, doesn\u2019t help, by adopting a hijab and announcing he\u2019s a revert (\u201cpervert, more like\u201d \u2013 inevitably, amusingly).</p> <p>Jordan is the best character at Ackley Bridge \u2013 smart, offensive to everyone, the school wind-up merchant, who also represents a pessimistic but realistic view that such attempts at integration are futile. \u201cDo they think they can keep us quiet with a lick of paint and some crap about learning to live together?\u201d he asks the school after breaking into the office and taking over the public address system. \u201cIt don\u2019t matter if you\u2019re white or Asian, there\u2019s no jobs for us, we\u2019re all going nowhere. We, we\u2019re the immigrants, the benefit scroungers. If you\u2019re white, you\u2019re racist. And if you\u2019re Asian, you don\u2019t belong.\u201d</p> <p>The teachers aren\u2019t a whole lot better than they kids. Well, there\u2019s the Carter-Bell-Nawaz love triangle. And Mr Bell rips the hijab off an Asian girl, thinking she\u2019s a not-Asian boy (Jordan). And eventually he loses it completely and punches Jordan. I know, it\u2019s never right for a teacher to hit a pupil, but if ever a punch was a teeny bit justified, this one is.</p> <p>Then there\u2019s Miss Keane, a hippy-dippy flippy-floppy backpacker who only just makes it back from the airport in time for the beginning of term. Her backpack went missing, hence the inappropriate footwear. Miss Keane is locked in a custody battle with her ex over their daughter. Neither of them wants Chloe; they\u2019re battling not to have custody of her. Chloe repays her mum by showing up in her class with a hangover and then throwing up in the bin. Then, for extra revenge, she tweets a picture of her mum\u2019s boobs, with a twist-of-the-knife hashtag: #AckleyBridgeCollege.</p> <p>Ackley Bridge is very social media savvy; additional content was aired, pre-launch, on Snapchat, to drum up a bit of buzz. It\u2019s kind of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2014/apr/02/waterloo-road-axed-long-running-drama\">Waterloo Road</a> meets Shameless (the opening scene of Missy and Naz on a sofa, in a skip, drinking cider, giggling and quoting Einstein, could have come from the latter). However, despite the similarities, and Albert\u2019s words (\u201ceducation is what remains after one has forgotten what one has learned in school\u201d), it\u2019s not as clever as Paul Abbott\u2019s show, nor does it have the performances. There\u2019s not a hell of a lot of subtlety going on in Ackley Bridge: it is drama shoved in your face, like a Grange Hill sausage on a fork.</p> <p>But then Ackley Bridge is for a younger audience, all the family ... almost (not you, go to bed, now). The parallel-communities thing gives it something else, as well as ringing true about Britain today, asking questions about whether total integration is possible, even necessary, both in school and out of school. That side of things is handled carefully and sensitively. Real issues aren\u2019t avoided, cultural differences aren\u2019t denied; at the same time, obvious and boring stereotypes are avoided.</p> <p>If that makes it sound worthy, it really isn\u2019t. It\u2019s pleasingly loud and mischievous. Well, it\u2019s school, of course it is. As well as boobs, Ackley Bridge has balls. And a heart.</p>",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/commentisfree/2017/aug/09/trump-fire-and-fury-has-revived-my-nuclear-nightmares",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>I can\u2019t remember exactly when I stopped dreaming of nuclear annihilation. It must have been the 90s, when my fear of nuclear war was subsumed by other fears, maybe even some optimism. This fear was huge during the 80s. When the great storm of 1987 hit, I remember all the trees crashing and electricity going off and thinking: \u201cWell I suppose this is it. Something to do with Iran,\u201d and going back to sleep. Slow environmental collapse took over from the imagining of a nuclear winter. Now I fear terror and robots more. Both on the same day sometimes.</p> <p>It is remarkably easy, though, to resuscitate that old fear because it was all-engulfing at the time. The doctrine of mutually assured destruction was its highest goal. Those were the days, my friend. We thought we would all end.</p> <p>And here we are back again with Trump, who is forever warning us that the world is hell but threatening to make it more so. Does he really have the little plastic card known as \u201cthe biscuit\u201d that has to be snapped in two to reveal the nuclear codes? Strange times indeed when half the world is wishing it could be taken away from him. Presumably in a military coup.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/aug/08/donald-trump-north-korea-missile-threats-fire-fury\">\u201cFire and fury\u201d</a> is an attempt at biblical language to describe mass murder. This is being said while people <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2015/aug/06/after-the-atomic-bomb-hiroshima-and-nagasaki-then-and-now-in-pictures\">remember Nagasaki</a> and recount the details of the aftermath. A place, we are told, where the living envied the dead, where skin hung off children like cloth, where victims lay in darkness, their wounds full of maggots.</p> <p>Yet anyone who opposes nuclear weapons is accused of being naive beyond belief. Disarming in a multilateral world is an impossible ideal. As that ideal gets further away, so, until recently, has the idea of nuclear war.</p> <p>This was not always the case. In the 80s, the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament (CND) was huge and multi-generational. Indeed, on the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/fromthearchive/story/0,,1866956,00.html\">huge CND march in 1983</a>, when a million people came out on the streets, some of us were frustrated by how polite it all was. I had been at Greenham Common and wanted more direct action. CND seemed too woolly, and indeed there was a lot of criticism of Greenham as a women-only space from within its ranks.</p> <p>Nonetheless Michael Heseltine, minister of defence in 1983, was absolutely determined to undermine CND by spying on and bugging activists. CND was seen as a threat in itself. Not to want nuclear proliferation was, and remains, a challenge to the status quo. As Martin Amis said in <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Einstein%27s_Monsters\">Einstein\u2019s Monsters</a>: \u201cHow do we prevent the use of nuclear weapons. By threatening the use of nuclear weapons \u2026 the intransigence, it seems, is a function of the weapons themselves.\u201d Amis was derided at the time for his apocalyptic visions because this was 1987, and negotiations between Reagan and Gorbachev would result in <a href=\"http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/december/8/newsid_3283000/3283817.stm\">the non-proliferation Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty</a> in 1988. Membership of CND fell, people felt safer.</p> <p>But that moment is worth remembering now we have these two narcissistic monsters (the other being Kim Jong-un) threatening each other with warheads. How can this be de-escalated? \u201cNuclear war. LOL,\u201d as Twitter would have it. \u201cWe will all be gone in a flash.\u201d No we won\u2019t. Only the lucky ones will.</p> <p>I know this because the horror of nuclear weapons was brought home to us in the 80s. The terror was domesticated, and it was domesticated through the culture. This was extremely important. The \u201cprotect and survive\u201d leaflets of 1980 were seen as a kind of joke by many. The peace campaigner EP Thompson, of course, produced <a href=\"http://digitalarchive.wilsoncenter.org/document/113758\">Protest and Survive</a> as a response. The government had suggested that you could construct a fallout shelter out of cardboard. Or get under the table.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/aug/09/trump-brink-nuclear-war-stop\">Trump has taken us to the brink of nuclear war. Can he be stopped? | Jonathan Freedland</a> </p> </aside>  <p>In <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/dec/24/raymond-briggs-interview-the-snowman-ethel-and-ernest\">Raymond Briggs\u2019s When the Wind Blows</a>, Jim and Hilda build such a shelter, but when they leave it they are exposed to radiation. Their hair begins to fall out, their gums bleed, their water is contaminated, they start vomiting. When they go outside, they smell burning meat \u2013 the corpses of their neighbours.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2014/oct/20/threads-the-film-that-frightened-me-most-halloween\">Threads</a>, shown on the BBC, was even darker. Sheffield town hall is hit as warheads burst over the North sea. There is looting, cholera and typhoid. A year later, some of the smoke and soot clears but cancer is everywhere. Ten years later, life is returning to a medieval barbarism, with the government communicating to its small population only through radio.</p> <p>There was no \u201cduck and cover\u201d from the early propaganda films. The cheerful advice on how to survive a nuclear war was meaningless. This imagining of the darkness was crucial, but since then the fear has faded, replaced by other horrors perhaps.</p> <p>Nowadays, CND and its aims are regarded as slightly out of step. You can buy lovely CND earrings on Etsy. The peace sign was designed by <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2008/aug/21/photography.fashion\">Gerald Holtom</a>, a conscientious objector during the second world war. \u201cI was in despair,\u201d he said and drew that despair and formalised it by putting a circle around it. He had drawn himself, \u201chands palm outstretched and downwards, in the manner of Goya\u2019s peasant before the firing squad\u201d.</p>",
