          "body": "<p>Physicists have announced the discovery of gravitational waves, ripples in the fabric of spacetime that were first anticipated by <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/alberteinstein\">Albert Einstein</a> a century ago.<br /></p> <p> \u201cWe have detected gravitational waves. We did it,\u201d said David Reitze, executive director of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (Ligo), at a press conference in Washington.</p> <p> The announcement is the climax of a century of speculation, 50 years of trial and error, and 25 years perfecting a set of instruments so sensitive they could identify a distortion in spacetime a thousandth the diameter of one atomic nucleus across a 4km strip of laserbeam and mirror.</p> <p> The phenomenon detected was the collision of two black holes. Using the world\u2019s most sophisticated detector, the scientists listened for 20 thousandths of a second as the two giant black holes, one 35 times the mass of the sun, the other slightly smaller, circled around each other.</p> <p> At the beginning of the signal, their calculations told them how stars perish: the two objects had begun by circling each other 30 times a second. By the end of the 20 millisecond snatch of data, the two had accelerated to 250 times a second before the final collision and a dark, violent merger.</p> <p> The observation signals the opening of a new window on to the universe.</p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/video/2016/feb/11/gravitational-waves-discovery-changes-everything-video\"            data-short-url=\"http://gu.com/p/4gjbp\"                    data-show-ads=\"true\"            data-video-id=\"2454865\"            data-video-name=\"Why discovering gravitational waves changes everything\"            data-video-provider=\"guardian.co.uk\"            > <video data-media-id=\"gu-video-56bcb63fe4b0d007e4723bec\" class=\"gu-video\" controls=\"controls\" poster=\"\"> <source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/mainwebsite/2016/02/11/160211GravWaves5_desk.mp4\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/small/2016/02/11/160211GravWaves5_small.3gp\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/large/2016/02/11/160211GravWaves5_large.3gp\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/HLS/2016/02/11/160211GravWaves5.m3u8\"/><source src=\"https://cdn.theguardian.tv/webM/2016/02/11/160211GravWaves5_synd_768k_vp8.webm\"/> </video> <figcaption><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/video/2016/feb/11/gravitational-waves-discovery-changes-everything-video\">Why discovering gravitational waves changes everything</a></figcaption> </figure>   <p> \u201cThis is transformational,\u201d said Prof Alberto Vecchio, of the University of Birmingham, and one of the researchers at Ligo. \u201cWe have observed the universe through light so far. But we can only see part of what happens in the universe. Gravitational waves carry completely different information about phenomena in the universe. So we have opened a new way of listening to a broadcasting channel which will allow us to discover phenomena we have never seen before,\u201d he said. </p> <p> \u201cThis observation is truly incredible science and marks three milestones for physics: the direct detection of gravitational waves, the first detection of a binary black hole, and the most convincing evidence to date that nature\u2019s black holes are the objects predicted by Einstein\u2019s theory.\u201d</p> <p> The scientists detected their cataclysmic event using an instrument so sensitive it could detect a change in the distance between the solar system and the nearest star four light years away to the thickness of a human hair. </p> <p>And they did so within weeks of turning on their new, upgraded instrument: it took just 20 milliseconds to catch the merger of two black holes, at a distance of 1.3 billion light years, somewhere beyond the Large Magellanic Cloud in the southern hemisphere sky, but it then took months of meticulous checking of the signal against all the complex computer simulations of black hole collision to make sure the evidence matched the theoretical template. </p> <p> The detector was switched off in January for a further upgrade: astronomers still have to decipher months of material collected in the interval. But \u2013 given half a century of frustration in the search for gravitational waves \u2013 what they found exceeded expectation: suddenly, in the mutual collapse of two black holes, they could eavesdrop on the violence of the universe. </p> <p> Prof B S Sathyaprakash, from Cardiff University\u2019s school of physics and astronomy, said: \u201cThe shock would have released more energy than the light from all the stars in the universe for that brief instant. The fusion of two black holes which created this event had been predicted but never observed.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2016/02/gravitywave-zip/giv-27167Dz4AE8qnlMPa/\" data-alt=\"Gravitational waves\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2016/02/gravitywave-zip/giv-27167Dz4AE8qnlMPa/\">Gravitational waves</a> </figure>  <p> The finding completed the scientific arc of prediction, discovery and confirmation: first they calculated what they should be able to detect, then decided what the evidence should look like, and then devised the experiment that clinched the matter. Which is why on Thursday scientists around the world were able to hail the announcement as yet another confirmation of their \u201cstandard model\u201d of the cosmos, and the beginning of a new era of discovery.</p> <p> Astronomers have already exploited visible light, the infrared and ultraviolet, radio waves, x-rays and even gamma-rays in their attempt to understand the mechanics of stars, the evolution of the galaxies and the expansion of the universe from an initial big bang 13.8bn years ago.</p> <h2><strong>Unequivocal</strong></h2> <p>Thursday\u2019s announcement was the unequivocal first detection ever of gravity waves. The hope is that gravity wave astronomy could start to answer questions not just about the life of stars but their deaths as well: death by collision, death in a black hole, death in some rare stellar catastrophe so fierce that, for a few thousandths of a second, the blast is the brightest thing in the universe.<br /></p> <p> Even before the Ligo detectors in two US states reopened for business late last year, researchers were confident that a detection would follow swiftly. The announcement came after months of speculation, and decades of theoretical and practical work by an international network of more than a thousand scientists and engineers in Britain, Europe, the US and around the world.</p> <p> Professor Kip Thorne, of the California Institute of Technology, and one of the founding fathers of Ligo, said that until now, astronomers had looked at the universe as if on a calm sea. All of that had changed.</p> <p> \u201cThe colliding black holes that produced these gravitational waves created a violent storm in the fabric of space and time, a storm in which time speeded up and slowed down, and speeded up again, a storm in which the shape of space was bent in this way and that way,\u201d he said.</p> <p> Prof Neil Turok, director the <a href=\"https://www.perimeterinstitute.ca/\">Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics </a>at Waterloo in Canada, and a former research colleague of Prof Stephen Hawking, called the discovery \u201cthe real deal, one of those breakthrough moments in science\u201d.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"11cfd2383f7eaf7964dbfce254cea2d47fe0c70c\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/11cfd2383f7eaf7964dbfce254cea2d47fe0c70c/0_0_3134_1881/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Ligio co-founder Rainer Weiss, left, and Kip Thorne, right, hug on stage during a news conference at the National Press Club in Washington.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Ligo co-founder Rainer Weiss, left, and Kip Thorne, right, hug on stage during a news conference at the National Press Club in Washington.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Andrew Harnik/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p> Not only had the detector picked up the collision of two enormous black holes across a distance of almost a billion light years of space, it recorded the distinctive \u201cchirp\u201d as the two spiralled towards each other.</p> <p> The discovery, he said, completes a scientific arc of wonder that began 200 years ago, when the great British scientist Michael Faraday began to puzzle about how action was transmitted across the distance of space; how the sun pulled the Earth around. If the sun moved 10 yards, very suddenly, would the Earth feel the difference?</p> <p> He reasoned that something must cross space to transmit the force of gravity. Faraday\u2019s reasoning inspired the great British mathematician James Clerk Maxwell to think about how an electric force travelled, and arrive at an understanding of light and a prediction of radio waves.</p> <p> \u201cEinstein, when he came to write down his theory of gravity, his two heroes were Faraday and Maxwell,\u201d said Turok. \u201cHe tried to write down laws of the gravitational field and he wasn\u2019t in the least surprised to discover that his predictions had waves, gravitational waves.\u201d</p> <p> The Ligo discovery signals a new era in astronomy, he said.</p> <p> \u201cJust think of radio waves, when radio waves were discovered we learned to communicate with them. Mobile communication is entirely reliant on radio waves. For astronomy, radio observations have probably told us more than anything else about the structure of the universe. Now we have gravitational waves we are going to have a whole new picture of the universe, of the stuff that doesn\u2019t emit light \u2013 dark matter, black holes,\u201d he said.</p> <p> \u201cFor me the most exciting thing is we will literally be able to see the big bang. Using electromagnetic waves we cannot see further back than 400,000 years after the big bang. The early universe was opaque to light. It is not opaque to gravitational waves. It is completely transparent.</p> <p> \u201cSo literally, by gathering gravitational waves we will be able to see exactly what happened at the initial singularity. The most weird and wonderful prediction of Einstein\u2019s theory was that everything came out of a single event: the big bang singularity. And we will be able to see what happened.\u201d</p> <p>\u2022 The headline to this article was amended on 12 February 2016. An earlier version said the discovery was a breakthrough after two centuries of expectation. This has been corrected.<br /></p> <p><br /></p> <p></p>",

        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>Is giftedness a case of nature or nurture? Opinion is divided. While one school of thought says that some children <a href=\"http://www.telegraph.co.uk/films/gifted/how-do-i-know-if-my-child-is-gifted/\">have an innate ability to achieve higher</a> than their peers, others will argue that <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/jul/25/no-such-thing-as-a-gifted-child-einstein-iq\">most people can reach standards of performance</a> associated with being gifted and talented. </p> <p>In <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2017/jul/27/how-do-we-boost-childrens-brainpower-live-chat\">our recent Q&amp;A</a>, experts discussed the latest thinking on how people become high performers and what teachers and parents can do to help young people excel in their chosen areas. Here\u2019s a summary of their thoughts: </p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/teacher-blog/2017/aug/02/create-culture-excellence-schools-students-teachers\">How can we create a culture of excellence in schools?</a> </p> </aside>  <h2>1. Ask students what they like</h2> <p>For a start, I think we could ask students what they like. It\u2019s much easier to do better at something if you are motivated to do so, so we should encourage children to do better in subjects they\u2019re good at. I think one of the main ideas around high ability education is getting people to achieve highly in areas where they already show competency. <em>Colm O\u2019Reilly, director, <a href=\"https://www.dcu.ie/ctyi/index.shtml\">Centre for Talented Youth Ireland</a>, Dublin City University</em></p> <p>If people don\u2019t enjoy a subject, I think schools have a responsibility to raise their attainment, but to not force them to excel. Schools can do many different things to raise attainment, such as whole-school approaches to behaviour or effective pedagogy, or individual interventions such as mentoring and apps. Encouraging learners who are assessed as having high potential to explore the subjects they really love is the way to go. <em>Simon Coyle, co-founder, <a href=\"http://www.thebrilliantclub.org/\">The Brilliant Club</a></em></p> <h2><strong>2. Work out what is holding them back</strong></h2> <p>Young people can be held back by not seeing the value of the gifts they have. As parents and teachers, we have to encourage them to see the potential in their talent, where it can lead them, and the opportunities it offers them. <em>Colm O\u2019Reilly</em></p> <p>Gifted children are not good at everything. [Our assessments] show what can hold the child back: sensory issues, social and emotional issues such as perfectionism, and lack of resilience. Even the simplest thing can throw a child off course. Some children with high ability also have special needs or a disability. These children can have low self-esteem and underachieve because their needs are not recognised. <em>Denise Yates, chief executive, Potential Plus UK</em></p> <h2>3. Understand how students learn<br /></h2> <p>I don\u2019t hold with the view that all children can or should be taught in the same way. I used to support numeracy and literacy programmes for adults and it was about finding that lightbulb moment when someone says: \u201cNow I get it!\u201d That is what good teaching does. There are too many children, including high learning potential children, who are \u201csquare pegs in round holes\u201d. <em>Denise Yates</em></p> <h2>4. Incorporate games and other activities<br /></h2> <p>Games can have an enormous impact on high performance \u2013 think of the strategy needed for Monopoly, for example. Strategic thinking is essential for high performance, too. <em>Wendy Berliner, joint chief executive, Education Media Centre</em></p> <p>Using games and activities are such a powerful tool for high ability students. Learning strategy and technique is useful for bright children to apply in other areas of their lives, and activities such as the Model United Nations is a great way to teach current affairs and international relations. <em>Colm O\u2019Reilly</em></p> <h2>5. Get parents involved</h2> <p>Some children can be held back by parents who don\u2019t understand their importance as the child\u2019s first and longest-serving teacher. Parents need to have high expectations of their children if they are to do well \u2013 not unrealistic, just high. Research shows it makes the difference. <em>Wendy Berliner</em></p> <h2>6. Be open about developing growth mindsets</h2> <p>The growth mindset has proved really helpful in some schools. The term, coined by Carol Dweck, demonstrates the difference between a fixed mindset \u2013 thinking that you have a set level of ability that will determine your academic outcome \u2013 and a flexible mindset, where you can grow your intelligence. It\u2019s true that you have to be overt in doing this. Many schools now talk to students about the fact that they can grow their intelligence, but it\u2019s sometimes a bit hollow because they don\u2019t talk about how they can do this. <em>Deborah Eyre, academic researcher and founder of <a href=\"https://www.highperformancelearning.co.uk/\">High Performance Learning</a></em></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2016/oct/12/the-problem-of-perfectionism-five-tips-to-help-your-students\">The problem of perfectionism: five tips to help your students</a> </p> </aside>  <h2><strong>7. Talk about the future</strong></h2> <p>I think it helps to show a child what their potential future holds if they can develop their talents, and show that this future is something that is fulfilling but also tangible. <em>Colm O\u2019Reilly</em></p> <p>It\u2019s also helpful for students to see the link between a potential future and what they need to start doing to make it possible. <em>Deborah Eyre</em></p> <p><em>Read the full Q&amp;A <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2017/jul/27/how-do-we-boost-childrens-brainpower-live-chat\">here</a>.</em></p> <p><strong>Follow us on Twitter via <a href=\"https://twitter.com/GuardianTeach\">@GuardianTeach</a>, like us on <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/GuardianTeacherNetwork/\">Facebook</a>, and join the <a href=\"https://profile.theguardian.com/agree/GTNF?returnUrl=https://teachers.theguardian.com/Registration.aspx\">Guardian Teacher Network</a> the latest articles direct to your inbox</strong></p> <p><strong>Looking for a teaching job? Or perhaps you need to recruit school staff? <a href=\"https://jobs.theguardian.com/jobs/schools/?INTCMP=gdnwb_copts_editorial_jobs_SchoolsArticle_\">Take a look at Guardian Jobs</a>, the education specialist.</strong></p>",

          "body": "<p>No one should be in any doubt that scientists can blunder, just like anyone else. <br /></p> <p>Many doctoral theses have lost a crucial, un-backed-up section due to late-night fat fingers. In <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/may/02/smashing-physics-jon-butterworth-review-cern-higgs-boson-particle\">Smashing Physics</a> I wrote about the first, abortive attempt to start up the Large Hadron Collider in 2008 \u2013 not to mention a proton decay experiment that accidentally siphoned a cesspit into its (previously) clean detector volume.<br /></p> <p>None of those are especially productive mistakes \u2013 though sometimes the rewritten thesis can be an improvement, and we did do some useful work while the LHC was repaired.           "body": "<p>Scott Kelly is a 53-year-old American astronaut and a veteran of four space flights. He retired last year after spending 11 continuous months on the International Space Station. During his time on board the ISS, he orbited the Earth 5,440 times and made three space walks. He was also part of a study with his identical twin and fellow astronaut, Mark Kelly, to examine the genetic effects of spaceflight. As Mark was on Earth and Scott in space, they made for perfect comparative analysis, though it was not the reason Kelly was chosen for the mission. He has just published a memoir, <em>Endurance: A Year in Space, a Lifetime of Discovery</em>.</p> <p><strong>What do you think has been the most important achievement of manned space\u00a0travel?</strong><br />I think it\u2019s how it accelerates our development of technology, whether its telecommunications, computer power, the ability to put satellites into orbit. I think we\u2019d live in a much\u00a0different world if we didn\u2019t fly\u00a0in\u00a0space.</p> <p><strong>You lost several friends in the </strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/columbia\" title=\"\"><strong>2003 Columbia disaster</strong></a><strong>. And as you say, there were many warnings about the foam problem that caused the accident that went unheeded. How did you deal with that knowledge, and did it ever make you lose confidence in the supporting staff?</strong><br />It was hard \u2013 several close friends were on that mission, and I nearly ended up as the pilot myself \u2013 but you cope. Clearly it was a wake-up call for the whole organisation, but I didn\u2019t lose confidence. We adjusted our management philosophy after the accident. I had faith that Nasa would conduct a rigorous investigation, and it was obvious to me during my next mission that they were proceeding with an abundance of caution.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/gallery/2016/mar/02/scott-kelly-nasa-iss-space-earth-in-pictures\">Scott Kelly snaps photos of Earth and the galaxy from space \u2013 in pictures</a> </p> </aside>  <p><strong>What\u2019s the psychological and physical effect of literally coming back to Earth?</strong><br />Physically there\u2019s stiffness, swelling of my legs, rashes where my skin hasn\u2019t touched anything, nausea. In space you lose a significant amount of blood volume. You regain it when you get back very quickly but what you don\u2019t regain is the red blood cells you lost with it and that takes months to recover. That makes you feel fatigued. It\u2019s a six- to eight-month recovery. Then there\u2019s things you can\u2019t feel: bone loss, muscle loss, structural changes in my eyes. The effects of radiation at a genetic level \u2013 I don\u2019t know what they\u2019ll be. The psychological effect, at least for me, being in this controlled environment and being told what to do and when to do it for a year, and then coming back and not having that type of structure, it\u2019s definitely a challenge.</p> <p><strong>Do you know what the twin study of you and your brother was focused on? And have you been told about any results?</strong><br />Mostly genetic research but also cognitive studies. The research is still happening. It takes three to five years for the results to be published, so we don\u2019t really know much about the conclusions yet. The one big find so far was that my telomeres, basically these things at the end of our chromosomes that shorten with stress and age, actually ended up longer than Mark\u2019s. It\u2019s the opposite of what the scientists expected, given the challenging environment on the ISS, exposure to radiation, etc. I was already six minutes younger than Mark but, as Einstein predicted, I\u2019ve come back six minutes and 13 milliseconds younger after a year in space.</p> <p><strong>What about the sense of being cut off from humanity. You\u2019re stuck with a handful of people for months on end. Did that never torment you?</strong><br />You\u2019re connected with email and you can make phone calls and follow the news. On the one hand you\u2019re aware what\u2019s going on on Earth, but the fact that you\u2019re not on it does make you feel a little bit separate. It gives you a different perspective on our planet, which is a very beautiful oasis in our solar system, but at the same time has a lot of challenges and struggles: the environment, a lot of war and conflict and hardship.</p> <p><strong>Do you think there\u2019s a limit to how long people can physically and mentally stay up in space?</strong><br />I think it would depend on what they\u2019re doing and what you want them to do when they\u2019re done being in space. If you had no choice, you could probably live there for years. If you\u2019re going to Mars, I think that\u2019s doable. People are going to spend years in space and they\u2019ll want to get back to somewhere with gravity. There probably needs to be some kind of artificial gravity as part of the spacecraft. Going to Mars and back is not going to require artificial gravity, but if you wanted to go to the moons of Saturn some day, it probably would.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"5a3f0d7bdd4a32b7b92e950ad3499a18fa57b3c1\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5a3f0d7bdd4a32b7b92e950ad3499a18fa57b3c1/0_0_4928_3280/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A selfie taken by Kelly while on board the International Space Station, 12 July 2015.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"666\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A selfie taken by Kelly while on board the International Space Station, 12 July 2015.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Scott Kelly/Nasa via AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><strong>What does the space walk feel like?</strong><br />It\u2019s pretty crazy. Hopefully, when people get to that part of the book, it\u2019ll make them feel like they\u2019re there. I think it\u2019s like that type two kind of fun. Type one kind of fun is fun while you\u2019re doing it, like a carnival ride. Type two is fun when it\u2019s done. It\u2019s kind of like that.</p> <p><strong>On one of your previous missions, a cosmonaut became untethered during a space walk. What would have happened if he hadn\u2019t fortuitously hit an antenna that bounced him back?</strong><br />Frankly, he would have died \u2013 either from rising CO<sub>2</sub> or losing oxygen. It was a possibility I tried to avoid contemplating too much when I did it myself for the first time.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>With current technology, to go to the nearest Earth-like planet outside the solar system would take about 80,000 years</p> <footer> <cite>Scott Kelly</cite> </footer> </blockquote> </aside>  <p><strong>What were the most testing aspects of your first space walk?</strong><br />Probably the sheer amount of time. Even before the walk itself, you spend weeks preparing and studying. You\u2019re in these incredibly complex suits for almost 12 hours straight \u2013 hours in advance, and then almost eight for the walk itself. They work great but can be really stiff and cumbersome. I never totally get why they call it spacewalking \u2013 you\u2019re crawling around with hands, and you\u2019re working and repairing every second. Not exactly a stroll.</p> <p><strong>It lasted many hours. Were you at any point anxious?</strong><br />Not especially. I\u2019ve had a knack for compartmentalising since my days in the navy. There are so many little tasks to take care of on a spacewalk \u2013 eight hours is barely enough time to complete everything we\u2019re assigned. So I just kept focused on what was in front of me: my gloves, the pieces of the station in front of me. I barely even looked at the Earth looming just outside my field of vision.</p> <p><strong>Do you think it\u2019s inevitable that at some point we\u2019ll have some manned space flight to Mars?</strong><br />I don\u2019t know if it\u2019s inevitable. It think it will happen. Inevitable means it has to happen. It seems to me that, despite any issues there may be with climate change and pollution, Earth is much more inhabitable than Mars, which basically has no atmosphere or oxygen or, as far as we know, forms of life. With our current technology, to go to the nearest Earth-like planet outside the solar system would take about 80,000 years. Whoever got on that spaceship, their ancestors would probably be a different species.</p> <p><strong>You say that reading </strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/mar/14/100-best-nonfiction-no-7-right-stuff-tom-wolfe\" title=\"\">Tom Wolfe\u2019s <strong><em>The Right Stuff</em></strong></a><strong> inspired you to become a pilot, which in turn led to being an astronaut. What inspired your\u00a0brother?</strong><br />Honestly, you\u2019d have to ask him. He had his life organised far earlier than I did, so he took the more traditional path to becoming a pilot and then an astronaut. Maybe he didn\u2019t need the kick I did from reading Wolfe\u2019s book. I think he was also inspired, like I was, by our families. Our grandfather, a merchant marine officer and fireboat captain, and our mother, who put in tremendous work to join the local police force. It inspired us to try the hardest thing we could manage to find.</p> <p><strong>And was there ever rivalry between you?</strong><br />Not really. Though technically it did take him two tries to get into Nasa \u2013 his first application got rejected. I sometimes remind him.</p> <p><strong>If there\u2019s one moment you could relive as an astronaut, what would it be?</strong><br />Coming back from space after a year. Just the smell after the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soyuz_(spacecraft)\" title=\"\">Soyuz</a> hatch opened. I can\u2019t imagine a better feeling.</p> <p>\u2022\u00a0<em>Endurance: A Year in Space, a Lifetime of Discovery</em> by Scott Kelly is published by Doubleday (\u00a320). To order a copy for \u00a317 go to <a href=\"https://www.guardianbookshop.com/endurance-524237.html\" title=\"\">guardianbookshop.com</a> or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&amp;p over \u00a310, online orders only. Phone orders min p&amp;p of \u00a31.99</p>",

          "body": "<p>A first edition of Sir Isaac Newton\u2019s <em>Principia Mathematica</em> has become the most expensive printed scientific book ever sold at auction after a winning bid of $3.7m (\u00a33m), the auction house Christie\u2019s has announced.</p> <p>The edition of Newton\u2019s 1687 work, described by Albert Einstein as \u201cperhaps the greatest intellectual stride that it has ever been granted to any man to make\u201d, went for nearly two and a half times its highest estimate.</p> <p>It was one of the lots in <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/dec/05/principia-sir-isaac-newton-first-edition-auction-christies-new-york\">Wednesday night\u2019s sale of fine books</a> and manuscripts auctioned at Christie\u2019s New York office which raised a total of \u00a37.5m.</p> <p>The continental edition, which was intended to be distributed on the European mainland by Samuel Smith, bears some differences from the British edition. Only about 80 such <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/mar/08/cambridge-university-library-dusts-off-rare-volumes-display\">first editions</a> were thought to have been published, with about 400 in total produced.</p> <p>Edmund Halley, the astronomer after whom the comet was named, edited the work, having encouraged Newton to produce a single text setting out his ideas. Halley paid for the printing because the Royal Society had run out of funds.</p> <p>The society retains two copies of the book, including the original manuscript on which the first print run in 1687 was based, which is described as its \u201cgreatest treasure\u201d.</p> <p>Among other ideas, the work sets out Newton\u2019s laws of motion and his law of universal gravitation. The work is a \u201cbenchmark in human thought\u201d, Keith Moore, the head of the Royal Society library, has previously said.</p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s not just the history and development of science; it\u2019s one of the greatest books ever published. It was hugely influential in terms of applying mathematics to basic physical problems.\u201d<br /></p> <p>He linked the popularity of scientific texts with the number of people who have made their money from technology advancements. \u201cPeople who have big books these days maybe are the kinds of people who have made their money on the internet or the web ... If you have a few million quid to spend, why wouldn\u2019t you buy a copy of Principia Mathematica?</p> <p>\u201cIf you\u2019ve made your money from a really cool algorithm, you will probably appreciate Newtonian physics.\u201d</p> <p>According to Christie\u2019s, other sale highlights included nine lots of correspondence to the Marquis de Chastellux, featuring six letters by George Washington and three by Thomas Jefferson. They sold for a total of \u00a3900,000.</p>",

          "body": "<p>The premise of Kanye West\u2019s Saint Pablo tour sounds like it\u2019s based on a dare: perform an entire concert on a flying stage above the crowd. So, could he pull it off?</p> <p> There were moments in West\u2019s Toronto set that felt indelible, with the rapper/producer leaping around on his flying platform that sat above a rapturous mosh pit, bathing it in light. The man with the arena-sized ego managed to create scenes of spirited communal joy.</p> <p> West isn\u2019t the first to have dreamt up a flying stage: his collaborator Drake, his arch-nemesis Taylor Swift, and Nickelback have used smaller versions. It solves the problem of how to bring a musician closer to the fans, and recognizes that a concert hinges on how they and react and relate to one another.</p> <p> True, Saint Pablo\u2019s imagery recalls his 2014 summer festival shows, which found a masked West alone in front of a giant, monolithic screen. This tour is equally dependent on him as a central, unsupported performer, but with its stage that can tilt, bump and dip down just above fans\u2019 heads so they could nearly touch their idol when he lies down above them. It\u2019s dynamic and compelling. </p> <p>The stark, minimalist design offered a rich range of associations harnessed and tethered, West recalled at once a skyscraper construction worker (complete with industrial gloves); a prisoner battling a chain; and a Cronenberg-esque bionic human hooked up to technology with a bumpy <a href=\"http://cronenbergmuseum.tiff.net/collaborateurs_13-collaborators_13-eng.html\">umbilical cord</a>. The stage was part Blade Runner flying car (with Ridley Scott\u2019s hazy <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-fu7jN2_2pE\">black-and-sodium orange color scheme</a> echoed throughout the whole show), part Close Encounters of the Third Kind <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S4PYI6TzqYk\">musical spaceship</a> (complete with blinding lights and fat bass synth sounds that might have shattered glass), and part Robert Wilson theatre prop.</p> <p> The show\u2019s final image could have emerged from Wilson and Philip Glass\u2019s <a href=\"https://backtotheworld.net/2012/06/14/robert-wilson-and-philip-glass-bed-from-einstein-on-the-beach-in-toronto-june-9-2012/\">Einstein on the Beach</a>: the tilted stage carries a crouching West slowly over the arena\u2019s floor, from darkness through a single spotlight, and beyond, to where he disembarks on the floor, slaps some hands and exits. It\u2019s a little grandiose and Christ-like, what with the gospel choir from Ultra Light Beam playing on repeat, but it\u2019s also unexpectedly moving. </p> <p> And when West is good, he\u2019s very, very good. He dialed down his trademark ranting (unlike the first show in Indianapolis, which found him apologizing to Nike at length, as one does) and dialed up the hits, reaching back from Jesus Walks through a triumphant Touch the Sky to a thwacking Stronger. He also ran through most of the self-obsessed psychodrama on his endlessly reworked Life of Pablo, proving a magnetic figure, celebratory, defiant and, crucially, focused. </p> <p>Implausible though it may seem, West even at times came across as an everyman, stepping out of the spotlights to the edges of the stage, and pulling on his tether as if straining against his own limitations. West may tell everyone he\u2019s a god, but he\u2019s compelling because he\u2019s all too human.</p>",

          "body": "<p>The collision of a pair of neutron stars, marked by ripples through the fabric of space-time and a flash brighter than a billion suns, has been witnessed for the first time in the most intensely observed astronomical event to date.</p> \n<p>The extraordinary sequence, in which the two ultra-dense stars spiralled inwards, violently collided and, in all likelihood, immediately collapsed into a black hole, was first picked up by the US-based Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (Ligo).<br></p> \n<p>As its twin detectors, in Louisiana and Washington state, picked up tremors in space-time that had spilled out from the merger 130m light years away, an alert went out to astronomers across the globe. Within hours, 70 space- and ground-based telescopes swivelled to observe the red-tinged afterglow, making it the first cosmic event to be \u201cseen\u201d in both gravitational waves and light.</p> \n<aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> \n <blockquote> \n  <p>Shoemaker was alerted by a ringtone on his phone reserved for when black holes or neutron stars collide</p> \n </blockquote> \n</aside> \n<p>Dave Reitze, executive director of Ligo, said: \u201cWhat is amazing about this discovery is it is the first time we\u2019ve got a full picture of one of the most violent, cataclysmic events in the universe. This is the most intense observational campaign there has ever been.\u201d</p> \n<p>Einstein first predicted the existence of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/feb/11/gravitational-waves-discovery-hailed-as-breakthrough-of-the-century\">gravitational waves</a> a century ago, but the first experimental proof that space itself can be stretched and squeezed took until 2015, when Ligo scientists detected a collision of black holes. But this dark merger, and the three detected since, were invisible to conventional telescopes. </p> \n<p>This time, as the stars collided, they emitted an intense beam of gamma rays and the sky was showered with heavy elements, resolving a decades-old debate about where gold and platinum come from. </p> \n<figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2017/10/gravitywaves-zip/giv-3902CuAwVVfaSYO5\" data-alt=\"When neutron stars collide graphic\"> \n <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2017/10/gravitywaves-zip/giv-3902CuAwVVfaSYO5\">When neutron stars collide graphic</a> \n</figure> \n<p>Neutron stars are the smallest, densest stars known to exist: about 12 miles wide, with a teaspoon of neutron star material having a mass of about a billion tons. The core is a soup of pure neutrons, while the crust is smooth, solid and 10 billion times <a href=\"https://www.space.com/6682-neutron-star-crust-stronger-steel.html\">stronger than steel</a>.</p> \n<p>The 100-second hum picked up by Ligo told the story of how the two stars, each slightly heavier than the sun, approached their death. Initially separated by 200 miles, they circled each other 30 times a second. As they whirled inwards, accelerating to 2,000 orbits each second, the signal rose in pitch like a slide whistle.</p> \n<p>Two seconds later, Nasa\u2019s Fermi space telescope picked up an intense burst of gamma rays, emitted as shockwaves rushed through jets of matter funnelled out of the poles during the monumental impact of the collision.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e7LcmWiclOs\"> \n <iframe width=\"460\" height=\"259\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/e7LcmWiclOs?wmode=opaque&amp;feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> \n <figcaption>\n  This animation captures phenomena observed over nine days following the neutron star merger known as GW170817. \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>What happened next is uncertain. A neutron star weighing more than twice the mass of the sun (the combined mass here) has never been seen before \u2013 but neither has a black hole so small. Theoretical predictions suggest an almost instantaneous gravitational collapse into a black hole is most likely.</p> \n<p>\u201cNeutron stars are at this sweet spot between a star and a black hole,\u201d said Prof Andreas Freise, a Ligo project scientist at the University of Birmingham. \u201cWhen two of them collide, we expect them to immediately collapse into a black hole, leaving behind a bit of dust and stuff.\u201d</p> \n<p>David Shoemaker, spokesman for the Ligo Scientific Collaboration, said: \u201cIt\u2019s [probably] the first observation of a black hole being created where there was none before, which is pretty darn cool.\u201d</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"8c60c39d90b0c2ed69a166dda42c916b2c6e97c2\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8c60c39d90b0c2ed69a166dda42c916b2c6e97c2/0_0_2100_1500/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Neutron star merger seen in gravity and matter\" width=\"1000\" height=\"714\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> \n  <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Neutron star merger seen in gravity and matter: the right panel contains a visualization of the stars\u2019 matter, the left shows how space-time is distorted near the collisions.</span> \n  <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Karan Jani/Georgia Tech</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>The observations herald a new era of rapid-response astronomy, in which transient and unexpected cosmic events can be observed in detail for the first time. When Ligo\u2019s software picked up a signal at 1:41pm UK time on 17 August, Shoemaker was one of a small team at Ligo to be alerted by a ringtone on his phone reserved for when black holes or neutron stars collide.</p> \n<p>\u201cMy phone went off and I smiled,\u201d he said.</p> \n<p>Within an hour, the detection had been confirmed by Virgo, a European gravitational wave detector near Pisa, the source of the signal had been triangulated to a small patch of sky and a global alert was triggered. </p> \n<p>Prof Stephen Smartt, of Queen\u2019s University Belfast, was leading a five-day observation run of supernovae on the New Technology Telescope at La Silla, Chile, when the news came in.</p> \n<p>\u201cWe dropped everything and pointed at that bit of sky,\u201d he said. \u201cThis was the most unusual object we\u2019d ever seen.\u201d</p> \n<p>Smartt\u2019s team, and those on other telescopes, observed the faint new blob and measured its spectrum to assess the chemical composition. The blob was a fireball of radioactive heavy chemical elements, known as a kilonova, that had been blown out from the collision at one fifth of the speed of light shortly after the gamma ray burst.</p> \n<aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> \n <blockquote> \n  <p>The wedding band on your finger or the gold watch you\u2019re wearing was most likely produced by two neutron stars colliding</p> \n </blockquote> \n</aside> \n<p>Previously, scientists had speculated that the sheer force of neutron star collisions would be enough to force extra neutrons into the nuclei of atoms, forging heavy elements like gold and platinum, but until now this idea was purely theoretical.</p> \n<p>\u201cPeople have been looking for that forever,\u201d said Freise.</p> \n<p>\u201cThis is the first real confirmation that heavy elements such as gold, platinum and uranium are either solely or predominantly produced in binary neutron star collisions,\u201d said Reitze. \u201cThe wedding band on your finger or the gold watch you\u2019re wearing was most likely produced a billion years ago by two neutron stars colliding. That\u2019s pretty cool.\u201d</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_SQbaILipjY\"> \n <iframe width=\"460\" height=\"259\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/_SQbaILipjY?wmode=opaque&amp;feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> \n <figcaption>\n  This is what the gravitational wave signal of the two stars colliding sounds like.\n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> \n <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2017/oct/16/mondays-gravitational-wave-observation-is-astronomical-alchemy\">Monday's gravitational wave observation is astronomical alchemy</a> </p> \n</aside> \n<p>Earlier this month, three US scientists who played a crucial role in the development of Ligo were awarded <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/oct/03/nobel-prize-physics-discovery-gravitational-waves-ligo\">the Nobel prize in physics</a> for the first detection of gravitational waves. Shoemaker pointed out that two of the new laureates \u2013 and others \u2013 had been working on the project long before it captured the world\u2019s attention</p> \n<p>\u201cThis kind of thing doesn\u2019t happen because there are suddenly neat instruments,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s decades of work and people working together in a collaborative way. It\u2019s quite phenomenal.\u201d</p> \n<p>The findings were published on Monday in a series of papers in journals including Science, Nature and Physics Review Letters.<br></p>",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/books/2017/jul/18/neil-degrasse-tyson-fighting-science-denial-starts-with-people-not-politicians",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>Albert Einstein has been called many things: a genius, a pioneer, a Nobel prize winner. Neil deGrasse Tyson just calls him a badass.</p> <p>\u201cI think it fits, right? It\u2019s not a stretch,\u201d he tells Guardian Australia before his appearance in Melbourne on Saturday night. \u201cThe dude\u2019s a badass.\u201d<br /></p> <p>This description of the father of modern physics is one of many notable<strong> </strong>turns of phrase in Astrophysics for People in a Hurry, the latest book from the astrophysicist and host of the StarTalk podcast. He is currently touring Australia with Think Inc to promote the book and talk about the science of the universe, with shows in Melbourne, Perth, Brisbane and Sydney.</p> <p>The book has had an extraordinary global reception, placing in the top five of the New York Times\u2019 bestseller list for 10 weeks. Its success reflects a broader appetite around the world for science told with passion and conviction, outside of high school textbooks.<br /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/may/05/the-great-climate-silence-we-are-on-the-edge-of-the-abyss-but-we-ignore-it\">The great climate silence: we are on the edge of the abyss but we ignore it | Clive Hamilton</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Tyson stresses, though, that if you\u2019re not in a hurry you really shouldn\u2019t buy it.<br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>\u201cIf you\u2019ve found time to read other books on astrophysics, you\u2019re not in a hurry,\u201d he says. \u201cPut this book down and read the other stuff. I\u2019m very serious about this: don\u2019t buy the book if you\u2019re not in a hurry.\u201d <br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>The book is not quite astrophysics for dummies; while it is simplified, it is not simple. It is more a collection of the best and most thrilling moments; astrophysics\u2019 greatest hits.<br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s astrophysics handpicked for the most mind-blowing things that exist in the universe,\u201d Tyson says.<br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>It is also the first time Tyson has recorded an audiobook; those in a hurry, after all, don\u2019t always have time to sit down and read. One particular benefit of this, he says, is to make the book available for those stuck in traffic in Los Angeles \u2013 and also for those stuck in traffic in Australia, a situation he nevertheless finds highly improbable.<strong> </strong></p> <p>\u201cWhy there is traffic in Australia, I have no idea,\u201d he says. \u201cHardly anybody lives here. I don\u2019t know what the hell\u2019s wrong, y\u2019all got to figure that one out.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"afa1742a2c7aab13ccf80b3259ce925c97cc4352\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/afa1742a2c7aab13ccf80b3259ce925c97cc4352/0_120_1800_1080/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Tyson, right, speaking at an event in Spain last year\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Tyson, right, speaking at an event in Spain last year.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Ramon de la Rocha/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>\u201cWithin a 30km radius of where I live are more people than the country of Australia. And you guys have traffic. Maybe it\u2019s just an inescapable law of the universe.\u201d<br /></p> <p>Tyson\u2019s mission as a science educator is not without obstacles. In Australia and around the world, the denial of scientific truth is very real, sometimes at the very highest levels of government. But how do you fight and challenge these kind of ideas? Tyson has a different view to some: the focus shouldn\u2019t be on the politicians, he says, but on the people themselves.</p> <p>\u201cI don\u2019t concern myself much with politicians,\u201d he says. \u201cIn an elected democracy, they represent an electorate. So if an electorate votes for somebody who denies what science is and how it works, then the issue is not with the politician but with the electorate.<br /></p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--thumbnail\" data-media-id=\"e71d26cf8ef5d4a2e3d00f88b7c410a879962a0c\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/e71d26cf8ef5d4a2e3d00f88b7c410a879962a0c/0_0_198_321/198.jpg\" alt=\"Cover image for Neil deGrasse Tyson\u2019s book Astrophysics for People in a Hurry\" width=\"198\" height=\"321\" class=\"gu-image\" /> </figure>  <p>\u201cI\u2019m an educator and I feel a certain duty to educate the public so that, when they vote, their vote can be as informed as it possibly can, with whatever political leanings they might have. That\u2019s what makes the richness of a diverse political system.\u201d<br /></p> <p>While the descriptions of black holes and anti-matter Tyson sets out in his book can sometimes sound like science fiction, he stresses that many of the ideas in the genre reflect the science of the real world.<br /></p> <p>\u201cI don\u2019t turn to sci-fi in the way most people do,\u201d he says. \u201cMost people do it to escape. For me, just [by] doing my job I\u2019m escaping. The universe itself is a form of escapism.<br /></p> <p>\u201cWarped space, black holes, wormholes: all of this comes from us.\u201d<br /></p> <p>The near future of astrophysics promises to be particularly exciting: like science, it is driven by data, and for astrophysics that often involves space missions to gather information from the distant cosmos. </p> <p>Tyson says that the understanding of dark matter may be one of the key developments over the next 10 years. And there is, of course, the possibility of finding life on another planet.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jul/14/the-cynical-and-dishonest-denial-of-climate-change-has-to-end-its-time-for-leadership\">The cynical and dishonest denial of climate change has to end: it's time for leadership | Gerry Hueston</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Could the world handle that? <br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>\u201cIf you had some philosophy that precluded life from existing elsewhere and then we find it, you\u2019re probably not going to say, OK, we\u2019re wrong, everything we taught is wrong, everything we preach is wrong, let\u2019s close up shop,\u201d Tyson says.<br /></p> <p>\u201cWhat is more likely is that it will simply be absorbed into our understanding of the universe.\u201d<br /></p> <p>He recalls the aphorism that every great truth passes through three phases: \u201cFirst, they say it\u2019s not true. Second, they say it conflicts with the Bible. Third, they say they\u2019ve known it all along.\u201d</p> <p>\u2022 <a href=\"https://www.thinkinc.org.au/events/tysonau2017/\"><em>N</em><em>eil deGrasse Tyson: </em><em>A Cosmic Perspective is on in Perth on 22 July, Brisbane on 23 July and Sydney on 29 July</em></a></p>",

          "body": "<p>In one respect, of course, Jos\u00e9 Mourinho is right. Modern football is for ever trying to read too much into too little. One bad week \u2013 three poor results \u2013 is nothing compared to his previous career. Manchester United supporters, perhaps, will welcome his belligerence in attacking the \u201c<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/sep/22/jose-mourinho-hits-out-at-football-einsteins-for-trying-to-undermine-him-manchester-united\" title=\"\">football Einsteins</a>\u201d who have \u201ctried to delete 16 years of my career\u201d. After a start to the season in which he has at times seemed slightly cowed, Mourinho has shown that there is fight left in him.</p> <p>Others will wonder, though, whether an edgy <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/sep/21/northampton-town-manchester-united-efl-cup-match-report\" title=\"\">3-1 victory in the EFL Cup against a third-tier side</a> is really the platform on which to be mounting such a ferocious defence of his position. What does that say about how hurt he has been by the criticism of the past week? What does it say about the self\u2011confidence that was once his trademark and one of his key attributes?</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/sep/22/jose-mourinho-hits-out-at-football-einsteins-for-trying-to-undermine-him-manchester-united\">Jos\u00e9 Mourinho hits out at \u2018football Einsteins\u2019 for trying to undermine him</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The Einsteins line is intriguing. Even said sarcastically, it is a strange insult to choose. Five years ago when he was managing Real Madrid, Mourinho approvingly cited Einstein before the first leg of their Champions League semi-final against Barcelona. \u201cOne day he [Einstein] said that the only mechanical force more powerful than steam, electricity and atomic energy is will,\u201d Mourinho said. \u201cThat Albert guy was not stupid. With will you can achieve things.\u201d</p> <p>Was he, in this case, using Einstein as a synonym for \u201cgenius\u201d? Or was it more specific than that? Is he following the more general trend of rejecting experts? Was he attacking some sort of distant boffin he imagines slaving in a lab to come up with theories to attack him? Sharp as John Giles and Christophe Dugarry may be as pundits, Einstein isn\u2019t the first word that comes to mind to describe them. It was the final line of the answer that perhaps gave the truest insight. \u201cThe new football,\u201d Mourinho said, \u201cit\u2019s full of Einsteins.\u201d The new football? What\u2019s that? When did it begin?</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/audio/2016/sep/22/football-weekly-extra-chelsea-arsenal-wenger-efl-cup-valencia-woe\">Chelsea v Arsenal, EFL Cup thrills and Valencia's woes \u2013 Football Weekly Extra</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Precisely what he meant is perhaps less significant than what the line implied. It was an acknowledgement of age, of the fact that there was an old football before that he, by implication, preferred, a time before Einsteins. He is not the swaggering young gunslinger radiating vigour and upsetting the established order any more. And that, really, is the problem with the reference to his 16-year career, as Mourinho must know. After all, nobody could really call Ars\u00e8ne Wenger \u201c<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/feb/14/jose-mourinho-arsene-wenger-specialist-failure\" title=\"\">a specialist in failure</a>\u201d if they took the entirety of his career into account. The jibe stung because of the clear drop-off in Wenger\u2019s results over the past decade. But Mourinho, too, has seen a decline; it\u2019s not as obvious as Wenger\u2019s and he may offer circumstances in mitigation, but it is there.</p> <p>Between 2002-03 and 2009-10, Mourinho won seven league titles and two Champions Leagues; in the six seasons since he has won two league titles and no Champions Leagues.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/sep/21/efl-cup-fourth-round-draw-manchester-united-manchester-city\">EFL Cup draw: Manchester United face Manchester City, Liverpool host Spurs</a> </p> </aside>  <p>It is not particularly surprising. Sir Alex Ferguson and Valeriy Lobanovskyi are obvious exceptions who skew the perception, but very few managers have success at the very highest level for more than a decade. It is a difficult, tiring job that requires constant re-evaluation and evolution. The will becomes diminished. It is far too early to suggest that Mourinho is finished at the top, but the doubts are growing.</p> <p>In a world in which pressing, at the top end of club football at least, has become the dominant mode, Mourinho\u2019s preference for reactive football in big games is an outlier. It is too simple to say the game has moved on, but equally he can no longer be said to be at the cutting edge. That contributes to a general crisis of image and that impinges on his capacity to mould others to his will.</p> <p>We\u2019ve got used to him. His attacks on rivals, directors, referees and the authorities once provoked shock; now his every utterance is filtered through the recognition that he likes to play games. That is confusing because there have been times recently when he clearly has lost control of himself only for his outbursts of emotion to be treated as part of some strategy of manipulation. Either way, the impact of his public statements has been diminished; Mourinho no longer commands the narrative as he once did.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"5f801e799fee0a4473b1cf1d5ecd7ca57671c209\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5f801e799fee0a4473b1cf1d5ecd7ca57671c209/722_182_1598_959/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Jose Mourinho\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018Mourinho is not the swaggering young gunslinger radiating vigour and upsetting the established order any more.\u2019</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Matt West/BPI/Rex/Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>At the same time, a case can be made that he no longer commands players as he once\u00a0did. Talk to those who played for him at Porto and it\u2019s like talking to members of a cult: they still regard him as a quasi-messianic figure. His reigns at Chelsea and Real Madrid, though, ended in rancour and there have already been rumblings at United.</p> <p>His greatest results have come when leading outsiders, players with points to prove, galvanising them behind a cause. It is harder to do that, perhaps, when you are in charge of the richest club in the country. And harder to do that with modern players, who for Mourinho are arguably a bigger problem in new football than the Einsteins.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/sep/20/manchester-united-jose-mourinho-losses-mount\">Scrutiny grows on Manchester United\u2019s Jos\u00e9 Mourinho as losses mount up</a> </p> </aside>  <p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/aug/09/manchester-united-sign-paul-pogba-93-million-juventus\" title=\"\">Paul Pogba arrived at United</a> and announced he wanted to win the Ballon d\u2019Or. It is one player and one interview but the focus on the individual prize did seem to exemplify a growing mentality.</p> <p>At some point super-clubs become interchangeable, historic identities eroded behind a quasi-franchise model founded on growing the brand across the globe, and when that is the case there is no reason for a talented player to care which helped him to his ultimate goal, particularly if that is the Ballon d\u2019Or rather than the Champions League. And if a player feels no great emotional commitment to a club, if he does not buy into their cause, for how long will he put up with the abrasive managerial style of\u00a0a\u00a0Mourinho?</p> <p>That, more than anything else, is what makes <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/sep/20/manchester-united-jose-mourinho-criticism-luke-shaw-efl-cup-northampton\" title=\"\">Mourinho\u2019s public criticism of players</a> \u2013 three times in his past six league matches, stretching back to his final game in charge of Chelsea \u2013 such a concern. Where once he was a master at drawing attention to himself, of deflecting blame away from players, he now seems regularly to offer their failings as an excuse, and that at a time when players have never been less willing to accept negativity.</p> <p>The world has changed and Mourinho has perhaps not changed with it. He remains, of course, a formidable coach. The situation at United is far from irredeemable, but Pep Guardiola\u2019s instant impact at Manchester City only serves to highlight the growing questions about a coach who <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2012/jan/23/mourinho-real-madrid-sid-lowe\" title=\"\">has always seemed damaged by what happened in Madrid</a>, who perhaps has not quite adapted to the fact he is not the bright young iconoclast any more.</p>",
          "headline": "Manchester United\u2019s Jos\u00e9 Mourinho: no longer the bright young iconoclast"

        "webTitle": "Manchester United\u2019s Jos\u00e9 Mourinho: no longer the bright young iconoclast | Jonathan Wilson",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/commentisfree/2015/dec/07/einstein-universe-gravitational-waves-theory-relativity",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>History may judge 2015 as the year when mankind opened up a completely new window on the universe, exactly a century after <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/alberteinstein\">Albert Einstein</a> laid the scientific foundations for it. The excitement concerns the possibility of detecting one of nature\u2019s most elusive phenomena \u2013 <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2015/feb/12/the-hunt-for-gravitational-waves-could-be-nearing-success\">gravitational waves</a> \u2013 which could pave the way for a much better understanding of <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/black-holes\">black holes</a>, neutron stars and other violent astronomical systems.</p> <p>Several new projects have been launched in the past few months to make gravitational waves the Next Big Thing in astronomy. Rumours have it that one of these \u2013 the US\u2019s Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (Advanced Ligo) \u2013 already \u201cdetected something\u201d in September, but the scientists involved remain tight-lipped. Time will tell.</p> <p>The search for gravitational waves goes back to the dark days of the first world war. In 1915, as Europe was engulfed in carnage, science took a great leap forward. In a series of four lectures delivered at the Prussian Academy of Sciences in Berlin in November and December, Einstein presented a new theory of gravitation, replacing that of Isaac Newton, which had endured for two and half centuries.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/dec/01/lisa-pathfinder-set-to-launch-paving-way-for-discovery-of-gravitys-secrets\">LISA Pathfinder set to launch, paving way for discovery of gravity's secrets</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Called the <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/life-and-physics/2015/jun/23/the-genesis-and-renaissance-of-general-relativity\">general theory of relativity</a>, it has been described as one of the greatest intellectual achievements in history. What makes general relativity distinctive is that it treats gravitation not as a force between bodies such as the sun and the Earth, but as a warping or distortion in the geometry of space and time. This huge conceptual reorientation, plus the sheer mathematical beauty of the theory, ensured that general relativity acquired both a mystique and a fearsome reputation for impenetrability that made Einstein a byword for genius.</p> <p>But however elegant a scientific theory may be, it is worthless if it cannot predict something new. Einstein did indeed make some predictions, but the distinctive effects he described were truly tiny. One of them is created by the spacewarp near the sun. A star beam passing close to the solar surface will be slightly bent as it traces a path through the curved geometry there. An observer on Earth will see an extremely slight displacement in the position of the star when the sun passes near it in the sky.</p> <p>The so-called \u201cbending of light effect\u201d was tested by the English astronomer Arthur Eddington in 1919 during a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_May_29,_1919\">solar eclipse</a>, when the sun\u2019s glare was blotted out, enabling nearby stars to be seen. Eddington\u2019s delicate measurements triumphantly agreed with the predictions of general relativity. It was this experiment more than any other that, almost overnight, transformed Einstein into an international celebrity.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>Interferometers need to spot changes equivalent to the width of a human hair in the distance to the nearest star</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>General relativity is based on a system of equations notoriously hard to solve, but shortly after Einstein set out his new theory he produced a particular solution to his equations describing an unusual form of waves that travel across space at the speed of light. Unlike light, however \u2013 or any electromagnetic radiation \u2013 gravitational waves are literally ripples in the fabric of space-time itself.</p> <p>What does this enigmatic description mean? In operational terms it is easy to visualise. Because gravitation is a warping of geometry, when a gravitational wave crosses a region of space it stretches distances in one direction and shrinks them in a perpendicular direction, in an oscillating fashion. If such a wave passes through matter \u2013 for example, the Earth \u2013 it should squash and stretch it periodically, and so set the planet vibrating. Easy to spot, surely?</p> <p>The trouble is that, once again, the predicted effects are unbelievably small. The basic reason for this feebleness can be traced back to the sheer weakness of gravitation: electricity is a thousand trillion trillion trillion times stronger, which is why electromagnetic waves are commonplace, but gravitational waves were sidelined for decades as a mere curiosity. But in the 1960s a handful of physicists began to wonder whether they could actually be detected in the laboratory. In principle this is very simple: just look for otherwise unexplained tremors in a chunk of matter. In practice it\u2019s not so easy, because the world is filled with noise and vibration.</p> <p>After experimenting for some years, researchers settled on lasers as the best way to go. By reflecting a laser beam off a mirror, any slight changes in the distance to the mirror caused by the passage of a gravitational wave should show up in the quality of the light. The arrangement is known as an interferometer. The US has two 4km-sized laser interferometer gravitational observatories and Europe has one, <a href=\"http://www.ego-gw.it/public/about/whatIs.aspx\">Virgo, located near Pisa</a>.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2015/feb/12/the-hunt-for-gravitational-waves-could-be-nearing-success\">The hunt for gravitational waves could be nearing success</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Both Ligo and Virgo operated successfully for several years, but no gravitational waves were detected: not really surprising, given the vibrations being sought are smaller than the size of an atomic nucleus over several kilometres. A striking comparison is that the interferometers need to spot changes equivalent to the width of a human hair in the distance to the nearest star. How likely is it to succeed, and for the substance of those September rumours to be confirmed? If a supernova occurred in our galaxy tomorrow, Advanced Ligo would detect it as a short but intense burst of gravitational waves. But such events are rare and one may not occur this century.</p> <p>Alternatively, one could observe a pair of neutron stars or black holes \u2013 both massive but highly compact objects \u2013 in close orbit. As the stars cavort around each other at high speed, they serve as a prolific source of gravitational waves, draining the system of energy. This causes the stars to go into a death spiral, ending in a titanic collision and creating a single black hole. Ligo and Virgo aspire to routinely detect such events far beyond the confines of our own galaxy, the Milky Way, in order to study the fine details of the objects\u2019 violent demise and turbulent aftermath.</p> <p>The main motivation for gravitational wave detectors, however, is not to test Einstein\u2019s theory one more time, welcome though that would be. Conventional telescopes detect light or radio waves, and satellites have extended the range across the entire electromagnetic spectrum; gravitational observatories, however, would probe an entirely new spectrum, enabling the study of astronomical phenomena, such as neutron star coalescence, that are inaccessible in any other way. And because gravitational waves are so penetrating, they could enable us to peer into regions of space obscured from normal view by gas and dust, such as the environment around <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/feb/27/supermassive-black-hole-rotate-speed-light\">supermassive black holes</a>.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/dec/08/einstein-inspired-by-james-clerk-maxwell\">Einstein inspired by James Clerk Maxwell | Letters</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Ground-based interferometers are not the only way to study gravitational waves. Ambitious plans are afoot to put an interferometer into space to detect very long waves from much larger astronomical systems such as supermassive black holes. A first step towards <a href=\"http://lisa.nasa.gov/\">Lisa (Laser Interferometer Space Antenna)</a> was taken with <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/dec/01/lisa-pathfinder-set-to-launch-paving-way-for-discovery-of-gravitys-secrets\">last week\u2019s launch</a> of a satellite to test key aspects of the technology.</p> <p>As always in science, there is potential for a prize as yet unknown. For history has shown that every time the universe is studied with a new type of instrument, unexpected discoveries are made. Gravitational waves are created by any massive rapidly moving objects, from stars and black holes to the big bang itself. With Advanced Ligo up and running, and Advanced Virgo about to launch, it would be highly fitting if the first definitive detection of gravitational waves were to coincide with the centenary of general relativity. The universe is sure to spring surprises: this could yet prove to be Einstein\u2019s greatest gift.</p>",

          "body": "<p>The grim reaper comes for everyone in the end, but sometimes he is in less of a rush. This was certainly true for <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/02/oldest-human-dies-in-indonesia-aged-146\">Sodimedjo, an Indonesian man who died on Sunday</a>, but whether he was the full 146 years he claimed remains doubtful \u2013 not least because his purported birthdate is 30 years before local birth records began.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/02/oldest-human-dies-in-indonesia-aged-146\">'Oldest human' dies in Indonesia aged 146</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Scientists have their own reasons to be sceptical. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/oct/05/human-lifespan-has-hit-its-natural-limit-research-suggests\">A study</a> published last year pointed to the existence of an upper ceiling on the natural human lifespan.</p> <p>While the average life expectancy has steadily increased since the 19th century, data from the <a href=\"http://www.supercentenarians.org/\">International Database on Longevity</a> showed that the age of the very oldest people on the planet appeared to plateau in the mid-1990s \u2013 at a mere 114.9 years. Since the apparent plateau happened at a time when the reservoir of healthy centenarians was expanding, scientists concluded that an intrinsic <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/apr/17/violet-brown-jamaican-oldest-person-117-emma-morano\">biological limit had been reached</a>: even if you evade accidents and disease, your body will still steadily decline until it passes the point of no return, the data appeared to suggest.</p> <p>Jan Vijg, a geneticist at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York City, who led this research, said: \u201cWe simply provided evidence that humans do indeed have a ceiling that they really cannot go beyond. That\u2019s part of being human.\u201d</p> <p>There will be the occasional outlier \u2013 the French supercentenarian and oldest woman to have lived, Jeanne Calment, was 122 when she died in 1997, but most of us have a shorter intrinsic \u201cshelf life\u201d. The probability of someone living to 146 is infinitesimal, Vijg said. \u201cIf somebody told you that they saw a UFO yesterday but it\u2019s gone now, you\u2019d probably be polite, but you wouldn\u2019t believe it,\u201d said Vijg. \u201cThat\u2019s my reaction with this story.\u201d</p> <p>Before resigning yourself to the knowledge that you will almost certainly expire by the time you reach 115 years, it is worth noting that <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/unsolvedmysteries/story/0,,1155662,00.html\">this ceiling could be moveable in the future</a>.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--supporting\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/sep/28/internal-clock-makes-some-people-age-quicker-and-die-younger-regardless-of-lifestyle\">Internal 'clock' makes some people age faster and die younger \u2013 regardless of lifestyle</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Richard Faragher, professor of biogerontology at the University of Brighton, puts it this way: <strong>\u201c</strong>How long can a human live if you don\u2019t do anything to them? Probably around 120. But there is a separate question, how long do people last if you can do something to them?\u201d</p> <p>Until now, the steady increase in average life expectancy (as distinct from lifespan) has been driven by fewer people smoking, better nutrition and antibiotics. Drugs and surgery for heart disease and cancer have also played a part.</p> <p>However, scientists are only just beginning to explore the possibility of therapies designed to target the process of ageing itself, as well as the illnesses that come with advancing years. This field has recently taken an intriguing twist, as <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/sep/28/internal-clock-makes-some-people-age-quicker-and-die-younger-regardless-of-lifestyle\">evidence has emerged</a> that ageing is not simply the manifestation of environmental wear and tear. Instead, the latest work suggests that ageing is at least partly driven by an internal genetic clock that actively causes our cells and organs to grind to a halt.</p> <p>This raises the intriguing possibility that ageing could be slowed or even reversed, and some <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/dec/15/ageing-process-may-be-reversible-scientists-claim\">animal studies have already claimed to do just this.</a> </p> <p>\u201cI wouldn\u2019t argue that the ceiling is unmoveable,\u201d said Vijg. \u201cBut trying to say what the age limit is, science can\u2019t yet say, it\u2019s predicting the future.\u201d</p>",

          "body": "<p>Marilyn Stafford\u2019s photographs depict a century of change, from shifting dress shapes to the impact of world conflicts. Today they are also proof of the long and varied life of a unique artist.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2017/apr/29/the-chic-and-the-shabby-paris-in-the-1950s-by-marilyn-stafford\">The chic and the shabby: Paris in the 1950s by Marilyn Stafford</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Stafford, 91, who lives in Sussex, was born in Ohio in 1925 and launched her career with a 1948 amateur portrait of Albert Einstein, before going on to work alongside the famed photographers <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/dec/23/henri-cartier-bresson-the-decisive-moment-reissued-photography\" title=\"\">Henri Cartier-Bresson</a> and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2012/may/13/robert-capa-gerda-taro-relationship\" title=\"\">Robert Capa</a>. Many of the photographs highlight the poverty in 1950s Paris, where Stafford was living with her first husband, a British foreign correspondent. In the poor quarters of Bastille and Boulogne-Billancourt, Stafford found street children living around the notorious slums of Cit\u00e9 Lesage-Bullourde, now the site of the Paris Opera Bastille.</p> <p>Other photographs in the show follow the development of Stafford\u2019s photo-documentary approach to fashion shoots. She took the models out on to the boulevards and squares. \u201cFashion photography was a double-edged thing,\u201d she said. \u201cOn the one hand it was marvellous, all the beauty of the designs and the fabrics was delightful. But the business end of it had its dicey side.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"a87e7f62547d18a08fd9503f6abc0cb6bbd105d2\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/a87e7f62547d18a08fd9503f6abc0cb6bbd105d2/15_62_525_315/500.jpg\" alt=\"Marilyn Stafford in borrowed mink coat during a 1950s fashion shoot in Paris.\" width=\"500\" height=\"300\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Marilyn Stafford in borrowed mink coat during a 1950s fashion shoot in Paris.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Gene Fenn</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Stafford\u2019s first front-page picture was taken for the <em>Observer </em>from North Africa in 1958, showing fleeing Algerian refugees. \u201cI was very involved with the <em>Observer</em>.
