I believe that documentary work should raise social issues, and was very happy when other photographers and journalists were commissioned to go out and record the situation.\u201d</p> <p>Growing up during the Depression in America, Stafford was aware, she said, not just of the poverty of hungry migrants from the Dust Bowl, but also of those fleeing Germany to safety before the second world war.</p> <p>\u201cI congratulate myself for surviving so long, but I have never put myself in positions of real danger. I was very friendly with Bob Capa, and once he suggested that I go to work with Chim, the working name of another Magnum photographer, David Seymour, as an assistant. But I knew he was a war correspondent, so I said I would not go. And, of course, both of them were killed covering conflicts.\u201d</p> <p>Stafford has launched <a href=\"http://fotodocument.org/fotoreportage-award/\" title=\"\">an award in her name for young female photographers</a>. \u201cThe object is to give women a little bit of money towards building up a photo essay that addresses important issues. I am doing it in conjunction with the arts organisation FotoDocument [submissions by 26 May],\u201d Stafford said. \u201cLife has been good to me, so I felt I should try to give something back. When I started out it was very hard for a woman in Fleet Street, and I am sure, although it has improved, that that is still true.\u201d</p>",

          "body": "<p>It\u2019s a total fluke. No one was thinking about making the most precise test yet of general relativity when the Soyuz rocket lifted off from French Guiana on 22 August 2014. The European Space Agency was launching Galileo 5 and 6, a pair of navigation satellites to break Europe\u2019s reliance on the American GPS system.</p> <p>At first everything appeared to be going well. The rocket cleared the launch pad and sped away from the surrounding rain forest on its way to space. But trouble was brewing inside the rocket\u2019s upper stage, the final motor that would put the satellites into their operational orbit.</p> <p>A pipe containing frigid liquid helium had been placed <a href=\"http://esamultimedia.esa.int/docs/galileo/Galileo_Sav_flyer_j15_low-res.pdf\">too close to a fuel line</a>. The fuel froze, stopping the upper stage from manoeuvring correctly and placing the brace of satellites in the wrong orbit.<br /></p> <p>Instead of a circular path, they followed elliptical orbits from 13,713 km up to 25,900 km and back down again. Using onboard thrusters, the satellites were manoeuvred into somewhat less elliptical orbits and a team of specialists is now studying whether this will allow them to be used for their intended navigation purposes. Even if not, the satellites are far from a complete write-off.<br /></p> <p>They continue to orbit Earth twice every day, changing their altitude by 8500 km on each circulation. As luck would have it, this makes them perfect for a world leading test of Einstein\u2019s general theory of relativity.<br /></p> <p>Devised 100 years ago this month, general relativity is a theory of gravity. One of its mind-bending predictions is that time will pass more slowly in a gravitational field. In other words, clocks on Earth \u2018tick\u2019 more slowly than clocks in space.<br /></p> <p>This was demonstrated on 18 June 1976 by the American space probe <a href=\"http://funphysics.jpl.nasa.gov/technical/grp/grav-probea.html\">Gravity Probe-A</a>, which was lobbed to an altitude of 10,000 km before it fell back to Earth. Although in space for just under two hours, its transmissions showed that the highly accurate clock on board had sped up.<br /></p> <p>Now, such clocks are routinely used on global navigation satellites because their signals have to be corrected for these effects. They speed up by a few tenths of a microsecond every day. If not taken into account, this would <a href=\"http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Navigation/Galileo_satellites_set_for_year-long_Einstein_experiment\">cause navigation errors of around 10 km per day</a>.<br /></p> <p>The remaining elliptical orbits of Galileo 5 and 6 mean that their onboard clocks will continuously sweep through weakening and strengthening parts of Earth\u2019s gravitational field as they orbit to and fro. This will continuously affect the rates of the clocks in a way that can be predicted by theory and measured from the satellites\u2019 signals.</p> <p>At the end of the year-long experiment, scientists from the <a href=\"https://www.zarm.uni-bremen.de/\">ZARM Center of Applied Space Technology and Microgravity</a>, Germany, and <a href=\"https://syrte.obspm.fr/spip/\">SYRTE Syst\u00e8mes de R\u00e9f\u00e9rence Temps-Espace</a>, France, expect to have measured this time dilation to four times the accuracy of previous experiments.</p> <p>Continually testing Einstein\u2019s predictions is the key to making progress in gravitational physics. There is reason to believe that gravity behaves subtly differently in extremely strong gravitational fields such as those found close to black holes. If so, minuscule variations from relativity\u2019s predictions could be seen in the wider universe. So, physicists are always on the look out for a new way to test Einstein\u2019s ideas.<br /></p> <p>Scientists often talk about serendipity when accidentally discovering new phenomena that they were not actually looking for. This story shows that the same can happen with spacecraft operations.<br /></p> <p>And in the centenary year of the general relativity\u2019s formulation, think of it as an anniversary present.<br /></p> <p><a href=\"http://www.stuartclark.com\">Stuart Clark</a><em> is the author of </em><a href=\"http://www.amazon.co.uk/The-Unknown-Universe-About-Chapters/dp/1781855749/ref=tmm_hrd_title_0\">The Unknown Universe</a><em> (Head of Zeus), and co-host of the podcast </em><a href=\"https://soundcloud.com/user-388589543/the-stuniverse-podcast-episode?utm_source=soundcloud&amp;utm_campaign=share&amp;utm_medium=facebook\">The Stuniverse</a><em> (</em><a href=\"http://www.bingofilms.co.uk\">Bingo Productions</a><em>). He is teaching the </em><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/guardian-masterclasses/2015/jul/21/back-to-school-how-the-universe-works-with-dr-stuart-clark-masterclass\">Guardian Masterclass, How the Universe Works</a><em> in December.</em></p>",

        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>Every few weeks, I\u2019ll get an angry email or tweet about a terrible, stupid thing I supposedly said. The irritated person will point to <a href=\"https://thewaterpipe.files.wordpress.com/2013/12/j-valenti.jpg\">a stern-looking photo </a>of me paired with this quote: \u201cThe patriarchy is using equality to oppress women. Now we need a new wave of feminism to be more equal than men.\u201d I have no problem admitting this is an absurd statement, mostly because I never wrote or said it.</p> <p>Despite the line being entirely fabricated, it\u2019s been shared and attributed to me countless times over the years, most recently in an article published by a well-known conservative magazine. Then, I was able to get a correction; otherwise I\u2019ve had to accept that this stupid thing I never said will live on with my name attached to it in perpetuity. Thanks, internet!</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/14/insults-rape-threats-writers-online-harassment\">Insults and rape threats. Writers shouldn\u2019t have to deal with this | Jessica Valenti</a> </p> </aside>  <p>While we\u2019ve come to accept the existence of online hoaxes or fake memes as inevitable, what we haven\u2019t sorted out is our collective responsibility to the truth. Do we pause before sharing something if we\u2019re not certain of its true origin? Should there be consequences for <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/feb/21/lord-mcalpine-twitter-defamation-cases\">tweeting or sharing something false?</a></p> <p>Part of what\u2019s difficult is that <a href=\"http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2011/05/anatomy-of-a-fake-quotation/238257/\">fake or incorrect quotes</a> come in a seemingly infinite variety of wrongness. Sometimes the words are real, but the source isn\u2019t. Donald Trump, for example, was fond of tweeting out this quote, attributing it to Albert Einstein: \u201cYou have to learn the rules of the game. And then you have to play better than anyone else.\u201d The person who actually said this was Senator Dianne Feinstein, in <a href=\"https://www.buzzfeed.com/andrewkaczynski/donald-trump-has-tweeted-a-lot-of-fake-albert-einstein-quota#.nrBVOBABW\">a 1985 Cosmopolitan article</a>.</p> <p>At other times the quote and source are correct, but the context is all wrong. Fashion website Verily Magazine <a href=\"https://twitter.com/verilymag/status/722795195364990976\">tweeted out an image</a> this week of a thin white model with long, red hair posing in a candlelit tent on the beach. The quote alongside reads: \u201cMy wish for you is that you feel no need to constrict yourself to make others comfortable.\u201d It\u2019s quite a lovely sentiment, until you realize that the words were <a href=\"http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/07/tanehisi-coates-between-the-world-and-me/397619/\">written by Ta-Nehisi Coates</a>, directed to his son about growing up black in a white supremacist society.</p> <p>Mostly, though, the words are just faked; my guess is that we choose to believe them because they seem to confirm our worst suspicions about a person. Take <a href=\"http://i.imgur.com/RXQmOgt.jpg\">this disturbing image</a> of Ted Cruz with Josh Duggar, a reality television star who <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2015/06/03/what-to-expect-from-the-fox-news-interview-with-josh-duggars-parents/\">admitted to molesting some of his young siblings</a>. The quote superimposed over the image says: \u201cWhile there may have been an age difference, Josh Duggar\u2019s transgressions are far less an affront to God than what gays do to each other.\u201d Given Cruz\u2019s <a href=\"http://www.advocate.com/election/2015/12/04/listen-ted-cruzs-latest-anti-lgbt-tirade\">long anti-LGBT history,</a> and as inarguably unlikeable as the presidential hopeful is, it\u2019s tempting to believe that he could say such a thing. But of course he <a href=\"http://www.politifact.com/texas/statements/2015/may/28/facebook-posts/made-ted-cruz-quotation-has-texan-comparing-child-/\">never did.</a></p>  <figure class=\"element element-audio\" data-canonical-url=\"https://soundcloud.com/the_guardians_what_would_a_feminist_do/episode-five-trumps-self-defeating-misogyny\"> <iframe width=\"460\" height=\"460\" src=\"https://w.soundcloud.com/player/?visual=true&url=http%3A%2F%2Fapi.soundcloud.com%2Ftracks%2F259373049&show_artwork=true\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure>  <p>I imagine that some of the people who spread fake quotes attributed to me, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/BillColeman106/status/722747303359094784\">like this new one I\u2019ve come across</a>, truly believe that they could be mine. But <a href=\"http://femfreq.tumblr.com/post/134929929680/harassment-through-impersonation-the-creation-of\">just as often</a>, they\u2019re created with the sole purpose of defaming or harassing a person \u2013 banking on the knowledge that once something is online, it\u2019s near-impossible to stop. And that it\u2019s much harder to convince someone that you never said something than to prove that you did.</p> <p>Naturally, mistakes can <a href=\"http://seniorplanet.org/how-the-internet-put-a-powerful-quote-in-meryl-streeps-mouth/\">happen without malice</a>, and the problem isn\u2019t always about the internet. Last year, for example, the US postal service unveiled a stamp dedicated to Maya Angelou that <a href=\"http://factually.gizmodo.com/new-stamp-features-fake-maya-angelou-quote-1696245603\">included a quote she never wrote.</a></p> <p>Short of not sharing anything without a link to its original source, it\u2019s hard to know how to stop the spread of false quotes. And getting too caught up with <a href=\"https://xkcd.com/386/\">the wrongness of people on the internet</a> is a surefire way to never know happiness again.</p> <p>Perhaps if we all paused before retweeting, thought a beat before we shared with confidence, we could at least individually slow the misinformation. As Benjamin Franklin said: \u201cTake time for all things \u2013 great haste makes waste.\u201d At least, I think he said it.</p>",

          "body": "<p>A US banker has been ordered to pay his ex-wife half of the family\u2019s \u00a3140m fortune, after the court of appeal rejected his claim that his \u201cgenius\u201d outshone her contribution to the marriage.</p> <p>Randy Work, 49, a former executive at Texas-based private equity firm Lone Star, had first claimed that his wife of 20 years, Mandy Gray, was entitled to only \u00a35m because she had \u201cunfortunately\u201d failed to stick to the terms of their prenuptial agreement and had had an affair with the couple\u2019s personal physiotherapist. </p> <p>A high court judge rejected Work\u2019s claim that he made an \u201cexceptional contribution\u201d to the marriage and was therefore entitled to more than a 50-50 split of the couple\u2019s assets, which include a \u00a330m mansion in Kensington, west London, complete with swimming pool and fitness centre and an \u00a318m ski lodge in Aspen, Colorado. </p> <p>Ruling on their divorce in 2015 Justice Holman told the businessman that his wealth contribution \u2013 which Work said totalled more than $300m in 10 years \u2013 was not \u201cwholly exceptional\u201d and rejected his claim to be a financial \u201cgenius\u201d. </p> <p>\u201cI personally find that a difficult, and perhaps unhelpful, word in this context,\u201d Holman said. \u201cTo my mind, the word \u2018genius\u2019 tends to be overused and is properly reserved for Leonardo da Vinci, Mozart, Einstein and others like them.\u201d</p> <p>Work, who has spent at least \u00a33m fighting to keep his wife from collecting half of the family fortune, took the case to the court of appeal which on Tuesday unanimously rejected his appeal against Holman\u2019s ruling. \u201cIn our view the husband has failed to demonstrate that Holman J\u2019s decision was wrong,\u201d three court of appeal judges said. </p> <p>London has become known as the divorce capital of the world because British judges tend not to discriminate between breadwinner and homemaker and order equal splits of combined fortunes. However, Work had hoped to convince the court of appeal judges to allow him to join those few men who had been granted more than half of the combined assets in a divorce in recognition of the \u201cwholly exceptional nature\u201d of their success. </p> <p>Sir Martin Sorrell, founder of advertising firm WPP, was awarded 60% of joint assets in his 2005 divorce from Sandra, his wife of 33 years. In 2014, a judge granted the ex-wife of Chris Hohn, the billionaire founder of hedge fund The Children\u2019s Investment Fund, 36% of their $1.5bn fortune. </p> <p>Holman had ruled that although Work was an \u201castute businessman\u201d, Gray was a \u201chighly intelligent\u201d woman who had given up her career to follow her husband to Tokyo, where he made hundreds of millions of pounds exploiting the Japanese financial crisis. </p> <p>\u201cA successful claim to a special contribution requires some exceptional and individual quality in the spouse concerned. Being in the right place at the right time or benefiting from a period of boom is not enough,\u201d Holman said. </p> <p>\u201cIt may one day fall for consideration whether a very highly paid footballer, who is very good at his job but may be no more skilful than past greats, such as Stanley Matthews or Bobby Charlton, makes a special contribution or is merely the lucky beneficiary of the colossal payments now made possible by the sale of television rights.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"490596de21f0f33fadaaf3341a8d4f4b403ba990\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/490596de21f0f33fadaaf3341a8d4f4b403ba990/0_169_2348_2348/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Mandy Gray, who split up with Work in 2013.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Mandy Gray, who split up with Work in 2013.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Nick Ansell/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Holman said Work and Gray, 47, had been \u201ctwo strong and equal partners\u201d and he would not have been able to amass his vast fortune without her contribution. </p> <p>The pair, who are both American and have two teenage children, met in 1992 and married in 1995.         "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/science/2016/feb/14/british-scientists-crucial-role-in-stronomical-breakthrough-gravitational-waves-einstein",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>A long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away, two massive collapsed stars \u2013 known as black holes \u2013 collided. The resulting explosion created ripples in the fabric of spacetime. Known as gravity waves, those ripples reached Earth on 14 September last year, where they were picked up by a pair of detectors known as the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (Ligo).</p> <p>It was an astronomical first. After decades of effort, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/feb/11/gravitational-waves-discovery-hailed-as-breakthrough-of-the-century\" title=\"\">scientists had finally detected gravitational waves</a>, whose existence Albert Einstein had predicted, with some hesitation, in 1915 in his Theory of General Relativity. Not surprisingly, the detection has been hailed as a scientific milestone and made headlines round the world. If nothing else, this was surely the final vindication, a century on, of the great man\u2019s genius.</p> <p>But there is more to the discovery, for this is also a story of remarkable scientific pig-headedness and resolve, one that has much in common with Samuel Johnson\u2019s acerbic view of remarriage being a triumph of hope over experience. Certainly scientists could not be accused of being faint-hearted. For the past 30 years, new gravitational wave detectors were built, but failed to pinpoint any hint of these extra-galactic signals. So scientists and engineers simply returned to the drawing board and refined their instruments \u2013 to try again, only to fail once more.</p> <p>In 1998 I interviewed Professor Jim Hough of Glasgow University\u2019s physics department about his work on the Geo-600 gravitational wave detector, the UK-German collaboration that had just been built outside Hanover. Hough has been hunting gravitational waves since 1970 and at the time was quietly confident that this latest machine would soon hit pay dirt. \u201cWe should spot gravitational waves by 2001,\u201d he confidently told me at the time. It transpires that he was 15 years out.</p> <p>\u201cAt the time, we thought that supernovae \u2013 exploding stars \u2013 would produce gravitational waves that would be fairly easily detectable,\u201d Hough says today. \u201cThen the theorists decided they probably didn\u2019t produce detectable gravitational waves. So we had to make our instruments even more sensitive so that we could pick up waves from more esoteric events, such as collisions of neutron stars or black holes.\u201d</p> <p>This proved to be a distinctly tricky task, however. Gravitational waves may be generated by enormously energetic events but these are also incredibly remote. As a result, a wave\u2019s energy is dissipated to a tiny fraction of its original magnitude by the time it reaches Earth and produces a shift of a only few hundred billion-billionths of a metre in a detector\u2019s instruments.</p> <p>It sounds an improbably tiny measurement to make. In fact, the process is relativity straightforward. A detector has tunnels running along two long arms (on Ligo they stretch for 4km) and an identical beam of light tuned to a single wavelength is shone down each of them. At the end is a mirror that reflects the beams back down the tunnel to a central detector, where they are recombined so that their wavelengths are kept in step. In other words, the beams\u2019 light waves peak together, producing a bright spot.</p> <p>However, if the mirrors\u2019 positions are moved very slightly \u2013 by, for instance, a gravitational wave changing the length of one arm more than the other \u2013 a peak on one beam will coincide with a trough in the other beam and the image will be darkened.</p> <p>The trouble is that gravitational waves are not the only types of vibration that can affect a detector. If a person walks close to one of its mirrors, his or her mass will be sufficient to exert a tiny gravitational influence on it, causing the mirror to shift. In the case of Geo-600, there is the problem of the North Sea. The coast is more than 100km away. Nevertheless, the waves pounding on that distant shore create a clear signal for its delicate instruments. Fortunately that signal is a highly rhythmic one and can be removed from the machine\u2019s output.</p> <p>Far more pernicious is the problem of thermal noise \u2013 the heat of the apparatus itself. This causes mirrors and mountings to vibrate slightly, again creating spurious signals. Dealing with this issue has pushed the ingenuity of gravitational wave scientists to its limits and has involved the development of delicate systems of mirrors and pendulums made from pure silica. This system eliminates most of the thermal vibrations that have bedevilled detectors in the past.</p> <p>The silica set-up developed at Geo-600 uses four platforms suspended from each other in layers like a giant, shiny mobile. This eradicates virtually all vibrations. \u201cIt is the scientific equivalent of the best crystal glassware,\u201d says Hough\u2019s colleague Professor Sheila Rowan.</p> <p>The system was developed with input from a team of scientists from Glasgow, Strathclyde and Birmingham universities and from the Rutherford-Appleton Laboratory near Didcot in Oxfordshire, and was the final component of the sensationally successfully upgrade of Ligo. Scientists at the Ligo labs \u2013 one based at Hanford in the US\u2019s Pacific north-west and the other in Livingston, Louisiana \u2013 had begun hunting for gravitational waves in 2002. The two detectors found nothing and were switched off in 2010. A $200m upgrade involved fitting them with new features that included the silica mirrors that British scientists had helped develop.</p> <p>Within weeks, the machines hit pay dirt. In September last year, both detected gravitational waves that have since been shown to come from two massive black holes colliding 1.3 billion light years from Earth. \u201cWe did it. This was truly a scientific moonshot. We landed on the Moon,\u201d said David Reitze, executive director of Ligo.</p> <p>It should also be noted that, this time, Hough had been remarkably prescient in anticipating the discovery. \u201cWe should see gravitational waves, probably in an American machine fitted with our devices, by around 2015,\u201d he told me in a 2012 interview. And that, of course, is exactly what has occurred.</p> <p>The elation with which this discovery has been greeted is understandable though we should be clear how it came about. The theoretical framework that explains gravitational waves is old: it was outlined by Einstein in 1915 in his Theory of General Relativity. Neither is the basic detection method new: it was in use 20 years ago.</p> <p>What changed the state of the playing field was the involvement of teams of scientists from different disciplines and several nations, including Britain, Germany and the US, who combined their talents to find ways to eliminate all the spurious signals that were blocking detection of gravitational waves. This massive clearing-up exercise involved lots of people: materials scientists, who developed those delicate silica mirrors that removed the thermal vibrations; geologists, who played a key role in the understanding of seismic events that affected detectors; and laser scientists, who created the special stable beams now used in these machines.</p> <p>The commitment, the level of collaboration and the diligence and determination displayed by these hunters of gravitational waves is startling, and a gratifying indication of what can be achieved by big science. For decades, new headaches and problems beset the quest for gravity waves, but, with remarkable singlemindedness, they have been swatted aside.</p> <p>We should record a note of caution, of course, one sounded by astronomer Gerry Gilmore of Cambridge University. \u201cGravitational waves are \u2018classical\u2019 physics that are related to the mere 5% of the universe that is made of ordinary matter,\u201d he points out. \u201cWe still have the nature of reality to discover. So let\u2019s be excited but remain humble. We do indeed know more and more, but it is still all about very little. There is the issue of discovering the make-up of dark matter, for example.\u201d</p> <p>The Ligo result is still a remarkable discovery, of course, but what comes next? There are many answers to this question, it transpires. For a start, it is now clear that astronomers have created a new type of astronomy: gravitational wave observation.</p> <p>Until now, everything we have learned about the universe has been based on studies of electromagnetic radiation \u2013 from infrared to visible light to gamma rays. Gravitational waves are going to give us a new way of looking at the universe. Indeed, they have already thrown up one unexpected finding. That burst of gravitational waves detected by Ligo shows they were produced by a collision of one black hole \u2013 a collapsed star that was 35 times the mass of our sun \u2013 with another that was slightly smaller.</p> <p>\u201cWe were confident about the existence of small black holes a few times the mass of the sun, and about very, very large ones,\u201d says Hough. \u201cBut this confirms the existence of a range of intermediate black holes, about which we had theoretical doubts. Now those have gone. We\u2019re already going places.\u201d</p>",

          "body": "<p>The president-elect can\u2019t spell. This is the least of our Donald Trump problems, but interesting nonetheless. The explanations that come to mind are that he is one of the following: a) careless; b) dyslexic; c) illiterate; or d) showings signs of dementia.</p> <p>Regarding the ominous final suggestion, symptomatic misspelling is a primary test for failing wits. The future Potus will be, at 70, the oldest president to enter the White House. The Brezhnev years beckon.</p> <p>Demographically, Trump is now in red-zone territory for what we prophylactically Latinise as \u201cdementia\u201d. It is now the leading cause of death in the UK. Perhaps it is less of a problem in the US.</p> <p>Many of <a href=\"http://lagosconvo.com/rants/epic-fail-17-times-donald-trump-failed-basic-spelling/\">Trump\u2019s tweets have been wildly misspelled</a>, and he came up with a glorious macaronic on 17 December when he described the Chinese seizure of an unmanned US drone as an <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/dec/17/donald-trump-china-unpresidented-act-us-navy-drone\">\u201cunpresidented act\u201d</a>.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"0f054a77b100fca1636c94d46ef5e5b75ac1a26b\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/0f054a77b100fca1636c94d46ef5e5b75ac1a26b/0_0_621_323/500.png\" alt=\"Trump's misspelled China tweet\" width=\"500\" height=\"260\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Trump\u2019s latest public misspelling.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Twitter</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>This fuses, with James Joycean virtuosity, into a neologistic lexical alloy: first, it has never happened before; second, it won\u2019t happen again after \u201cBarrack\u201d (as Trump misspells it \u2013 has he not read Obama\u2019s birth certificate?) makes way for a real president.</p> <p>Of course, paramount leaders need not be of spelling-bee-ace quality. Gordon Brown, in April 2009, wrote a handwritten, 70-word letter of apology to an aggrieved Nadine Dorries splattered with misspellings, including the addressee\u2019s surname (\u201cDorres\u201d), \u201cpolitcal\u201d, \u201cknowlege\u201d, \u201cembarassment\u201d and \u201cadvizer\u201d. The letter also revealed that Brown has impenetrable handwriting, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/education/mortarboard/2009/may/01/gordon-brown-dyslexia-spelling\">which is often used to cover for dyslexia</a>; the odd guessed-at-but-wrong spelling can be tactically camouflaged. There is a lot of it about. Between 5% and 10% of the population do this, according to one report.</p> <p>Want to know what it is like being dyslexic? Try spelling dyslexic backwards in five seconds. Personally, I don\u2019t have any difficulty and I have worked out why: I can visualise words in my active and passive vocabulary printed out on a screen \u2013 usually in 25-point Times New Roman. Spelling backwards, right to left, is easy. Some of us, however, don\u2019t have <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/dec/18/pictures-trigger-memories-faster-than-words-neuroscientist\">top-notch visual memory</a>.</p> <p>What has been proved is that there is no correlation between dyslexia and intelligence. In fact, Maryanne Wolf at Tufts University, whose lab investigates it, suggests that there may be an inverse relationship.</p> <p>Wolf\u2019s thesis is borne out by consolatory websites that inform people with dyslexia that they are not alone. F Scott Fitzgerald misspelled his friend\u2019s name as Ernest Hemmingway. Hemingway himself couldn\u2019t spell for nuts. Neither could Einstein. Even Shakespeare signed his name in at least six ways.</p> <p>This is a serious issue. Why don\u2019t we make a serious effort to rid our language of embedded archaeological debris? Spell it like it sounds. Why shouldn\u2019t we write what we say \u2013 \u201cguvment\u201d instead of \u201cgovernment\u201d?</p> <p>It would save time educationally and spare pain (and demotion) to those who, however intensively they are taught, will never spell correctly.</p> <p>I hope to God, for all of our sakes, that Trump is, indeed, dyslexic and not that other, awful D-word.</p>",

          "body": "<h2>Jean-Michel Basquiat</h2> <p>The subway invaded the art gallery in 1980s New York. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/sep/08/race-power-money-the-art-of-jean-michel-basquiat\">Basquiat</a>, who died in 1988 aged 27, crystallised this moment, embodying a new youthful attitude that helped make today\u2019s art what it is. He left behind a legacy of scrawled and slashed paintings that punch themselves into your mind. His angry electric style seems even more relevant now than it did then. </p> <ul> <li>21 September-28 January, <a href=\"https://www.barbican.org.uk/whats-on/2017/event/basquiat-boom-for-real\">Barbican Art Gallery, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Pablo Bronstein</h2> <p>The Argentine artist presents 50 new sketches of buildings from the second half of the 20th century alongside rarely seen historical material to examine \u201cthe long reign of pseudo-Georgian architecture\u201d as a force shaping the British vernacular. </p> <ul> <li>21 September-11 February, <a href=\"https://www.architecture.com/knowledge-and-resources/knowledge-landing-page/pablo-bronstein-at-riba\">RIBA, London</a>. </li> </ul>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--thumbnail\" data-media-id=\"cdfd6f6751177215ef26581acf1727e3cc3ac6a4\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/cdfd6f6751177215ef26581acf1727e3cc3ac6a4/0_0_2042_4329/472.jpg\" alt=\"Fool\u2019s House, 1961\u201362, by Jasper Johns.\" width=\"472\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Fool\u2019s House, 1961\u201362, by Jasper Johns.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Jasper Johns / VAGA, New York / DACS, London 2017</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>Jasper Johns: Something Resembling Truth</h2> <p>Almost every trend in 21st-century art can be traced back to things <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/apr/12/jasper-johns-major-royal-academy-retrospective-us-artist\">Jasper Johns</a> did in the 1950s. American pop art can be dated from the moment he started painting a stars and stripes flag over collaged news stories in 1954. Minimalism starts there too, or maybe his monochrome 1955 version. As for body art, it was seeded by his strange casts of mouths and noses in 1955. It goes on. Like dreams, his creations can be endlessly interpreted without ever truly yielding up their secrets. A single work by Jasper Johns can hit you like a truck with its profundity, so this huge retrospective may be almost unbearable in its intellectual might and poetic power.</p> <ul> <li>23 September-10 December, <a href=\"https://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibition/jasper-johns\">Royal Academy, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Turner prize 2017</h2> <p>Somehow the Turner prize survived the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2000/nov/19/featuresreview.review3\">sensationalist 1990s</a>, and renews itself by finding new purpose. Its maturity is said loud and clear by the inclusion of two artists older than 50 on <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/may/03/turner-prize-shortlist-2017-lubaina-himid\">this year\u2019s list</a>: Lubaina Himid was born in 1954; Hurvin Anderson in 1965. They\u2019ve crashed the barrier imposed back in the days of Young British Art: good for them. Also shortlisted are Andrea B\u00fcttner and Rosalind Nashashibi in what may prove a vintage year. </p> <ul> <li>26 September-7 January, <a href=\"http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/ferens-art-gallery/exhibition/turner-prize-2017\">Ferens Art Gallery, Hull</a>.</li> </ul> <h2>Lego House</h2> <p>Danish architect Bjarke Ingels\u2019 BIG practice has created a brick-shaped fun palace for the world\u2019s favourite toymaker, where visitors can get creative in blue, red, green and yellow \u201cexperience zones\u201d, see what master builders get up to in its gallery, then chill out with a Brickaccino coffee. </p> <ul> <li>28 September, <a href=\"https://www.legohouse.com/en-gb/explore/what-is-lego-house\">Billund, Denmark</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Opera: Passion, Power and Politics</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"9398469624ce5a7109879022f7ec6dfd177ea8c6\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/9398469624ce5a7109879022f7ec6dfd177ea8c6/0_0_2000_1272/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Power play \u2026 Philip Glass\u2019s Einstein on the Beach in Los Angeles, 2013.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"636\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Power play \u2026 Philip Glass\u2019s Einstein on the Beach in Los Angeles, 2013.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Lawrence K Ho/Victoria and Albert Museum</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The roots of opera go back to Renaissance Italy, where fantastic court spectacles designed by the likes of Leonardo da Vinci mixed with melancholy love songs to create a new art of myth and passion. In 1607, Monteverdi\u2019s L\u2019Orfeo gave opera dramatic and musical depth. This exhibition traces the history of an art form that has been uniquely interwtined with the politics of modern Europe, from Verdi\u2019s operas of power and liberation to the controversial impact of Wagner in Germany. Paintings by Degas, Manet and more feature alongside relics in a show that will surely be sumptuous.<br /></p> <ul> <li>30 September-25 February, <a href=\"https://www.vam.ac.uk/exhibitions/opera#intro\">V&amp;A, London</a>. </li> </ul>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--thumbnail\" data-media-id=\"f1bd0011839ea2f032d6f7cf36a60064972e25cc\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/f1bd0011839ea2f032d6f7cf36a60064972e25cc/0_0_4815_6694/719.jpg\" alt=\"Detail from Paradisiacal, 2014 by Waqas Khan.\" width=\"719\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Detail from Paradisiacal, 2014 by Waqas Khan.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Courtesy of Sabrina Amrani Gallery and the artist</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>Waqas Khan </h2> <p>The visionary art of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/feb/25/waqas-khan-sufi-islam-artist-pakistan-interview\">Waqas Khan</a> has the power to lift you into a poetic paradise of shimmering lines in cosmic space. He is a true original, whose big, abstract drawings are as intricate as the structure of a leaf, as alive as water, as absorbing as a book. He lives and works in Lahore and this, his first solo show in a British gallery, is an unprecedented chance to explore his artistic magic in depth.<br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <ul> <li>30 September-28 February, <a href=\"http://manchesterartgallery.org/exhibitions-and-events/exhibition/waqas-khan/\">Manchester Art Gallery</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Reflections: Van Eyck and the Pre-Raphaelites</h2> <p>The early 15th-century Flemish artist Jan van Eyck painted with such eye-fooling and intricate skill he was rumoured to be an alchemist. The Arnolfini Portrait, a painting of an Italian merchant couple standing with strange formality in their bedroom in Bruges while Van Eyck himself is reflected in a convex mirror at the back of the room, is arguably his strangest and most miraculous work of all. This exhibition explores the instant impact it made on British art when it was bought by the National Gallery in 1842.</p> <ul> <li>2 October-2 April, <a href=\"https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/whats-on/exhibitions/reflections-van-eyck-and-the-pre-raphaelites\">National Gallery, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Superflex</h2> <p>Free beer! Well, perhaps not this time, but one of the revolutionary projects created by this Danish art collective was an \u201copen source\u201d beer that subverted capitalism by extending the culture of the internet to the material world. Expect something similarly cheeky and radical when they take over the vast space of the Turbine Hall. Superflex was founded by Danish artists Jakob Fenger, Bj\u00f8rnstjerne Christiansen and Rasmus Nielsen but works with a shifting army of specialists in projects called \u201cTools\u201d, because they are meant to be useful. Ideas will pour freely, even if the beer doesn\u2019t. </p> <ul> <li>3 October-2 April, <a href=\"http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-modern/exhibition/hyundai-commission-superflex\">Tate Modern, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Everything At Once</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"39cc99a12c7a8fed8c62d9d4122e7e4fbfcc4ccf\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/39cc99a12c7a8fed8c62d9d4122e7e4fbfcc4ccf/0_1380_8558_2848/1000.jpg\" alt=\"MIG 29 Soviet Fighter Plane and Clouds, 2005, by Cory Arcangel, on show in Everything At Once.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"333\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">MIG 29 Soviet Fighter Plane and Clouds, 2005, by Cory Arcangel, on show in Everything At Once.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Jack Hems/Courtesy Lisson Gallery</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>This all-star exhibition in the spectacular brutalist architectural setting of the <a href=\"http://180thestrand.com/\">Store Studios</a> is a 50th-anniversary celebration of one of London\u2019s leading commercial galleries. Founded in 1967 in the heyday of the conceptual art movement, the Lisson Gallery has maintained its thoughtful approach with surprising success into the age of pop conceptualism. Participants range from the unpredictable wit of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/jul/07/ryan-gander-make-every-show-like-its-your-last-manchester-review\">Ryan Gander</a> to video pioneer <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/nov/15/susan-hiller-interview-self-doubt-is-always-present\">Susan Hiller</a> and epic walker <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/apr/16/richard-long-earth-sky-houghton-hall-interview\">Richard Long</a>. </p> <ul> <li>5 October-10 December, <a href=\"http://www.lissongallery.com/exhibitions/everything-at-once\">180 The Strand, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Dal\u00ed/Duchamp</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--thumbnail\" data-media-id=\"d82b111ebacdac25af51bf605bb46cf21c0873a7\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/d82b111ebacdac25af51bf605bb46cf21c0873a7/534_0_2895_2592/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Lobster Telephone (red), 1938, by Salvador Dal\u00ed and Edward James.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"895\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Lobster Telephone (red), 1938, by Salvador Dal\u00ed and Edward James.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Edward James Foundation/Fundaci\u00f3 Gala-Salvador Dal\u00ed, DACS 2017</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Two artists who were obsessed with sex team up to create what will surely be autumn\u2019s kinkiest show. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/duchamp\">Marcel Duchamp</a> (1887-1968) and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/dali\">Salvador Dal\u00ed</a> (1904-89) both gloried in perversity. Duchamp said eroticism was the heart of his work and proved it with his final installation, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89tant_donn%C3%A9s\">\u00c9tant donn\u00e9s</a> (\u201cHaving been given\u201d), which allows the visitor to look through a peephole at a pornographic sculpture. As for Dal\u00ed, where to begin? His paintings include <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2014/sep/28/the-10-best-works-of-erotic-art#img-8\">The Great Masturbator</a> (1929), whose title is self-explanatory, and his confessions of depravity even shocked his surrealist comrades. This is a marriage made in art heaven: the genius of Duchamp should shine a light on Dali\u2019s deconstructions of aesthetic beauty, while Dali\u2019s wickedness will free Duchamp from the academic theorists who hold him prisoner. </p> <ul> <li>7 October-3 January, Royal Academy, London.</li> </ul> <h2>Arp: The Poetry of Forms</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"cd1b932e4d37e385d4b3451d5f00a041cb6a8d12\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/cd1b932e4d37e385d4b3451d5f00a041cb6a8d12/1424_897_3775_3774/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Hommage \u00e0 Rodin, 1938, by Jean Arp.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Hommage \u00e0 Rodin, 1938, by Jean Arp.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Ken Adlard/Private Collection, London</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>In the age of Brexit, an exhibition of this sculptor who transcended Europe\u2019s borderlines is a timely reminder of how art can defy national boundaries. Arp (1886-1966) called himself either Hans or Jean depending on whether he was speaking German or French. He came from the disputed region of Alsace-Lorraine, so it was a moot point. In the first world war, he escaped to the neutral polyglot Swiss city of Zurich where he helped found dadaism. His endlessly playful abstract creations are as liberated as the man.</p> <ul> <li>13 October-14 January, <a href=\"https://www.turnercontemporary.org/exhibitions/jean-arp-the-poetry-of-forms\">Turner Contemporary, Margate</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Rebecca Warren: All That Heaven Allows</h2> <p>The imaginative, sensual and hilarious sculpture of Rebecca Warren is one of the joys of modern British art. It\u2019s amazing she has never won the Turner prize (she was shortlisted in 2006). Then again, perhaps an artist whose most celebrated work, Helmut Crumb, combines the styles of two of the most sexist artists going will always strike some people as lacking radical seriousness. Which is a shame because Warren has helped put sculpture \u2013 as opposed to readymade objects \u2013 back into the mainstream of contemporary art. </p> <ul> <li>14 October-7 January, <a href=\"http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-st-ives/exhibition/rebecca-warren\">Tate St Ives</a>.</li> </ul> <h2>Ilya and Emilia Kabakov: Not Everyone Will Be Taken Into the Future</h2> <p>Of all the exhibitions that have marked this year\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/feb/12/revolution-russian-art-1917-1932-review\">centenary of the October Revolution</a>, this is the most exciting. Ilya Kabakov is one of the greatest artists produced by the Soviet Union \u2013 and one of the most subversive. In the 1980s, he left the USSR and started working with his niece Emilia on installations as labyrinthine as a Russian Orthodox church and as rich in their storytelling as a Dostoevksy novel. What is it like to live in utopia? And what happens when it goes wrong? Find out in these poetic reveries on the strange history of the world\u2019s first communist state.<br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <ul> <li>18 October-28 January, <a href=\"http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-modern/exhibition/ilya-and-emilia-kabakov-not-everyone-will-be-taken-future\">Tate Modern, London</a>.</li> </ul> <h2>Soutine\u2019s Portraits</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"7e8c20e6c8fdf8e227f725d6bd258847dd009976\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7e8c20e6c8fdf8e227f725d6bd258847dd009976/0_0_4632_6415/722.jpg\" alt=\"The Young Pastry Maker by Cha\u00efm Soutine.\" width=\"722\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Young Pastry Maker by Cha\u00efm Soutine.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Alamy Stock Photo</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Cha\u00efm Soutine painted with savage expressionism in a Paris dominated by abstract art. Born near Minsk, he arrived in the French capital of modernism in 1913 but instead of embracing cubism or any other art fashions, he painted compassionate, almost childlike portraits of workers in the hotels and kitchens of the art deco age. Soutine went into hiding to escape being captured by the Nazis but became ill on the run and died in 1943. The paintings in this show prove him one of the most humane visionaries of modern art.</p> <ul> <li>19 October-21 January, <a href=\"http://courtauld.ac.uk/gallery/what-on/exhibitions-displays/soutine\">Courtauld Gallery, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Instant Stories: Wim Wenders\u2019 Polaroids</h2> <p>For a long time, film director and photographer <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/wim-wenders\">Wenders</a> took Polaroids as a day-to-day visual notebook and diary. Quick images of passing moments full of intense Polaroid colour, these pictures shot in the 1970s and 80s record what his world looked like in the years when he was working on films such as The American Friend (1977) and Wings of Desire (1987). It is a nostalgic trip into a lost visual world.</p> <ul> <li>20 October-11 February, <a href=\"https://thephotographersgallery.org.uk/whats-on/exhibitions/wim-wenders-instant-stories\">Photographers\u2019 Gallery, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Susan Philipsz</h2> <p>Explorers stranded in the endless emptiness of outer space are the protagonists of the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2010/dec/07/susan-philipsz-turner-prize\">2010 Turner prize winner</a>\u2019s new work, which is based on Karl-Birger Blomdahl\u2019s 1959 science-fiction opera Aniara<em>. </em>The plight of these would-be colonists of Mars is heard on a 12-speaker installation by this artist with a rare ear for the melancholy emotional resonance and sculptural solidity of sound. The exhibition also includes homages to Bowie from her back catalogue and the socialist anthem the Internationale.</p> <ul> <li>20 October-4 March, <a href=\"http://www.balticmill.com/whats-on/exhibitions/susan-philipsz\">Baltic, Gateshead</a>. </li> </ul>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--thumbnail\" data-media-id=\"5d936ad64eb246fc9072ecbdba6f6802cd94edc7\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5d936ad64eb246fc9072ecbdba6f6802cd94edc7/0_0_2630_3300/797.jpg\" alt=\"Madame C\u00e9zanne in a Yellow Chair, 1888/90, by Paul C\u00e9zanne.\" width=\"797\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Madame C\u00e9zanne in a Yellow Chair, 1888/90, by Paul C\u00e9zanne.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: The Art Institute of Chicago</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>C\u00e9zanne Portraits</h2> <p>This exhibition proves that C\u00e9zanne is the true father of modern art. It is astonishing to see how early he was deconstructing the very idea of portraiture in paintings from the 1880s that ask who we really see when we look in the mirror. From early portraits of his friends and family with their tragicomic sense of the human condition to self-portraits unrivalled since those of Rembrandt, there is a staggering intellect and courage to C\u00e9zanne\u2019s depictions of people. </p> <ul> <li>26 October-11 February, <a href=\"http://www.npg.org.uk/whatson/cezanne-portraits/exhibition/\">National Portrait Gallery, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Monochrome</h2> <p>Black and white \u2013 a lot of artists have used it. This exhibition makes connections between the Renaissance and Baroque technique of <em>grisaille</em>, in which scenes were shown in shades of grey to make them look like sculptural reliefs, and modern monchrome art. The 1960s paintings of Bridget Riley, Olafur Eliasson\u2019s installation <a href=\"http://olafureliasson.net/archive/artwork/WEK101676/room-for-one-colour\">Room for One Colour</a> and other cool modern things are juxtaposed with the likes of D\u00fcrer and Rembrandt.</p> <ul> <li>30 October-18 February, <a href=\"https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/whats-on/exhibitions/monochrome-painting-in-black-and-white\">National Gallery, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Impressionists in London</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"ba9ef3832c4efe2c368093bd6f5252d5166b628d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ba9ef3832c4efe2c368093bd6f5252d5166b628d/0_0_1300_843/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The Avenue, Sydenham, 1871, by Camille Pissarro.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"648\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Avenue, Sydenham, 1871, by Camille Pissarro.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: National Gallery, London</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Thank God, the nation\u2019s gallery of British art has found an excuse to show some French art instead. The artists who would first exhibit as impressionists in 1874 fled to London to escape the Franco-Prussian war of 1870-71. While in Britain, they painted views of the city and its suburbs whose vitality and freshness put homegrown Victorian art to shame. To look at <a href=\"https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/camille-pissarro-the-avenue-sydenham\">Pissarro\u2019s The Avenue, Sydenham</a> (1871) is to breathe a fresh air stuffy British art never let in. Monet would return in later years to stay at the Savoy and paint views from his hotel room that are simply the greatest visions of London in art.</p> <ul> <li>2 November-7 May, <a href=\"http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-britain/exhibition/ey-exhibition-impressionists-london\">Tate Britain, London</a>. </li> </ul>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--thumbnail\" data-media-id=\"7a721dcaf36f0fe883040098827dcb7da7035503\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7a721dcaf36f0fe883040098827dcb7da7035503/0_0_2400_2600/923.jpg\" alt=\"One of Them Is a Human #1 by Maija Tammi.\" width=\"923\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">One of Them Is a Human #1 by Maija Tammi, a contender for the Taylor Wessing prize.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Maija Tammi</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>Taylor-Wessing photographic portrait prize</h2> <p>The most sensational <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/sep/05/photo-girl-fleeing-isis-shortlisted-taylor-wessing-portrait-prize-2017\">contender for this year\u2019s prize</a> is Maija Tammi\u2019s disconcertingly soulful portrait of a female android, casting thoughtful shadows on its \u2013 her? \u2013 face so that we seem to encounter a conscious mind. The other shortlisted artists, C\u00e9sar Dezfuli and Abbie Trayler-Smith, show powerful photojournalism. Dezfuli deserves first prize for his commandingly intense <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/sep/05/photo-girl-fleeing-isis-shortlisted-taylor-wessing-portrait-prize-2017\">portrait of migrant Amadou Sumaila</a>. A snapshot of the modern world.<br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <ul> <li>16 November-4 February, <a href=\"http://www.npg.org.uk/whatson/twppp-2017/exhibition/\">National Portrait Gallery, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Surrealism in Egypt</h2> <p>Where could this art of dreams and the unconscious make more sense than in Cairo, where the unreal pyramids loomed over a rich collision of cultures? This exhibition surveys the Art and Liberty group, who explored the radical possibilities of surrealism there in the 1930s and 40s. A little-known chapter of surreal history.<br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <ul> <li>17 November-18 March, <a href=\"http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-liverpool/exhibition/surrealism-egypt-art-et-liberte-1938-1948\">Tate Liverpool</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Gilbert and George: The Beard Pictures and their Fuckosophy</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"c8a1713c8c34f3601280cfe1b320a3fc1155de87\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/c8a1713c8c34f3601280cfe1b320a3fc1155de87/0_0_3543_3164/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Beardout 2016, by Gilbert &amp; George.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"893\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Beardout 2016, by Gilbert &amp; George.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Gilbert &amp; George/Courtesy White Cube</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>This autumn is the 50th anniversary of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/may/19/gilbert-and-george-at-home-east-end-restoring-pictures\">Gilbert and George</a>. They met on 25 September 1967 at St Martin\u2019s College and have been together ever since. They\u2019re celebrating their golden jubilee with exhibitions in London that include this big show of new work. Fashionable as ever, they\u2019ve caught up with the 21st century\u2019s love of beards. And as ever they aim to provoke with their latest \u201cfuckosophy\u201d. Let\u2019s raise a glass to artists who never got bored because they were never being boring.</p> <ul> <li>22 November-28 January, <a href=\"http://whitecube.com/exhibitions/gilbert_and_george_bermondsey_2017/\">White Cube Bermondsey, London</a>. </li> </ul> <h2>Modigliani</h2> <p>Twelve nudes by this doomed romantic hero of modern art should make for a stupendously sensual show. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/jun/26/tate-modern-to-stage-largest-uk-retrospective-of-modiglianis-work\">Modigliani</a> is much more curious figure than his myth might suggest. It\u2019s true that the naked paintings at the heart of this show got him into trouble with the Paris police in 1917. Yet his art is a beautiful blend of the cubist style he encountered in France and the much older Renaissance tradition of the nude he grew up with in his native Italy. That mix of modernity and tradition is what makes him so accessible. Add to that his short, intense life with sex and drugs aplenty, and you have an artist who will always be young. </p> <ul> <li>23 November-2 April, <a href=\"http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-modern/exhibition/modigliani\">Tate Modern, London</a>. </li> </ul>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--thumbnail\" data-media-id=\"0e296eddc42edf407bb3603bc569f8c94523ee36\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/0e296eddc42edf407bb3603bc569f8c94523ee36/0_0_4832_6000/805.jpg\" alt=\"Jack Goes Swimming (Jack), 2013, by Rose Wylie.\" width=\"805\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Jack Goes Swimming (Jack), 2013, by Rose Wylie.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: jY/Courtesy of the artist</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>Rose Wylie </h2> <p>Now that age appears no bar to winning the Turner prize, 82-year-old <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2012/feb/13/rose-wylie-painter\">Rose Wylie</a> may well be on next year\u2019s shortlist. Meanwhile, this prestigious showcasing of her anything but pompous pictures is a milestone in a very long career. Wylie\u2019s paintings are dadaist free-for-alls of cartoonish daubing that look like she painted them in 10 seconds. Has she grown up now she\u2019s entered her 80s? </p> <ul> <li>29 November-4 February, <a href=\"http://www.serpentinegalleries.org/press/2017/07/rose-wylie\">Serpentine Sackler Gallery, London</a>. </li> </ul>",

          "body": "<p>Of all the mysteries in the universe, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2016/feb/01/what-is-a-black-hole-stephen-hawking-reith-lectures\">black holes</a> surely top the list. They have such strong gravitational fields that once an object falls in, it will never be able to escape.</p> <p>What then happens to that object is a total mystery that current physics cannot answer. Our best ideas suggest that in the overwhelming gravity, matter is simply crushed out of existence \u2013 but what does that actually mean? Can it really happen?<br /></p> <p>When you think about it, it all just sounds just a bit too sci-fi-ish. Maybe its even enough to tie your brain in such knots that you spontaneously exclaim \u2018<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/may/31/what-is-covfefe-donald-trump-baffles-twitter-post\">covfefe</a>!\u2019.</p> <p>Black holes were predicted to exist in the early part of the 20th century by Einstein\u2019s general theory of relativity, and were met with wide-spread scepticism from physicists and astronomers. </p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2016/feb/01/what-is-a-black-hole-stephen-hawking-reith-lectures\">What is a black hole?</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Although most now accept that black holes must exist, there is no killer piece of evidence that proves them beyond doubt. This means that some researchers continue to wonder whether something unknown halts the collapse before the gravitational field becomes strong enough to create the black hole.</p> <p>The key characteristic of a black hole is the \u2018event horizon\u2019. This is the invisible boundary that separates it from the rest of the Universe. If a star crosses the event horizon it would simple wink out, like a light being turned off.</p> <p>However, if something halted the formation of the black hole, then there would be a solid surface for the star to strike. In this case, the collision would cause the object to flare up in brightness. </p> <p>Now, astronomers from <a href=\"https://www.utexas.edu/\">University of Texas at Austin</a> and <a href=\"http://www.harvard.edu/\">Harvard University</a>, have worked out that the flare would last for months or years as the smashed star\u2019s gas cooled down. And they\u2019ve been looking for such outbursts.</p> <p>They searched the <a href=\"https://panstarrs.stsci.edu/\">Pan-STARRS</a> archive for signals. This 1.8-metre telescope in Hawaii has recently completed a 3.5-year survey of half the northern sky, specifically looking for things that change brightness.</p> <p>The team looked at the centre of galaxies, where supermassive black holes (or their equivalents) are thought to reside. They calculated that in 3.5 years they should see around 10 flares if the objects were solid rather than black holes.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2013/jul/18/supermassive-black-hole-gas-cloud\">Cosmic gas cloud fights supermassive black hole | Stuart Clark</a> </p> </aside>  <p>They saw no flares at all. This strengthens the case that the objects at the centre of galaxies are indeed black holes that swallow stars whole and not compact, solid objects.</p> <p>Astronomer Ramesh Narayan, one of the <a href=\"https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article-lookup/doi/10.1093/mnras/stx542\">authors of the study</a>, told the <a href=\"http://www.ras.org.uk/news-and-press/2997-do-stars-fall-quietly-into-black-holes-or-crash-into-something-utterly-unknown\">Royal Astronomical Society</a>: \u201cOur work implies that some, and perhaps all, black holes have event horizons and that material really does disappear from the observable universe when pulled into these exotic objects, as we\u2019ve expected for decades.\u201d</p> <p>But don\u2019t put the flags out just yet. Although the work adds to the substantial body of circumstantial evidence for the existence of black holes it yet again stops short of being the smoking gun that absolutely proves their existence. </p> <p>What we would really like to see is the light from a swallowed star disappearing from view. Well, perhaps we did see something like this back in 1992. </p> <p>Nasa astrophysicist Joseph F. Dolan used data from the ultraviolet instrument on the Hubble Space Telescope to keep tabs on the black hole candidate Cygnus X-1, located 6000 light years from Earth.<br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/guardian-masterclasses/2017/mar/24/is-there-life-beyond-earth-masterclass-astronomy-space-planets-science-lecture-course-dr-stuart-clark\">Is there life beyond Earth? A astronomy class with Dr Stuart Clark</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Dolan\u2019s <a href=\"http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1086/322917/pdf\">research</a> identified two ultraviolet signals that each looked like a luminous cloud of gas spiralling towards the black hole before disappearing completely, as would be expected when it crossed the event horizon.</p> <p>These were tantalising observations but frustratingly such signals have not been seen again despite <a href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1104.3164\">other searches</a>. But now, there is renewed hope that proof may be just around the corner.</p> <p>The <a href=\"http://www.eventhorizontelescope.org\">Event Horizon Telescope</a> is currently collecting and analysing data that could show us the event horizon of the black hole thought to sit in the centre of our own galaxy. If it succeeds, then the hard work begins. </p> <p>Scientists will have to fully face up to the Herculean task of explaining what happens inside a black hole. Only by stepping beyond Einstein to a <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2016/feb/01/what-is-a-black-hole-stephen-hawking-reith-lectures\">quantum theory of gravity</a> will they be able to do that.</p> <p><em><a href=\"http://www.stuartclark.com/\">Stuart Clark</a> is the author of <a href=\"http://www.amazon.co.uk/The-Unknown-Universe-About-Chapters/dp/1781855749/ref=tmm_hrd_title_0\">The Unknown Universe</a> (Head of Zeus). He will be delivering the Guardian masterclass on <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/guardian-masterclasses/2017/mar/24/is-there-life-beyond-earth-masterclass-astronomy-space-planets-science-lecture-course-dr-stuart-clark\">Is there life beyond Earth?</a>.</em></p>",

          "body": "<p>We live in an era that has unleashed all manner of odious, racist rhetoric. The bar for what retains the power to shock us is being raised daily. But some comments still cut deep. \u201cCulture and demographics are our destiny. We can\u2019t restore our civilization with somebody else\u2019s babies,\u201d <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/13/steve-king-somebody-elses-babies-iowa-racist\">said the Iowa state representative Steve King</a> over the weekend. It is rare to encounter such blatant bigotry \u2013 even today.<br /></p> <p>\u201cSomebody else\u2019s babies\u201d may be the clearest three-word expression, the most concentrated distillation of racism, that we have heard so far. It so obviously demonstrates the belief that people of some races are not equal to other human beings. Those three words explain so much of what has been happening in this country. </p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/13/steve-king-somebody-elses-babies-iowa-racist\">Steve King defends 'somebody else's babies' remark despite backlash</a> </p> </aside>  <p>King had been tweeting his support for Geert Wilders, a far-right Dutch politician who is <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/15/dutch-pm-mark-rutte-boosted-by-spat-with-turkey-as-election-nears\">being closely watched in the Netherlands elections</a> on Wednesday. Wilders calls Moroccan immigrants \u201cscum\u201d and has proposed banning the Qur\u2019an, taxing hijabs and closing mosques throughout the Netherlands. Bigots embolden other bigots. Donald Trump has done this favor to racists across the globe \u2013 now others are doing the same. </p> <p>During the controversy that greeted his tweet, King denied that his comment was about race but insisted that it was about \u201cwestern civilization\u201d \u2013 a term <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/jul/18/steve-king-white-people-republican-convention\">he\u2019d clarified in July</a>, on an MSNBC panel. Back then, he had questioned the contributions made by any \u201csubgroup\u201d to a culture rooted in \u201cwestern Europe, eastern Europe and the United States of America and every place where the footprint of Christianity settled the world. That\u2019s all of western civilization.\u201d</p> <p>But where would our civilization be without algebra (invented by the Arabs)? Or without Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera, without Albert Einstein, without tacos and baklava, without Toni Morrison and James Baldwin, without Miles Davis, without blues and jazz? Where would our culture be without the countless inventions and innovations that immigrants and people of color have made to every aspect of our daily lives, to our health, our happiness, our welfare? <br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>It\u2019s maddening to have to list the contributions made by our non-white, non-US born communities. But it\u2019s an argument we\u2019ve been obliged to make before. Saul Bellow, among our most respected American novelists, asked, in an interview, \u201cWho is the Tolstoy of the Zulus? The Proust of the Papuans?\u201d and later complained: \u201cWe can\u2019t open our mouths without being denounced as racists, misogynists, supremacists, imperialists or fascists.\u201d</p> <p>But King has shown no interest in clarifying or modifying his statement, as Bellow did. In fact, King took it farther. And it\u2019s those three words \u2013 \u201csomeone else\u2019s babies\u201d \u2013 that appall those of us who might have hoped that public discourse could not possibly get much uglier. No matter how mindlessly King prattles on about western civilization, it\u2019s clear whose babies he considers to be \u201csomeone else\u2019s.\u201d<br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>Let us picture neonatal units in urban hospitals, where babies of every color are sleeping, stretching, being fed, adjusting to this chilly, noisy, bright new world. Is King suggesting that we deport the brown and black babies \u2013 who will do nothing to \u201crestore\u201d our civilization and who will dilute our \u201cpure\u201d gene pool \u2013 and only allow the white infants to develop into productive citizens? <br /></p> <p>I\u2019ve heard people say that they don\u2019t like babies, but most of us agree that we\u2019re moved and entertained by them: by their innocence, their playfulness, their cuteness, their faces and personalities already hinting at the adults they will become. What did these babies do, on their short time on earth, to deserve such enmity, such heartlessness?</p> <p>One of our most basic duties as human beings \u2013 as animals, in fact \u2013 is to protect our young, to nurture and help them survive. But Steve King (and his supporters) seem not to understand this; to him, the only babies we should welcome into this world are those who look like us, whose skin is white.</p> <p>This is the kind of thinking we find at play in the recent wave of hate crimes. The men behind those attacks could not have believed that their victims had once been babies whose mothers loved them. The teenage girl who videotaped her father being arrested by Ice agents in Los Angeles was someone else\u2019s baby \u2013 in fact, the baby of the dad who was being dragged away. <br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>Conservatives against immigration say we can\u2019t admit everyone who wants to enter our country. What about our national security? they ask. Lost in this debate is the fact that we are talking about human beings. Humans who wouldn\u2019t have left their homes and everything they cared about unless they felt they had to, unless they had no choice but to leave in order to escape poverty and crime. <br /></p> <p>They love their parents and children. Their babies are precious, vulnerable, full of potential. They mourn their dead and are grief-stricken when their loved ones\u2019 tombstones are defaced. <br /></p> <p>In Wild Swans, Jung Chang\u2019s eloquent memoir about the lives of three generations of women in China, she quotes a saying of Confucius: \u201cImagine my heart was yours!\u201d It\u2019s as good a piece of advice as any I\u2019ve heard, and it\u2019s painful to realize that men like Steve King can\u2019t see past the skin color \u2013 of a baby! \u2013 to imagine the heart (like his, like ours) softly beating within. </p>",

          "body": "<p>Rightwing populist party Alternative f\u00fcr Deutschland (AfD) would unpick several postwar safeguards put in place to constrain the power of Germany\u2019s national executive if it took power, the party\u2019s draft manifesto suggests.</p> <p>The campaign programme was presented by the AfD\u2019s co-leaders Frauke Petry and J\u00f6rg Meuthen at a press conference in Berlin.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/feb/27/germany-rightwing-afd-party-struggles-internal-crisis\">Germany's rightwing AfD party struggles to cope with internal crisis</a> </p> </aside>  <p>It demands that Germany should be able to revoke citizenship of \u201ccriminal migrants\u201d who join terror groups or criminal gangs within 10 years of becoming German nationals, even if this renders them stateless \u2013 a move that would not only break with the German constitution but also international law.</p> <p>Denaturalisation was used as an instrument of repression against political enemies, including prominent figures such as Albert Einstein and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/01/totalitarianism-in-age-donald-trump-lessons-from-hannah-arendt-protests\">Hannah Arendt</a>, during the Nazi era and in the GDR.</p> <p>In reaction to these abuses, West Germany <a href=\"https://dejure.org/gesetze/GG/16.html\">banned </a>denaturalisation into statelessness in its <a href=\"https://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/englisch_gg/\">basic law</a> in 1949 and later signed up to a <a href=\"http://www.unhcr.org/protection/statelessness/3bbb286d8/convention-reduction-statelessness.html\">UN resolution</a> on the reduction of statelessness.</p> <p>The AfD\u2019s draft manifesto further pledges to introduce a Swiss system of direct democracy, whereby citizens can propose plebiscites on changes to the constitution, and promises the German people \u201ca vote along the British model on whether Germany should stay in the eurozone and, if need be, the EU\u201d.</p> <p>Such a policy would also require changes to the German constitution, since referendums at national level can currently only be held on the issue of redrawing the borders of the country\u2019s federal states. </p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"e201cc9e24b7a4dc5dc9d4807751b3938fb2b22a\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/e201cc9e24b7a4dc5dc9d4807751b3938fb2b22a/0_290_5418_3251/1000.jpg\" alt=\"J\u00f6rg Meuthen, Petry and AfD deputy spokesman Albrecht Glaser.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">J\u00f6rg Meuthen, Petry and AfD deputy spokesman Albrecht Glaser.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Clemens Bilan/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The German basic law also currently forbids government to call and set the terms of a referendum \u2013 something which would have to change if Germany were to follow \u201cthe British model\u201d.</p> <p>Mechanisms of direct democracy were deliberately limited during the foundation of postwar Germany after Hitler had used a series of referendums in order to shore up power after 1933.</p> <p>The AfD\u2019s draft manifesto states that \u201cthe introduction of the referendums after the Swiss model therefore have to be a non-negotiable part of any coalition negotiations\u201d.<br /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jan/18/afd-politician-says-germany-should-stop-atoning-for-nazi-crimes\">AfD politician says Germany should stop atoning for Nazi crimes</a> </p> </aside>  <p>AfD\u2019s chances of taking part in coalition negotiations after the German federal elections on 24 September are extremely slim since the bigger centrist parties have ruled out coalitions with the populist party.</p> <p>AfD polled at up to 15% last September, but recent surveys put it at below 10% of the national vote. The fall in support has been fuelled by party <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/feb/27/germany-rightwing-afd-party-struggles-internal-crisis\">infighting</a>.</p> <p>AfD\u2019s election platform also adopts a demand for \u201cnegative immigration\u201d \u2013 an idea recently coined by Austria\u2019s Freedom party. </p> <p>It proposes that the number of people allowed to enter Germany would be pegged below the number of people leaving: specifically, the draft suggests 200,000 more people would have to leave the country than arrive.</p> <p>Other AfD policies include a <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/01/german-far-right-party-ban-minarets-burqa-alternative-fur-deutschland\">general ban on headscarves</a>, the scrapping of inheritance tax and the rejection of rent controls.<br /></p>",

          "body": "<p>John McDonnell wrote an article on 26 February announcing that a \u201c<a href=\"http://labourbriefing.squarespace.com/home/2017/2/26/the-soft-coup-is-under-way\" title=\"\">soft coup</a>\u201d is under way against Jeremy Corbyn. This coup, claimed McDonnell, \u201cis being perpetrated by an alliance between elements in the Labour party and the Murdoch media empire, both intent on destroying Jeremy Corbyn and all that he stands for\u201d. But the truth is that not everyone who wants Corbyn out is a Blairite stooge, or in thrall to Rupert Murdoch: the latest ally of the Progress Putsch is <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/mar/07/stephen-hawking-jeremy-corbyn-disastrous-labour-resign\" title=\"\">Stephen Hawking</a>.</p> <p>This, to remind you, is the man who said \u201cI wouldn\u2019t be here today if not for the NHS\u201d, and warned that the NHS \u201cmust be preserved from commercial interests who want to privatise it\u201d. He has also pointed out that inequality is one of the biggest threats to the planet. Sentiments not so far from those of a certain Islington MP. Not exactly the rightwing ideologue of McDonnell\u2019s imagination.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/mar/07/stephen-hawking-jeremy-corbyn-disastrous-labour-resign\">Stephen Hawking: Jeremy Corbyn is a disaster for Labour</a> </p> </aside>  <p>But we now have a Labour party where more Corbyn supporters think a short speech by Tony Blair caused the defeat in Copeland than believe their leader had anything to do with it. In that context it will be interesting to see McDonnell\u2019s statement about Hawking\u2019s comments. Perhaps the Russians who hacked the EU referendum and the presidential race have somehow found their way into Hawking\u2019s speech synthesizer? Or maybe the \u201cMSM\u201d, the mainstream media, has twisted Hawking\u2019s words, and he\u2019s actually branch chair of Physicists for Jezza?</p> <p>A constant feature of the current leadership of the Labour party is to blame anyone but Corbyn for the party\u2019s failures. But maybe, when one of the smartest people in the world claims that Corbyn is a \u201cdisaster for the Labour party\u201d, and when Owen Jones, a journalist long seen as Corbyn\u2019s biggest ally in the media, says it would be hard to vote for him were there another leadership election, the thing to do isn\u2019t it decry the critics as red Tories, the thing to do is to listen. We are approaching a point where the strongest critics of Corbyn are not the Conservatives, most of whom can\u2019t believe their luck that he\u2019s clung on so long. No, Corbyn\u2019s detractors are increasingly those who originally supported him: people who care immensely about the NHS, people who are most invested in getting Labour into power.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/mar/01/corbyn-staying-not-good-enough\">Jeremy Corbyn says he\u2019s staying. That\u2019s not good enough | Owen Jones</a> </p> </aside>  <p>A friend of mine who was heavily involved in campaigning in the Stoke byelection gave me a depressing account of it. Apparently, door-knockers in Stoke had noticed that the more they mentioned Corbyn, the more likely it was that the person on the other side of the door would slam it in their face. Another friend who has been a Labour member for years tells me they have given up canvassing by phone because, more often than not, any mention of Corbyn gets them hung up on. These reports are anecdotal, of course. But they chime with the harder data provided by polling.</p> <p>In Brexit Britain, only a Labour government would properly guarantee workers\u2019 rights and minimise any impact on living standards. But with the SNP dominant in Scotland, and the boundary reforms set to benefit the Conservatives, the only route to power is via a competent leader. I voted for Corbyn the first time round, but it has become clear that for the Labour party to survive, he must step down. Don\u2019t take it from me, take if from the heir to Einstein.</p>",
