        "webTitle": "Even Stephen Hawking says Corbyn has failed. This is no rightwing conspiracy | Sam Glover",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/sport/2017/dec/17/james-wade-bipolar-darts-word-championships-donald-mcrae",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>\u201cShe was shaking like a leaf when she met me because she doesn\u2019t go out of the house normally,\u201d <a href=\"http://jameswade.co.uk/\" title=\"\">James Wade remembers</a> as he describes the moment last month when his impact on people far beyond darts became obvious again. Wade was about to reach the quarter-finals of the Players Championship in Minehead when his wife, Samantha, was approached by a deeply apprehensive woman. \u201cIt was nice when the lady came up,\u201d Samantha says before turning to her husband. \u201cBut she had so many issues, didn\u2019t she?\u201d</p> <p>\u201cYeah,\u201d Wade says. \u201cShe was agoraphobic, bipolar and had many more anxiety issues but, somehow, she got in a car and allowed her husband to drive her from Bolton to Minehead.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/dec/13/retiring-phil-taylor-win-world-darts-championship\">Retiring Phil Taylor can ensure it is all about him at World Darts Championship</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The woman was in torment yet knew she needed to talk to someone who would understand \u2013 a darts player who, this year, has slipped out of the world top 10 for the first time in over a decade. Wade is still ranked world No11 and he begins <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2017/dec/11/one-last-fling-before-phil-taylor-turns-power-off\" title=\"\">his first match in the world championship</a> at Alexandra Palace on Sunday believing he is finally playing well enough to match the semi-finals he has reached three times previously. But he also suffers and has been diagnosed as having bipolar and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Wade has spoken out so honestly he was <a href=\"https://www.bipolaruk.org/blog/introducing-james-wade\" title=\"\">asked to become a patron of Bipolar UK</a> \u2013 whose logo he wears in place of another sponsored tag.</p> <p>This tangled personal history encouraged the woman to seek his help. Samantha, who was watching her husband play, saw \u201cshe was really nervous and had a fear\u201d. After he had won his match she told the outline of her story to Samantha who immediately took her backstage so Wade could meet her.</p> <p>\u201cI gave her a perfect weapon,\u201d he suggests. \u201cI said: \u2018It feels impossible at times \u2013 but you take these small steps for your children.\u2019 I then said something harsh because, sometimes, you need to: \u2018Remember, other people will suffer more than you through this.\u2019 She gave me a strange look but I said: \u2018Your children. You need to try to make the biggest effort for them, rather than giving up.\u2019 She said: \u2018I have given up.\u2019 I told her: \u2018You can\u2019t give up because it\u2019s not fair on them.\u2019 She promised she would try and her husband said to me afterwards: \u2018I\u2019ve never heard her that positive and determined for years.\u2019</p> <p>\u201cI was so impressed because she was shaking uncontrollably. I just thought: \u2018How brave are you?\u2019 Her husband was really happy. I\u2019m guessing they hadn\u2019t been out together for a long time.\u201d</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>I\u2019m walking around my ideal world with money, cars and sunshine but behind me it\u2019s like a nuclear bomb has gone off</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>This uplifting story emerges 45 minutes after we start talking and it is introduced by Samantha. She used to be a glamour model, who met her husband when her agent found her a gig as a \u201cwalk-on girl\u201d at a darts tournament in Nottingham. Yet something moving and profound has developed in a marriage which salvages Wade while often testing his wife in unimaginable ways. It becomes clear how fragile Wade is after they confirm that today is a difficult day \u2013 in spite of him engaging so fully in this interview \u2013 and he also reveals he sometimes likes to come off the pills that stabilise him.</p> <p>Wade describes how his mood alters without medication: \u201cI\u2019m walking around my ideal world where I\u2019ve got money, cars, sunshine and flowers in front of me while behind me it\u2019s like a nuclear bomb has gone off. I have lots of fun and get my sparkle back but I turn into an idiot again and upset people and I need to take the pills again. But I push my luck a few more days. I\u2019m having the best party. I\u2019m having a ball in my head.\u201d Samantha smiles. \u201cIt\u2019s just the rest of us \u2026\u201d</p> <p>I recall how Wade had said that taking his medication removed the devil but robbed him of his sparkle. He looks at me steadily. \u201cShouldn\u2019t I be allowed to sparkle a little? That\u2019s the sacrifice I made because when I was in a bad place I wanted to \u2026\u201d Wade hesitates. He has said before he wanted to kill himself. \u201cYeah, yeah,\u201d he says gruffly.</p> <p>Does Samantha understand his desire to sometimes break free from the muffled shackles of medication? \u201cNo, she doesn\u2019t.\u201d \u201cI don\u2019t,\u201d Samantha says, \u201cbecause I have to live with him.\u201d</p> <p>She says this without resentment, and Wade glances at her. \u201cThat\u2019s your one time to be selfish and you\u2019re entitled to that because I\u2019m selfish other times.\u201d \u201cYeah,\u201d Samantha says, \u201cit can be really hard work. I can tell when James has missed tablets.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"a79721d3b6a596355a4ea159cab3e7b34147b324\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/a79721d3b6a596355a4ea159cab3e7b34147b324/0_0_3000_2146/1000.jpg\" alt=\"James Wade is third behind Phil Taylor and Michael van Gerwen in terms of the most major titles won in the history of the PDC\" width=\"1000\" height=\"715\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">James Wade is third behind Phil Taylor and Michael van Gerwen in terms of the most major titles won in the history of the PDC.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Simon Cooper/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>\u201cShe puts them in a tablet box,\u201d Wade says, \u201cand I take them out and hide them. After three days I start having fun. God knows what I\u2019d end up doing if I was off the medication for two weeks. I\u2019d probably remortgage the house.\u201d</p> <p>Does the thought scare him? \u201cIt scares Samantha. I\u2019d never do it but it wouldn\u2019t scare me. I would upset myself though. I\u2019ve got two personalities. It\u2019s like the devil and the angel. I got diagnosed with bipolar and ADHD and I still don\u2019t think they got it right. Maybe I\u2019m in denial? I\u2019ve been to the Priory twice over 33-day stints so they\u2019ve had long enough to study me and I\u2019ve been with the same psychiatrist for seven years. But I\u2019ve said what I think I\u2019ve got.\u201d</p> <p>Samantha looks up and says, softly: \u201cA lot of time you\u2019re just different. That\u2019s all.\u201d Wade nods. \u201cI think I\u2019ve got a mild form of autism but it\u2019s a known fact everyone with problems like this disagrees with the specialists who know what they\u2019re talking about.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2017/dec/14/anti-sports-personality-year-awards-2017\">The Anti-Sports Personality of the Year awards 2017</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Does it help seeing his psychiatrist? \u201cI prefer not to see her so much. There\u2019s only so much of your past you want to dig up. I know my trigger points by now.\u201d</p> <p>The past scars the 34-year-old and he still feels anger towards teachers who humiliated him as \u201ca clown or troublemaker\u201d without attempting to understand his condition. Wade names the two teachers who ridiculed him most and wishes he could seem them now. He only found a belated sense of self-worth when he began working as a mechanic in his dad\u2019s garage, a form of work he still enjoys away from darts.</p> <p>The game often threatens to unhinge him but it has also helped. \u201cDarts is probably the first thing where somebody said: \u2018You\u2019re good at that.\u2019 Wade <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/dec/12/phil-taylor-darts-interview\" title=\"\">is third behind Phil Taylor</a> and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/dec/15/michael-van-gerwen-phil-taylor-world-darts-championship\" title=\"\">Michael van Gerwen</a> in terms of the most major titles won in the history of the PDC. He has lifted eight championships and the first of these, the World Matchplay, was in 2007.</p> <p>Three years later he spent his 27th birthday in tears, wishing he was dead.</p> <p>\u201cI went to the Priory after my 27th. The thing that made me do it was when my dad said: \u2018I just want my son back\u2019. My dad gives very little. Even though I\u2019ve spoken about my condition in interviews he\u2019s never even mentioned it since. He loves me, it\u2019s just that many men aren\u2019t good at talking. I\u2019m pretty good but he\u2019s a closed book. You also understand some of it is probably hereditary.\u201d</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>You get the idiotic minority that go: 'Look at the nutter.' And then the other side who are not sure what to say</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>When was his second visit to the Priory? \u201cAbout two years later. I had to go because my mind was out of control and going 600mph. I was in mania and needed to be slowed down. Since I\u2019ve spoken about these issues people have said it was brave but talking is the easiest way. You get the idiotic minority that go: \u2018Look at the nutter.\u2019 And then you get the other side who take a step back because they\u2019re not quite sure what to say. If you go in there with an arm in a cast it\u2019s: \u2018Get well soon.\u2019 This is different.</p> <p>\u201cWhen I came back from the Priory I went to the UK Open and everyone fell quiet. One player spoke to me and there were a hundred players in there. Colin Lloyd spoke to me first and then Andy Jenkins and, slowly, a few others spoke as well. But there\u2019s no need to be uncertain when speaking to me. It\u2019s not like I\u2019ve got a contagious disease from the moon.\u201d</p> <p>Wade prefers to call his condition \u201ca gift. It\u2019s also a hindrance but I think Einstein and Da Vinci had some serious issues. To have the insight and drive to discover or produce something totally new you can\u2019t have a normal thought-process. You need to be different to chase something hard when everyone is laughing at you.\u201d</p> <p>In terms of his own gift, can he shut out people and his problems when playing darts? \u201cIf I\u2019m flying, yeah. It doesn\u2019t happen very much now. That\u2019s partly because of my tablets.\u201d</p> <p>If he didn\u2019t have to take medication would he be a much better player? \u201cOh yeah. It\u2019s no secret I wasn\u2019t taking tablets when I had most of my major success. I still do well but as soon as I started taking them it went downhill a little.\u201d</p> <p>\u201cIt upsets me when James is having a bad day,\u201d Samantha says. \u201cHe goes on stage in front of thousands of people and sometimes they give him a hard time: \u2018Oh, he doesn\u2019t look interested.\u2019 They have no idea that before he gets on the oche he\u2019s got a huge battle in his head.\u201d</p> <p>Wade nods. \u201cI\u2019m just lucky I\u2019ve got Samantha. She deserves a medal. She knows what goes on behind closed doors and when I\u2019m unbearable. But she doesn\u2019t tell anyone.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/feb/15/raymond-van-barneveld-best-darts-but-keep-losing\">Raymond van Barneveld: \u2018I\u2019m playing the best darts of my career \u2026 but keep losing\u2019</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Samantha does not like darts and she had no idea Wade was one of the world\u2019s leading players when they met. Within three weeks of her leading him out to the oche, they had tattooed each other\u2019s names into their skin. \u201cI got her name on my chest,\u201d Wade says. \u201cSamantha had mine on her hip. I said: \u2018I\u2019ll marry you\u2019 and she went: \u2018Yeah!\u2019\u201d</p> <p>The world championship brings intense scrutiny and, for Wade, \u201cfailure in darts is highlighted more than any game. You\u2019re up there, on your own, and it\u2019s very lonely. People rave about the worlds and I guess there\u2019s no greater achievement in the game than winning it. But it\u2019s not my favourite tournament. I love Blackpool most.\u201d</p> <p>Attention will focus largely on <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/dec/13/retiring-phil-taylor-win-world-darts-championship\" title=\"\">Taylor who, having won the world title 16 times</a>, retires after the tournament. Wade has played <a href=\"http://www.dartsdatabase.co.uk/HeadToHead.aspx?plaKey=11&amp;plbKey=1\" title=\"\">Taylor 71 times and won only 14</a>. \u201cI beat him the first time we played and the last time we played but he beat me in 16 finals. If you ask me who is the best when everyone\u2019s at their peak I\u2019d say Taylor followed by <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/dec/14/gary-anderson-pdc-world-darts-championship-interview\" title=\"\">Gary Anderson</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2011/dec/12/adrian-lewis-world-champion-darts\" title=\"\">Adrian Lewis</a> and Michael van Gerwen. But Michael is consistently brilliant. Phil is the best I\u2019ve played against \u2013 and then it\u2019s Michael.\u201d</p> <p>Wade plays Keegan Brown in the first round on Sunday evening and, after discussing such moving and sometimes distressing moments, he is hopeful but pragmatic. \u201cHe\u2019s a good player but I\u2019ve got a burst of form which is down to the practice. I\u2019d love to win the tournament but I don\u2019t need to win it. There are more important battles for me to win every day.\u201d</p> <p><em>In the UK, Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123. In the US, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is 1-800-273-8255. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international suicide helplines can be found at www.befrienders.org.</em></p> <p><em>The William Hill World Darts Championship is live on Sky Sports until 1 January</em></p>",

        "webTitle": "James Wade: \u2018You need to be different to chase something hard when everyone is laughing at you\u2019",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/science/blog/2016/mar/07/its-africas-time-to-rise-lets-end-our-academic-isolation",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>Africa\u2019s challenge is how to create a strong higher education sector to prepare a new generation of leaders in the professions, business and civil society. This is necessary because the continent has long struggled with how to create and deliver quality tertiary education to its young people. Making progress on this challenge is possible now because Africans are stepping up after decades of academic isolation and inadequate support from their own leaders and from the West.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2015/jul/02/higher-education-in-africa-science-not-aid\">Higher Education in Africa: Our continent needs science, not aid</a> </p> </aside>  <p>There are fewer than 2,000 colleges and universities on a continent with a billion people in 55 countries. In comparison, the US is home to more than 4000 institutions for 320 million people. Less than 7% percent of Africans have college degrees compared to 30% of North Americans and Europeans. More than half of Africa\u2019s population is under the age of 30. This is either a demographic dividend, if the talent is developed, or a demographic curse if the next generation is large, economically marginal and unable to do the work of advanced economies. Africa is the leading continent in the fraction of its young people sent abroad for education. Sadly, many of the young have remained abroad and represent a \u201cbrain drain\u201d from Africa while providing a talented dose of diversity in America and Europe.<br /></p> <p>Coming on the heels of <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/uk/blackhistorymonth\">Black History Month</a> in the US, now is a good time to draw parallels between the education of black people in the US and Africa. And while there are significant challenges and obstacles in terms of educational equity for black people in the US, there is a significant parallel and lesson to be found in comparing colonial Africa and pre-civil rights America. In both cases, there was a de-emphasis on science and math. Black people were given little instruction and were discouraged from these fields. This pattern became embedded and remains that way: black people are scarce in the technology sector. In recent years, rapid growth and higher pay has been in jobs that draw on analytical skills. Knowledge-based jobs have become the key to both national economic growth and personal opportunity. Similarly, in Africa, math was not and is not emphasised, with the result that many of the professional jobs in an emerging continent go to foreign nationals, not African nationals. African schools are not producing the engineers, scientists or architects required to advance its economies in the ways Asian countries did a generation ago. The lesson for Africa is that they must prepare the educated labor force needed for the economic advancement they seek.<br /></p> <p>There are two other issues that challenge the African continent related to tertiary education. Only a handful of the sub-Saharan African schools (outside of South Africa) are ranked in the top 500 in the world. That means African academics are isolated from the global knowledge generation which increasingly comes from collaboration across ranked institutions and national borders. Africans educated in Africa, with some exceptions, are not part of the global talent pool \u2013 employers in Africa complain that they cannot find Africans for professional positions and as a result must bring in outsiders or send the work to the west.<br /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2015/aug/10/15-steps-closer-to-quality-higher-education-in-africa\">15 steps closer to quality higher education in Africa</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Finally, the research tradition in Africa and especially in science and math is very limited. Whether the issue is research on infectious disease, how to adapt to climate change, ways to increase agricultural productivity, or the best strategy for global leverage of Africa\u2019s rich reserve of commodities, there is a dire need for more African scholars who can conduct research on the issues.<br /></p> <p>As we move to a \u201cflat world\u201d where digital connection removes some barriers to innovation such as distance and physical isolation, Africa is isolated from the most important market \u2013 that of talent and knowledge generation. Those outside with resources can engage Africa but without knowledge and resources, Africa cannot move itself into the global economy. It will be important that Africa owns, develops, manages, and deploys its talent both to advance its own development and to be among the global players in the science and technology domains as diverse as agriculture and medicine on the one hand, and climate change and business management, on the other. When a nation can compete on the production and use of knowledge, there is a better chance for shaping its own fate.<br /></p> <p>That opportunity can become real if two things happen. The first is that Africa\u2019s talent profile is enhanced by preparing more young people and supporting their research and connection to global peers. Happily, African STEM talent is being developed and a strong group of young scientists is on display in a week at the <a href=\"nef.org/gg2016\">Next Einstein Forum</a> in Dakar, Senegal where young African scientists together with colleagues from the West are meeting to develop ways to support science and expand its reach.<br /></p> <p>The second challenge is to build a set of institutions that are first-class, committed to serving as a model for excellence, globally connected, and focused on fields that advance industry and professions. These institutions also need to address African problems and promote economic development. One example of African-based progress is the <a href=\"https://www.aims.ac.za/\">African Institute for Mathematical Sciences</a> (AIMS) which is a network of graduate programs that offer excellent graduate education with a world-class faculty. AIMS collaborates with leading global institutions and is expanding to connect with research partners and global companies. AIMS has programs in six countries and plans to expand to 15.<br /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2015/oct/26/africa-produces-just-11-of-global-scientific-knowledge\">Africa produces just 1.1% of global scientific knowledge - but change is coming</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Other institutions that have been created first class include Ashesi University in Ghana and the Aga Khan University in East Africa. The Pan African University is just starting with an ambitious plans in several countries. There is also the need to transform and support existing institutions in order to broaden the number of quality institutions.<br /></p> <p>Developing new talent and creating and transforming existing schools is a big lift. To find a model for success one need only look at South Korea. In 1960, Ghana and South Korea were similarly undeveloped and struggling countries. South Korea took the education and industry route to rapid development and is now in the first rank among nations in STEM education. They are industry giants in a diverse sectors. In the US, South Korean companies displaced market leading companies like Motorola (with Samsung), General Electric appliances (with LG) and they have two Korean cars among the top ten ranked cars for 2015.<br /></p> <p>More than ever before we can be cautiously optimistic. Many challenges and obstacles to progress remain. Technology can make rapid progress possible. There are Africans who are stepping forward to lead change. Students are eager to have educational resources in their home countries. Political and economic development are beginning to occur together. Much remains to be done but there is now a sense that its Africa\u2019s time to rise.<br /></p> <p><br /></p>",
          "headline": "It's Africa's time to rise: let's end our academic isolation"

        "webTitle": "The full list of nominations for the Golden Globes 2018",
        "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/dec/11/golden-globes-2018-the-full-list-of-nominations-film-tv-shape-of-water"

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/science/2016/feb/09/watch-this-spacetime-gravitational-wave-discovery-expected",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>A decades-long search for gravitational waves is expected to end in triumph this week when scientists declare they have discovered ripples in the fabric of spacetime, possibly created by the collision of two massive black holes travelling at close to the speed of light.</p> <p>First predicted by Einstein, and generated by the most cataclysmic events in the cosmos, gravitational waves stretch and squeeze space and all within it as they spread out across the universe. Their discovery, if confirmed, is certain to earn a Nobel prize.<br /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/feb/09/gravitational-waves-everything-you-need-to-know\">Gravitational waves: everything you need to know</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Scientists have hunted for signs of the waves for decades, but until now, their attempts have been frustrated by false signals and instruments that were not sensitive enough to detect the waves by the time they reached Earth.<br /></p> <p> That is expected to change on Thursday, when physicists in the US reveal their latest data from an experiment known as LIGO, or the Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory. The team have detectors in Washington and Louisiana that can spot passing gravitational waves via the minuscule changes in length they produce in two 4km-long pipes.<br /></p> <p>At a press conference in Washington, LIGO scientists are anticipated to reveal a clear, unambiguous gravitational wave signal. It may have come from two vast black holes, one 29 times more massive than the sun, the other 36 times more massive, spiralling around each other and finally crashing together to form a new black hole 62 times the mass of the sun. For all its heft, the new body may be no more than 200 miles wide.<br /></p> <p>The missing mass - equivalent to that of three suns, or six trillion trillion kilotonnes - was converted into energy and released as the gravitational waves LIGO is believed to have detected.<br /></p> <p>\u201cPeople are hugely excited. The rumour is that it\u2019s a whopping big signal, in other words, it\u2019s unambiguous, and that is fantastic,\u201d said Pedro Ferreira, professor of astrophysics at Oxford University, and author of the 2014 book, <a href=\"http://www-astro.physics.ox.ac.uk/~pgf/Pedro_Ferreira/The_Perfect_Theory.html\">The Perfect Theory: a century of geniuses and the battle over general relativity</a>.<br /></p> <p>When Einstein published his theory of general relativity in 1915, he changed forever how scientists view the universe. The theory showed that mass makes spacetime curve, an effect that has a multitude of implications. One, that light from distant stars will bend around the sun, was confirmed by Arthur Eddington during the solar eclipse of 1919.<br /></p> <p>The detection of gravitational waves would tick off the last major prediction of general relativity. It would demonstrate that the equations drawn up by Einstein, who refused to believe in black holes himself, hold true in what ranks as the most extreme realm of physics.<br /></p> <p>But there is more to the discovery of gravitational waves than simply proving they exist. If the LIGO signal is as strong as rumours suggest, new instruments could be built to detect gravity waves from colliding black holes and other hugely energetic events all over the universe. </p> <p>\u201cIt would be like having a telescope that, instead of looking at objects in the electromagnetic spectrum, is looking at them with gravitational waves,\u201d said Ferreira. \u201cWe could see things in a completely different way. It would be very blurred vision - gravitational waves are not good at pinpointing objects - but they would help us understand what happens when black holes hs fall into one another.\u201d<br /></p> <p>\u201cThe fact is whenever we\u2019ve looked at the universe in new ways, with x-rays, with radio waves, we\u2019ve discovered incredible stuff, exotica. So this is going to open up a new window, and for sure we\u2019ll discover bizarre stuff,\u201d he added.<br /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--supporting\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2015/feb/12/the-hunt-for-gravitational-waves-could-be-nearing-success\">The hunt for gravitational waves could be nearing success</a> </p> </aside>  <p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/jan/12/gravitation-waves-signal-rumoured-science\">Rumours</a> that the LIGO team had detected gravitational waves have been circulating in the astrophysics community for months. But <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/across-the-universe/2016/jan/12/gravitational-wave-detection-could-be-a-false-alarm\">many researchers were sceptical</a> and feared the rumours might have been sparked by synthetic signals which are added to the data to test the team\u2019s analytical procedures.<br /></p> <p>\u201cAfter all the rumours over the past few months I certainly expect them to announce a detection at this point,\u201d said Alberto Sesana, a researcher at the University of Birmingham\u2019s Gravitational Wave Group. \u201cWe have to bear in mind that LIGO is one experiment and the only one that can detect such sources. If they claim to have detected gravitational waves, it cannot be confirmed by another instrument, and that is always an issue. But they have been very cautious in doing this properly. I\u2019m confident they have clear and strong evidence for it.\u201d<br /></p> <p>There is a chance a signal will be announced from another source, such as a pair of neutron stars spinning around one another, or a neutron star falling into a black hole. But such cosmic events would be expected to produce weaker signals than the large spike scientists anticipate the LIGO team to reveal.<br /></p> <p>Scientists have declared the discovery of gravitational waves before only to have their hopes dashed. In 2014, researchers on an experiment called Bicep2 claimed to have found evidence for gravitational waves from the big bang, but further analysis by other groups showed that the signals they picked up could be entirely explained by <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/sep/22/gravitational-waves-space-dust\">space dust</a> interfering with their measurements.<br /></p> <p>Ulrich Sperhake, a theorist at Cambridge University who studies how gravitational waves are generated by black holes, said the community was very excited and expectant. \u201c I don\u2019t know anyone in the field who expects anything other than a detection to be announced,\u201d he said. \u201cAnything but the onset of a new era in observational gravitational astronomy would come as a major surprise on Thursday, but there remains a tiny speculative element to it until we\u2019ll have the official LIGO announcement.\u201d</p> <p>Martin Hendry, a member of the LIGO team at Glasgow University, would not be drawn on the details of Thursday\u2019s announcement. \u201cI can\u2019t say anything more at this stage than wait and see. Or should that be \u201cwatch this spacetime?\u201d he said.</p>",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/commentisfree/2017/apr/25/plastic-eating-bugs-wax-moth-caterpillars-bee",

          "body": "<p>Caterpillars that can munch up plastic bags <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/apr/24/plastic-munching-worms-could-help-wage-war-on-waste-galleria-mellonella\" title=\"\">have just been identified</a>, fuelling excited speculation that this could one day eliminate global pollution from plastic waste. The chance discovery, initially made by a scientist and amateur beekeeper whose plastic bag had been eaten through by the moth caterpillars, was reported this week by researchers at Cambridge University and the Spanish National Research Council.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/apr/24/plastic-munching-worms-could-help-wage-war-on-waste-galleria-mellonella\">Plastic-eating worms could help wage war on waste</a> </p> </aside>  <p>How thoughtful of nature to provide bugs that eat our rubbish. Is this the end of landfill, turtles with plastic-congested stomachs, and trees adorned with tattered ribbons of shopping bags?</p> <p>Well, it\u2019s never that simple, is it? Attempts to commandeer nature to do our dirty work never seem to turn out as hoped, whether these take the form of planting trees to soak up carbon dioxide, or introducing invasive species for pest control, or using microorganisms to clean up oil spills. Remember the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/30/cane-toads-on-the-march-invasive-species-finds-ideal-niche-in-australia\" title=\"\">Australian cane toad debacle</a>? The toads were introduced in the 1930s to control crop pests but instead gorged themselves on other local wildlife and spread across the country.</p> <p>These creatures, the larvae of the greater wax moth (<em>Galleria mellonella</em>), can devour polyethylene, which along with the closely related polypropylene is the main type of plastic found in waste. But you\u2019d need an awful lot of them to make a significant dent on the plastic waste problem. The UK alone discards almost 2m tonnes of this stuff every year. At the rate of consumption reported by the researchers \u2013 one worm gets through about two milligrams of plastic a day \u2013 you\u2019d need billions of caterpillars eating constantly all year round to deal with that.</p> <p>Quite aside from how and where you\u2019d farm all these bugs, there\u2019s something about them that news reports have failed to mention. Wax moths, which are found throughout the world, are so-called because they eat wax. Specifically, they love to eat the wax from which bees make their honeycombs \u2013 and so <a href=\"https://www.beeworks.com/wax-moth/\" title=\"\">they can devastate\u00a0bee colonies</a>. The two common species of wax moth, of which\u00a0<em>Galleria mellonella</em> is one, are thought to cause more than \u00a34m worth of damage annually in the United States\u00a0alone.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"664b602e4c25976655fdd916dbea062d071945f2\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/664b602e4c25976655fdd916dbea062d071945f2/0_100_4096_2458/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Bees in a hive\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018With bee populations already under severe stress, we might want to think twice about breeding one of their common airborne enemies in huge numbers.\u2019</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Peter Komka/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>With <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/feb/26/decline-of-bees-poses-potential-risks-to-major-crops-says-un\" title=\"\">bee populations already under severe stress</a> from pesticides, habitat loss and predators, we might want to think twice about breeding one of their common airborne enemies in huge numbers \u2013 even if the intention was to somehow keep them in plastics-processing centres. The idea that if bees disappear then humankind will follow four years later, popularly misattributed to Albert Einstein, might be a touch hyperbolic. But without their pollinating assistance, crop cultivation would be in deep trouble.</p> <p>Polyethylene sits around in the environment because its molecules are so hard to break down. Ordinary soil microorganisms don\u2019t have the resources for it. These plastics are built up from the hydrocarbon molecules in oil, and ideally we\u2019d turn them back into oil after we had used them, regenerating a valuable substance rather than sacrificing it as waste. Chemists have been working long and hard to do that, using special catalysts to induce the chemical reactions. But it\u2019s tough, and only very recently have they started to see progress. It\u2019s precisely because wax is chemically similar to polyethylene that the wax moth caterpillars can biodegrade it.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/feb/17/tiny-plastic-pellets-found-on-73-of-uk-beaches\">Tiny plastic pellets found on 73% of UK beaches</a> </p> </aside>  <p>A far easier and less hazardous solution to the plastic problem could be found in bacteria, however. After all, it seems you can find bacteria that will eat almost anything. Some happily devour toxic chemicals, such as perchlorate (weed killer); others thrive amid radioactive waste. And indeed last year <a href=\"https://www.newscientist.com/article/2080279-bacteria-found-to-eat-pet-plastics-could-help-do-the-recycling/\" title=\"\">a team of Japanese scientists</a> identified a bacterium existing in the\u00a0wild that can feed on another common plastic, polyethylene terephthalate, which is used to make bottles for soft drinks and\u00a0water.</p> <p>It\u2019s possible that bacteria might, in fact, be responsible for the plastic-digesting ability of <em>Galleria mellonella</em> larvae. Another wax-eater, the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_mealmoth\" title=\"\">Indian mealmoth</a>, was found in 2014 to house\u00a0bacteria in its digestive tract that\u00a0can break down polyethylene. <em>Galleria</em> might prove to have such gut bacteria too.</p> <p>Those bacteria could provide the ideal solution. They could be brewed up in fermentation vats that would dissolve plastics without anyone having to contemplate breeding vast wax moth colonies. Alternatively, it might be possible to extract the particular enzymes the caterpillars use and put them to work on their own \u2013 a kind of concentrate of gastric juices.</p> <p>These are the real reasons why the new discovery is promising, and not because we\u2019ll soon be feeding plastic bags to caterpillars. As usual with science, you don\u2019t get the solution on a plate, but have to follow clues with patience and care. It doesn\u2019t make for great headlines. But honestly, the bees would thank you for it.</p>",

          "body": "<p>While I agree with Maulfry Worthington (<a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/global/2015/jun/18/city-headlines-cereal-offenders-einstein\" title=\"\">Letters</a>, 19 June) that our schools should encourage more curiosity, it is unfortunate that she repeats the near-calumny that Einstein was a \u201cpatent clerk\u201d who would \u201cbecome\u201d a great physicist. In fact Einstein worked as a technical examiner at the <em>Eidgen\u00f6ssisches Institut f\u00fcr Geistiges Eigentum</em> (the Swiss Federal Intellectual Property Office) in 1902-09 to support himself while he completed his PhD thesis in physics and did his early work on quantum mechanics and special relativity. He was already published in <em>Annalen der Physik</em> before joining the patent office. Einstein did not have good academic connections, which made it hard to secure a teaching post, but was recognised as a physicist of the first rank very early in his career.</p> <p>While curiosity is absolutely a necessary trait for success in science, the hard work has also to be done, and the exams passed, even by Einstein.<br /><strong>Keith Braithwaite</strong><br /><em>Beckenham, Kent</em></p>",

          "body": "<p>Advertisements that perpetuate sexist stereotypes, from men bungling housework to girls being less academic than boys, will be banned under rules being proposed by the industry watchdog.</p> \n<p>The crackdown by the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) will toughen rules on ads that are deemed to present activities as only appropriate for one gender or another, or that mock those who do not conform to stereotypical gender roles. </p> \n<p>It will also toughen rules on ads that \u201cbody shame\u201d young women after an outcry over Protein World\u2019s controversial \u201cBeach body ready\u201d campaign, which was not banned despite a petition with 70,000 signatures claiming that its depiction of a bikini-clad model in an ad for a weight-loss product was socially irresponsible.</p> \n<p>The ASA\u2019s proposals, outlined in a report conducted with research firm GfK, are part of an effort to address the portrayal of women in ads in particular. </p> \n<p>The project, which the watchdog considers the most comprehensive review of gender stereotyping anywhere in the world, follows a major crackdown on \u201cairbrushing\u201d, which has seen major beauty ads featuring stars such as <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2017/apr/19/cara-delevingne-rimmel-mascara-ad-banned-airbrushing\">Cara Delevingne</a>, Natalie Portman, and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/27/loreal-julia-roberts-ad-banned\">Julia Roberts</a> banned. It has also banned ads <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/06/gucci-ad-banned-unhealthily-thin-model-asa\">featuring \u201cunhealthily thin\u201d models</a>. </p> \n<p>Its proposals will also clarify the existing code relating to ads that objectify or inappropriately sexualise women and girls.</p> \n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> \n <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/may/14/is-this-the-year-advertisers-wake-up-to-perils-of-cultural-appropriation\">Is this the year advertisers wake up to perils of cultural appropriation?</a> </p> \n</aside> \n<p>\u201cOur review shows that specific forms of gender stereotypes in ads can contribute to harm for adults and children,\u201d said Ella Smillie, lead author of the report. </p> \n<p>\u201cSuch portrayal scan limit how people see themselves, how others see them, and limit the life decisions they take. Tougher standards in the areas we\u2019ve identified will address harms and ensure that modern society is better represented.\u201d<br></p> \n<p>The ASA said it was not looking at implementing a blanket ban \u2013 it will still be acceptable for ads to feature a woman doing cleaning or a man doing DIY tasks \u2013 but there are versions of this type of commercial that will now come under scrutiny.<br></p> \n<p> For example, ads that would probably be banned under the proposed new rules include \u201cshowing family members creating a mess while a woman is seen having the sole responsibility cleaning it up\u201d. </p> \n<p>Ads that suggest an activity is inappropriate for girls or boys because it is stereotypically associated with the other sex would similarly be banned, as would those featuring men \u201ctrying and failing to undertake simple parental or household tasks\u201d.</p> \n<p>The ASA report, entitled Depictions, Perceptions and Harm, found that harmful stereotypes can \u201crestrict the choices, aspirations and opportunities of children, young people and adults\u201d. </p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> \n <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"c8f22da2-3172-4f58-92af-8817e7087f58\" data-atom-type=\"media\"> \n  <div> \n   <iframe width=\"420\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/vWWZkQ5sZ2c\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen> </iframe> \n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>Guy Parker, the chief executive of the ASA, said: \u201cPortrayals which reinforce outdated and stereotypical views on gender roles in society can play their part in driving unfair outcomes for people.</p> \n<p>\u201cWhile advertising is only one of many factors that contribute to unequal gender outcomes, tougher advertising standards can play an important role in tackling inequalities and improving outcomes for individuals, the economy and society as a whole.\u201d</p> \n<p>The ASA\u2019s report will now be handed to the <a href=\"https://www.revolvy.com/main/index.php?s=Committee%20of%20Advertising%20Practice\">Committee of Advertising Practice</a>, which sets the UK ad code across all forms of media \u2013 from TV and newspapers to billboards and online ads \u2013 to develop new standards to be turned into rules and enforced by the ad watchdog.</p> \n<p>The review examined gender stereotyping across areas including body image, objectification, sexualisation, gender characteristics and roles and mocking people for not conforming to gender stereotypes.</p> \n<p>Pressure to address the portrayal of women in ads, in particular relating to objectification and body image, has been building for a number of years.</p> \n<p>In 2015, the Sun <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/jan/19/has-the-sun-axed-page-3-topless-pictures\">scrapped Page 3\u2019s topless women after 44 years</a>, a move which came following rising pressure from campaigners including No More Page 3. </p> \n<p>Before their virtual extinction at the hands of the internet, the lads\u2019 magazine market \u2013 led by titles including FHM, Loaded, Nuts and Zoo \u2013 <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/aug/02/tesco-lads-mags-covers-more-modest\">found</a> itself <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/aug/02/tesco-lads-mags-covers-more-modest\">confined to top shelves and \u201cmodesty bags\u201d</a> by supermarkets feeling the heat of public pressure. </p> \n<p>Liberal Democrat MP Jo Swinson waged a <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/sep/19/liberal-democrats-airbrush-ban\">long-running campaign</a> against \u201coverly perfected and unrealistic images\u201d of women in advertisements.</p> \n<p>The push started at the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/sep/19/liberal-democrats-airbrush-ban\">Lib Dem party conference in 2009</a>, which used its first day of debate to discuss the myriad ways that women are increasingly encouraged to \u201clive up to\u201d unrealistic ideals of beauty and imagery that \u201coften trivialises their position within society\u201d. </p> \n<h2><strong>Ads likely to be banned</strong></h2> \n<p><strong>Protein World\u2019s Beach Body Ready campaign</strong><br>The advertising watchdog cleared <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/jul/01/protein-world-beach-body-ready-ads-asa \">the highly controversial campaign</a> despite nearly 400 complaints it objectified women and was socially irresponsible. The weight-loss ads featuring a bikini-clad model sparked a huge backlash over alleged \u201cbody-shaming\u201d including a protest in London\u2019s Hyde Park and a petition on Change.org that attracted more than 70,000 signatures. The ASA cleared the ads, saying it did not think the image of the model \u201cshamed women who had different body shapes into believing they needed to take a slimming supplement to feel confident wearing swimwear in public\u201d. Ironically, it ended up being banned for making misleading health claims about the Protein World supplement.</p> \n<p><strong>Cara Delevingne naked for Tom Ford perfume</strong><br>The model and, more recently, actor appeared on a billboard in east London lying naked on her front with the side of her breast and buttocks visible while holding a bottle of Tom Ford Black Orchid perfume. The advertising watchdog received complaints that it was degrading and objectified women and that the billboard could be seen by children and was close to churches and mosques. The ad was cleared by the ASA, but it was deemed not to be allowed to be displayed within 100 metres of schools. </p> \n<p><strong>Sexist Gap ad stereotyping children\u2019s futures<br></strong><a href=\"http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3718308/How-seriously-think-OK-Gap-Kids-provokes-fury-sexist-ad-calling-little-boys-scholars-girls-social-butterflies-spells-Einstein-s-wrong.html\">An ad for US fashion chain Gap\u2019s kids brand</a> featured a young boy, \u201ccalled the Little Scholar\u201d, while the girl featured in the ad is labelled \u201cthe Social Butterfly\u201d.           "body": "<p>By the end of the 19th century, many physicists believed there really wasn\u2019t any more to learn about the workings of nature and the properties of matter and radiation. On balance, it might have been easier for everyone if things had stayed that way. Then we could just study Newton and Maxwell and all go home, too. Here\u2019s a picture of an apple landing on Newton\u2019s head.</p> <p>Things changed in 1900 when Max Planck proposed that the energy of electromagnetic radiation was proportional to its frequency. This is known as Planck\u2019s constant which is a tiny number. Even smaller than one. This led Planck to conclude that the radiation had to be lumpy.</p> <p>Everyone ignored Planck \u2013 presumably because they couldn\u2019t understand him \u2013 until Einstein realised that, in a photoelectric effect, high intensity light did not result in electrons being knocked free with more energy, just <em tabindex=\"-1\">more </em>electrons being knocked free. Wow! In 1909, Rutherford discovered that when alpha particles were fired at a thin gold foil, most of them passed through harmlessly. Only <em tabindex=\"-1\">a few</em> bounced back! This led him to conclude that ...</p> <p>Look, I\u2019m sorry, this is pointless. You\u2019re not really following a word of this, are you? Nor has the illustrator, who has just resorted to doodling people skiing and some pints of lager. I did try warning Ladybird that quantum mechanics is far too tricky to explain in 25 pages but they were insistent. And the money was quite good. That\u2019s the Al-Khalili constant.</p> <p>Let\u2019s try making things a bit simpler. Here are some quantum rules. Electrons can only fall to a lower orbit if there is enough space. Therefore, one electron has to wait till a photon has allowed another electron to jump to a higher orbit before it can go a bit lower. There is a long queue to switch orbits and electrons have been known to barge their way to the front rather than wait their turn. Naughty electrons! Actually scrub all that because, in 1921, Niels Bohr discovered that atoms weren\u2019t like miniature solar systems and were more like clouds of fuzzy electron-ness.</p> <p>I\u2019m touched you\u2019re still with me. Really, I am. Most people would have given up. I\u2019ll try to speed up. Here\u2019s a drawing of Schr\u00f6dinger without his cat thinking uncertainly about wave function \u2013 which Heisenberg turned into his Uncertainty Principle. This can be quite easily explained. Imagine a sentence that you can just about understand on its own. Now imagine another sentence following it that you can just about understand on its own. The uncertainty principle predicts that when you try to read a third sentence, you will almost certainly be uncertain about how it related to the previous two.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--thumbnail\" data-media-id=\"577d9519026694945c743e60759ac88972d826ce\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/577d9519026694945c743e60759ac88972d826ce/0_0_672_1000/672.jpg\" alt=\"Quantum Mechanics: A Ladybird Expert Book by Jim Al-Khalili (Michael Joseph, \u00a37.99)\" width=\"672\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Quantum Mechanics: A Ladybird Expert Book by Jim Al-Khalili (Michael Joseph, \u00a37.99)</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Penguin</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>I now want to talk about tunnelling. A quantum particle can travel in all sorts of directions. For instance, it can either go over a hill or through it. Sometimes it can do both things at the same time. That\u2019s how the sun shines. Also, for every piece of matter, there is anti-matter and if they collide all hell breaks loose.</p> <p>We now come to a picture of Schr\u00f6dinger <em>with</em> his cat. Poor old Snowy was shut in a state of quantum superposition inside a box with some radioactive material and managed to be both dead and alive at the same time. The only way of knowing which was the real state was by opening the box \u2013 which Schr\u00f6dinger didn\u2019t want to do because he would have been gutted if Snowy had died. As far as anyone knows, Snowy is still dead and alive inside his box.</p> <p>In the mid-1930s, quantum mechanics became even more quantum with the discovery of quarks, leptons and gauge bosons. Here\u2019s a drawing of a spade going into the ground because the illustrator was having a nervous breakdown. Here\u2019s something a bit spooky. Two separated particles can be connected, in that something that happens to one can simultaneously affect the other, even if it has to travel faster than the speed of light which isn\u2019t really possible. One way of trying to think about this is through quantum electrodynamics, which states that empty space is never really empty. Rather, it\u2019s like an empty car park that is full of cars.</p> <p>I could be writing any old nonsense by now and you wouldn\u2019t be any the wiser. My editor certainly wasn\u2019t and seemed to be under the impression this was another in the Ladybird parody series. So what does it all mean? Search me. One of the guiding precepts is that we can never know what is going in the quantum world when we are not looking. Or, as I\u2019ve just proved, when we are.</p> <p><strong>Digested read, digested:</strong> W = TF<sup>2</sup>.<br /></p>",

          "body": "<p>It is some eight decades since Christ Church, Oxford, offered Albert Einstein refuge from Nazi Germany.</p> <p>To one internal critic of this act of generosity to \u201ca German\u201d, of all people, the college\u2019s dean at the time countered: \u201c[Einstein\u2019s] attainments and reputation are so high that they transcend national boundaries, and any university in the world ought to be proud of having him.\u201d</p> <p>The legacy of that decision continues today. The <em>Observer</em> has learned that, in the spirit of the 1930s, Oxford is once again opening its doors to imperilled intellectuals. Academics fleeing Syria, where <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2015/sep/08/from-syria-to-sudan-how-do-you-count-the-dead\" title=\"\">250,000 people have died</a> in the civil war, have been quietly offered positions at Christ Church, St John\u2019s and Merton. Several other colleges, including Hertford and Wadham, are expected to follow their lead.</p> <p>Stephen Wordsworth, executive director of the <a href=\"http://cara1933.org/\" title=\"\">Council for At Risk Academics</a> (Cara), an organisation established by Beveridge before the second world war, co-ordinating Oxford\u2019s efforts, said that he had met some of the heads of colleges and that things were \u201cmoving well\u201d.</p> <p>\u201cI hope we will soon be able to add to the number of people we can support,\u201d he said. \u201cThe great majority of the people we help nowadays urgently need to escape from very difficult or dangerous situations, but feel strongly that it is their duty to return, when they can, to help rebuild better societies in their home countries.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote\"> <blockquote> <p>I hope we will soon be able to add to the number of people we can support</p> <footer> <cite>Stephen Wordsworth, executive director of Cara</cite> </footer> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>\u201cIn the meantime, they need to find places at universities and similar institutions where they and their families will be safe, and where they can maintain and develop the skills and networks they will need, when that time comes.\u201d</p> <p>It is understood that Cara has so far placed four Syrian academics at Oxford colleges. Wordsworth said they have another 100 applicants, two-thirds of whom are Syrians, whom they wish to support. His organisation is currently supporting 140 academics from the wider Middle East.</p> <p>Those taken in by colleges will have their university fees, accommodation, food and professional costs met, and are invited to stay for a maximum of two years.</p> <p>At Christ Church, the dean, the Very Rev Professor Martyn Percy, said a Syrian professor of pharmaceutical chemistry, Hadia AlMahli, started her time with them this month and they could be open to others joining her.</p> <p>\u201cWe took a decision several months ago that we would try to offer hospitality to academics at risk in the Middle East,\u201d said Percy, whose college is one of the largest and wealthiest in Oxford.</p> <p>\u201cHadia was in Aleppo working at the university when she was forced to leave because of missiles and rockets raining down on the city.\u201d</p> <p>When Einstein moved to Princeton from Oxford in 1933, he asked that the \u00a3400 stipend he received from the college be used to save fellow \u00e9migr\u00e9s.</p> <p>It is unlikely that Oxford\u2019s colleges will take in more than a dozen academics from Syria, given their financial pressures. But they say they hope to live up to their past.</p>",

          "body": "<p>Researchers have just discovered that crying to sad music is mood enhancing. Now, I\u2019m no Bert Einstein, but I could have told them that a lifetime ago. There is a simple reason that we call it a good weep \u2013 because it\u2019s good for us. (OK, I just made that up, but it could \u2013 or should \u2013 be true.)</p> <p>The <a href=\"http://www.drozthegoodlife.com/healthy-lifestyle/mental-health/news/a3782/crying-sad-music-improves-mood-study/\">Japanese study</a> surveyed how 154 participants responded to music, and how often they experienced goose bumps, shivers, crying or a lump in their throat. They concluded that songs that induced tears resulted in pleasure and participants feeling calmer</p> <p>I\u2019m not boasting, but I reckon I might just be one of the world\u2019s top weepers. I can cry anywhere, at any time, without warning \u2013 quietly, desperately, uncontrollably. This might sound terribly bleak, but it isn\u2019t, because invariably I feel better for it at the end. In fact, the only people who suffer are those who witness it or have to comfort me.</p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OlKaVFqxERk\"                                                                        > <iframe width=\"460\" height=\"259\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/OlKaVFqxERk?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure>   <p>For a long time I used to cry every Saturday when my partner and I went to Sainsbury\u2019s for our weekly shop. After a while, she decided to go shopping by herself. These days I cry at bad news, good news and occasionally even indifferent news, often ably assisted by a suitably heart-tugging soundtrack.</p> <p>Music, of course, is moving in itself. But it has the added punch of being a shortcut to, and shorthand for, our past. All we\u2019ve achieved, loved and lost is often represented in song. And whether it\u2019s the potency of cheap music, the ethereal genius of Mozart, or simply the period it evokes, makes no odds.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>Over the past year, as the world has gone tits up, I\u2019ve become desperate in my search for music to make me cry</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>As the way we have consumed music has changed, so has my addiction to music that makes me cry. Back in the day, I\u2019d listen patiently to a whole album knowing that track seven would do it for me, but now I need the instant hit. It\u2019s a habit I indulge privately, often when the house is still and everybody is asleep. That\u2019s when I\u2019ll get on to the web desperately searching for songs to make me cry. Why? Because it makes me feel good.</p> <p>Some of them will be good old guilty pleasures \u2013 Chicago\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OlKaVFqxERk\">If You Leave Me Now</a> does the job beautifully, while <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?gl=PL&amp;hl=pl&amp;v=gUuliMnJ9dg\">Immortality</a> by the Bee Gees with C\u00e9line Dion goes straight to the heart (particularly Barry\u2019s introduction: \u201cNow we come to a magical moment in the whole proceedings. We\u2019d like to bring on our guest star ladies and gentlemen, Miss C\u00e9line Dion\u201d). For a classical weepy nothing does it for me quite like <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qQuahSdTvU4\">Kathleen Ferrier singing Gluck\u2019s What is Life?</a></p> <p>One song that reduces me to a quivering wreck is <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cAu3a7CMA84\">Somewhere</a> from West Side Story, but it has to be this <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cAu3a7CMA84\">Barbra Streisand version</a>, and if we\u2019re going right to the heart of it, three minutes 15 seconds in, when Babs just soars. Trust me you will feel on top of the world after you\u2019ve cried yourself a river for Tony and Maria.</p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cAu3a7CMA84\"                                                                        > <iframe width=\"460\" height=\"259\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/cAu3a7CMA84?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure>   <p>Blowin\u2019 in the Wind is a wonderful song, but Bob Dylan\u2019s original doesn\u2019t do anything for me emotionally. However, give it to Little Stevie Wonder and Clarence Paul and I cry like a baby. Why? Maybe because there\u2019s something unbearably poignant about him singing \u201cHow many roads must a man walk down before they call him a man\u201d when he is still a boy. (Clarence Paul is just in the background on <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HzQNxFvfJ6M\">this version</a>)</p> <p>Aretha Franklin\u2019s A Natural Woman <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XHsnZT7Z2yQ\">performed at the Kennedy Center in 2015</a> in front of the Obamas at a tribute to Carole King has given me many a good weep. It\u2019s not simply the brilliance of Aretha\u2019s singing or Carole\u2019s song. It\u2019s certainly not the song\u2019s innate sadness \u2013 this is one of the great songs about the transcendent power of love. It\u2019s the triple emotional whammy in the video \u2013 Aretha sitting at the piano to perform then standing up, mic in hand, and throwing her fur coat to the floor, King watching with joyous disbelief, and Michelle and Barack weeping along, proving even politicians can be properly human.</p> <p>My passion for crying goes back to when I was ill as a young boy and was bed-bound for a long time. I had all this horribly constipated emotion and anger lodged deep within me. After a while I realised I had to cry at least once a day, and if I didn\u2019t the buildup was such that it became physically painful. Eventually I began to think crying was like an orgasm \u2013 liberating, joyous and a relief. And if those tears didn\u2019t come, boy you were left frustrated.</p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XHsnZT7Z2yQ\"                                                                        > <iframe width=\"460\" height=\"259\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/XHsnZT7Z2yQ?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure>   <p>Over the past year, as the world has gone tits up, I\u2019ve become desperate in my search for music to make me cry. I suppose it\u2019s like any addiction \u2013 the more you indulge, the more you need. Sometimes I search the internet hoping to find songs I\u2019ve never heard of that will give me a bigger, better weep than anything before. This is how I came across Jeff Buckley\u2019s gorgeous version of <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AUq9sgPqfJ8&amp;spfreload=10\">We All Fall in Love Sometimes</a>. I defy you not to cry.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/dec/26/george-michael-press-encounters-publicist-tabloids\">Encounters with George Michael \u2013 'His publicist thought I was tabloid scum'</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Recently, there have been two songs I\u2019ve returned to time and again for a satisfying sob. Strangely, they are not sad songs, but idealistic ones, and both are performed by Pete Seeger. This Land is Your Land, sung by Seeger with Bruce Springsteen at the Obama inauguration, breaks my heart. There is no more moving reminder of what is possible.</p> <p>But my ultimate weepy is We Shall Overcome. I adore the scratchy black-and-white recording of <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MEZkZamGCmE\">We Shall Overcome</a> Seeger performed with members of the civil rights movement in 1963. The only<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TCbACC-lskU\"> version</a> that makes me blub more is this one sung last year by a group of asylum-seeker friends. Watch, weep, and agitate.</p>",

          "body": "<p>Not a single person at Olga Petrov\u2019s* school knows the real reason she came to be teaching in the North of England. Even now, more than a decade after moving to the UK, it\u2019s clear that she still feels uncomfortable talking about the situation that led to her fleeing Russia. She says, hastily, that she was forced to leave due to her involvement in a political movement. \u201cThere were threats to myself and my family and it became impossible to work and have a normal life. I was in a dangerous position.\u201d</p> <p>The Russian-language teacher left for London with her children before settling in the North. Visiting her children\u2019s primary school every day, Petrov soon felt a strong urge to teach in her new country. \u201cI realised that there were many similarities [between schools in Russia and in the UK] \u2013 there\u2019s the same atmosphere in school, teachers are the same \u2013 and I thought that I could easily do this job.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2017/jul/07/war-and-violence-drive-majority-of-people-fleeing-to-europe-by-sea-not-economics\">War and violence drive 80% of people fleeing to Europe by sea, not economics</a> </p> </aside>  <p>However, she faced a couple of difficulties \u2013 namely improving her English and a lack of demand for Russian teachers. Ruling out the classroom, she earned a living as a private Russian tutor and interpreter for four years, but her desire to teach in a school only grew. Around this time, Petrov discovered <a href=\"http://www.reconnectonline.org.uk/\">Reconnect</a>, a charity set up to help refugees to fulfil their ambitions of teaching in the UK. </p> <p>Reconnect advised and supported her to organise documents from the National Academic Recognition Information Centre (NARIC) confirming her overseas qualification, and she studied to improve her English before applying for a teacher training diploma. She worked at a primary school, then got a job as a part-time Russian teacher at a secondary school. \u201cI just knew I wanted to teach Russian,\u201d she says. \u201cI don\u2019t know what would have happened if I hadn\u2019t had the opportunity to find out about the training.\u201d </p> <h2>Disappearing funding</h2> <p>Petrov is one of an <a href=\"http://www.redcross.org.uk/What-we-do/Refugee-support/Refugee-facts-and-figures\">estimated 118,995 refugees</a> living in the UK. Many of those are highly skilled but unable to easily find work. Those with a teaching background come up against a number of challenges in rejoining the profession in their new country. \u201cMany refugees are not familiar with and are in need of information and an understanding of the UK education system, learning practices, curriculum, policies, entry requirements and progression routes,\u201d explains Theodros Abraham, an associate lecturer in development studies at Birkbeck, University of London, and founder of Reconnect. \u201cThe available services are few, fragmented, unfocused and short-term.\u201d Reconnect has so far helped 54 refugees from 20 countries gain Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) since it was started in 2003. </p> <p>Over the years, funding to help refugees enter the profession has evaporated. The Refugee Council\u2019s Refugees Into Teaching programme, which supported people looking to requalify and take on paid teaching positions through mentoring and placements, closed in 2011 after three years due to cuts. The organisation now offers informal advice. </p> <p>\u201cWhen it comes to refugees rebuilding teaching careers, complex and confusing requalifying pathways make this very difficult,\u201d says Andrew Lawton, integration and employment services manager at the Refugee Council. \u201cSpecialist guidance is needed if we are able to support refugees back into the classroom and back into the jobs they love.\u201d</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>Specialist guidance is needed to support refugees back into the classroom and back into the jobs they love</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Syrian Yasser al-Jassem, 36, has found it difficult to find paid teaching work. Since moving to Manchester two years ago, the former Arabic teacher has volunteered at schools and taken courses such as safeguarding child protection through <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"http://www.empowering-learning.com/\">Empowering Learning,</a> a training programme designed to help place overseas teachers in the UK.</p> <p> \u201cIdeally I need to do my QTS but it takes years,\u201d he says.\u201cI don\u2019t know if maybe it\u2019s easier to do maths, English and science GCSE then I can apply for a teaching assistant job.\u201d He\u2019s currently working as a private Arabic tutor. He says that he still needs to improve his English before teaching in a school, but is frustrated by the lack of assistance from the authorities. \u201cThe government doesn\u2019t help us,\u201d he says. \u201cThe job centre pushed me to find any job, and although I\u2019m a teacher they don\u2019t care. I want to teach \u2013 for me, it\u2019s not just a job.\u201d</p> <p>Abraham advises would-be teachers to obtain official assessment and confirmation of their overseas qualifications from NARIC, then apply for places on appropriate teacher-training programmes.</p> <p>Lawton adds that it is possible that a qualified teacher from outside EU can teach within a school without a UK-issued QTS, but generally it is easier to get the QTS first. He notes, though, that while undertaking a part-time teacher training programme provides the most viable opportunity for many refugees, it can be very costly given their circumstances.</p> <h2>Jumping the hurdles</h2> <p> When refugees are able to get past the hurdles and become teachers, their background means they have the ability to inject a wealth of skills, knowledge and experience to schools. \u201cThe most distinctive capacities refugees and asylum seekers can bring to classrooms are the fact that they have overcome, and are still overcoming, enormous challenges, to have got to being a teacher,\u201d says Jay Derrick, director of teacher education at University College London, Institute of Education. The college ran a special route to a standard post-compulsory PGCE for refugees and asylum seekers from 2007 to 2013 until government funding was withdrawn.</p> <p>The fact that they have lived in very different situations socially, culturally, linguistically and politically means that they contribute to the diversity of classrooms, he says. Some refugee teachers talk about their backgrounds with their class. </p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/2016/nov/22/five-ways-to-help-migrant-children-settle-in-your-class\">Five ways to help migrant children settle in your class</a> </p> </aside>  <p>This is the case for Ines Salom Lynch, a 31-year-old primary school teacher at a school in Barnet, London. Salom Lynch arrived in the UK when she was just six years old after her family left war-torn Bosnia. She often speaks to children at the school about her background and in June organised assemblies raising awareness of refugees \u2013 giving a nod to famous refugees such as Albert Einstein \u2013 as part of Refugee Week.</p> <p>As Derrick notes, \u201cThere are increasing numbers of students in UK classes who also come from families affected by migration and who may also be refugees. Teachers with experience of this themselves can obviously add value to the learning of such students, and to that of students who haven\u2019t had these experiences, and whose lives have been relatively stable.\u201d </p> <p><em>*name has been changed</em></p> <p><strong>Follow us on Twitter via <a href=\"https://twitter.com/GuardianTeach\">@GuardianTeach</a>, like us on <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/GuardianTeacherNetwork/\">Facebook</a>, and join the <a href=\"https://profile.theguardian.com/agree/GTNF?returnUrl=https://teachers.theguardian.com/Registration.aspx\">Guardian Teacher Network</a> for lesson resources and the latest articles direct to your inbox</strong></p> <p><strong>Looking for a teaching job?
