          "body": "<p>You\u2019ll all correct me if I\u2019m wrong I know, but I think Malcolm Turnbull is the only person in politics who has ever said to the Sydney broadcaster Alan Jones, on air, <a href=\"http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2014/s4019785.htm\">that he should know his place</a>.<br /></p> <p>\u201cAlan, I am not going to take dictation from you. I am a cabinet minister,\u201d Turnbull said to his 2GB host in the middle of 2014, when he was a cabinet minister.</p> <p>Jones, riled, as he so often is, told Turnbull in the same interview he had \u201cno hope ever of being the leader \u2013 you\u2019ve got to get that into your head: no hope ever.\u201d</p> <p>As the kids might say, yeah/nah, Alan.</p> <p>Turnbull returned successfully to the Liberal party leadership despite Jones\u2019 ominous pronouncement, and it was clear at the time Jones made it that Turnbull had at least a possibility of returning to the leadership, given Tony Abbott had delivered the dog of a budget that would kill his prime ministership.</p> <p>Some pundits would retire hurt if they\u2019d swung that hard with a prediction and come up short, but evidently undeterred by his uneven record as a political soothsayer, Jones this week moved on to the energy minister, Josh Frydenberg, declaring that the political career of the \u201cminister for blackouts\u201d was \u201cfinished\u201d.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-tweet\" data-canonical-url=\"https://twitter.com/AlanJones/status/885231827287384064\">  <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"><p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">I&#39;ve known the Minister for Blackouts, Josh Frydenberg for years. Josh- you are out... your political career is finished. <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/auspol?src=hash\">#auspol</a> <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/energy?src=hash\">#energy</a></p>&mdash; Alan Jones (@AlanJones) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/AlanJones/status/885231827287384064\">July 12, 2017</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <p>It\u2019s a bit hard to know what this statement means, given Frydenberg is one of the most irrepressible people I\u2019ve ever encountered in political life.</p> <p>He\u2019s like the Energiser Bunny. Eddie Everywhere. My observation of him as a parliamentarian suggests Frydenberg was born to the life, is playing the long game, and has absolutely no plans to go anywhere. </p> <p>It\u2019s just verbiage in other words. It\u2019s empty, shock jock, swagger; sound and fury, signifying nothing.</p> <p>So how about I say for our elected representatives what many of them feel but won\u2019t say publicly \u2013 Alan Jones, who on earth do you think you are?</p> <p>Just in case it\u2019s not obvious, the answer to that question is simple. You are some guy with a show on the wireless. That\u2019s the long and short of it.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/may/31/josh-frydenberg-predicts-big-battles-within-coalition-after-finkel-review\">Josh Frydenberg predicts 'big battles' within Coalition after Finkel review</a> </p> </aside>  <p>You are not God, or Einstein, or the person who is going to cure cancer, or even a number in the Liberal party room, or a cabinet minister, or a party leader, who might be able to determine whether or not Frydenberg\u2019s career is finished.</p> <p>You are some guy on the radio.</p> <p>That\u2019s it, Alan.</p> <p>Look I\u2019m sure you do good in the world, I\u2019m sure you\u2019ve got dear friends and loved ones and people who think you are marvellous, but a bloke on the radio is who you are.</p> <p>You cannot giveth and taketh away. You can just manufacture a migraine-inducing cacophony, interspersed with the odd musical theatre review, and call it a breakfast show.</p> <p>A busy week for Alan this week. As well as writing off Josh Frydenberg, he told the News South Wales premier, Gladys Berejiklian, she had \u201cput her head in a noose\u201d by <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/jul/12/shenhua-coalmine-halved-as-nsw-government-buys-back-part-of-mining-licence\">not cancelling the Shenhua Watermark coalmine</a>.</p> <p>Jones built up to his charming lynch mob metaphor with a monologue running almost to 15 minutes, which the premier periodically punctuated with, \u201cBut Alan, please ...\u201d \u201cAlan, can I ...\u201d \u201cAlan, can I say this ...\u201d \u201cAlan, with all due respect ...\u201d</p> <p>For his part, Jones couldn\u2019t \u201clisten to this stupidity ...\u201d He had <em>better things to do</em>. (How hilarious \u2013 what better thing to do than bring the premier on your program and show her who is boss? Isn\u2019t that the crux of the whole enterprise?) \u201cGladys can you get this into your head ...\u201d</p> <p>Not content with shouting over the top of the most powerful woman in NSW, Jones found another woman who had failed to measure up: \u201cI noticed yesterday that the new head of the Australian Energy Market Operator said they basically have a direct impact on energy prices.\u201d</p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s a woman,\u201d he said, presumably, in case that was unclear.</p> <p>(Need we go on? I\u2019m afraid we must.) </p> <p>\u201cThe woman is Audrey Zibelman and she says the Finkel review identifies a number of changes that need to be made to ensure system security and we really need to get on with it. Now this woman is full of rubbish.</p> <p>\u201cFrom her comments on the public record, the woman is a global warming advocate and a promoter of wind turbines. She says of Finkel, let\u2019s get on with it. This is the woman Zibelman. She should have been sacked yesterday. She should have never been appointed.\u201d</p> <p>And so it went on.</p> <p>The woman Zibelman was \u201cideologically constipated\u201d. She was a Turnbull appointment. \u201cTurnbull is the prime minister. You see they can get away with this stuff. That woman, watch for her, she should be run out of town.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/jul/12/shenhua-coalmine-halved-as-nsw-government-buys-back-part-of-mining-licence\">Shenhua coalmine scaled back as NSW government buys back part of licence</a> </p> </aside>  <p>That woman. Prime ministers, pissants that they are, getting away with this stuff, having power, appointing people, running the country. Imagine the cheek.</p> <p>Champagne radio. Why bother with facts when you can do rolling rage?</p> <p>This week there was some quiet but illuminating discussion in political circles about <a href=\"https://meanjin.com.au/essays/political-life/\">an essay I\u2019ve written for the latest edition of Meanjin</a> about the toxic culture of Australian politics.</p> <p>The life I describe in the essay is borderline unbearable. A lot of the current inhabitants of #auspol privately agree.</p> <p>Part of the reason political life is borderline unbearable is because the line between reason and unreason in public discourse sometimes feels gossamer thin. We are saturated with ranting which generates heat, but no light. This hot house ranting is taking place inside bespoke bubbles.</p> <p>Inside our various, populist, or ideologically driven, or vengeful gated communities, tribal wars are raging in this country, and there is a competition to see who can be the most outrageous.</p> <p>The public at large is switching off, fancying they won\u2019t be any the worse for it. The sad truth is they are right.</p> <p>So what can we do?</p> <p>Well, for a start, Alan can be left to his own devices. Prime ministers, premiers and ministers don\u2019t need to consent to be raw meat thrown to a lion. They can respect their office, even if Jones doesn\u2019t.</p> <p>The time they spend trying to placate Alan on the radio could be put to better use, liking looking after the interests of the people who vote them into office, and being seen to look after those interests.</p> <p>If Alan is troublesome because <a href=\"http://www.smh.com.au/comment/alan-jones-paul-murray-ray-hadley-friends-the-coalition-could-do-without-20170707-gx743f.html\">he\u2019s got a direct line to the Coalition base</a>, then centre right politicians need to examine how they create their own direct line to the base. These things are not impossible, particularly not in this day and age. They just take work.</p> <p>As to the broader problem of politics as endless seminar, that\u2019s a tougher nut to crack.</p> <p>The deputy prime minister, Barnaby Joyce, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/jul/14/it-just-frustrates-me-barnaby-joyce-hits-out-at-liberal-party-infighting\">had some choice words for his Liberal colleagues</a> this week that they\u2019d do well to reflect on.</p> <p>I\u2019ve known Joyce for a very long time, and I\u2019ve never seen him so frustrated.</p> <p>He told me the feedback he was getting out in the regions is visceral. \u201cThey look at political candidates and say \u2018Have you ever actually lived, mate? Do you know what it\u2019s like to not have any money in your wallet? Do you know what it\u2019s like to think, shit, I want a life with dignity and I\u2019m on the pension, and I can\u2019t actually afford food, so how do I do this and keep my dignity in this town?\u2019 \u201d</p> <p>That\u2019s one hell of a gap for politics to bridge, and there\u2019s really only one antidote.</p> <p>Don\u2019t be drawn into the stupid, noxious bubbles. They waste your time and erode your agency. Remain calm. Focus on the problems that need solving.</p> <p>Stow the endless seminar, the self justification, and apologia \u2013 and get to work.</p>",

          "body": "<p>With the demise of the communist-led countries of eastern Europe and the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact, the world breathed easier and we all felt that we would no longer stand permanently on the edge of a nuclear Armageddon. The post-cold war escalation of Nato activities and the encirclement of Russia threatens, once again, to take us back to those precarious times (<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/27/uk-to-deploy-hundreds-of-troops-and-aircraft-to-eastern-europe\" title=\"\">800 UK troops join Nato force</a>, 27 October). One doesn\u2019t have to be an apologist for Putin to recognise that Russia is being demonised and the recent reinforcement of Nato troops in Estonia and Romania will only increase Russia\u2019s fear of western intentions and ratchet up the danger of conflict.</p> <p>The idea that Putin\u2019s Russia poses a threat to western Europe is a myth concocted by the US and the military-industrial complex in order to assert its worldwide hegemony. Russia\u2019s effective intervention in Syria to prop up Assad and to prevent the forces of Islamic fundamentalism taking over does not fit the script written by the US and its allies, so there is a renewed determination to punish them \u2013 an extremely dangerous tactic that could backfire catastrophically. We need to demand that our government plays no role in this unnecessary escalation.<br /><strong>John Green</strong><br /><em>London</em></p> <p>\u2022 You report that \u201ctensions between Nato members and Russia have been heightened since Moscow annexed Crimea in 2014 and Ukraine descended into civil war as a result\u201d. I would like to stress the importance of using correct wording when describing the situation in eastern Ukraine so that readers are not misled about the real essence of the conflict.</p> <p>The international community, including organisations such as the UN, EU, OSCE and the Council of Europe have clearly recognised that there is nothing but Russian aggression against Ukraine which has led to the illegal annexation of Crimea and the military aggression in the east of Ukraine. In total, Russia has occupied 47,000 sq km of Ukrainian territories which is more than the territory of a number of European states.<br /><strong>Natalia Galibarenko</strong><br /><em>Ambassador of Ukraine to the UK</em></p> <p>\u2022 Your article \u201c<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/24/cold-war-20-how-russia-and-the-west-reheated-a-historic-struggle\" title=\"\">Cold war 2.0</a>\u201d (25 October) suggested that \u201cextended sanctions could weaken Putin\u2019s grip on power\u201d. My impression was that this had been western policy towards Russia for more than 10 years now, during which time President Putin\u2019s popularity within the country has never fallen below 60% and at present \u201clanguishes\u201d at 82%. I think it was Einstein who defined insanity as \u201cdoing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results\u201d.<br /><strong>Paul Hewitson</strong><br /><em>Berlin, Germany</em></p> <p>\u2022 Your article\u201cCold war 2.0\u201d refers to \u201cthe day after Russia annexed Crimea from Ukraine\u201d. But, as was reported at the time, the Crimean parliament had declared independence from Ukraine following a plebiscite, then petitioned the Russian duma to be reincorporated into Russia, which was duly granted. One\u00a0may or may not approve of how this all happened, but the process was different to what your writers imply.<br /><strong>Prof Robin Milner-Gulland</strong><br /><em>Washington, West Sussex </em></p> <p><strong><em>\u2022 Join the debate \u2013 email </em></strong><a href=\"mailto:guardian.letters@theguardian.com\" title=\"\"><strong><em>guardian.letters@theguardian.com</em></strong></a></p>",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/books/2016/sep/17/spies-in-the-congo-susan-williams-review",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>Where did the US get the uranium it needed to build the atom bombs it dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki? From a mine somewhere in the US? In Canada? My guess is that not many people know, or have even asked. The answer lies deep in the heart of Africa. It was extracted from the Shinkolobwe mine in then Belgian Congo, owned by Union Mini\u00e8re, part of the mother country\u2019s biggest and wealthiest company, Soci\u00e9t\u00e9 G\u00e9n\u00e9rale de Belgique. Without access to that mine, the atom bomb might never have been built by American scientists during the second world war.</p> <p>Susan Williams\u2019s last book, <em>Who Killed Hammarskj\u00f6ld?</em>, prompted the UN to set up a new inquiry into<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/14/un-inquiry-1961-dag-hammarskjold-air-crash\"> the death \u2013 in a plane crash in Northern Rhodesia \u2013 of its former secretary general</a>. Her new, meticulously researched book has shades of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/grahamgreene\">Graham Greene</a>, a hint of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/josephconrad\">Conrad</a>, even echoes of <em>Indiana Jones</em>.</p> <p>Using newly opened archives and personal interviews, she describes how the American <a href=\"https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/intelligence-history/oss/art03.htm\">Office of Strategic Services</a> (OSS) \u2013 forerunner of the CIA \u2013 recruited a motley band to ensure the uranium reached the US and did not fall into the hands of Nazi Germany. The group of hand-picked officers included two ornithologists \u2013 good training, perhaps, for a spy. They posed as rubber prospectors or investigators of diamond smugglers. The word \u201curanium\u201d never passed their lips: instead, even in coded telegrams, they referred to \u201craw material\u201d, \u201cdiamonds\u201d, or, simply, \u201cgems\u201d.They were not told why the US was so desperate to secure a regular supply of the high-grade uranium ore. Not even Wilbur Owings Hogue, the OSS station chief in Belgian Congo, described by Williams as \u201ca very clever civil engineer with a self-deprecating sense of humour\u201d, was told.</p> <p>Their task was made more difficult and dangerous by pro-German sentiments among some of the Belgian industrialists and colonists in the Congo. Union Mini\u00e8re had already sold significant amounts of uranium ore to Germany. (Williams points to what was happening in Belgium itself, where businesses were dealing with their German occupiers: in 1943 alone, Belgian firms delivered 155 locomotives to Germany.) However, the US had a key ally in <a href=\"http://www.atomicheritage.org/profile/edgar-sengier\">Edgar Sengier</a>, head of Union Mini\u00e8re\u2019s New York-based operations, who after the war was awarded the medal for merit, which was then the US government\u2019s highest civilian award.</p> <p>In Congo, many businessmen were waiting to see who looked like winning the war before committing themselves to the Allies. Senior Belgian officials were themselves involved in diamond smuggling, sometimes in Red Cross parcels, for their personal benefit. There were always doubts about their loyalties; few could be trusted. Using diamond smuggling as cover for their true role remained a potentially fatal strategy for OSS officers. Hogue\u2019s life was threatened more than once, as a result of leaks from a Belgian journalist he recruited as an informer.</p> <p>Williams contrasts the luxurious living of Congo\u2019s white inhabitants with the brutal treatment of the black population. She describes how, on his first day there, a US code officer was faced with the sight of a Congolese man in ragged shorts, kneeling on the ground, with a Belgian official standing over him with a <em>chicotte</em> \u2013 a whip made of leather thongs with a metal end. \u201cEvery lash was followed by a scream of agony,\u201d the US officer recorded. \u201cWhen the prescribed number of lashes had been delivered, the black\u2019s skin from neck to waist was a mass of blood with ribs shining through.\u201d The officer was told it was punishment for stealing a packet of cigarettes from a Belgian.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>The moral authority of the struggle against fascism was not applied to the inequalities and injustice in the Congo</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Soon after the end of the war, in November 1945, strikers protesting at terrible living and working conditions in L\u00e9opoldville (now Kinshasa, capital of Democratic Republic of the Congo) and the port of Matadi (through which much of the uranium was shipped) were killed along with women and children. \u201cThe moral authority of the struggle against fascism was not applied to the inequalities and injustice in the Congo,\u201d Williams writes. Workers at the Shinkolobwe mine were not protected at all from radiation.</p> <p>If I have a quibble about <em>Spies in the Congo</em> it is that, on occasion, dense \u2013 albeit rich \u2013 detail slows down the pace of what is truly a thriller, in which Williams paints clear and sympathetic pictures of characters thrust into a totally unfamiliar territory.</p> <p>She opens her book with a letter Albert Einstein wrote to President Roosevelt on 2 August 1939, alerting him to the possibility of constructing a powerful bomb turning uranium into a new and important source of energy. \u201cThe most important source of uranium is Belgian Congo,\u201d Einstein wrote.</p> <p>There is another terrible legacy, aside from the bombs dropped on Japan, at the source of that uranium. Radioactive waste at Shinkolobwe has led to birth defects and cancers. After the collapse of a mineshaft, the UN asked the International Atomic Energy Agency to <a href=\"http://www.unep.org/Documents.Multilingual/Default.asp?DocumentID=412&amp;ArticleID=4661&amp;l=en\">investigate conditions there</a>. Its study found that 6,000 small-scale miners had been digging for coltan and cobalt: everyone working there was at risk of developing health problems because of high levels of radiation.</p> <p>\u201cShinkolobwe has never been commemorated,\u201d the Congolese journalist Oliver Tshinyoka noted last year \u2013 the 70th anniversary of the atom bomb attacks on Japan. This book might help to change that.<br /></p> <p><strong>\u2022 </strong><em>Spies in the Congo: the Race for the Ore That Built the Atomic Bomb </em>is published by Hurst. To order a copy for \u00a325 go to <a href=\"https://bookshop.theguardian.com/spies-in-the-congo.html?utm_source=editoriallink&amp;utm_medium=merch&amp;utm_campaign=article\">bookshop.theguardian.com</a> or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&amp;p over \u00a310, online orders only. Phone orders min p&amp;p of \u00a31.99.</p>",

          "body": "<p>For a while, I had the perfect tagline on my dating profile, and it was all thanks to <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/dec/28/carrie-fisher-best-quotes-wisdom\">the wit of Carrie Fisher</a>: \u201cInstant gratification takes too long.\u201d</p> <p>It alerted me to the dimmer bulbs in the chandelier. \u201cYour tagline makes no sense. What could be quicker than instant?\u201d Blocked! <br /></p> <p>But: \u201cGreat Postcards from the Edge quote there\u201d = date request! <br /></p> <p>Alas, that led to little success so I\u2019m again taking Fisher\u2019s advice, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2017/jan/09/golden-globes-2017-quotes-of-the-night\">as echoed by Meryl Streep</a> this month: \u201cTake your broken heart, make it into art.\u201d The art I\u2019ve decided to make is to discover the world\u2019s best one-liner. This one\u2019s for you, Carrie:</p> <p>Some one-liners are so great, they\u2019ve become their own cliches. Some characters deserve their own category for speaking almost exclusively in them - take a bow, Oscar Wilde, Dorothy Parker, Groucho Marx, Mae West, Mark Twain, Maya Angelou.</p> <p>What makes a great one-liner? Certainly not an inspirational quote in an infuriatingly pretty font over an evocative filtered landscape. They are more likely to be bawdy, rambunctious and not always kind. The edge makes them memorable, although that\u2019s not to say they can\u2019t be profound. </p> <p>Straight-up humour isn\u2019t enough: the funniest one-liners have a sardonic, sarcastic or even bitchy undertone. The dreamier ones need a tinge of sadness or bitterness. Those offering guidance need to insinuate it\u2019s advice the author of the phrase wistfully - or bitterly - wishes they\u2019d taken themselves. Concision is essential. <br /></p> <p>Some wordplay will make the \u2018inspirational\u2019 one liner forgivable for its linguistic merit. Don\u2019t state the bleeding obvious: tell us something counterintuitive, or something that reveals the grit of your struggle and how you\u2019ve mastered words as your response.</p> <p>Retorts are out; if you need someone to rack up a line for you to knock down, then strictly speaking that isn\u2019t a one-liner. It should include all its wit, grit and tips in that standalone line. Metaphors, self-deprecation and genuine poignancy are in.</p> <p>With those criteria in mind, here\u2019s my - unapologetically subjective - stab at the shortlist of the world\u2019s greatest one-liners of all time:</p> <p><strong>Self-deprecating</strong><br />\u201cIt costs a lot of money to look this cheap\u201d - Dolly Parton<br />\u201cI used to be Snow White, but I drifted\u201d - Mae West<br />\u201cMy face looks like a wedding cake left out in the rain\u201d - WH Auden</p> <p><strong>Wordplay</strong><br />\u201cI can resist everything, except temptation\u201d - Oscar Wilde<br />\u201cBetter to be looked over than overlooked\u201d - Mae West<br />\u201cThere are two kinds of people in the world: Those who believe there are two kinds of people in the world and those who don\u2019t\u201d - Robert Benchley</p> <p><strong>Perceptive</strong><br />\u201cIf you can\u2019t explain it to a six-year-old, you don\u2019t understand it yourself\u201d \u2013 Albert Einstein<br />\u201cFaith: not wanting to know what is true\u201d - Friedrich Nietzsche<br />\u201cAnything that is too stupid to be spoken is sung\u201d - Voltaire<br />\u201cCopy from one, it\u2019s plagiarism; copy from two, it\u2019s research\u201d - Wilson Mizner<br />\u201cMoral indignation is jealousy with a halo\u201d - HG Wells</p> <p><strong>Sardonic</strong><br />\u201cI\u2019ve had a perfectly wonderful evening, but this wasn\u2019t it\u201d - Groucho Marx<br />\u201cEvery love\u2019s the love before in a duller dress\u201d - Dorothy Parker<br />\u201cWar is God\u2019s way of teaching Americans geography\u201d - Ambrose Bierce<br />\u201cIf you haven\u2019t got anything nice to say about anybody, come sit next to me\u201d - Alice Roosevelt Longworth (and Olympia Dukakis in Steel Magnolias, of course)</p> <p><strong>Underrated</strong><br />\u201cHappiness makes up in height what it lacks in length\u201d - Robert Frost<br />\u201cIf you think education is expensive, try ignorance\u201d - Derek Bok</p> <p><strong>Just brilliant</strong><br />\u201cYou can lead a horticulture, but you can\u2019t make her think\u201d - Dorothy Parker<br />\u201cThere is only one thing in the world worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about\u201d - Oscar Wilde </p> <p><strong>Advice</strong><br />\u201cWhen someone shows you who they are believe them; the first time\u201d - Maya Angelou<br />\u201cWhen you\u2019re going through hell, keep going\u201d - Winston Churchill<br />\u201cBefore you leave the house, look in the mirror and take one thing off\u201d - Coco Chanel<br /></p> <p><strong>Poignant</strong><br />\u201cSometimes the questions are complicated and the answers are simple\u201d - Dr Seuss<br />\u201cAt 18 our convictions are hills from which we look; at 45 they are caves in which we hide\u201d - F Scott Fitzgerald</p> <p><strong>Inspirational</strong><br />\u201cWe are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars\u201d - Oscar Wilde<br />\u201cIt is never too late to be what you might have been\u201d - George Eliot<br />\u201cNo one can make you feel inferior without your consent\u201d \u2013 Eleanor Roosevelt<br />\u201cIf everything is under control, you are going too slow\u201d - Mario Andretti</p> <p><strong>I can relate</strong><br />\u201cBeing a writer is like having homework every night for the rest of your life\u201d - Lawrence Kasdan</p> <p><strong>I\u2019d best wrap this up because:</strong><br />\u201cHe that uses many words for explaining any subject, doth, like the cuttlefish, hide himself for the most part in his own ink\u201d - John Ray</p> <p><strong>And finally, take all these with a pinch of salt because:</strong><br />\u201cThe aphorism is a personal observation inflated into a universal truth, a private posing as a general\u201d - Stefan Kanfer</p> <p>What do you think is the world\u2019s best one-liner?</p> <p><em>Gary Nunn is a regular contributor to Mind your language. Twitter: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/GaryNunn1\">@garynunn1</a></em></p>",

          "body": "<p>Nothing says I\u2019m over it like riding on to the Brixton Academy stage <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IAgU_c3qaiE\">on a unicorn with a neon mane</a>, wearing glitterball trousers and a fruit codpiece and flinging handfuls of glitter from Barbarella\u2019s handbag.</p> <p> While your mind de-boggles, some context: the 2013 album The Terror by Oklahoma\u2019s legendary psychpop experimentalists the Flaming Lips was a work coloured in dark and anguished tones by singer <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/jan/12/flaming-lips-wayne-coyne-on-miley-cyrus-acid-asap-rocky\">Wayne Coyne</a>\u2019s split from his partner of 25 years. On a tour to support the album, Coyne spent much of the show atop a podium of pulsating umbilical cords singing songs of paranoia and despair like some doleful B-movie overlord from Planet X. For a band renowned for joyous psychedelic extravaganzas, it made for cold and unsettling viewing, their 35-year good trip finally turning bad.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/jan/12/the-flaming-lips-oczy-mlody-album-review\">The Flaming Lips: Oczy Mlody review \u2013 some of their prettiest music in years</a> </p> </aside>  <p> Though the band\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/jan/12/the-flaming-lips-oczy-mlody-album-review\">new album, Oczy Mlody</a>, echoes the sparse, forlorn experimentalism of The Terror, Coyne has thankfully conceded that the Lips work best live in their traditional form as the embodiment of cartoon psychedelia, perhaps after stern words from <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UVmMEcXCy_A\">new best mate Miley Cyrus</a>. So tonight we\u2019re back at rock\u2019s greatest acid punch party, a surreal cross between the Magical Mystery Tour, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/aug/14/noel-fieldings-luxury-comedy-gets-funnier-the-more-it-apologises-for-its-own-rubbishness\">Noel Fielding\u2019s Luxury Comedy</a> and the sort of ecstatic ticker-tape inauguration parade that was going on in Donald Trump\u2019s head.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"d3a08ca20244d51932e4fbabc2c6643a4b96223a\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/d3a08ca20244d51932e4fbabc2c6643a4b96223a/0_300_5760_3456/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Flaming Lips frontman Wayne Coyne in London.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Flaming Lips frontman Wayne Coyne in London.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Simone Joyner/Redferns</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p> At the opening sci-fi overture of Race for the Prize, the venue explodes with balloons, confetti cannons and rainbow visuals as Coyne \u2013 done out like a Tim Burton-Albert Einstein \u2013 throws a huge silver balloon sign reading \u201cFUCK YEAH LONDON\u201d into a crowd peppered with Father Christmases. For a tender acoustic take on Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots: Pt One, he\u2019s flanked by overgrown aliens and goblins and repeatedly hugs an inflatable sun.</p> <p> Come the mangled Beck-in-a-tumble-dryer electro-rock of What Is the Light?, the forest of dot-matrix strings hanging overhead \u2013 let\u2019s call them Rapunzel lights \u2013 descends to stage level so that Coyne, wandering within them, looks as if he\u2019s showering in sine waves. The two-hour show includes light-up gongs, psychedelic nudes and gigantic dancing eyeballs beamed in from an alternate universe in which the Residents are playing stadiums.</p> <p>Disclaimer: no hallucinogens were abused in the making of this review.</p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=unLnJvzf-So\"                                                                        > <iframe width=\"460\" height=\"259\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/unLnJvzf-So?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure>   <p>Songs from their current comedown phase provide amorphous, dream-like counterpoint. On glacial mecha-ballad How??, a crestfallen plea for liberal freedoms that feels all the more hopeless in the face of Donald Trump\u2019s tangerine terror-glare, Coyne sounds as if he\u2019s trapped in one of <a href=\"https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems-and-poets/poems/detail/43991\">Coleridge\u2019s pleasure-dome ice caves</a>, while album highlight The Castle resembles a fanfare for fairytale royalty. And, of course, Coyne sings Dalek chill-out tune There Should Be Unicorns astride a life-sized prop unicorn, having presumably gone skip-diving at Mariah Carey\u2019s house.<br /></p> <p> Whether walking over the crowd in his giant plastic ball singing David Bowie\u2019s Space Oddity, donning a strobe-light medallion for The WAND or leading a concerted effort to break the ceiling by screaming \u201clove\u201d ahead of <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lPXWt2ESxVY\">Do You Realize??</a>, Coyne seems reborn, once again dishing out the purest, most potent dose of feelgood psychedelia imaginable.           "body": "<p>Contrary to most expectations, the Australia-India Test series is proving to be an absolute cracker, with the teams <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/live/2017/mar/20/india-v-australia-third-test-day-five-live\">locked together</a> 1-1 going into the decider that begins on Saturday in Dharamsala. </p> <p>Australian commercial sponsors of sport must always be delighted when the results are close, wherever they are played. Excitement means more viewers, leading to greater brand recognition for the \u201c<a href=\"https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/who-we-are/opportunity-initiatives/opportunity-from-good-business-practice/cricket.html\">proud sponsor</a>\u201d. One of only two \u201c<a href=\"http://www.cricketaustralia.com.au/\">platinum partners</a>\u201d of Cricket Australia, the Commonwealth Banksponsors the national game at all levels.</p> <p>But if the Commonwealth Bank is really so \u201cproud\u201d of its association with Cricket Australia, why is it investing in projects that endanger the health of Australian cricketers?</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/mar/17/ian-chappell-stands-by-adani-mine-letter-despite-being-called-elitist-by-coalition-mp\">Ian Chappell stands by Adani mine letter despite being called 'elitist' by Coalition MP</a> </p> </aside>  <p>CommBank is the most structurally significant private investor in fossil fuels in Australia. It is Australia\u2019s <a href=\"http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-08/commonwealth-bank-reports-cash-earnings-at-$2.4bn/8004262\">biggest bank</a> by market capitalisation and <a href=\"https://www.marketforces.org.au/2016lending/\">loaned more money to fossil-fuel projects</a> in 2016 than any other Australian bank. These are the same fossil fuels \u2013 coal, oil and gas \u2013 that are the major drivers of global warming, leading to shocking increases in extreme weather, including <a href=\"https://www.climatecouncil.org.au/angry-summer-report\">heatwaves</a>. </p> <p>Although cricket is a summer sport, extreme heat is no joke for cricketers, as anyone who has played the game in such conditions can confirm. </p> <p>There are well-known examples of the effect of extreme heat on cricketers. After compiling an extraordinarily brave double century against India in the tied Test at Chennai in 1985, Australian batsman Dean Jones <a href=\"http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/605597.html\">described</a> what it was like to bat in infernal conditions: \u201cWhen you\u2019re urinating in your pants and vomiting 15 times, you\u2019ve got massive problems.\u201d </p> <p>When finally dismissed for 210, Jones was taken to hospital on a saline drip.</p> <p>Physical activity in extreme heat can lead to severe health problems, including fatalities. According to the <a href=\"https://www.climatecouncil.org.au/silentkillerreport\">Climate Council</a>, heatwaves have killed more Australians than any other natural hazards and have caused more deaths since 1890 than bushfires, cyclones, earthquakes, floods and severe storms combined.</p> <p>Although they have always been with us in Australia, extremely hot days are now far more frequent. Just a couple of weeks ago, all grade cricket matches in Sydney were <a href=\"http://www.cricketnsw.com.au/news/heatwave/2017-02-10\">cancelled</a> for what was <a href=\"http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/cricket/heat-takes-toll-with-all-sydney-grade-cricket-at-the-weekend-called-off/news-story/6cf610b825afc664f7b7f6ebab984f30\">reported</a> to be the first time in the competition\u2019s history, in order to protect the welfare of players, umpires and volunteers from the extreme heat which scientists say was <a href=\"https://www.climatecouncil.org.au/angry-summer-report\">driven</a> by global warming. </p> <p>As Cricket NSW doctor John Orchard noted, \u201cgrade cricket does not have the infrastructure in place to safely monitor and manage heatstroke in what is essentially an amateur, volunteer-run organisation\u201d.</p> <p>The disproportionate impact of extreme heat on amateur cricket is particularly ironic, given CommBank\u2019s recent \u201crealignment\u201d of its sponsorship of Cricket Australia (explained <a href=\"http://mcsaatchi.com.au/work/cba-cricket/\">here</a> in a briefing by Saatchi) to a greater focus on support for the game at a community level. </p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2017/mar/20/elon-musk-port-augusta-four-renewable-energy-projects\">Elon Musk, meet Port Augusta: four renewable energy projects ready to go</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The Commonwealth Bank\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.commbank.com.au/about-us/docs/sustainability-20151103-group-environment-policy.pdf\">group environment policy</a> publicly supports the 2015 Paris Agreement and its goal of limiting global warming to well below 2C. Yet CommBank remains the most structurally important private investor in fossil fuels in Australia. Commonwealth Bank chief executive officer, Ian Narev, in giving <a href=\"http://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Hansard/Hansard_Display?bid=committees/commrep/25c45154-53de-4c1b-956a-8142c25709b4/&amp;sid=0001\">evidence before the parliamentary inquiry</a> into the banks on 7 March 2016, was not able to give a single example of a project that had been refused finance because of the bank\u2019s commitment to the emissions targets in the Paris Agreement. </p> <p>CommBank has not even ruled out providing finance to Adani\u2019s Carmichael coalmine, which is incompatible with both a 2C target and the survival of the Great Barrier Reef. </p> <p><a href=\"http://mcsaatchi.com.au/work/cba-cricket/\">According</a> to Saatchi, the brand promise of CommBank is \u201cenablement for all Australians\u201d, but global warming threatens the mass disabling of our human potential. If CommBank doesn\u2019t want its brand to be associated with cricket matches being cancelled and players collapsing or pissing in their pants from heatstroke \u2013 quite apart from the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/great-barrier-reef\">bleaching of the Great Barrier Reef</a> and all the broader impacts of global warming \u2013 then it is time to get out of investing in fossil fuels.</p> <p>Last week two former Australian cricket captains \u2013 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/mar/16/ian-and-greg-chappell-call-on-adani-to-abandon-carmichael-mine-project\">Ian and Greg Chappell</a> \u2013 were among 91 prominent signatories to a letter calling on Adani to abandon the Carmichael mine project. </p> <p>In explaining his opposition to Adani\u2019s plans, Ian Chappell <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/mar/17/ian-chappell-stands-by-adani-mine-letter-despite-being-called-elitist-by-coalition-mp\">said</a> \u201cyou don\u2019t need to be Einstein when you see the frequency and the ferocity of some of the weather events that we\u2019ve been having\u201d.</p> <p> If CommBank wants the trust of cricketers and cricket lovers of Australia, it needs to rule out any future involvement with the Carmichael mine and stop investing in the fossil fuel projects which threaten the health and enjoyment of all those who play and support our national game.</p> <p><em>\u2013 David Ritter is the CEO of Greenpeace Australia Pacific</em></p>",

          "body": "<p>The president-elect might hate Hollywood but he just pulled a classic old Hollywood move: like a glowering, cigar-chewing studio head, Donald Trump has hired his son-in-law. Jared Kushner, married to Ivanka Trump, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/09/jared-kushner-senior-adviser-donald-trump\" title=\"\">has been appointed his senior adviser</a>, and transition officials have solemnly announced that they have received \u201clegal counsel\u201d to ensure that this does not violate US anti-nepotism law.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jan/11/europe-loved-obama-trump-us-president-democracy\">Europe loved Obama. Trump\u2019s excesses remind us precisely why | Anne Perkins</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Perhaps the counsel amounted to a careful, syllable-by-syllable scrutiny of Richard Nixon\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HiHN3IJ_j8A\" title=\"\">classic maxim</a>: \u201cWhen the president does it, that means that it is not illegal.\u201d In 1933 the MGM studio chief <a href=\"http://www.hollywoodsgoldenage.com/moguls/mayer.html\" title=\"\">Louis B Mayer</a> hired his son-in-law <a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/learning/general/onthisday/bday/0510.html\" title=\"\">David O Selznick</a> to run a production unit. Selznick was of course very talented, but his elevation inspired the eternal Hollywood gag: The Son-in-Law Also Rises.</p> <p>The favoured relative inspires suspicion and resentment in the hearts of colleagues \u2013 and finally, mysteriously, in the heart of the aged patron himself. Perhaps Kushner pondered the career of <a href=\"http://ww2today.com/23rd-december-1943-galeazzo-cianos-last-reflections-before-execution\" title=\"\">Count Galeazzo Ciano</a>, who married <a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/10/obituaries/edda-ciano-84-daughter-disavowed-mussolini-for-count.html\" title=\"\">Mussolini\u2019s daughter Edda</a>, became foreign minister, but was eventually imprisoned by his father-in-law and sentenced to death by firing squad. It is said that when Mayer\u2019s business partner Samuel Goldwyn met Albert Einstein, he told him: \u201cI got a theory about relatives, too. Don\u2019t hire them.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>The attitude of gratitude</strong></h2> <p>I have in the past reflected on the phenomenon of the \u201cthankbrag\u201d, a cousin to the humblebrag, generally deployed on social media in a spirit of effusive humility. (\u201cThanks so much to everyone for all your lovely comments about my recent article\u201d; \u201cThanks so much to the fans whose support inspires me and have put my new album/film/TV show/dating app straight in at number one\u201d.) It was while gobbling down fiction over Christmas and New Year that I realised that acknowledgments sections are the source of some world-class thankbrags.</p> <p>After powering through <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/sep/24/conclave-by-robert-harris-review\" title=\"\">Robert Harris\u2019s addictive and gripping thriller, Conclave</a>, about the election of a new pope, I chanced upon the following: \u201cAt the outset of my research I asked the Vatican for permission to visit the locations used during a conclave that are permanently closed to the public. I am grateful to Monsignor Guillermo Karcher of the Office for the Liturgical Celebrations of the Supreme Pontiff for arranging my visit.\u201d Does that mean permission was granted? And that the author saw things denied to \u201cthe public\u201d? I guess so. In which case: what\u2019s the point of hiding your light under a bushel and thanking Monsignor Karcher for general unspecified help? If anyone has earned thankbragging rights, it\u2019s Harris.</p> <h2><strong>Sausages and shame</strong></h2> <p>In <a href=\"http://www.lrb.co.uk/v39/n01/alan-bennett/diary\" title=\"\">his annual London Review of Books diary</a>, Alan Bennett has put his finger on a contemporary nightmare: stuffing yourself at the hotel breakfast buffet. If you\u2019ve got bed-and-breakfast inclusive rates, the temptation to go mad is sometimes overwhelming: \u201cSome of the well-to-do guests can\u2019t wait to get the food back from the breakfast bar to their table, one young man downing a tumbler of orange juice en route and a boy stuffing himself with sausages before he even sits down.\u201d</p> <p>Comedian <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/dec/08/michael-mcintyre-big-show-saturday-night-tv\" title=\"\">Michael McIntyre</a> has also commented on middle-class behaviour at the breakfast buffet: how guests feel the urge to sit down at their tables pointlessly for a microsecond, before jumping up and galloping over to the eggs and bacon. At many a film festival I have disgraced myself by trying to curate, secretly, two separate picnic meals for lunch and dinner from the breakfast buffet \u2013 casually draping magazines and papers over my table so the disorder supposedly disguises the activity of wrapping bananas and slices of Parma ham in various paper napkins. Oh, the shame of it.</p>",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/science/brain-flapping/2016/mar/01/the-myth-of-the-know-it-all-scientist",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>I\u2019m currently in the middle of a publicity campaign for my first book, <a href=\"http://www.amazon.co.uk/Idiot-Brain-Neuroscientist-Explains-Really/dp/1783350814/ref=sr_1_1_twi_pap_2?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1456776153&amp;sr=1-1\">The Idiot Brain</a>. And yes, that previous sentence is part of it. It\u2019s about all the things the human brain does weirdly, illogically and just plain wrong. As a result, I\u2019ve ended up talking to a lot of people about the brain, from <a href=\"http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b070fdhv\">Libby Purves</a> to <a href=\"http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p03kc6jn\">Steve Wright</a> to <a href=\"https://amp.twimg.com/v/dea2bb5e-0ef3-4dca-85f2-32b43b2e5a1c\">Tim Lovejoy</a>, so I\u2019ve been asked many questions about it. </p> <p>However, these people are professionals; it\u2019s when you take questions from the general public or more \u201calternative\u201d media, that\u2019s when things get bizarre. My favourites so far are:</p> <ul> <li>Which are smarter, tigers or wolves?<br /></li> <li>How does astrology work?<br /></li> <li>Do we have free will or not?<br /></li> <li>Why do I have epilepsy?<br /></li> <li>What\u2019s up with vaccines?<br /></li> <li>My laptop wasn\u2019t working and I had a dream about how to fix it, and I tried the fix and it worked, so how did that happen?<br /></li> </ul> <p>Technically, I\u2019m not trained to answer these question (assuming answers even exist). For the record, <a href=\"http://orca.cf.ac.uk/54380/\">I\u2019ve a PhD in memory processing</a>. Obviously, if I\u2019m going to put myself out there as an authority on things then I should expect questions. A fair point. </p> <p>However, even during school and university, I\u2019d regularly get asked things I had no ability to answer. They often weren\u2019t even about neuroscience, but things like \u201chow do radio waves travel through space?\u201d, or \u201cif evolution is true, why don\u2019t people have wings?\u201d (That last one is real). </p> <p>Other scientists I\u2019ve spoken to report similar, regular occurrences. It\u2019s just something people do. If you\u2019re a doctor, people you meet ask you to look at their rashes/lumps. If you\u2019re a comedian, people you meet say \u201ctell us a joke\u201d. And if you\u2019re a scientist, people assume you know <em>all</em> science, something which would likely require several lifetimes of study. </p> <p>In truth, most <a href=\"http://matt.might.net/articles/phd-school-in-pictures/\">professional scientists are very specialist</a>. This is true for most fields of expertise. If you meet a professional historian who specialises in the Victorian era, asking them how ancient Egyptians stored their grain would be illogical. Maybe this does happen to historians? I can\u2019t say. It happens to scientists though. </p> <p>So where does this \u201cscientists know all science\u201d preconception come from? And why does it persist? As ever, there are numerous possible contenders.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"8ad3dd47f5d520322b285e1aee7a9cce1738ce38\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8ad3dd47f5d520322b285e1aee7a9cce1738ce38/0_93_4827_2901/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Human brain, artwork\" width=\"1000\" height=\"601\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Honestly, these things are more trouble than they\u2019re worth.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: SCIEPRO/Getty Images/Science Photo Library RF</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2><strong>The human brain</strong></h2> <p>I <a href=\"http://www.hive.co.uk/Product/Dean-Burnett/The-Idiot-Brain--A-Neuroscientist-Explains-What-Your-Head-is-Really-Up-to/18261495\">just published a book about the brain</a> (did I mention that already?) so I tend to blame it for many of life\u2019s woes. But the ways in which it handles information could lead to this weird preconception of the omniscient scientist. Our brains, in fairness, have to deal with a lot of information, so often uses short cuts and generalisations, things like <a href=\"http://psychology.about.com/od/hindex/g/heuristic.htm\">heuristics</a>. </p> <p>Heuristics are basically the brain\u2019s way of using short cuts when it comes to decision making and problem solving. <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Categorization\">How we categorise the information we encounter is tricky enough as it is</a>, but heuristics help us just clump information together in functionally useful ways. </p> <p>You can see how this would lead to inaccuracies or even <a href=\"https://sites.psu.edu/psych256su14/2014/09/08/12345/\">prejudices</a> though. In this case, if someone struggles to understand science, they would mentally lump the totality of it together as \u201cstuff I don\u2019t understand\u201d. Same goes for encountering scientists, they may label them as \u201cpeople who understand things I don\u2019t\u201d without any of the specifics or nuances of it. </p> <p>However, these preconceptions are likely to originate from somewhere.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"0b36736c08c4446422e3946dafcd805a727a37fd\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/0b36736c08c4446422e3946dafcd805a727a37fd/27_0_3473_2086/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Embargoed to 0001 Tuesday March 1 File photo dated 06/07/11 of children raising their hands to answer a question, as growing teacher shortages are having a damaging impact on children\u2019s education, according to the Association of School and College Leaders (ASCL). PRESS ASSOCIATION Photo. Issue date: Tuesday March 1, 2016.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"601\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u201cWho here has the wrong idea about what scientists are capable of?\u201d</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Dave Thompson/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2><strong>Education</strong></h2> <p>If you study science, you get more and more specific the further you progress. But everyone starts off with the basics, and, in the UK at least, at a young age you get taught \u201cscience\u201d. So you start off with this notion that science is just one \u201cthing\u201d, and have to gradually figure out otherwise. </p> <p>However, despite the <a href=\"http://www.cam.ac.uk/research/discussion/school-starting-age-the-evidence\">debate over what age is best to start formal education</a>, nobody argues that the things you learn at a very young age are extremely important and <a href=\"http://www.livestrong.com/article/150356-how-education-affects-early-child-development/\">shape your development and later life</a>. However, the existence of countless <a href=\"http://www.stemnet.org.uk/\">STEM</a> campaigns and organisations reveals that it\u2019s a lot of work to get children interested in science and related subjects. Would it be surprising then, if many people never really move on from the \u201cscience as one homogenous lump\u201d phase due to a disinterest in science, and regard scientists as interchangeable as a consequence?</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"7cce32ce3751dcdba3dfd59e1cb64c1741dfb52c\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7cce32ce3751dcdba3dfd59e1cb64c1741dfb52c/0_0_3000_1800/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The New Day launchCopies of the UK\u2019s first new stand-alone national newspaper in three decades, The New Day, are seen on sale in central London. PRESS ASSOCIATION Photo. Picture date: Monday February 29, 2016. Monday\u2019s first edition of The New Day features a front page with the headline \u201cStolen childhood\u201d on a splash about the \u201cplight of 40,000 infant carers\u201d. See PA story MEDIA Newspaper. Photo credit should read: Anthony Devlin/PA Wire\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u201cPEER REVIEW IS FOR LOSERS!\u201d</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Anthony Devlin/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2><strong>The media</strong></h2> <p>How scientists are portrayed in the media probably doesn\u2019t help either. Look at any new discovery or development or even just a quirky bit of trivia reported in the mainstream, and it invariably begins with \u201cscientists have discovered\u2026\u201d or \u201cScientists claim\u2026\u201d or \u201cAccording to scientists\u2026\u201d and so on. </p> <p>You seldom get this in any other field. The latest government initiative does not begin with \u201cPoliticians have decided\u2026\u201d The sports news doesn\u2019t tell us that \u201cFootball teams played football yesterday, with around half of them winning\u201d. Any study or finding worth mentioning is invariably attributed to all scientists everywhere, so it\u2019s understandable if the average reader ends up thinking they\u2019re one and the same. </p> <p>There\u2019s also the narrative of <a href=\"http://www.bloomberg.com/bw/articles/2014-04-10/the-myth-of-the-lone-genius\">the \u201clone genius\u201d too</a>, which is a popular one. Your usual lesson or story about scientists typically focus on a single, brilliant (invariably male) intellectual, changing the world via his all-encompassing genius. While this makes for an inspiring narrative, it\u2019s a far cry from the collaborative effort most science is the result of. </p> <p>And this doesn\u2019t even include fictional scientists. <a href=\"http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b018ttws\">Sherlock</a>, <a href=\"http://house.wikia.com/wiki/House,_M.D.\">House MD</a>, <a href=\"http://marvelcinematicuniverse.wikia.com/wiki/Iron_Man\">Tony Stark</a>, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dana_Scully\">Dana Scully</a>, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donatello_(Teenage_Mutant_Ninja_Turtles)\">Donatello</a>, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brains_(Thunderbirds)\">Brains</a>, <a href=\"http://memory-alpha.wikia.com/wiki/Seven_of_Nine\">Seven of Nine</a>, even <a href=\"http://scoobydoo.wikia.com/wiki/Velma_Dinkley\">Velma</a>, it seems you can\u2019t go 10 minutes in pop culture fiction without encountering some genius who knows everything about everything, usually in very helpful and plot-relevant ways. This is bound to rub off on some people in the real world.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"44cd3072e8c153a39bec397d532847caf4795494\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/44cd3072e8c153a39bec397d532847caf4795494/0_70_4096_2456/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Identification of victims of the Vietnam warepa05187376 Biologist and trainer Oliver Krebs (L) explains the specifics of bones of German bodies to Vietnamese scientists in Hamburg, Germany, 29 February 2016. The South-East Asian country wants to identify the remains of hundreds of thousands of victims of the Vietnam war which ended more than forty years ago. EPA/DANIEL BOCKWOLDT\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">White coats, check. Glasses, check. All men, check. Yep, these are definitely scientists. Nobody would disagree.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Daniel Bockwoldt/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2><strong>Other scientists</strong><br /></h2> <p>Of course, this whole thing would be easier if it weren\u2019t for actual scientists actively making matters worse. Some scientists, maybe unintentionally, often make declarations about other fields which don\u2019t stack up with what the evidence says. I know I\u2019ve done it myself in previous posts, judging by the comments I\u2019ve had. I see it often, in pop science books where the author strays into issues of psychology and neuroscience, areas that they aren\u2019t that familiar with but which need to be addressed in order to provide a coherent narrative. In many ways, books are maybe not the best format to communicate how science works. </p> <p>Except mine of course, <a href=\"https://www.waterstones.com/book/the-idiot-brain/dean-burnett/9781783350810\">mine is great</a>. </p> <p>But also, sadly, you get the scientists who achieve influence and prestige (maybe by <a href=\"http://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/32287/title/All-s-Not-Fair-in-Science-and-Publishing/\">taking more credit than they deserve</a>) who start to believe their own press, and end up making declarations about fields beyond their own, using confidence instead of actual awareness of how things work. </p> <p>A very recent example came from the Guardian itself with an <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/27/how-to-raise-a-brilliant-child-without-screwing-them-up\">article by Oliver James</a>, about how genetics don\u2019t influence intelligence. Whatever James\u2019s skills as a psychologist, his genetics knowledge seems, at best, seriously limited, as <a href=\"https://twitter.com/TomChivers/status/704240329751465984\">several</a> <a href=\"https://twitter.com/AdamRutherford/status/704233635893911552\">scientists</a> have pointed out. But he has a platform, so <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2016/feb/10/opinion-vs-facts-why-do-celebrities-so-often-get-it-wrong\">must be right, yeah</a>?</p> <p>Fact is, the idea that scientists know all science is a useful one for many, so isn\u2019t disputed, maybe even actively encouraged. If scientists really did know everything, they\u2019d know how to stop this. But they don\u2019t. So they don\u2019t.</p> <p><em>Dean Burnett is aware that this piece contains a shameful number of book plugs but it\u2019s the only way his publicist would agree to return his family unharmed.         "type": "article",
        "webPublicationDate": "2016-03-01T12:00:46Z",
        "webTitle": "The myth of the know-it-all scientist | Dean Burnett",
        "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2016/mar/01/the-myth-of-the-know-it-all-scientist"

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/science/political-science/2016/apr/08/a-new-network-for-science-advice-in-africa",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>Last month, some of the brightest talents and most exciting advances in African science were on display at the <a href=\"http://gg2016.nef.org/\">Next Einstein Forum</a>. This landmark meeting, initiated by the African Institute of Mathematical Sciences, and held in Senegal, brought together almost 1000 researchers, entrepreneurs, businesses and policymakers from across Africa to celebrate and support the continent\u2019s most promising early-career researchers.</p> <p>A new cadre of fifteen <a href=\"http://nef.org/nef-fellows/\">Next Einstein Fellows</a> and fifty-four ambassadors was announced, and the forum ended with an upbeat <a href=\"http://nef.org/gg2016/dakar-declaration/\">declaration of commitment</a> to Africa\u2019s role in world-leading, locally-relevant science. This was accompanied by a call for greater investment by African governments in STEM education, particularly for young women. The <a href=\"http://www.nature.com/news/africa-s-elite-1.19558  http://www.nature.com/news/africa-s-elite-1.19558  http://www.nature.com/news/africa-s-elite-1.19558\">journal Nature was impressed</a>, noting in an editorial that \u201cthis forum was significant. It showed what powerful commitment there is to be tapped in this emerging generation of young African scientists.\u201d </p> <p>Optimism about science in Africa has <a href=\"http://www.nature.com/news/africa-science-plan-attacked-1.15451 \">ebbed and flowed over recent years</a>, as strategies and targets have emerged with a fanfare, only to be quietly dropped in the face of more pressing priorities. But <a href=\"http://en.unesco.org/node/252168\">UNESCO\u2019s latest global audit of science</a>, published at the end of 2015, concludes that <a href=\"http://www.scidev.net/sub-saharan-africa/r-d/analysis-blog/africa-analysis-continent-science-making-progress.html\">African science is firmly on the rise</a>. The number of journal articles published on the continent rose by sixty per cent from 2008 to 2014. Research investment rose from $12.9 billion in 2007 to $19.9 billion (US dollars) in 2013. Over the same period, R&amp;D expenditure as a percentage of GDP nudged upwards from 0.36 per cent to 0.45 per cent, and the population of active researchers expanded from 150,000 to 190,000. </p> <p>As the volume and quality of African research grows, more attention is being paid to how it is being used, and what structures exist to bring evidence and expertise into decision making. Here, the landscape is uneven. National academies of science are now used as a source of policy advice in several countries. A few (including South Africa, Zambia, Nigeria and Egypt) have appointed science advisory councils. Chief scientists or ministerial advisors are far more rare. A recent review by Thiambi Netshiluvhi of South Africa\u2019s Department of Science and Technology found \u201cinadequate capacity\u201d and \u201cpoor use of diverse structures\u201d for scientific advice in a majority of African countries.</p> <p>Now a new network has been launched to boost capacity at the science-policy interface.<a href=\"http://www.ingsa.org/ingsa-news/ingsa-africa-chapter-under-development/\"> INGSA-Africa</a> is an offshoot of the <a href=\"http://www.ingsa.org/\">International Network for Government Science Advice (INGSA)</a>, itself established in 2014, following the first <a href=\"http://www.ingsa.org/ingsa-news/2014-conference/\">global summit on science advice to governments</a>.</p> <p>With backing from the <a href=\"http://www.icsu.org/icsu-africa/about-icsu-roa/about-us\">International Council for Science</a>, INGSA-Africa aims to support scientists, policymakers, practitioners and national academies to share experience, build capacity and strengthen the use of scientific evidence in policy across the continent. Its launch follows a successful <a href=\"http://www.ingsa.org/ingsa-news/new-south-african-capacity-building-workshop/\">training workshop for early-career scientists</a>, which took place in South Africa at the end of February 2016, with participants from fourteen African countries. </p> <p>That workshop had space for only forty-five scientists, but almost six hundred applied to attend, suggesting a level of unmet demand which INGSA-Africa will try to address. Further training sessions are planned for Senegal, Ethiopia and Egypt, and teaching materials are being developed, using real policy dilemmas to highlight how scientific advice can operate in practice. Several of the founding members of INGSA-Africa will also participate in the next global summit on scientific advice to governments, which will take place <a href=\"http://www.ingsa.org/events/2016-conference/\">in Brussels in September 2016</a>.</p> <p><a href=\"http://nef.org/nef-fellows/tolu-oni/\">Tolu Oni</a> is involved both in INGSA-Africa, as a member of its steering group, and the Next Einstein Forum, as one of its newly appointed fellows. Dr Oni, who works as a senior lecturer in public health medicine at the University of Cape Town, says that science advice is now high on the agenda in South Africa. She wants INGSA-Africa to play a role \u201cin coordinating efforts and developing a more structured, methodological approach to the ways we do it.\u201d Over time, she suggests it \u201chas the potential to become the go-to network for training, so that academies, young academies and others use it to develop the skills of the next generation of scientific advisers. Science advice is a skill and it can be taught.\u201d</p> <p><a href=\"http://www.pmcsa.org.nz/a-short-biography-of-peter-gluckman/\">Sir Peter Gluckman</a>, New Zealand\u2019s chief scientist and founding chair of the International Network for Government Science Advice, agrees: \u201cThere\u2019s no shortage of insight, skill and energy across Africa\u2019s science community that can help to develop robust advisory processes. I\u2019m impressed by the group of scientists who have taken this on, and look forward to INGSA-Africa making an important contribution.\u201d </p> <p>Of course, science in Africa still faces huge challenges of deep inequalities, under-investment, weak infrastructure and brain drain. But as the Next Einstein Forum showcased so well, there are a growing number of people, places and projects that give reasons to be optimistic. And as Africa\u2019s research base strengthens, the next task is to bring more of its evidence and expertise into decision making, in ways that can help to meet local priorities and <a href=\"http://www.globalgoals.org/\">global goals</a>.</p> <p><em><a href=\"https://twitter.com/jameswilsdon\">James Wilsdon</a> is professor of research policy</em><em> in the <a href=\"http://www.sheffield.ac.uk/faculty/social-sciences\">Faculty of Social Sciences at the </a><a>University of Sheffield</a>, and vice-chair of the International Network for Government Science Advice.</em></p>",

          "body": "<p>Charles Darwin\u2019s On the Origin of Species has been voted the most influential academic book ever written, hailed as \u201cthe supreme demonstration of why academic books matter\u201d and \u201ca book which has changed the way we think about everything\u201d.</p> <p>After <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/oct/14/public-vote-for-academic-book-that-changed-the-world\">a list of the top 20 academic books was pulled together</a> by expert academic booksellers, librarians and publishers to mark the inaugural <a href=\"http://acbookweek.com/\">Academic Book Week</a>, the public was asked to vote on what they believed to be the most influential. With titles in the running including A Vindication of the Rights of Woman by Mary Wollstonecraft, George Orwell\u2019s novel Nineteen Eighty-Four, and Adam Smith\u2019s The Wealth of Nations, Darwin\u2019s explanation of his theory of evolution was the public\u2019s overwhelming favourite, with 26% of the vote, said organisers.</p> <p>Professor Andrew Prescott of the University of Glasgow called Darwin\u2019s 1859 study \u201cthe supreme demonstration of why academic books matter\u201d. \u201cDarwin used meticulous observation of the world around us, combined with protracted and profound reflection, to create a book which has changed the way we think about everything \u2013 not only the natural world, but religion, history and society,\u201d he said. \u201cEvery researcher, no matter whether they are writing books, creating digital products or producing artworks, aspires to produce something as significant in the history of thought as Origin of Species.\u201d</p> <p>On the Origin of Species was followed in the public vote by The Communist Manifesto and The Complete Works of Shakespeare, with Plato\u2019s The Republic fourth, and Immanuel Kant\u2019s Critique of Pure Reason fifth - a choice heralded by the Booksellers Association\u2019s Alan Staton. \u201cWe seem to be governed by expediency and doublethink and it\u2019s reassuring to know that Kant\u2019s Categorical Imperative is known and thought important,\u201d he said.</p> <p>Philosopher Roger Scruton agreed. \u201cI am gratified that the Critique of Pure Reason, which must be surely one of the most difficult works of philosophy ever written, should have been chosen as among the most influential of all academic books,\u201d he said of the 18th-century text.</p> <p>\u201cKant set out on an extraordinary task, which was to show the limits of human reasoning, and at the same time to justify the use of our intellectual powers within those limits. The resulting vision, of self-conscious beings enfolded within a one-sided boundary, but always pressing against it, hungry for the inaccessible beyond, has haunted me, as it has haunted many others since Kant first expressed it.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>The top 20</strong></h2> <p><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/news/video/2013/sep/19/stephen-hawking-history-time-simple-video\">A Brief History Using his Dad\u2019s makeshift time machine \u2013 a laptop attached to a tin tub from a garden centre \u2013 Al ( accompanied by his pet hamster, Alan Shearer) tries to stop the seemingly inevitable from happening, therefore preventing the death of his father.</p> <p> This was an extremely enjoyable adventure.           "body": "<p>\u201cIf you want to learn about acting,\u201d the playwright Peter Gill told me, \u201ctalk to Luise Rainer.\u201d</p> <p>\u201cWho\u2019s Luise Rainer?\u201d I asked.</p> <p>Peter corrected my ignorance and told me Rainer, then 99, lived in Vivien Leigh\u2019s old building in Eaton Square, London. I watched The Great Ziegfeld and wrote to her immediately saying I was an actor and would love to meet her. My mother lived nearby and I offered myself up as a neighbour, a potential bearer of milk and biscuits, foolishly imagining a sort of abandoned princess living in penury. I walked to Belgravia and delivered my letter to the building with the blue plaque. Two days later a deep and ancient German voice was on the phone inviting me to tea.</p> <p>When I arrived at the top floor flat in my best suit (not at all the hovel I had imagined, but a bourgeois flat full of paintings and antiques) Luise was approaching slowly down the length of her hallway in her presentation outfit of silk trouser suit and a gold toque. She gave an impatient order to her Filipino maid and then spread her arms wide with a great curious smile and embraced me. She used a walking frame but there was still something jaunty and girlish about her, an attitude sent out from her hips and wrists. An actor to her bones. She set about scolding me for the state of my hair and my disgusting shoes, which she made me leave at the door \u2013 this became routine whenever I visited.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"767bea358c3570fd328518b17fbe997184db635d\"> <img src=\"https://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2015/1/6/1420544973137/67dff06d-4de2-4ae3-a678-53c46ae5b71d-460x276.jpeg\" alt=\"Luise Rainer\" width=\"460\" height=\"276\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Luise celebrates in 2011 after receiving a golden star on the Boulevard of Stars in Berlin.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Soeren Stache/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>In the living room was tea, cheesecake and champagne and, as we talked, with difficulty because of her failing hearing, she held my hand and urged me to fill and refill my champagne glass. She enjoyed the excuse for half a glass and drank it with all the delight of a schoolgirl with forbidden hooch.</p> <p>To my predictable Hollywood questions she gave humorous and well-kept replies. She was kind about her ex-husband Clifford Odets, she didn\u2019t think much of Clark Gable, she adored William Powell and Paul Muni and John Gilbert. \u201cBut I hardly remember, it was all so long ago.\u201d</p> <p>Her eyes turned serious when she spoke about her early theatre days in Germany with Max Reinhardt. At the time I was rehearsing to play Lucio in a touring production of Measure for Measure but the woman clutching my hand had played Isabella in that play under Reinhardt\u2019s direction. <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2013/sep/18/bertolt-brecht-arturo-ui-revival\">Brecht</a> (\u201crevolting man but a great writer\u201d) had written Grusha in The Caucasian Chalk Circle for her.</p> <p>I was embarrassed by the the contrast between my ungainly struggles as an actor and her natural ascent to the heights of the profession. But she knew how to enchant a man and it was almost a relief when she changed the subject to my girlfriends and quizzed me about love and sex, all the time squeezing my hand and laughing with her great eyes. These were favourite subjects and she would counsel me and reprimand me, always referring to her second husband as the perfect man, who had kept her love and faithfulness simply by noticing, but never forbidding, any attachments that she might be forming.</p> <p>She had a startling energy driven by a curiosity that was evidently a factor in her longevity. It was a huge frustration to her that her faculties were failing but her eyes \u2013 those watery lamps that had made her famous \u2013 held out, and she always tried to see the latest exhibitions. She was full of delight about the Hammersh\u00f8i show at the Royal Academy on that first meeting, and she talked about painting as though it sustained her.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"572280f8a07fc5b0b6b282d6ac6e853fc5577dd5\"> <img src=\"https://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2015/1/6/1420545548499/997b7376-c9cc-4955-9230-b8ffdcf36701-460x276.jpeg\" alt=\"Luise Rainer in The Good Earth\" width=\"460\" height=\"276\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">In The Good Earth with Paul Muni in 1937.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Courtesy Everett Collection/Rex Features</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>She showed me her own art in her study, collages of objects, and nearby on a shelf in the corner her two best actress Oscars, won in 1937 (for The Great Ziegfeld) and 1938 (for The Good Earth) \u2013 the year of my dad\u2019s birth, a fact that boggled my mind. And over by the sofa a picture of her arm in arm with Einstein, on the beach. When she spoke about Einstein she was modest about their friendship, remembering above all how much he made her laugh.</p> <p>Her impishness could turn to fierceness in a second. She asked me to take her to the Gauguin exhibition at the Tate and after I picked her up in my car she grew furious at the route I was taking and began to direct me at every turn. <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/jan/16/gauguin-tate-modern-crowds\">At the crowded show</a> I wheeled her about in a wheelchair trying to find a gap to see the paintings through. Luise simply hit anyone in the way, bashing them in the ankles with her walking stick. When they turned around to see who was attacking them the lamps were already lit and fixed on the Tahitians.</p> <p>\u201cQuite flat,\u201d she said afterwards of Gauguin\u2019s efforts.</p> <p>It\u2019s probably not possible to learn how to act by talking to an actor, not over champagne and cheesecake anyhow, but it seemed to me that her strength, which contradicted her demeanour, protected something very delicate inside her. Her eyes expressed a very refined sensibility. Her personal style was simple, almost tomboyish, but her emotions on screen were ornate. To some her acting seems overexpressive or too fraught, but her imagination led to overwhelming identification with the women she played and there was a hard core of truth to it. She would say simply: \u201cYou must be inside the person.\u201d</p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k86Fj85sBIM\"                                                                        > <iframe width=\"460\" height=\"345\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/k86Fj85sBIM?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure>   <p>She represented what to me is an old-fashioned idea of the artist as someone who must be kept apart from the fray, protected from base things, surrounded by special people. Perhaps that makes her sound grand but she was just a bohemian from another era, more modern than the present in many ways, the unconventionality and delight in life not simply a posture but a hard won defiance.</p> <p>Her never ceasing dismay at my clothes and the state of my hair was of a piece with that sensibility. She had a horror of coarseness and triviality, of people who valued money or talked business and I imagine those things were two parts to one in the Hollywood cocktail. By picking the fight with Louis B Mayer that ended her career in Hollywood she was protecting her art, not surrendering it. And of course she wasn\u2019t prepared to baste the turkeys which Mayer started sending her way. A very good lesson, and a hard one to follow. Thumbing her nose in the way that she did tells you quite how strong she was. She was deadly serious about acting.</p> <p>My time with her always felt like a special occasion. She asked me to accompany her to a reception at the Mexican embassy for Carlos Fuentes, another of the many great men she knew. I combed my hair and tried to provide ballast but after my fourth margarita I\u2019m not sure who was holding on to whom. Fuentes approached with Eric Hobsbawm and introduced him to Luise. Neither nonagenarian could hear a word the other said but enough was made clear as they grinned and chuckled at each other, apparently delighted by the ridiculousness of their great ages.</p> <p>As she approached her birthday, she would say: \u201cNo one should be 100 years old. It\u2019s absurd!\u201d</p> <p>But her impish energy, mischief and curt humour was fully present during her centenary celebrations despite how tired she complained they made her. After a showing of The Great Ziegfeld at the NFT she turned to the audience from the front row, swept her arm across the span of the auditorium and smiled. Her eyes lit up the room just as they had on the screen and I realised \u2013 that sort of enchantment is not something you can learn.</p>",
