          "body": "<p>California\u2019s state treasurer announced on Tuesday that it is imposing a year-long ban on working with Wells Fargo after staff \u201cfleeced\u201d the bank\u2019s customers by creating 2m unauthorized accounts. </p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/sep/27/wells-fargo-sales-tactics-investigation-john-stumpf\">Wells Fargo executives forfeit millions and CEO to forgo salary amid inquiry</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The move by the US\u2019s largest state comes as the bank faces another grilling in Congress over the scandal that has already led the bank to pay $185m in penalties and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/sep/27/wells-fargo-sales-tactics-investigation-john-stumpf\">clawback millions in bonuses</a> from top executives.</p> <p>\u201cThe recent discovery that Wells Fargo &amp; Company fleeced its customers by opening fraudulent accounts for the purpose of extracting millions in illegal fees demonstrates, at best, a reckless lack of institutional control, and, at worst, a culture which actively promotes wanton greed,\u201d John Chiang, California\u2019s state treasurer, <a href=\"http://www.treasurer.ca.gov/news/releases/2016/20160928_letter.pdf\">wrote in a letter</a> to the bank on Tuesday.<br /></p> <p>Chiang\u2019s office oversees nearly $2tn in annual banking transactions and manages a $75bn investment pool. </p> <p>\u201cMy office has long relied on Wells Fargo, our oldest California-based financial institution, as a partner to meet the state\u2019s investment and borrowing needs,\u201d wrote Chiang. \u201cBut, to borrow from Albert Einstein, \u2018Whoever is careless with the truth in small matters cannot be trusted with [larger] matters.\u2019 In the case of Wells Fargo, how can I continue to entrust the public\u2019s money to an organization which has shown such little regard for the legions of Californians who have placed their financial well-being in its care?\u201d</p> <p>The $185m settlement announced at the end of the month was a result of an audit that revealed that Wells Fargo staff created as many as 1.5m deposit accounts and 565,000 credit card accounts without customers\u2019 consent. As a result, the bank fired more than 5,300 employees. The bank denies that the creation of these accounts was part of an orchestrated effort. </p> <p>According to bank\u2019s critics, the bank\u2019s staff opened such unauthorized accounts in order to meet their sales quotas. The bank announced yesterday that it is terminating all of its sales quotas starting 1 October.</p> <p>In light of this scandal, Chiang\u2019s office has effective immediately suspended its investment in all Wells Fargo securities, use of Wells Fargo as a broker-dealer for investment purchases and use of Wells Fargo as managing underwriter on negotiated sales of California state bonds. </p> <p>These sanctions are in effect for 12 months during which Chiang asked that Wells Fargo quarterly report back its compliance with the terms of its $185m settlement with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the Los Angeles city attorney, and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.</p> <p>Chiang has also called for separation of the chief executive and chair positions at Wells Fargo \u2013 both of which are currently held by John Stumpf, a review of Wells Fargo\u2019s compensation practices and clawbacks of pay for those executives who are linked to the predatory sales practices.</p> <p>\u201cWells Fargo has diligently and professionally worked with the state for the past 17 years to support the government and people of California.           "body": "<p>A biography of the 19th-century explorer Alexander von Humboldt, who has \u201cfaded from collective memory\u201d despite being dubbed \u201cthe Shakespeare of the sciences\u201d by his peers, has won the \u00a325,000 prize for the best science book of the year.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/nov/13/the-invention-of-nature-the-adventures-of-alexander-von-humboldt-andrea-wulf-review\">The Invention of Nature: The Adventures of Alexander von Humboldt, the Lost Hero of Science by Andrea Wulf \u2013 review</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Andrea Wulf\u2019s The Invention of Nature, which lays out the life of the Prussian explorer and naturalist Humboldt, was named winner of the Royal Society Insight Investment science book prize on Monday evening by chair of judges Bill Bryson. Humboldt, who lived from 1769 to 1859, inspired scientists and writers including Jules Verne and Charles Darwin in his day. He has more things named after him than anyone who has ever lived, including an ocean current, a six-foot squid and a breed of penguin.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"88096619af4a210bb07d7895b1db16f2f1549fcd\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/88096619af4a210bb07d7895b1db16f2f1549fcd/0_251_5760_3456/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Andrea Wulf .\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Andrea Wulf .</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Murdo Macleod for the Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Bu according to the Royal Society, of which he was a foreign member, he has \u201cfaded from collective memory\u201d in the English-speaking world today.</p> <p>Bryson, a previous winner of the award, said that Wulf\u2019s biography, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/jan/26/frances-hardinges-the-lie-tree-wins-costa-book-of-the-year-2015\">which also won the Costa biography prize</a>, was \u201ca thrilling adventure story as much as a science book about a polymath who had an extraordinary impact on our contemporary understanding of nature\u201d.</p> <p>Other contenders for this year\u2019s prize included <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/25/the-gene-an-intimate-history-siddhartha-mukherjee-review\">Siddhartha Mukherjee\u2019s The Gene</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/sep/10/the-hunt-for-vulcan-by-thomas-levenson-review-newton-einstein-and-the-invisible-planet\">Thomas Levenson\u2019s The Hunt for Vulcan</a>, and Tim Birkhead\u2019s look at the bird egg, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/apr/17/most-perfect-thing-inside-birds-egg-tim-birkhead-review-alex-preston\">The Most Perfect Thing</a>.</p> <p>\u201cThe decisive factor for the winning book was that it excited and gripped us as judges the most,\u201d said Bryson. \u201cIt is a book you will find yourself talking endlessly about with friends in the pub.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/jun/07/andrea-wulf-a-journey-through-thousands-of-books-and-spectacular-landscapes\">Andrea Wulf on a scientific adventurer 'chased by 10,000 pigs'</a> </p> </aside>  <p>\u201cHumboldt may not be well known today but he remains very much of our time: his work tackled many of today\u2019s big issues like climate change and biodiversity loss and the interconnectedness of nature,\u201d said Brian Cox, the Royal Society\u2019s professor for public engagement in science. \u201cMoreover, he was a polymath who was curious about everything and was a superb communicator. His interdisciplinary approach puts paid to the ridiculous notion that science and the arts are separate entities. We should be taking our cues from Humboldt \u2013 be curious and be informed by science on the big issues.\u201d</p>",

          "body": "<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2014/feb/04/albert-einstein-relativity-theory\">Einstein's theory of relativity stands up to scrutiny: archive, 4 February 1924</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Gravitational waves were predicted as part of Einstein\u2019s theory of general relativity. Scientists have been searching for evidence of their existence ever since. </p> <p>In 1971, <a href=\"http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2016/2/11/1455208933838/3-July-1971---gravitation-001.jpg\">the Guardian\u2019s Night Sky column</a> reported on attempts by Dr J Weber, at the University of Maryland, to detect gravitational radiation from very large masses. NASA meanwhile was planning to place a gravimeter on the moon.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"9e3718c0acaa08dea6e0a9704e07d7ede7cf0678\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/9e3718c0acaa08dea6e0a9704e07d7ede7cf0678/0_0_2026_3236/626.jpg\" alt=\"The Guardian, 3 July 1971\" width=\"626\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Guardian, 3 July 1971.</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The Observer <a href=\"http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2016/2/11/1455210067998/11-February-1979-Observer-001.jpg\">reported a breakthrough in 1979</a>, after scientists at the University of Massachusetts observed a pair of pulsars orbiting around one another.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"8a7e530aee964ce6440cfb04e93f17ee3bec754c\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8a7e530aee964ce6440cfb04e93f17ee3bec754c/0_0_1582_2484/637.jpg\" alt=\"The Observer, 11 February 1979.\" width=\"637\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Observer, 11 February 1979.</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>A collaboration between Germany and the UK <a href=\"http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2016/2/11/1455210945408/12-October-1990-Guardian--001.jpg\">was announced in 1990</a>, proposing the world\u2019s first gravitational wave observatory. Professor Jim Hough, pictured, is a leading expert in the field of gravitational waves.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"9cb3147eb68161876b1d6056fe921c6852ff21da\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/9cb3147eb68161876b1d6056fe921c6852ff21da/16_12_3032_1847/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The Guardian, 12 October 1990\" width=\"1000\" height=\"609\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Guardian, 12 October 1990. <a href=\"http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2016/2/11/1455210945408/12-October-1990-Guardian--001.jpg\">Read the full article.</a></span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Ligo - the laser interferometer gravitational-wave observatory in the United States - was <a href=\"http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2016/2/11/1455211856882/11-November-1999-gravitat-001.jpg\">switched on in November 1999</a>.           "body": "<p>Well then. Nobody knows anything any more, do they? Michael Gove was mocked for saying that everyone was sick of experts (or thereabouts), and I\u2019ve always been sympathetic to that mocking, but it is starting to seem as though \u2013 in political predictions at least \u2013 he has a point. There\u2019s so much received wisdom about how to win a key marginal, and what will alienate the middle ground, and why you ignore this demographic or that at your peril. And yet, after the shock of Thursday, none of that received wisdom seems to be so wise any more.</p> <h2>1. Young people do turn out</h2> <p>I\u2019ll admit it. I was sceptical. Despite seeing evidence of great enthusiasm for Corbyn among the young (we all saw it: rallies, fashion, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/video/2017/jun/07/grime4corbyn-ive-never-trusted-a-politician-before\">grime4corbyn</a>), I was cynical about whether that would translate to turnout. I thought it would be bigger, but maybe not huge. We don\u2019t know just how high the 18-24 turnout was yet, and won\u2019t do so for around a week, so don\u2019t believe that 72% stat doing the rounds on social media. But it\u2019s clear that young people flocked to the polls more than ever before, breaking a trend that has existed in UK politics since \u2013 well, for ever. Let\u2019s hope that this enthusiasm among young people lasts. As Laura Kuenssberg said on the BBC last night: \u201cThis is the election where young people started voting. And it may seem that for all the political parties the demographics of who they have to please might be shifting.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-tweet\" data-canonical-url=\"https://twitter.com/ladyhaja/status/872948997371113473\">  <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"><p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">&quot;This is the election young people started voting.&quot; \ud83d\udc4d\ud83d\udc4d\u270a\ufe0f And wouldn&#39;t this be wonderful? -&gt; <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/BBCelection?src=hash\">#BBCelection</a> <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/Election2017?src=hash\">#Election2017</a> <a href=\"https://t.co/ycfr2wC6zH\">pic.twitter.com/ycfr2wC6zH</a></p>&mdash; HannahJane Parkinson (@ladyhaja) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ladyhaja/status/872948997371113473\">June 8, 2017</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <h2>2. Newspapers don\u2019t rule all</h2> <p>Well, well, well. Poor Dacre. Poor Murdoch. Paul Dacre, the Daily Mail\u2019s editor and Theresa May\u2019s cheerleader, has seen his savage, relentless campaign against Labour fall flat. This is a paper that the day before the polls ran 13 pages of febrile anti-Labour content, and splashed: \u201c<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/jun/07/daily-mail-devotes-13-pages-to-attack-on-labour-apologists-for-terror\">APOLOGISTS FOR TERROR</a>\u201d on page one. This is a lot, in the wake of two terrorist attacks. It\u2019s a lot, whatever you think of Corbyn\u2019s associations in the past, to scream all of that about a man who stood on a stage in Manchester at a memorial for the dead. In other words: read the room, Mail. The hyperbole and frenzied attacks may well have been too much for some people to stomach. Ditto the Sun\u2019s consistent bile towards Diane Abbott, which echoed the Tory party\u2019s rhetoric. (Murdoch was <a href=\"https://twitter.com/johnprescott/status/872957575788101632\">said to be</a> so incensed at how the election played out he stormed out from an office.)</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/09/tabloids-crush-corbyn-power-politics-sun-mail-labour\">The Sun and Mail tried to crush Corbyn. But their power over politics is broken | Suzanne Moore</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Sure, the Mail has a circulation of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/apr/10/national-daily-newspapers-lose-more-than-half-a-million-readers-in-past-year\">1.4 million and the Sun just under two million</a>. I argued just the other day that having those sorts of headlines above the fold, in newsagents across the country, is a huge advantage \u2013 perhaps I was wrong. Could this be another blow to the dominance of the rightwing press? <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/09/tabloids-crush-corbyn-power-politics-sun-mail-labour\">Is the grip finally weakening</a>? </p> <h2>3. The party seen as strongest on the economy might not always win?</h2> <p>Labour, to a certain extent historically, but especially after the Tories tried to pin the global financial crash on Brown\u2019s administration, has been viewed as not, to coin a phrase, strong and stable on the economy. It\u2019s always the party that is seen as the strongest on the economy, the most responsible with the purse strings that wins. And actually, that is true of this result, but who expected Labour to give such a run for its, er, money. If Corbyn\u2019s Labour can do this well in the polls despite the voters being told every single day that he was recklessly profligate and endless talk of a \u201c<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/06/magic-money-tree-theresa-may-banks-nurses\">magic money tree</a>\u201d, then that represents a shift. (And somehow the Tories managed to get away without costing a single one of their policies, aside from the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/may/24/theresa-may-free-school-breakfasts-undercosted-tory-manifesto\">free school breakfasts</a>, which they got massively wrong. Good one.)</p> <h2>4. Lynton Crosby isn\u2019t a strategy genius </h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"0a6e3983f7478c05e5193256fc02fe7dedf68da2\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/0a6e3983f7478c05e5193256fc02fe7dedf68da2/0_35_594_356/500.jpg\" alt=\"lynton crosby\" width=\"500\" height=\"300\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018Lynton Crosby has now run two disastrous, horrendously negative campaigns \u2013 Zac Goldsmith\u2019s mayoral punt, and now 2017.\u2019</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>There was a time (the worst time) that you couldn\u2019t move for people quoting Lynton Crosby\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/politics/shortcuts/2016/mar/02/will-michael-fallon-dead-cat-strategy-work-on-sadiq-khan\">dead cat strategy</a> as if it were Einstein-level genius (the theory that you throw something else into the narrative to cause distraction when the narrative is turning against you \u2013 \u201ca dead cat on the table\u201d being the weird RSPCA-friendly euphemism here). But Crosby has now run two disastrous, horrendously negative campaigns \u2013 Zac Goldsmith\u2019s mayoral punt, and now 2017. Same in Australia. It turns out that siloing your candidate in warehouses, arrogantly refusing debate appearances, and launching viciously personal attacks doesn\u2019t play great. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/09/tories-politics-of-fear-lynton-crosby-jeremy-corbyn-theresa-may\">Back to the drawing board</a>, Lynton.</p> <h2>5. The in-crowd doesn\u2019t know everything</h2> <p>The polls, mostly, were wrong. Even the exit polls underestimated Labour\u2019s strength. The pundits were wrong. People like me didn\u2019t think Corbyn could do this well, I admit it. Talking heads shook them, and said never in a million years. Even the politicians themselves got it wrong \u2013 until late last night, Labour itself was braced for something of a wipeout, with talk coming from aides that Labour candidates were drafting concession speeches. It\u2019s become obvious that there\u2019s a whole chunk of the electorate that polling, canvassing, aides and tellers aren\u2019t picking up on. They might be hiding (shy voters fudging answers in polls, and so on), or they might be hiding in plain sight (see Corbyn\u2019s massive online army, for instance).</p> <h2>6. Ukip voters did not flock to the Tories </h2> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/09/is-this-the-end-for-ukip-hard-brexit\">Is this the end for Ukip? | Richard Whitaker</a> </p> </aside>  <p>This one is more specific to this one election, but a big surprise to many was the collapsing vote going in many cases to Labour, <a href=\"https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/3740217/ukip-swing-to-tories-hands-theresa-may-35-seats/\">rather than as widely assumed</a>, the Tories. It\u2019s possible that some Ukippers aren\u2019t happy with how Brexit is shaping up, but perhaps more likely that they are coming to grips with austerity. Broxbourne showed a particularly big Ukip-to-Labour swing. </p> <p>All of this means it is possible that pollsters, politicians, journalists and staffers have been relied on too much to fortune-tell, and that the political analysis model is broken. But, hey, what would I know?</p>",

          "body": "<h2><strong>Back in Time for Christmas</strong><br />9pm, BBC2</h2> <p>A lesson in festive nostalgia, as the Robshaw family step back in time to celebrate Christmas over six decades under the guidance of Giles Coren. They begin in 1940, with wartime austerity and Christmas dinner on the rationing list. Lionel Blair pops in to tell them stories of singing for people using the London Underground as an air-raid shelter. There is also a glimpse of 1950s optimism, followed by cocktail parties, carols and the arrival of the artificial Christmas tree in the 1960s. Concludes Tuesday with the 70s, 80s and 90s. <em>Hannah Verdier</em></p> <h2><strong>Our Guy in Latvia</strong><br />9pm, Channel 4</h2> <p>Guy Martin is best known as a daredevil with a penchant for breaking land-speed records. Tonight, however, he undertakes a slower, more personal journey: back to the Baltics, to find out the truth about his late grandfather Walter Kidals. How did Walter make it from German-occupied Latvia to postwar Hull to marry Martin\u2019s grandmother? The story involves stirring feats of Boy\u2019s Own derring-do, including audacious prison camp escapes, that put even Martin\u2019s own adventures in the shade. <em>David Stubbs</em></p> <h2><strong>Inside Einstein\u2019s Mind: The Enigma of Space and Time</strong><br />9pm, BBC4</h2> <p>A century ago last month, the 36-year-old physicist Albert Einstein published his theory of general relativity, embedding himself in popular culture as the cliche of the dishevelled boffin and dramatically expanding humankind\u2019s understanding of the universe. This terrific film illuminates not only Einstein\u2019s conclusions but also the means by which he arrived at them, adroitly negotiating that always\u2011difficult balance between bewildering and patronising the passing viewer to furnish an engrossing narrative. <em>Andrew Mueller</em></p> <h2>Trollied<br />9pm, Sky1</h2> <p>It\u2019s nearly Christmas at Valco and fruit-recognition training is in full swing, while a poisonous spider is on the loose. In the second of the double bill, the supermarket\u2019s staff celebrate its birthday in 1960s fancy dress as the series bows out. There are some real gems in the ensemble cast, most notably Jason Watkins and Sarah Parish playing out Gavin\u2019s bittersweet romance with rival supermarket manager Cheryl in the store\u2019s freezer. Trollied is from the Stella school of comedy: not always hilarious, but gently watchable.<em> HV</em></p> <h2>Dr Christmas<br />9pm, TLC</h2> <p>It\u2019s time to deck the halls: unless you\u2019re an American kajillionaire, that is, in which case you may have already outsourced decorative duties to Bob Pranga, AKA Dr Christmas. This schmaltzy one-off follows the Doc and his business partner Debi as they bring ice rinks, monster trees and giant gingerbread men to Beverly Hills. In this opening episode, the not-so-secret Santa lends a hand to a former Saved by the Bell star, a soap actor and a TV presenter. Garish, obviously, but likely to induce a gleeful \u201cOMG\u201d or five, too. <em>Hannah J Davies</em></p> <h2><strong>Fargo</strong><br />10pm, Channel 4</h2> <p>After perhaps the most taut moment of an impressive second series, and with the seemingly bullet-proof Peggy and Ed (Kirsten Dunst and Jesse Plemons) somehow managing to live another day, you can\u2019t help but wonder whether the scene where they let the deadly assassin Hanzee escape could prove to be their eventual undoing. After arriving to save the day, Lou is now involved in jurisdictional politics, while Hanzee returns to the Gerhardt compound with news of recent events. That\u2019ll be awkward, then. <em>Ben Arnold</em></p> <h2>The Best of Bad TV: The 70s <br />10pm, Channel 5</h2> <p>As the Christmas schedules creep on to Britain\u2019s EPGs, expect the annual parade of pundits pining for TV\u2019s 1970s golden age. While there may have been Morecambe and Wise, Fawlty Towers and Porridge, there was also room for rampant racism, sickening sexism and competitive disco dancing on Britain\u2019s three channels. Time for a showcase evening promoting the very worst the decade had to offer. Including interviews with Peter Purves, Valerie Singleton and Jane Rossington, AKA Jill from Crossroads. <em>Mark Gibbings-Jones</em></p> <h2>Film Choice</h2> <p><strong>Lawless</strong> (John Hillcoat, 2012) 11.10pm, Film4</p> <p>More rough stuff from the director of the post-apocalyptic drama The Road and The Proposition. Apparently based on a true story, it\u2019s set in 1931 Virginia, where brothers Tom Hardy and Shia LaBeouf lead the Bondurant clan in their illegal moonshine business. Which is all very well until a corrupt, sadistic Fed (Guy Pearce) starts muscling in. Relentlessly violent. <em>Paul Howlett</em></p> <p><strong>The Truman Show</strong> (Peter Weir, 1998) 2.05pm, 9.50pm, Sky Movies Greats</p> <p>Jim Carrey\u2019s Truman Burbank lives in the peaceful town of Seahaven, unaware that he is the subject of a round-the-clock TV show, his friends and family merely actors playing roles. It\u2019s an inspired idea and Weir plays it out brilliantly, with Ed Harris superb as the godlike show creator. <em>PH</em></p> <h2>Today\u2019s best live sport</h2> <p><strong>International Premier Tennis League Micromax</strong> Indian Aces take on Japan Warriors before the Philippine Mavericks do battle with the UAE Royals. 12noon, Sky Sports 3</p> <p><strong>Premier League Football: Leicester City v Chelsea</strong> High-flying Foxes take on relegation-threatened Chelsea. 7pm, Sky Sports 1</p> <p><strong>Championship Football: Blackburn Rovers v Nottingham Forest</strong> Mid-table clash. 7.30pm, Sky Sports 5</p> <p><strong>American Football: Miami Dolphins v New York Giants </strong>NFL action. 1am, Sky Sports 1</p>",

          "body": "<p>The great theoretical physicist breakfasted on these slightly sweetened fried eggs. It might sound strange at first, but there\u2019s no reason eggs have to be served as a savoury breakfast. The honey and butter give the eggs a golden sheen.</p> <p><strong>Serves one</strong><br />Melt a knob of butter in a wide frying pan. Once fizzing, slide in two really fresh, free-range eggs and fry until almost cooked to your liking. Add a teaspoon of honey and, once that\u2019s melted, tilt the pan slightly and repeatedly spoon the hot mixture over the egg until the top of the yolk is just opaque. Einstein liked his with fresh bread rolls, but they\u2019re equally good on hot buttered toast.</p>",

          "body": "<p><a href=\"http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004810/reference\">Chris Carter</a> has returned to write and direct <a href=\"http://www.imdb.com/title/tt4549946/reference\">Babylon</a>, the newest episode of The X-Files, which can mean only one thing: a symbolism-heavy hour that makes almost no sense and has coded (and explicit!) wingnuttery throughout. And also a great soundtrack.<br /></p> <p>We open on a Muslim kid praying in a normal-looking suburban Texas home \u2013 indeed, we don\u2019t get a lot more specific than \u201csouth-west Texas\u201d, to quote the <a href=\"http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=chyron\">chyron</a>, for a while. He drives his little car through town, has a brief crisis of conscience over a couple of pretty young women in cowboy hats and short skirts, is sneered at by rednecks in a pickup who call him \u201cbrownie\u201d, picks up a pal from a hotel, and then goes to an art gallery called Ziggurat, which explodes.</p> <p>I waited the entire episode to find out that Islamist Terrorist Blows Up Texas Art Gallery was a red herring and that there were strange forces at work. There\u2019s apparently a painting inside of Muhammad pooping extremists, or so we hear in a very badly written <a href=\"http://www.cnn.com/2015/02/12/opinion/begala-stewart-blew-up-crossfire/\">Crossfire</a>-style news program that plays in the background (in Carter\u2019s defense, it would be hard to write dialogue worse than the invective pundits fling at each other on cable news), but isn\u2019t that too little motivation? Couldn\u2019t it be something more?</p> <p>No, apparently. We can believe in lizard people (come back, <a href=\"http://www.feralaudio.com/28-interview-with-x-files-writer-darin-morgan/\">Darin Morgan</a>!), but considering briefly that American Muslims might not be even less sympathetic monsters seems to be beyond the scope of this show\u2019s powers. Carter keeps trying to pretend he\u2019s not really taking a side in the debates he keeps bringing up, but he\u2019s bad at disingenuousness. Even the liberal commentator on the aforementioned news show seems to think that there\u2019s enmity between the west and the Middle East because there\u2019s too much blasphemy on TV and not because of bombs falling on hospitals.</p> <p>Mercifully, we cut to Mulder and Scully, who are trying to figure out another, more interesting mystery related to trumpets sounding out of the clear sky like something from the book of Revelation.</p> <h2>Separated at birth</h2> <p>The two are interrupted by Miller and Einstein (Lauren Ambrose and Robbie Amell), who look like Mulder and Scully would look if the show was on the CW and not Fox. The pair are nearly identical to their elders in temperament and of course Ambrose has bright red hair; it\u2019s one of several unexplained moments in the episode that give The X-Files its trademark panache.</p> <p>Mulder and Scully call Einstein and Miller \u2013 their partners\u2019 respective opposite numbers \u2013 and work out a creative solutions to what becomes the episode\u2019s central problem. That problem is an ingenious one: one of the terrorists has survived the bombing, but just barely. He\u2019s in a coma, and he may know something about the next attack.</p> <p>Of course, it\u2019s not clear how the agents know there\u2019s going to be a next attack, unless you think that one terrorist is two terrorists. Even if we\u2019ve giving Carter credit for referencing the shooting at the Curtis Culwell Center (in which two men wounded one person in the ankle and immediately died in a hail of bullets outside the artistic fruit of a <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/may/04/officer-and-two-suspects-reportedly-shot-at-draw-the-prophet-contest-in-texas\">Draw Muhammad contest</a>), there certainly wasn\u2019t a corresponding cell of enthusiastic, multiracial suicide bombers, as there is in this episode.</p> <p>Mind you, the locals of south-west Texas are none too admirable either. A nurse tries to kill Shiraz (our comatose terrorist kid) and lectures Einstein about how the UN want to fill the country with immigrants. Later, two agents from the Department of Homeland Security (!) try to do the same out of a desire for revenge.</p> <h2>\u2018I saw powerful things\u2019</h2> <p>The episode all comes down to both Mulder and Scully going off the reservation. Scully wants to talk to the young man using an MRI to see if she can read his brainwaves well enough to determine a \u201cyes\u201d or a \u201cno\u201d; Mulder wants to trip on shrooms to see if the kid shows up in his hallucinations.</p> <p>As per, Scully\u2019s solution is more plausible but Mulder\u2019s is vastly more entertaining: while Scully and Miller work the medical angle, Mulder and a very dubious Einstein procure a caplet of hallucinogens and Mulder dances his way through a surreal sequence scored by Tom Waits, Billy Ray Cyrus and Trace Adkins, of <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vNVguvNE7qc\">Honky Tonk Badonkadonk </a>fame, in which we see some familiar faces. \u201cYou were there!\u201d he tells Skinner after coming down. \u201cAnd the Lone Gunmen! And the badonkadonk!\u201d</p> <p>The punchline turns out to be that Einstein was too straitlaced to give Mulder illegal drugs and he\u2019s been tripping balls on vitamin B3; the further punchline is that it worked. Mulder recognizes the young man\u2019s mother \u2013 having seen her in the dream \u2013 as she tries to get inside the hospital and lets her come up to see him. Using Scully\u2019s brainwave translation method, they learn that he survived the bombing because he couldn\u2019t bring himself to detonate his vest.</p> <p>They also get a new clue: the Babylon hotel, where the rest of the United Terrorists of Benetton are hanging out (seriously, they look like if the <a href=\"http://www.whiffenpoofs.com/\">Whiffenpoofs</a> grew beards).</p> <p>A bunch of FBI agents raid the place, which is as neat a metaphor as needed for the way in which this whole exercise is so objectionable: if you\u2019re going to spend the next three minutes telling everyone how the episode was about all the ways love is better than hate \u2013 and trust me, Carter is \u2013 perhaps you ought not to shoot a climactic takedown sequence during which a bunch of guys in body armor waving huge guns around storm a roomful of praying Muslim men and step on their rugs. It tells a visual story I\u2019m not sure Carter knows he\u2019s telling.</p> <p>\u201cI saw things, though, Scully. Powerful things,\u201d Mulder says in the epilogue. \u201cI saw deep and unconditional love.\u201d</p> <p>\u201cI saw things, too,\u201d Scully replies. \u201cI witnessed unqualified hate that appears to have no end.\u201d</p> <p>\u201cHow to reconcile the two? The extremes of our nature?\u201d Mulder asks.</p> <p>\u201cThat\u2019s the question,\u201d Scully replies. \u201cMaybe the question of our times.\u201d</p> <p>Here\u2019s the thing: if you\u2019re going to reconcile the extremes of human nature, you could do worse than correctly identifying them first.</p>",

Asked how much money David Moyes would be handed next month, his reply was stark. \u201cLimited. I could probably say very limited with regards to the January transfer window. We\u2019re rebuilding and restructuring, it\u2019s going to take a while and we\u2019re not going to be able to spend to get out of trouble.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/10/swansea-city-sunderland-premier-league-match-report\">Fernando Llorente double steers Swansea to vital win over Sunderland</a> </p> </aside>  <p>This dictates that Moyes, Sunderland\u2019s seventh manager in just over five years, cannot expect anything approaching the \u00a315m budget that his predecessor, Sam Allardyce, spent last January. Allardyce spent that cash on Lamine Kon\u00e9, Jan Kirchhoff and Wahbi Khazri, who all played key roles in the club\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report\" title=\"\">escape from relegatio</a>n, but this season Khazri has lost form while Kirchhoff has struggled with injuries.</p> <p>With Moyes reluctant to offload his two most saleable assets, the goalkeeper Jordan Pickford and Kon\u00e9 \u2013 understood to have a \u00a325m release clause in his contract \u2013 in order to fund purchases, Sunderland\u2019s survival chances will be heavily dependent on their manager\u2019s coaching skills.</p> <p>It signals the end of a series of transfer\u2011market quick-fixes and managerial changes, which have averted a series of potential relegations but failed to break the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/oct/30/david-moyes-einstein-barry-glendenning\" title=\"\">cycle of struggle</a>.</p> <p>\u201cWe\u2019ve reached a point where we can\u2019t have that short-term hit to plug the holes in the dam,\u201d Bain said, pointing out that only three of the 46 players sold since 2009 made the club a profit.</p> <p>\u201cMaybe in the past \u2013 and I don\u2019t want to talk disparagingly of anyone at the moment \u2013 we didn\u2019t do the right due diligence on players. Ellis Short has put a lot of money into this football club.         "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/books/2017/feb/20/the-bughouse-poetry-politics-and-madness-of-ezra-pound-daniel-swift-review",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>The psychodrama surrounding one of America\u2019s greatest 20th century poets during, and immediately after, the second world war is so bizarre, it\u2019s astonishing that this chapter in the life of the modernist, madman, fascist and traitor AKA Ezra Pound has remained largely neglected for so long.</p> <p>In <em>The Bughouse</em>, Daniel Swift has reconnoitred a unique but hardly obscure literary target. The deranged figure of Pound behind bars has been hiding in plain sight for decades. Still, it is Swift\u2019s considerable achievement sympathetically to examine an extraordinary, often troubling, tale in an idiosyncratic biographical analysis that marries lit crit and memoir in a sometimes awkward fusion.</p> <p>Swift describes Pound as \u201cthe most difficult man of the 20th century\u201d. Others called him \u201cthe Trotsky of literature\u201d. He was certainly a rag-bag of contradictions: a racist who believed in African myth and Chinese philosophy, and an antisemite whose 800-page <em>Cantos</em> is an unfinished masterpiece of renowned beauty and complexity. \u201cAs much as Freud or Einstein,\u201d writes Swift, he \u201cinvented the modern age. He edited <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/dec/12/100-best-nonfiction-books-no-46-ts-eliot-the-waste-land-robert-mccrum\" title=\"\"><em>The Waste Land</em></a>.\u201d He also played tennis \u201clike an inebriated kangaroo\u201d, revered the US constitution, but spent the second world war broadcasting anti-American propaganda from Mussolini\u2019s Italy.</p> <p>Pound on fascist radio was a disaster waiting to happen. Ever since 1913, when he\u2019d read poetry into a phonoscope (an obsolete recording device), he was fascinated by a medium whose disembodied polyphony, he claimed, echoed his own techniques. \u201cI anticipated the damn thing in the first third of the <em>Cantos</em>,\u201d he wrote. In December 1941, just before Pearl Harbor tipped America into war, Pound began a series of broadcasts from Rome, partly about poetry but, more fatally, also about the folly of fighting against the Axis powers. By the time he was indicted for treason, which carried the death penalty, he had broadcast more than 200 times.</p> <p>Pound\u2019s radio prose was like the man: chaotic, confusing, sometimes comic, but always \u2013 says Swift \u2013 \u201ca little sad\u201d with references to \u201ckikes\u201d, \u201cyids\u201d, and Tennyson, and rants against \u201cchief war pimp, Frankie Finkelstein Roosevelt\u201d, who had \u201cchucked away our national, cultural heritage\u201d. Far away in Maryland, federal eavesdroppers wrote it all down.</p> <p>Like PG Wodehouse who, in utterly different circumstances, fell foul of Nazi radio, Ezra Pound turned himself over to US forces who, in May 1945, slammed him into a brutal punishment camp with 3,500 rapists, murderers and deserters. His \u201cgorilla cage\u201d was 6ft by 6ft of steel bars with no shelter from the sun or rain. By the middle of June, Pound had suffered a nervous collapse. But then, like Oscar Wilde in Reading jail, he began to write himself into a state of grace. In November 1945, he was flown back to Washington\u00a0DC to face trial. On landing, he asked: \u201cDoes anyone have the faintest idea of what I actually said in Rome?\u201d</p> <p>Pound was sent to St Elizabeths, a government hospital for the insane where, after examination, he was found to be \u201cmentally unfit for trial\u201d. He would be kept in \u201cS Liz\u201d for nearly 13 years, sequestered in the place he called \u201cthe bughouse\u201d.</p> <p>St Elizabeths, writes Swift, became \u201cthe world\u2019s most unorthodox literary salon: convened by a fascist, held in a lunatic asylum\u201d. Pound became a destination for cultural pilgrims, a mad poet visited by other poets: TS\u00a0Eliot, Elizabeth Bishop, William Carlos Williams, Marianne Moore, ageing modernists and newer voices such as Frederick Seidel, some of whom were almost as \u201ccrazy\u201d as Pound. The resident of St Elizabeths became a kind of creative godfather to several, more or less unstable, US writers of the 1950s, from Anne Sexton and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/oct/24/happy-100th-birthday-john-berryman-poetry\" title=\"\">John Berryman </a>to Delmore Schwartz and Robert Lowell.</p> <p>But how mad was he, who had always been a holy fool? Was he faking dementia to avoid the death penalty? To some visiting psychiatrists, the man who, in 1945, called Hitler \u201ca martyr\u201d, mourned \u201cpoor Benito\u201d and declared Stalin \u201cthe best brain in the business\u201d appeared to be simply a genius. Hadn\u2019t Shakespeare, no less, found lunatics, lovers and poets to be \u201cof imagination all compact\u201d?</p> <p>Swift, echoing this, says that Pound \u201cencapsulates the central questions about art, politics and poetry, about the connection between experimental art and extreme political sentiment\u201d. Struggling for answers, he undertakes a prolonged analysis of the meetings between patient 58,102 (Pound\u2019s case-file number) and six major poets, led by Eliot. This makes for an enthralling narrative, but it does complicate an already cubist portrait of an impossible character. We might be better informed, but we are, in truth, not much the wiser about the enigma of \u201cUncle Ez\u201d.</p> <p>What\u2019s not in doubt is Pound\u2019s tragedy, or the cruelty meted out to him: the years spent among the criminally insane, the isolation and the terrible distress. At night, Pound would stop his ears with paper to block the mad cries of his fellows. \u201cI want quiet,\u201d he begged one doctor. \u201cYou must decide whether I am to be cured or punished.\u201d</p> <p>While the authorities struggled with this conundrum, some poets appealed to President Truman for clemency, while Pound himself withdrew into a distracted seclusion in which he could write and hold court. By 1952, we find him on the hospital tennis court, reminiscing with Eliot about Rupert Brooke. In 1953, Lowell reports him \u201cmuch fatter and healthier\u201d. Within another year, the publication of new work raised old questions about a poet who could adapt Confucian odes, but was not fit to stand trial.</p> <p>Simultaneously, with the passage of time, he was morphing from traitor to throwback. In 1951, Salinger published\u00a0<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/feb/02/100-best-novels-catcher-in-the-rye-jd-salinger-holden-caulfield\" title=\"\"><em>Catcher in the Rye</em></a>; Stalin died in 1953; in 1955, Ginsberg\u2019s <em>Howl</em>\u00a0signalled a new generation. While the 50s unspooled, Pound reached a kind of premature posterity in St Elizabeths.</p> <p>Many young poets who came to \u201cthe bughouse\u201d to practise \u201cEzrology\u201d, returned to the world in a state of ecstatic reinvention. Some espoused Pound\u2019s mad politics. Inevitably, a few young women fell in love with him. Conspiracy theorists debated his fate. Was he a traitor protected by the hospital from the punishment he deserved; or a truth-teller tormented for his candour ?</p> <p>Swift struggles with this afterlife, unable to decide if this is \u201ca heroic drama about poets rescuing a poet\u201d or \u201ca case study in psychiatry\u201d. Pound seems to have understood himself better than the experts. \u201cOfficially, I am as crazy as a coot,\u201d he told his daughter on his release in 1958, \u201cbut not a peril to society or myself.\u201d He died in 1972, aged 87.</p> <p><em>\u2022\u00a0The Bughouse\u00a0</em>by Daniel Swift is published by Harvill Secker (\u00a325). To order a copy for \u00a320 go to\u00a0<a href=\"https://bookshop.theguardian.com/bughouse.html?utm_source=editoriallink&amp;utm_medium=merch&amp;utm_campaign=article\" title=\"\">bookshop.theguardian.com</a>\u00a0or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&amp;p over \u00a310, online orders only. Phone orders min p&amp;p of \u00a31.99</p>",

          "body": "<h2>This week\u2019s biggest stories</h2> <p>Life on an exoplanet is a tantalising prospect \u2013 but you may need to hitch a ride on USS Enterprise to reach it. For now, like Einstein, let\u2019s travel on a light beam. On it you arrive at the Aquarius constellation and get dazzled by a planet system much like ours. Its sun is named Trappist-1 and around it orbit seven planets. The sixth one is Earth-sized, has flowing water and harbours life. (Not really. But hold on to that thought, as it could.) <br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>Scientists believe the rocky world <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/may/18/atmosphere-discovery-makes-trappist-1-exoplanet-priority-in-hunt-for-alien-life\">could have been enveloped by atmosphere for billions of years</a>, making it possible for liquid water to exist on the surface. \u201cSince the discovery of the seven planets there has been a great deal of interest in \u2026 determining whether these planets have atmospheres. The presence of an atmosphere is perceived as one of the requirements for the habitability of a planet,\u201d said Manasvi Lingam at Harvard University. <br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>Meanwhile, back on our Earth, pathologists at Great Ormond Street hospital, London, have <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/may/18/100-century-old-tumours-could-shed-light-rare-childhood-cancers\">found a vault full of a century-old samples of tumours</a> responsible for some of the rarest forms of childhood cancers. Significantly, genetic information could be readily obtained from them, allowing scientists to discover which genes caused these diseases \u2013 and potentially a cure. <br tabindex=\"-1\" /></p> <p>Elsewhere, infertile mice have delivered healthy pups after <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/may/16/3d-printed-ovaries-allow-infertile-mice-to-give-birth\">pioneering ovary implants made with a 3D printer</a>. universes?</a> | Across the universe</strong></p> <blockquote class=\"quoted\"> <p> Increasingly astronomers and cosmologists seem to be invoking the multiverse to explain puzzling observations. It sounds bonkers but the latest piece of evidence that could favour a multiverse comes from the UK\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.ras.org.uk/news-and-press/2982-new-survey-hints-at-exotic-origin-for-the-cold-spot\">Royal Astronomical Society.</a> They recently published a study on the so-called \u2018cold spot\u2019. This is a particularly cool patch of space seen in the radiation produced by the formation of the universe more than 13 billion years ago \u2026 If there is a multiverse, scientists will have to accept that the ultimate goal of physics \u2013 to explain why our universe is the way it is \u2013 could be forever out of reach.</p> </blockquote> <p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/occams-corner/2017/may/18/monkey-memes-the-subtext-of-a-silly-sounding-aqa-gcse-exam-question-on-darwin\">The real importance of a silly-sounding GCSE question on Darwin</a> | Occam\u2019s corner</strong></p> <blockquote class=\"quoted\"> <p>The Darwin question would have allowed a creative person to explain the main aspects of evolution by natural selection \u2013 surely a topic as worthwhile as photosynthesis. But at the same time, the student could flex their knowledge of the undeniable truth that scientific discoveries have the potential to make ripples far beyond the facts, permeating into every nook and cranny of human society. What could be more crucial for any student of science to understand than the power and social legacy underpinning a discovery?</p> </blockquote> <p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/may/17/here-be-dragons-the-million-year-journey-of-the-komodo-dragon\">Here be dragons: the million-year journey of the Komodo</a> | Lost Worlds Revisited</strong></p> <blockquote class=\"quoted\"> <p>From Australia, Komodo dragons spread westwards, but when this happened is not known. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/fossils\">Fossils</a> from Flores\u2019 hot central region indicate that Komodo dragons first appeared on the island around one million years ago, and lived alongside pygmy elephants, giant tortoises and giant rats, and continued to do so for thousands of years.</p> </blockquote> <p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/series/science-blog-network\">Visit the Science blog network</a></strong></p> <p><strong>_____</strong></p> <h2>Science Weekly podcast</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"87bfa793d84ba121c41dd491de0ab6978d5f4863\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/87bfa793d84ba121c41dd491de0ab6978d5f4863/0_14_5120_3072/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Why is Alzheimer\u2019s so hard to cure?\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Why is Alzheimer\u2019s so hard to cure?</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Alamy</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>About 30 million people worldwide live with Alzheimer\u2019s disease, a figure that could triple by 2050, according to some estimates. Despite drug companies spending decades and hundreds of millions of dollars on research, there is no cure. Why is Alzheimer\u2019s so hard to eradicate? Find out <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/audio/2017/may/14/science-weekly-can-we-cure-alzheimers-podcast\">in this week\u2019s podcast</a> as <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/profile/iansample\">Ian Sample</a> is joined by <a href=\"http://www.dementiablog.org/author/dr-david-reynolds/\">Dr David Reynolds</a>, chief scientific officer at Alzheimer\u2019s Research UK, <a href=\"http://www.kcl.ac.uk/nms/depts/chemistry/people/core/morrisroger.aspx\">Prof Roger Morris</a>, a molecular neurobiologist at King\u2019s College London, and <a href=\"http://www.neuroscience.cam.ac.uk/directory/profile.php?gm522\">Prof Giovanna Mallucci</a> from the University of Cambridge.</p> <h2>Eye on science \u2013 this week\u2019s top images</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"d97bdfc0698296f705b791952a015fd9c63ed40d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/d97bdfc0698296f705b791952a015fd9c63ed40d/0_305_5272_3164/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The Doppler on Wheels scans a supercell thunderstorm during a tornado research mission in Elbert county near Agate, Colorado.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Doppler on Wheels scans a supercell thunderstorm during a tornado research mission in Elbert county near Agate, Colorado.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Drew Angerer/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Chasing storms is something of a sport for many scientists. The element of risk provides a thrill, as was the case with Tim Samaras, the US engineer famous for his research into tornadoes, who died chasing one in 2013. His account, <a href=\"http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2013/11/biggest-storm/draper-text\">the Last Chase</a>, was chronicled in the National Geographic. <br /></p> <p>The <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/gallery/2017/may/17/riders-on-the-storm-the-scientists-who-chase-tornadoes-in-pictures\">Riders of the storm</a> gallery offers a glimpse into why scientists chase storms. With funding from the US National Science Foundation and other government grants, scientists and meteorologists from the Center for Severe Weather Research try to get close to the heart of action, to better understand tornado structure and strength, how low-level winds affect buildings, and to learn more about storm formation and prediction.</p>",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/books/2016/mar/07/100-best-nonfiction-books-6-brief-history-of-time-stephen-hawking",

          "body": "<p>Curiosity is one of the human animal\u2019s essential qualities, and two questions \u2013 where did we come from, and how did we get here? \u2013 continue to express the insatiable curiosity that animates human consciousness. Today, when we consider our place in the universe, the cosmos remains the supreme frontier of mankind\u2019s propensity to wonder at its origins.</p> <p>Last month, an event in a remote corner of our universe, another contemporary reminder of this timeless curiosity, hit the international headlines with the dramatic verification of a concept first predicted by Einstein in 1915: gravitational waves.</p> <p>In the words of the <a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/14/opinion/sunday/finding-beauty-in-the-darkness.html?_r=0\"><em>New York Times</em></a><em>,</em> \u201ca minuscule jiggle, discovered in an exotic physics experiment\u201d saw two teams of American scientists, in collaboration with British and German partners, overcome almost insurmountable odds \u201cto open a vast new window on the cosmos\u201d. This, in simple language, was the wider significance of the moment \u2013 an astronomical \u201cfirst\u201d \u2013 when the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (Ligo) announced that <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/feb/09/gravitational-waves-everything-you-need-to-know\">a signal from gravitational waves</a> had been discovered emanating from the collision and merger of two massive black holes (collapsed stars) more than a billion light years away.</p> <p>The mind-dizzying scale of this data only begins to come into focus when you remember that just one light year is approximately 5.88 trillion miles. Welcome to <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2012/jan/01/stephen-hawking-at-70\">Stephen Hawking</a> and his universe.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>He devoted the final chapters to 'wormholes', 'spiral galaxies' and, perhaps most controversial, 'superstring theory'</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>It was, rather less distantly, in 1988 that Hawking confirmed his place as the most brilliant British scientist of his generation with the publication of <em>A Brief History of Time</em>, a succinct, entertaining and brilliantly lucid account of our relationship with the universe. In addition to his review of all the great theories of the cosmos, from Galileo and Newton to Einstein, Hawking, who was already renowned for his work on black holes, took the opportunity to explore and publicise some of the most speculative contemporary ideas about space and time. He devoted the final chapters of <em>A Brief History</em> to \u201cwormholes\u201d, \u201cspiral galaxies\u201d and, perhaps most controversial of all, \u201csuperstring theory\u201d, in a complex narrative that was also a sketch for Hawking\u2019s goal of a \u201ccomplete, consistent and unified\u201d theory of physics.</p> <p>It was his ambition, he wrote, to facilitate \u201cthe discussion of the question of why it is that we and the universe exist. If we find the answer to that, it would be the ultimate triumph of human reason \u2013 for then we would know the mind of God.\u201d</p> <p>What, you might ask, is the use of such hyperbole? What, indeed, is the justification for a highly theoretical department of science, such as astrophysics, that doesn\u2019t contribute to the improvement of the physical world (safer aeroplanes; faster cars; better washing machines)? Here we have to acknowledge the immense but intangible cultural significance of scientific inquiry, especially its ability to change mankind\u2019s perspective of its place in the universe.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2012/jan/01/stephen-hawking-at-70\">Stephen Hawking at 70: still the brightest star in the scientific universe</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Who knows what the Ligo experiment or <em>A Brief History</em> will achieve? If history is any guide, however, the impact on our consciousness is potentially profound. Already, as my <em>Observer</em> colleague <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/feb/14/british-scientists-crucial-role-in-stronomical-breakthrough-gravitational-waves-einstein\">Robin McKie recently reported</a>: \u201cIt is now clear that astronomers have created a new type of astronomy: gravitational wave observation.\u201d The Ligo breakthrough joins an extraordinary tradition of scientific endeavour. As one of the scientists behind Ligo put it, \u201cThis confirms the existence of a range of intermediate black holes, about which we had theoretical doubts. Now those have gone. We\u2019re already going places.\u201d</p> <p>Over the centuries, Aristotle, Copernicus, Galileo, Newton, Einstein and many others, often at great personal cost, have changed our understanding of the universe. Hawking\u2019s own boastful calculations of his book sales suggest that <em>A Brief History </em>will have influenced the minds of a generation as few other contemporary titles will have done. Translated into 40 languages, as he writes in the introduction to the latest paperback edition, <em>A Brief History</em> has sold \u201cabout one copy for every 750 man, woman and child in the world\u201d. Not bad for a book that, Hawking freely admits, he never expected \u201cto do anything like as well as it did\u201d.</p> <p>From its opening page, in which he repeats the apocryphal tale of the little old lady who told <a href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2013/nov/18/bertrand-russell-philosopher-religion-ethics-life\">Bertrand Russell</a> that \u201cthe world is really a flat place supported on the back of a giant tortoise\u201d, Hawking\u2019s intention is to instruct and entertain. He recounts, tongue in cheek, that when Russell is said to have replied, with a smirk, \u201cWhat is the tortoise standing on?\u201d, the old lady answered, \u201cYou\u2019re very clever, young man, very clever. But it\u2019s turtles all the way down.\u201d Plainly, Hawking can appreciate the ironies implicit in the speculative side of quantum physics.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>We are each free to believe what we want and it is my view that the simplest explanation is there is no God</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>In fact, what follows is not fanciful but hard-nosed, an authoritative account, addressed to the layman, of Hawking\u2019s understanding of space and time, the expanding universe, particle physics and the origins of the universe. Nearly 30 years from publication, Hawking has refined some of his ideas. In 1988, he seems to have been tempted by quasi-spiritual distractions. In 2011, he spoke out unequivocally in favour of an <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/2011/may/15/stephen-hawking-interview-there-is-no-heaven\">aetheistical understanding of man\u2019s origins</a>: \u201cWe are each free to believe what we want and it is my view that the simplest explanation is there is no God. No one created the universe and no one directs our fate. This leads me to a profound realisation. There is probably no heaven, and no afterlife either. We have this one life to appreciate the grand design of the universe, and for that, I am extremely grateful.\u201d</p> <p>Hawking\u2019s own life and his heroic struggle with the debilitating effects of motor neurone disease have become braided into the world\u2019s response to <em>A Brief History</em> and many of his subsequent speculations, as if his suffering has somehow sharpened his perception of the cosmos and its mysteries. For the media, the oracular nature of his utterances, and the remarkable courage with which he has defied all predictions of his imminent mortality, have imbued some of his theories with a quasi-mystical status. The most cursory reading of <em>A Brief History of Time</em> will remind his readers that there is nothing fuzzy or untested about the intelligence behind this contemporary classic.</p> <h2>A signature line</h2> <p>\u201cOur goal is nothing less than a complete description of the universe we live in.\u201d</p> <h2>Three to compare</h2> <p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/isaac-newton\">Isaac Newton</a>: <em>Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy</em> (1687)<br /><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/alberteinstein\">Albert Einstein</a>: \u201cOn the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies\u201d (1905)<br /><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/audio/2014/aug/11/science-weekly-podcast-aristotle-armand-leroi-lagoon\">Aristotle</a>: <em>On the Heavens</em> (circa 340 BC)</p> <ul> <li><em>A Brief History Of Time by Stephen Hawking (Bantam, \u00a38.99). To order a copy for \u00a37.19, go to <a href=\"https://bookshop.theguardian.com/brief-history-of-time.html?utm_source=editoriallink&amp;utm_medium=merch&amp;utm_campaign=article-100-best\">bookshop.theguardian.com</a> or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&amp;p over \u00a310, online orders only. Phone orders min. p&amp;p of \u00a31.99. </em><br /></li> </ul>",

          "body": "<p><span tabindex=\"-1\">Governments around the world are taking a leap into the future by investing heavily in quantum technology research. The UK alone has pledged </span><a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theengineer.co.uk/quantum-technology-roadmap-unveiled-for-the-uk/\">\u00a3270m over five years</a><span tabindex=\"-1\">, with the more cautious Australian government </span><a draggable=\"true\" href=\"http://www.theaustralian.com.au/higher-education/additional-70m-raised-to-finance-quantum-computer-in-silicon/news-story/7908abc97ad90aac5937cdb908ec958e\">promising a AU$25m</a><span tabindex=\"-1\"> (\u00a315m) investment over the same period, and the Canadians putting in </span><a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2016/apr/16/justin-trudeau-stuns-audience-with-quantum-computing-knowledge-canada-video\">$50m</a><span tabindex=\"-1\"> (\u00a331m).</span></p> <p>So just what are they investing in, and why? While the end product may be some way off, quantum technologies promise to deliver multibillion-pound industries across multiple sectors in return for that investment. </p> <p>Quantum has touched a political nerve, from the <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"http://uknqt.epsrc.ac.uk/\">UK\u2019s National Quantum Technologies Programme</a>, Australia\u2019s <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"http://www.cqc2t.org/\">Centre for Quantum Computation and Communication Technology</a>  or the European Union\u2019s \u20ac1bn (\u00a30.9bn) for an <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"http://www.wired-gov.net/wg/news.nsf/articles/Quantum+Manifesto+%E2%82%AC1bn+for+European+quantum+computer+18052016151500?open\">EU quantum manifesto</a>, not to mention Canadian prime minister Justin Trudeau\u2019s <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2016/apr/16/justin-trudeau-stuns-audience-with-quantum-computing-knowledge-canada-video\">well-documented knowledge of the topic</a>. </p> <h2>What is quantum technology?</h2> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/22/age-of-quantum-computing-d-wave\">Has the age of quantum computing arrived?</a> </p> </aside>  <p>When you think of quantum you\u2019re transported into the subatomic world of Schr\u00f6dinger and his cat and the ability to be in two states at the same time. </p> <p>In the case of the cat, locked in a box with a randomly triggered radiation source, it\u2019s both alive and dead until the box is opened and it can be observed as either one or the other. </p> <p>In the quantum computing world, the bits at the heart of a computer with a binary state of either one or zero become qubits (quantum bits), which can simultaneously be a one, zero, both or anything in-between. If a binary system has a one or zero at opposite poles of a sphere, then a quantum one has values anywhere and everywhere. </p> <p>This makes a quantum system fast at calculating because it can test every possibility simultaneously; no waiting for one calculation after another. Interrupt it at any given time to collapse it at one of its states, and hey presto you have your answer. </p> <p>There is, of course, a caveat: you have to control the qubits and the subatomic particles in which they are stored. And that is very, very hard indeed. Even the likes of Intel, which last year pledged $50m (\u00a339m) to quantum computing research at the University of Delft, admit that a practical quantum computer is at least a decade away. </p> <h2>Privacy is dead</h2> <p>What can we look forward to when quantum computers do arrive? Well, there\u2019s the death of encryption for a start.</p> <p>Encryption of data relies upon how time consuming it is to factor very large numbers into two primes. A quantum computer will quickly decrypt data that would take billions of years today. You might think this bad from the security perspective, allowing criminals to decrypt every encrypted database. </p> <p>But quantum research is expensive, very expensive. So the \u201cgood guys\u201d, with the government budgets, will get the tech first, by a long margin. And when the bad guys do get all the gear, what quantum giveth it will soon taketh away again. While quantum computers will crack most any encryption, you\u2019ll know your data\u2019s been looked at, thanks to something called entanglement. Einstein called this <a href=\"https://www.technologyreview.com/s/427174/einsteins-spooky-action-at-a-distance-paradox-older-than-thought/\">\u201cspooky action at a distance\u201d</a> and spooky it may be, but it does provide us with perfect privacy. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media-network/2016/dec/08/5g-cognitive-radio-future-connectivity-business\">Quantum key distribution</a> systems are already being developed that will know if they are being eavesdropped on and stop communicating until the spy goes away. </p> <h2>What will governments do with quantum?</h2> <p>Can quantum help governments wage war? Perhaps. The Ministry of Defence lab at Porton Down has been developing a device to measure tiny fluctuations in gravitational pull, which would act like <a href=\"http://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/gravity-sensor-detector-see-through-walls-underground-ministry-of-defence-mod-bbc-horizon-project-a6947906.html\">super accurate radar</a>, with the capability to see through walls or deep underground. </p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/news/2015/nov/04/relativity-quantum-mechanics-universe-physicists\">Relativity v quantum mechanics \u2013 the battle for the universe </a> </p> </aside>  <p>But some of the most exciting possibilities lie in the area of public health. Researchers at the University of Glasgow, working for one of the quantum technology hubs, established through \u00a3120m of UK investment, are hoping to revolutionise quantum imaging. Their projects include developing ultrasensitive cameras that can actually detect light down to a single photon. This has the potential to detect cancer without invasive medical imaging. </p> <p>And Australian researchers from the government-funded <a href=\"http://www.cqc2t.org/\">Centre for Quantum Computation and Communication Technology</a> are taking the field of medical imaging into a whole new dimension. Rather than using magnets to create 3D images, the team\u2019s <a href=\"http://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms12667\">nano-MRI project </a>uses the natural magnetic properties of the qubit to, in theory at least, allow imaging at the molecular level. If used to determine the structure of biomolecules such as proteins it could overcome many issues researchers face when developing new drugs.</p> <p>At the moment quantum computing is largely speculative and hugely expensive. It has staggering potential, but it remains to be seen whether governments\u2019 investments will pay off in the real world of public services. </p> <p><strong>Talk to us on Twitter via </strong><strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/guardianpublic\">@Guardianpublic</a> and </strong><strong><a href=\"https://register.theguardian.com/public-leaders/\">sign up</a></strong><strong> for your free weekly Guardian Public Leaders newsletter with news and analysis sent direct to you every Thursday.</strong></p>",

          "body": "<p>David Miliband, the former British foreign secretary now heading one of the world\u2019s largest humanitarian aid and refugee resettlement organizations, has denounced President Trump\u2019s refugee ban as a threat to the global standing of all western countries.</p> \n<p>Miliband, president of the New York-headquartered International Rescue Committee, is at the center of the billowing dispute over Trump\u2019s immigration order that has caused havoc at airports, prompted protests and court challenges, and provoked <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/30/state-department-mutiny-trump-refugee-ban\">unprecedented</a> <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/30/justice-department-trump-immigration-acting-attorney-general-sally-yates\">internal</a> opposition within the US government.</p> \n<p>In an interview with the Guardian, he slammed Trump\u2019s contentious action for imperiling the basis on which western countries were regarded favorably around the world<strong>. </strong></p> \n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> \n <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/31/jared-kushner-grandmother-refugee-holocaust\">'The world's doors were closed': Jared Kushner's grandma on refugee life</a> </p> \n</aside> \n<p>\u201cThis is a test for the western world not just for America. It\u2019s a test of whether or not we hold fast to the values of non-discrimination and to universal values of freedom from persecution, so the stakes are very high,\u201d he said.<br></p> \n<p>Miliband said that \u201cthe allure, the glow, the magnetism\u201d of the west was being cast in doubt. Such influence depended, he said, on the principle that people were able to \u201chold their political views, practice their religion, lead their lives in ways that are not dominated by capricious discrimination\u201d.</p> \n<p>He added: \u201cThat allure remains strong. But when you meet families that are being torn apart by this ban, that causes doubt about what our countries stand for, and that is one of the most dangerous aspects of this.\u201d</p> \n<p>Trump\u2019s executive order, signed last Friday, is focused in all but name at Muslims attempting to enter the US. It blocked all entry for 90 days for citizens of seven majority-Muslim countries: Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen.</p> \n<p>The order also singled out refugees for harsh treatment, those deemed by the UN to have a well-founded fear of persecution on grounds of race, religion, political views or other factors. Trump banned entry of all refugees for the next four months, with Syria made subject to an indefinite refugee ban.</p> \n<p>In total, some 60,000 refugees who have already been granted security clearance to come to the US, are now in limbo as a result of the ban.</p> \n<p>The order has caused aftershocks across the Middle East and Europe, itself in the throes of its own refugee crisis. In the UK, the prime minister, Theresa May, has come under <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/29/theresa-may-feels-heat-over-travel-ban-as-donald-trump-stands-firm\">fierce criticism</a> for cozying up to Trump, including holding his hand at the White House and inviting him to a state visit to the UK, while showing reluctance to criticize his immigration stance. </p> \n<p>Trump and May gave a joint press conference at the White House last Friday at which they heralded the renewed \u201cspecial relationship\u201d between the US and UK. Moments after May left Washington, the US president unleashed his executive order. </p> \n<p>Miliband noted the confluence of events. He said it was a \u201cpity\u201d that the UK prime minister \u201cwasn\u2019t able to express the British position at the press conference with Donald Trump standing next to her\u201d.</p> \n<p>He said: \u201cThe special relationship brings a special responsibility. Americans will notice clarity and conviction, and it\u2019s very important that it\u2019s expressed by America\u2019s closest allies.\u201d</p> \n<p>He added that he hoped the shock and outrage that had erupted across the US over Trump\u2019s immigration order would act as a wake-up call for Europe. \u201cThis should remind Europeans that what we now call European values of solidarity, compassion and internationalism were hard fought for. It should certainly be a reason for people in Britain to realize that Brexit is no excuse to abandon what we regard as civilized values.\u201d</p> \n<p>The IRC\u2019s work is likely to be affected on many levels by Trump\u2019s immigration ban. Founded in 1933 by Albert Einstein, himself a refugee to the US, the organization spans the full arc of the current crisis, from working on the ground in the countries covered by the order, including Iraq and Syria, as well as being one of the largest refugee resettlement groups in the US.</p> \n<p>The profile of the average refugee entering the US sharply contrasts with the ominous image of terrorist Trojan horses conjured up by Trump. Half of all refugees entering the country each year are children under the age of 14, and women make up a large portion of the remainder.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> \n <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"36addf8b-64a0-4d1d-92fa-fe3f37d7e70c\" data-atom-type=\"explainer\"> \n  <div>\n   <figure class=\"element element-explainer element-atom\" data-display-type=\"flat\"> \n    <h1>US travel ban - a brief guide</h1> \n    <div>\n     <p>The executive order signed by Donald Trump suspends the entire US refugee admissions system,&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/sep/02/donald-trump-syria-refugees-us-immigration-security-terrorism\">already one of the most rigorous in the world</a>, for 120 days.&nbsp;It also&nbsp;suspends the Syrian refugee program indefinitely, and&nbsp;bans entry to the US to people from seven majority-Muslim countries \u2013 Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen \u2013 for 90 days. The order has prompted a series of legal challenges, while thousands of Americans have protested outside airports and courthouses in solidarity with Muslims and migrants.</p>\n    </div> \n   </figure> \n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>A paradox of Trump\u2019s pledge to introduce \u201cextreme vetting\u201d is that refugees are already subjected to more extreme vetting by the US than any other group. They have to jump through numerous hoops in the course of an intense review that can last up to three years, including biometric testing, face-to-face interviews and background checks by the FBI, CIA and other intelligence and security agencies.</p> \n<p>By specifically targeting Muslims, Trump was playing with fire, Miliband said: \u201cThis policy is a propaganda gift to extremists around the world who want to tell Muslim communities that America doesn\u2019t want them and doesn\u2019t want to help them. That is a real and present danger to global stability.\u201d</p> \n<p>In his travels through the US in recent months, Miliband said he had met a number of individuals who underlined the positive contributions made by refugees. He recalled the baklava baker from Damascus whose house was bombed in 2012 and who recently relocated to America, and the Iranian Christian who fled religious persecution.</p> \n<p>Such encounters had taught him \u201cthe wisdom of the terrible quote from Stalin that a single death is a tragedy, a million deaths a statistic. I think there\u2019s a grave danger in the refugee crisis that the scale of the numbers desensitizes people. The first thing is to remember the human scale: what we are trying to do is make the world better one life at the time\u201d.</p> \n<p>Miliband noted that working as he does in the IRC\u2019s Manhattan offices he often glimpses the Statue of Liberty in the distance, causing him to reflect on the famous poem on its base: \u201cGive me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free.\u201d </p> \n<p>\u201cWe\u2019ve always known that America had its political divisions, but there has never been a notion of two Americas when it comes to the idea of providing a haven to refugees,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a shocking thought that America could divide on the very idea of its foundation.\u201d</p>",
