          "body": "<p>It is lunchtime. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/live/2016/may/28/england-sri-lanka-second-test-day-two-live\">England face Sri Lanka</a> in the second test, and the radio commentary is on as we eat. The cricketers are also at lunch, but the commentary from <a href=\"https://twitter.com/bbctms\">BBC Test Match Special</a> continues with an \u2018Ask the Umpire\u2019 session, in which bizarre and unlikely cricket scenarios are postulated,<br /></p> <blockquote class=\"quoted\"> <p><em>A batsman hits the ball in the air towards the stumps, it grazes the bowler\u2019s fingers, hits the stumps (with the non-striker out of his ground) and loops up into the air and is caught at mid-on. Who\u2019s out?</em></p> </blockquote> <p>and their resolution within the laws of cricket is explored. </p> <p>This prokes exasperation and amusement from the rest of my family, but then so does cricket in general to some extent. If you really want to understand the laws of cricket though (and I appreciate that is quite a big \u201cif\u201d), it is a useful exercise to imagine how they would operate in extreme cases.<br /></p> <p>While I am mildly interested in the laws of cricket, I am very interested in the laws of physics. Real experiments arbitrate eventually, of course, but thought experiments have a long and productive history of pointing the way to deeper understanding. <br /></p> <p>Probably the master of them was Einstein. He imagined trying to catch up with a ray of light, and decided the idea was absurd. This influenced his development of his theories of relativity, in which it is impossible to catch up with light, because it travels at the same speed for everyone. The theory led to predictions that are, arguably, equally absurd. Time flows at different rates depending on relative speed, for example. But those predictions have been thoroughly vindicated by real experiments. <br /></p> <p>Thought experiments including relativitistic pole-vaulters running into garages, spacefareing twins, or train guards with flashlights are still important in teaching relativity and testing how thoroughly you and your students have (mis)understood it.<br /></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/life-and-physics/2014/nov/22/sizing-up-a-new-particle-accelerator-and-the-cosmic-stupid-limit\">Sizing up a new particle accelerator, and the 'cosmic stupid' limit | Jon Butterworth | Life&amp;Physics</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Einstein bowled a series of thought experiments at the great Danish physicist Niels Bohr in the first half of the 20th Century, in an attempt to defeat quantum indeterminism. In this case, Bohr\u2019s straight bat was firm enough to reply, and he finished the innings \u2018not out\u2019. The result was a better understanding of physics all round, however.<br /></p> <p>Erwin Schr\u00f6dinger, one of the pioneers of quantum mechanics, also used thought experiments. As far as we know, no cats were harmed in his famous attempt to highlight the apparent contradictions of the so-called \u2018Copenhagen Interpretation\u2019 of the new theory. Schr\u00f6dinger\u2019s Cat lives on as a useful idea however, still relevant as physicists build larger and larger coherent quantum systems, in attempts to understand the fundamentals of quantum mechanics and also to make use of them in practical applications such as <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/22/age-of-quantum-computing-d-wave\">computing</a>.</p> <p>One of the biggest open questions in physics is how gravity and quantum mechanics might come together to give a single consistent description of nature. We may be lucky and get clues about this from real experiments, but much of the exploration of the boundaries between these two giants of physics has to take place at such extreme energies that thought experiments are the only way forward for now. The quantum emission of radiation near the event horizon of a black hole is a good example, famously theorized by Stephen Hawking.</p> <p>The bit about \u2018contrived extremes\u2019 lends itself to certain political analogies, especially in the UK and the USA at present, but I am not going to go there. An important aspect of thought experiments is that they are cheap and safe. In thought, we can travel to the event horizon of a black hole without being spaghettified. We can ponder quantum coherence without harming any cats, and try to overtake a light ray without leaving our armchair. We can check the rules of the game for consistency without having to watch every ball until one heads for the stumps, grazes the bowler\u2019s fingers and loops into the air.<br /></p> <p>And on that last point, to resolve the suspense cunningly introduced at the start of the article:<br /></p> <blockquote class=\"quoted\"> <p><em>The catch takes precedence over the run-out, so the striker is out. Same as bowled takes precedence over lbw.</em></p> </blockquote> <p>The quantum gravity business is, I\u2019m afraid, not yet resolved.</p> <p><em><a href=\"https://twitter.com/jonmbutterworth\">Jon Butterworth</a>\u2019s book </em><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/may/02/smashing-physics-jon-butterworth-review-cern-higgs-boson-particle\"><em>Smashing Physics</em></a><em> </em><em>is available as \u201cMost Wanted Particle</em>\u201d<em> in Canada &amp; the US.</em></p>",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/society/2017/sep/05/i-assumed-it-was-all-my-fault-the-adults-dealing-with-undiagnosed-adhd",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>Michelle Beckett, a 44-year-old entrepreneur from Harrogate, always knew she was different. But, like many women who suffer from <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/society/attention-deficit-hyperactivity-disorder\" title=\"\">attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD),</a> she did not fit the stereotypical profile of a child with the condition. Beckett\u2019s difficulties would come later in life, when she failed to live up to her academic potential, experienced two failed marriages and had mental health\u00a0problems.</p> <p>At 36, Beckett decided to seek help. A <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/neuroscience\" title=\"\">neuroscientist</a> in York told her that the results of an EEG\u00a0\u2013 a\u00a0recording of brain activity\u00a0\u2013 suggested she had ADHD. \u201cI\u00a0dismissed his diagnosis as rubbish,\u201d she says. \u201cHow could I\u00a0have ADHD? I\u00a0was just [being] crap and needed to sort myself\u00a0out.\u201d</p> <p>Beckett\u2019s problems escalated from there. She experienced mood swings so dramatic that any criticism could cause her to go from feeling happy to contemplating suicide. After a\u00a0failed business venture, she ended up in the care of a\u00a0local mental health crisis\u00a0team, believing that her \u201cfamily and the world would be far better off without\u00a0me\u201d.</p> <p>It was then that ADHD was mentioned again by a\u00a0psychiatrist, and, at the age of 44, she decided to seek a\u00a0private diagnosis; one that not only transformed her life but saved it: \u201cEverything fell into place. I\u00a0wasn\u2019t crap because I\u00a0found VAT returns painful,\u00a0blurted out stuff and\u00a0was messy. I\u00a0wasn\u2019t crap at all. I\u00a0have a\u00a0neuro difference, which gives me many advantages.\u201d Beckett is just one of many people who slipped through the diagnostic net as children and were left to cope with their ADHD into\u00a0adulthood.</p> <p>It\u2019s now <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3000907/\" title=\"\">30 years</a> since the American Psychiatric Association agreed that ADHD was the best term to describe this\u00a0condition. It has long been viewed as something that predominantly affects children\u00a0\u2013 mostly young boys\u00a0\u2013 but increasing numbers of adults are now being diagnosed. According to the <a href=\"http://www.rcpsych.ac.uk/healthadvice/problemsdisorders/adhdinadults.aspx\" title=\"\">Royal College of Psychiatrists,</a> ADHD is indeed more common in boys than in girls \u2013 surveys of children between the ages of five and 15 years have found that 3.62% of boys and 0.85% of girls had ADHD. As many people get older, however, the condition improves and around 1% of adults continue to have the condition, with about 2-4% showing partial\u00a0symptoms.</p> <p>ADHD in adults has come under the spotlight this year with new advances in clinical research. A BBC Horizon programme featured comedian Rory Bremner\u2019s personal journey to understand the science behind the condition. And the thinktank Demos has started a\u00a0research project exploring the social and financial impact of undiagnosed ADHD in adults. It is due to be completed this\u00a0year.</p> <p>Even though ADHD is viewed as a\u00a0modern condition, it was being discussed as early as the <a href=\"http://adhdhistory.com/sir-george-f-still/\" title=\"\">Edwardian\u00a0period, probably as a result of the </a>advent of compulsory schooling in\u00a0Britain.</p> <p>I\u00a0was diagnosed with ADHD when I\u00a0was six. I\u00a0doubt my psychiatrist felt much ambivalence when he was diagnosing me. During one of the assessments, instead of focusing on arranging a\u00a0series of pictures into chronological order, I\u00a0thought it would be more productive to climb to the top of the bookshelves in his office. I\u00a0was easy to diagnose, but many children with ADHD aren\u2019t bouncing off the walls or scaling bookshelves and are therefore much less likely to receive a\u00a0diagnosis in childhood. This is especially true for women, whose ADHD tends to manifest in less overt ways than it does in\u00a0boys.</p> <p>Dr Ashok\u00a0Roy, head of the Royal College of Psychiatrists\u2019 intellectual disability\u00a0faculty, says the core symptoms are the same in men and women, but that \u201cfemale patients\u2019 inattention problems often are combined with daydreaming, whereas men have more hyperactivity and behavioural problems, which are more noticeable during\u00a0childhood\u201d. Roy has also observed that women with ADHD also tend to suffer from other disorders that can affect their mood and\u00a0behaviour.</p> <p>Arielle, a 27-year-old writer from Boston, was diagnosed with ADHD when she was\u00a019. She remembers always being a\u00a0quiet child: \u201cI\u00a0didn\u2019t show the classic signs people think of when they hear about hyperactivity. Instead of bouncing off the walls, I\u00a0simply fidget constantly. I\u00a0slept through most of school, but, if I\u00a0was awake, I\u00a0never was an attentive listener,\u201d she\u00a0says.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>Over the years, I started to assume I was just lazy</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Arielle says her grades suffered throughout school because she was unable to focus on her homework. Her teachers told her that if she just did her homework, stayed awake in class and became organised, she could be a\u00a0straight-A student. \u201cOver the years, I\u00a0started to assume I\u00a0was just lazy. Instead of thinking there might be something wrong biologically, I\u00a0assumed it was all my fault. And, every time I\u2019d resolve to be better at being attentive in class, or neat or diligent about homework, I\u2019d inevitably\u00a0fail.\u201d</p> <p>Arielle feels that going undiagnosed until adulthood was \u201cpretty harmful\u201d for her, and sometimes tells herself that if she really had ADHD, someone would have noticed it sooner: \u201cI\u00a0still frequently doubt that I\u00a0have ADHD and sometimes believe I\u2019m just fooling everyone in an attempt to excuse my forgetfulness, messy nature, issues with planning ahead and problems completing\u00a0projects.\u201d</p> <p>It\u2019s not surprising that Arielle feels this way, as there is a\u00a0prevailing scepticism about the condition, even among psychiatrists. The most frequent criticism levelled at the diagnosis of ADHD is that it pathologises normal behaviours. The neurologist Dr Richard Saul promoted this idea in his 2014 book, ADHD Does Not Exist. At the same time, in <a href=\"http://time.com/25370/doctor-adhd-does-not-exist/\" title=\"\">an article for Time magazine</a>, Saul expressed concern over the stimulants used to treat ADHD\u00a0\u2013 most commonly methylphenidate\u00a0\u2013 and argued that, under the criteria employed to diagnose the condition, \u201cthe entire US population could potentially qualify. We have all had these moments and, in moderate amounts, they\u2019re a\u00a0normal part of the human\u00a0condition.\u201d</p> <p>These arguments tend to come as a\u00a0reaction to the recent explosion of ADHD diagnoses in children, particularly in the US. However, Roy argues that \u201cuntreated populations fare worse on academic, social and occupational outcomes as well as contact with the law\u201d. He argues that practitioners should \u201cguard against overdiagnosis by the use of systematic assessments using internationally agreed\u00a0criteria\u201d.</p> <p>In April this year, <a href=\"http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanpsy/article/PIIS2215-0366(17)30049-4/fulltext\" title=\"\">the Lancet </a>published a\u00a0report that suggests the condition is a\u00a0valid pathology. Researchers from nine countries scanned the brains of people aged between four and 63 years old, 1,713 with ADHD and 1,529 without. The report found small differences in brain size between those with the condition and those without it. These differences were more pronounced in children, and the differences were still apparent in unmedicated\u00a0subjects.</p> <p>If we accept that ADHD is real, then we might want to address the lack of awareness that exists within our society, as undiagnosed adults are often left to live dysfunctional lives. According to Roy, part of the problem when diagnosing adults is that they are more likely to \u201cinternalise their inner restlessness rather than act it out as children\u00a0do\u201d. Roy adds: \u201cThis may manifest as mood swings, difficulty getting along with others, problems holding down a\u00a0job, substance-abuse problems, and a\u00a0pattern of being irresponsible and making poor decisions. These behaviours may be incorrectly attributed to personality problems, anxiety or depression rather than\u00a0ADHD.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"8d41aa2d621c610505699ceb0ddc2338bd66c277\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8d41aa2d621c610505699ceb0ddc2338bd66c277/0_424_4122_5153/800.jpg\" alt=\"Victoria Jones \u2026 \u2018It has been a revelation to understand it.\u2019\" width=\"800\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Victoria Jones \u2026 \u2018It has been a revelation to understand it.\u2019</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Jon Super for the Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Indeed, the most common story I hear from those I speak to with ADHD is that they were diagnosed with conditions such as depression and anxiety before they discovered they had it. This is something I\u00a0can attest to. I\u00a0stopped receiving treatment for ADHD in my teens. This was partly because I\u00a0moved around so much but also because I\u00a0was resistant to the label; I\u00a0didn\u2019t want to believe there was something wrong with me. In my early 20s, I\u00a0sought treatment again only because my life was falling apart. I\u00a0didn\u2019t receive the support I\u00a0felt I\u00a0needed and was given antidepressants and anti-anxiety medication instead.</p> <p>Victoria Jones is a\u00a0very amiable student from Lancashire who begins talking to me a\u00a0mile a\u00a0minute in a\u00a0way that would defeat the deftest shorthand practitioner. Like many people with undiagnosed\u00a0ADHD, she had been treated for anxiety and depression for 10 years prior to her diagnosis. Before being diagnosed, Jones led a\u00a0chaotic life, experienced many failed relationships, flitted from one job to the other, and eventually ended up owing \u00a325,000 through impulse spending and her inability to manage her debts.</p> <p>Since being diagnosed with ADHD at age 34, she has been on \u201ca\u00a0rollercoaster\u201d of emotions and\u00a0learning: \u201cHaving been one of those people who thought it was an excuse for boys\u2019 \u2018naughty\u2019 behaviour, it has been a\u00a0revelation to learn about and understand\u00a0it.\u201d She is involved in an ADHD support group in Lancashire and wants to raise awareness about the condition: \u201cI\u00a0wish more than anything that the media, schools and other agencies were educated better on the topic and it became as understood and supported as autism. I\u00a0think this would give families, friends and the rest of society the means to assist in and improve the lives of those who have\u00a0it.\u201d</p> <p>John, 30, from the home\u00a0counties, says he has struggled with insomnia since childhood and has experienced problems in his personal and professional life due to his forgetfulness: \u201cMy relationships always suffer\u00a0\u2013 I\u00a0have lost count of the number of friends from my teens and early 20s I\u00a0no longer speak to due to being useless at keeping in touch, forgetting to respond to messages or simply not remembering that they exist.\u201d John adds that this applies to everything in his life: \u201cIf it\u2019s beyond my very narrow, immediate focus, it gets ignored, even consciously put to one side. I\u00a0will step over piles of urgent laundry to complete my pointless DIY project. I\u00a0will pay late fees on bills I\u00a0can easily afford just because it seems that paying them will take me several hours, and I\u00a0really want to do something\u00a0else.\u201d</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>I will step over piles of urgent laundry to complete my pointless DIY project</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>John was finally diagnosed quite recently and, like many adults with ADHD, he became aware of the condition through his own\u00a0research. He was assessed and diagnosed relatively quickly, but has mixed feelings about the treatment he has received: \u201cI\u2019ve been on methylphenidate since being diagnosed a\u00a0few months ago. Initially, I\u00a0thought it was a\u00a0gamechanger\u00a0\u2013 I\u00a0could sit down and complete something without getting distracted.\u201d But more recently John has begun to have doubts: \u201cI\u00a0notice I\u00a0can be a\u00a0little too focused, energetic and positive, and if I am doing something pointless when my meds kick in, that can be a\u00a0whole day\u00a0wasted.\u201d</p> <p>Andrew Kavanagh, 44, an animator from Dublin, didn\u2019t receive a\u00a0diagnosis until he was 43. \u201cI\u00a0often wondered why I\u00a0had so many challenges in achieving what others found relatively easy to do,\u201d he says. He only suspected he might have the condition when he met the neuroscientist \u00c1ine Behan, who, as CEO of Cortechs, was developing gaming technology to help children with ADHD improve their focus. \u201cI\u00a0knew little about the condition at the time, but as my research into the area deepened, I\u00a0recognised many of my own traits in the symptoms attributed to ADHD\u00a0sufferers.\u201d</p> <p>Kavanagh describes himself as fidgety, often impatient, a\u00a0poor sleeper and someone who struggles to complete tasks. \u201cI\u00a0often feel like when I\u00a0start something, I should be able to do it immediately rather than having to go through a\u00a0learning process. I\u2019ve always been impatient for results and often start a\u00a0lot of different things and quickly become\u00a0overwhelmed.\u201d</p> <p>Roy says that many adults remain undiagnosed because psychiatrists do not receive enough\u00a0training. He believes the government needs to invest more in this. Labour\u2019s shadow minister for mental health, Barbara Keeley, agrees. \u201cAdults with ADHD who are undiagnosed and untreated in childhood are at greater risk of low self-esteem, substance abuse, anxiety and depression,\u201d she says. \u201cInvesting in children\u2019s mental health services and in early intervention is key to preventing this spiral.\u201d She adds that it is \u201cdeeply worrying\u201d that Health Education England is cutting back on training courses for GPs and\u00a0trainees.</p> <p>The Department of Health describes Keeley\u2019s comments as \u201ccompletely misleading\u201d and adds that since 2005 the government has made an additional \u00a3250m available each year for children\u2019s mental health services, and that by the end of 2017 it intends to publish a\u00a0green paper setting out plans to improve access and the provision of\u00a0services.</p> <p>It\u2019s not clear if ADHD should be considered an\u00a0illness. It really describes a\u00a0different type of\u00a0brain, and may be partially responsible for the achievements of many successful people, including Albert Einstein and Katherine Ellison. Despite the serious problems that adults with undiagnosed ADHD face, many living with the condition say it has had a\u00a0positive impact on their lives\u00a0too. As well as being inattentive, their ADHD allows them to hyper-focus, and their impulsivity can inspire\u00a0creativity.</p> <p>Beckett says she wouldn\u2019t change her ADHD. \u201cI\u00a0can be quick-thinking, creative, adaptable, warm, enthusiastic, authentic, honest, spontaneous, ambitious, driven to change the world, feisty and outspoken. I am interested in many different types of people, many different issues and many concepts and ideas. I\u00a0strongly believe I\u00a0wouldn\u2019t have these traits if I\u00a0didn\u2019t have\u00a0ADHD.\u201d</p> <p>Kavanagh has a\u00a0similar outlook and likens ADHD to a \u201cclockwork toy wound up and set loose in a\u00a0labyrinth without a\u00a0map. You run in to a\u00a0lot of walls, but occasionally you break through some of\u00a0them.\u201d He, too, says he wouldn\u2019t change his condition: \u201cDespite all the hard knocks I have encountered getting to where I\u00a0am, I\u00a0wouldn\u2019t trade ADHD for anything. It\u2019s part of what makes me who I\u00a0am, and I\u00a0embrace\u00a0that.\u201d</p> <p><em>Some names have been changed. The charity </em><a href=\"http://www.addiss.co.uk/\" title=\"\"><em>Addiss</em></a><em> offers help and advice for people who wish to find out more about ADHD.</em></p>",

          "body": "<p>Last November, the Guardian environment columnist <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/profile/mckibben-bill\">Bill McKibben </a> made the grim prediction that the \u201cdamage from the US election would be measured in geologic time\u201d.</p> <p>One hundred days and counting into Trump\u2019s presidency, there\u2019s little reason for optimism. The former CEO Of ExxonMobil is our secretary of state. The new head of the US Environmental Protection Agency wants to dismantle the agency. The Keystone pipeline has been revived, the clean power plan is in peril, and vast swaths of the Atlantic seaboard may be opened to offshore drilling.</p> <p>At this critical moment, the Guardian has <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/gnm-press-office/2017/mar/30/guardian-bolsters-award-winning-environment-team\">expanded its environment desk</a>, adding three heavyweight reporters to its continent-spanning, award-winning team to bolster our coverage in the US and around the world.</p> <p>\u201cThe environment barely exists as a political issue in many developed countries, and there are climate change deniers in the White House,\u201d the Guardian\u2019s editor-in-chief, Katharine Viner, wrote in a recent email to staff announcing the appointments. \u201cThere has never been a greater need for serious and innovative environmental journalism.\u201d</p> <p>In the US, we\u2019ll continue to aggressively cover the Trump administration\u2019s ties to the fossil fuel industry and attacks on science. We\u2019ll tackle issues of environmental justice, and the impact of climate change and pollution on the nation\u2019s most vulnerable communities. Just today we launched <a draggable=\"true\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/may/02/keystone-xl-pipeline-route-water-native-american-reserves\">Life on the Keystone XL</a>, a three-part series documenting our reporter\u2019s 1,700-mile journey along the proposed pipeline route to meet the people and communities who will be affected should the construction go ahead.</p> <p>We\u2019ll also explore solutions and opportunities to the climate change crisis, such as innovative technology, renewable energy and green growth.</p> <p>As part of the new appointments, the Guardian\u2019s Jonathan Watts will take up the role of global environment editor in a few months\u2019 time. Below, he shares his thoughts on why, after 21 years reporting for the Guardian from Tokyo, Beijing and Rio de Janeiro, he believes this is the most important story on the planet right now.<br /></p> <p><em>Support the Guardian\u2019</em><em>s in-depth and investigative reporting on cli</em><em>mate change and environment <a href=\"https://membership.theguardian.com/supporter?INTCMP=gdnwb_copts_editorial_memco_jsclimate_copy\">by becoming a member</a> or <a href=\"https://contribute.theguardian.com?INTCMP=gdnwb_copts_editorial_memco_jsclimate_copy\">making a contribution today</a>.</em></p> <h2><strong>A message from Jonathan Watts, the Guardian\u2019s newly appointed global environment editor</strong></h2> <p>The environment has always been a subject close to my heart and it has become an increasing focus of my work over two decades with the Guardian. That is no doubt because the problems of climate change, biodiversity loss, pollution and over-consumption have become bigger and more apparent.<br /></p> <p>When I started out as a cub reporter in Japan in the mid-1990s, I learned a lot collaborating with Paul Brown, then the environment correspondent, on articles about the Tokaimura nuclear accident and Kyoto climate protocol. After moving to China in 2003, I increasingly found myself writing about smog, cancer villages, species extinction and carbon emissions. The ramping up of environmental stories was not a deliberate strategy. China\u2019s crisis was so bad that it was impossible to ignore. This made for grim news, but it also made me hopeful that it might be a fulcrum for change. </p> <p>After the Olympics in 2008, I switched jobs to become Asia environment correspondent. In this post, I covered the Copenhagen Climate Conference with John Vidal and Suzanne Goldenberg; the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2010/oct/25/nagoya-biodiversity-summit\">Nagoya biodiversity conference</a>; the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/apr/03/fukushima-fears-nuclear-angle-japan-suffering\">Fukushima tsunami and nuclear disaster</a>; and the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/mar/19/china-windfarms-renewable-energy\">rapid growth of wind</a> and solar power in the deserts of China. For the past five years, I have been the Guardian\u2019s Latin America correspondent, writing on a broader range of subjects but still putting a priority on environment and development, including <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/nov/27/amazon-deforestation-report-brazil-paris-climate-talks\">Amazon deforestation</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/03/honduras-berta-caceres-murder-enivronment-activist-human-rights\">killings of conservation activists</a>, the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/sep/09/amazon-tribe-protecting-forest-bows-arrows-gps-camera-traps\">role of indigenous communities in forest protection</a> and the disturbing frequency of forest fires, floods and other extreme weather events.</p> <p>So why am I going back into full-time, specialised environmental reporting? Because it is the most important story of our age. China led me to suspect that global economic growth had run into an ecological wall, which is the underlying source of stress and conflict in the world. When I moved to Latin America, I hoped to find alternative, less destructive paths of development, but there was a part of me that also felt I was running away from my own conclusions. The new post will take me back.</p> <p>The responsibility is huge. The timing is crucial. The Brexit referendum was a vote against globalisation. Trump is waging war on the environment. To counter these trends, the Guardian has devoted more resources to its environment coverage. I am looking forward to being a part of an expanded team, but we have a tough act to follow. Brown, Vidal, George Monbiot, Damian Carrington and other present and former colleagues have been pioneers in this field with agenda-setting coverage and comment. Trying to maintain that quality, ambition and influence \u2013 while looking for new approaches to changing situations \u2013 will be a hard but worthwhile task.<br /></p> <p>As to the task that humanity faces, I think the problem and the solution are environmental. The world\u2019s current concerns \u2013 rising nationalism, swelling migration, financial instability, worsening inequality and lack of confidence in governance systems \u2013 are to varying degrees caused by insecurity and fear about the future. Underlying that is an awareness (conscious or unconscious) that our current path of capital- and carbon-driven development is wrecking our home planet, running down resources, devastating other species and building up environmental costs that are increasingly difficult to offload on distant countries and coming generations. We have to pay a bill that has been run up over centuries and it feels as if we are broke. But that is misleading. There is still plenty left if we manage it well and share it more fairly.</p> <p>We need to reconsider what is important, what is worth paying for and how decisions are being made. At a national level, why are we devoting so much public money to subsidise fossil fuels that are destroying the climate? Why are most politics determined by four-, five- or six-year electoral cycles that suit the markets but not the long-term interests of voters? Why do our economic systems make it cheaper to dump plastic in the oceans than recycle? Why do the traditional beliefs of some countries encourage the slaughter of endangered animals or denial of climate science? Why are forests worth less than cropland? Why do we continue to prioritise material growth when it increasingly leads to obesity, cancer, conflict and instability?</p> <p>The key, I think, is to realise that, contrary to what Bill Clinton\u2019s election strategist once maintained, it\u2019s not \u201cthe economy, stupid!\u201d \u2013 it is in fact the environment that is shaping everything. Which is to say that we must put our home in order before we can consider anything else. That is tough. Currently, political systems are skewed against the environment and the subject is hidden away in a media ghetto. It is a depressing page on a news website or an unpopular slot on TV channels. Most of us would prefer to pretend it didn\u2019t exist. Yet, for me the environment is not a subject, it is the prism through which everything else must be seen. It is the basis for the economy, for science, for society, for politics. Adam Smith, Albert Einstein, Karl Marx and Mao Zedong never understood this. Nor did the founders of the great religions. They didn\u2019t need to. They did not live in the Anthropocene.</p> <p>So, how to put the environment front and centre is the big challenge. Following my predecessors, I will continue to visit the frontline of humankind\u2019s impact on the natural world \u2013 the oceans, forests, mountains, deserts, poles, science labs, conference halls and affected communities \u2013 where I will continue to bear witness and record testimonies of change. But they are just symptoms. I hope I can also work with and encourage my colleagues on other news desks to consider the environment in their coverage of politics, social change, economics, psychology, art, religion and education. Those areas, close to home, perhaps inside our heads, are where we will find the cause and the cure. It\u2019s time to colonise the colonisers.</p> <p>We are all entering disconcerting new territory. Given demographic, economic and consumerist trends, the next 30 years will be difficult. But there is more than enough new knowledge and technology, as well as old philosophy and religion, to make things much better. It is all about choices and action.</p> <p>\u2013 Jonathan Watts, incoming global environment editor for the Guardian </p> <p><em>Support the Guardian\u2019s </em><em>in-depth and investigative reporting on </em><em>climate change and environment <a href=\"https://membership.theguardian.com/supporter?INTCMP=gdnwb_copts_editorial_memco_jsclimate_footer\">by becoming a member</a> or <a href=\"https://contribute.theguardian.com?INTCMP=gdnwb_copts_editorial_memco_jsclimate_footer\">making a contribution today</a>.</em></p>",

          "body": "<p>A fortune teller once warned Zhou Youguang he would not live past 35. The prediction was plausible, as Zhou himself later noted. Average life expectancy in China was then around 30. He had experienced tuberculosis and depression and within a few years would narrowly escape death in a Japanese bombing raid that killed the man beside him. Yet his eventual death came the day after his 111th birthday.</p> <p>By then he had fewer than 50 peers worldwide. The rest are known primarily for their survival, and Zhou had a variety of explanations for his own longevity: modern medicine, eating when hungry and sleeping when tired, and simply the fact that \u201cGod has forgotten me\u201d, a remark reflecting both his humility and his humour. But he had staked his claim to a place in the history books more than half a century before, as \u201cthe father of pinyin\u201d, having established what became the international standard for romanisation of Chinese.</p> <p>It is thanks to pinyin that we now read about Beijing, not Peking. The system helped literacy rates in China to rocket: <a href=\"https://www.quora.com/Do-Chinese-people-read-write-understand-pinyin\" title=\"\">children learn pinyin</a> as a stepping stone to characters because \u2013 unlike these \u2013 it corresponds to the sound of words. It also became \u201ca bridge to speech between Chinese people\u201d, Zhou pointed out, helping Putonghua, or standard Chinese, to spread.</p> <p>\u201cBefore, I met a Cantonese and a Hokkien in foreign countries and couldn\u2019t communicate \u2013 I had to speak English to them. Without an alphabet you had to learn mouth to mouth, ear to ear,\u201d he told me when <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/feb/21/china\" title=\"\">I interviewed him</a> at his modest third-floor apartment in Beijing in 2008. He was a mere 102 then: fascinating, wry, delightful company and unnecessarily apologetic for the rustiness of his (fluent) English.</p> <p>He was born Zhou Yaoping \u2013 he adopted the pen name \u201cYouguang\u201d because he wanted to \u201cbring light\u201d into the world \u2013 to an official\u2019s family in Changzhou, eastern China. The Qing dynasty still ruled. But within five years, China would collapse into turmoil: Zhou would live through warlordism, the rise of the Kuomintang, foreign occupation, civil war, the communist revolution and all that followed.</p> <p>He studied at St John\u2019s University and then Guanghua University in Shanghai, graduating with a degree in economics; he had minored in linguistics. A fellow student was Zhang Yunhe, one of four famously accomplished sisters, whom he married in 1933. After the Japanese invasion they fled to the wartime capital, Chongqing, where their young daughter died of appendicitis because they could not reach the hospital in time.</p> <p>Yet even then he maintained hope. \u201cWhen you encounter difficulties, you need to be optimistic ... The pessimists tend to die,\u201d he told the AFP news agency.</p> <p>In 1946, he moved to New York, where he worked for a Chinese bank on Wall Street and met Albert Einstein via friends at Princeton. But when the communists took power in China three years later, Zhou rejected offers from American banks and chose to return, like so many idealistic intellectuals who hoped to build a new and better China. He became an economics professor in Shanghai.</p> <p>Soon afterwards came his greatest piece of luck. Zhou Enlai, the country\u2019s premier, had met him in Chongqing and now wanted him to oversee a reform of the written language. Zhou Youguang, who regarded his studies of language and linguistics as a hobby, allowed himself to be persuaded, and pinyin was launched in 1958. That shielded him from the worst when Mao Zedong unleashed the vicious <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Rightist_Movement\" title=\"\">anti-rightist campaign</a> a few years later and economist friends were persecuted; several killed themselves.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"da8e9a92591bd847b3b62c2d41d0cf34b95edbdc\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/da8e9a92591bd847b3b62c2d41d0cf34b95edbdc/0_25_569_341/500.jpg\" alt=\"Zhou Youguang and Zhang Yunhe on their wedding day, 30 April 1933.\" width=\"500\" height=\"300\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Zhou Youguang and Zhang Yunhe on their wedding day, 30 April 1933.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: The Paper</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>But after the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2012/feb/24/cultural-revolution-portraits-xu-weixin\" title=\"\">Cultural Revolution</a> broke out in 1966, Zhou was exiled to a labour camp in the countryside. In later life he chuckled with friends about his overqualification for the role to which he had been assigned: the former banker and father of pinyin had been set to work scaring birds away from crops.</p> <p>Following his rehabilitation, he oversaw the translation of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, earning himself the nickname Encyclopaedia Zhou. Officially he retired at 85, but at home he averaged an essay a month. The best tonic was remaining curious and continuing to learn, he said. His embrace of new ideas included helping Sharp to design the first practical electronic Chinese typewriter. The device showed only a single line of text at a time, but he wrote on it until the last; his friend the sinologist <a href=\"http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=9719\" title=\"\">Victor Mair</a> recalls him storing it as though it were a precious relic, unwrapping it each morning and setting to work with relish.</p> <p>The spread of computers and smartphones brought a fresh role for pinyin, which many people rely on to input characters. Zhou wrote at least 10 books after turning 100, but several were banned as he became increasingly outspoken, apparently concluding he had little to lose. In 2011 he told NPR radio network that he hoped to live long enough to see the Chinese authorities admit that the bloody crackdown on Tiananmen Square\u2019s pro-democracy protests in 1989 had been a mistake.</p> <p>\u201cHistory misled us,\u201d he said, when I asked him about his decision to return to China in 1949. Yet he did not regret coming home, he <a href=\"https://lijiazhang.wordpress.com/2017/01/15/great-linguist-zhou-youguang-dies-at-111/\" title=\"\">maintained</a>. Despite the traumas he witnessed and endured, he believed he was where he belonged.</p> <p>Zhang Yunhe, who became an eminent scholar of kunqu, one of the oldest forms of Chinese opera, died in 2002. Their son, Zhou Xiaoping, died in 2015. Zhou is survived by a granddaughter.</p> <p>\u2022 Zhou Youguang (Zhou Yaoping), language scholar, born 13 January 1906; died 14 January 2017</p>",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/technology/2017/apr/30/google-mo-gawdat-solve-for-happy-interview",
        "fields": {
          "body": "<p>Mo Gawdat is the chief business officer at Google X \u2013 the \u201cmoonshot factory\u201d responsible for some of the company\u2019s more audacious projects, such as self-driving cars and a balloon-powered global internet. Before he joined Google, while working as stock trader and tech executive in Dubai and in response to a period of depression, he used his engineer\u2019s mindset to create an \u201cequation for happiness\u201d. The equation says that happiness is greater than, or equal to, your perception of the events in your life minus your expectation of how life should be.</p> <p>When his 21-year-old son Ali died during a routine operation, Gawdat turned to the equation, which they had worked on together, in an attempt to come to terms with his tragic loss. Gawdat\u2019s book, <a href=\"https://bookshop.theguardian.com/solve-for-happy.html\"><em>Solve for Happy</em></a>, explains the theories underpinning the equation and how it helped him sustain his life after Ali\u2019s death.</p> <p><strong>To an outsider you were a successful, wealthy individual with a loving family; not an obvious candidate for someone who felt the need to devote themselves to developing a theory of happiness. You say the more money you had, the less happy you became. </strong><br />That is correct and it\u2019s not uncommon among many of my successful and wealthy friends. The scientific research will tell you that the more income you get the more happy you will become, but once you get to average income your happiness plateaus. Moreover, I found that when you go even higher, wealth starts to work against you \u2013 people start to treat you differently; you start to feel a constant disappointment.</p> <p><strong>You mention that while you were on the \u201chedonistic treadmill\u201d you bought two Rolls-Royces online on a whim.</strong><br />That truly was a turning point. This was again the attempt to fill that gap in my soul. When they arrived I was completely disappointed, they were pretty, I sat in them for 20 minutes but then I went back to my unhappy thoughts, and once you go back to the things that make you unhappy it doesn\u2019t matter what\u2019s parked in the garage. That was a turning point, that nothing material will solve this stuff.</p> <p><strong>Do you still have them?</strong><br />I\u2019ve been trying to sell them, I\u2019ve tried giving them to charity. They are in showrooms waiting to be sold. I rent cars now.</p> <p><strong>You weren\u2019t able to find joy in your life. Is finding joy a skill that should be taught?</strong><br />Absolutely. Happiness is very much like staying fit. You start with the decision that you are going to get fit, you find out how \u2013 but knowing that is not enough, you have to go to the gym to work out and eat healthily. To me the whole topic of happiness is exactly the same. First you understand that happiness is a choice, that you can actually achieve it and that there is a method to make it happen. Happiness is not a coincidence, it is not given to you by life, it\u2019s entirely our responsibility.</p> <p><strong>When your son died, did you feel like jettisoning your theories? Are you surprised that your equation held up in such tragic circumstances?</strong><br />You know how there are five stages of grief? We started with acceptance. My wife at the time made an insightful comment when they asked to do an autopsy on Ali\u2019s body: \u201cWill it bring Ali back?\u201d The realisation that nothing we could do, including crying in our rooms for the next 17 years, would ever bring him back\u2026 we started from there.</p> <p>I then went through a rollercoaster. But I would sometimes imagine talking to Ali and if you knew him, his first reaction would be: \u201cPapa I\u2019ve already died, there\u2019s nothing you can do about it, so what are you going to make out of it?\u201d When I started going through this dialogue it made me realise that this can be for a reason, for good can come out of it.</p> <p><strong>Do you ever wonder how you would have responded to your son\u2019s death if you hadn\u2019t developed your happiness equation?</strong><br />I would have definitely left life, I wouldn\u2019t have killed myself, but I would have found a corner somewhere and shut the door and sat there until they came. Ali was not just my son, he was my mentor, best friend, confidante, my teacher, he truly was \u201cit\u201d, basically. I can\u2019t imagine I would have handled it at all without the model we built together.</p> <p><strong>You talk about how happiness is a human\u2019s default state. Where\u2019s your evidence for this?</strong><br />That was one of the eye-openers for me. The first observation was I was a very happy young man until around 25, and then something went wrong, and I became very unhappy. To me, an engineer, that means you have a highly optimised machine that began to misbehave. So I started to go back to all the points where I was happy. If you go back to childhood, you observe that if a child\u2019s basic needs are met their default state is happy \u2013 they don\u2019t need an iPhone, they can play with their toes and be happy.</p> <p><strong>You say that the voice inside your head isn\u2019t you. If we aren\u2019t the voices inside our heads, what are we?</strong><br />We have a set of illusions. One of them is that we associate so strongly with the voice in our head when the reality is that it is just a biological function; it is exactly like your heart pumping blood around your body. It\u2019s your brain\u2019s way of delivering survival functions to you \u2013 its job is to scan the world around it using sensory input and then coordinate your muscle responses and take action so that you survive.</p> <p>Thoughts have truly propelled our civilisation, and we think of the voice inside our heads as us. But that isn\u2019t remotely true once you realise that you don\u2019t have to obey your thoughts \u2013 I can accept them, I can reject them, I can ask the brain to go and get me a better one. You can do what people do in meetings: you ask me a question, I give you an answer, but you can say to me: \u201cMo, can you get me a better answer?\u201d, and I go back to my brain and I say, give me a better answer. Treat your brain as a biological function and understand he is not the boss \u2013 you are the boss.</p> <p><strong>Can you explain what you mean by the illusion of time?</strong><br />We deal with time every day, yet no one really knows what time is, including the master of the science of time Albert Einstein. He\u2019ll tell you that past, present and future is nothing more than a stubborn persistent illusion. We have created machines that measure mechanical movement in such a way, yet we have no idea what it is that we are measuring and we are very happy to torture ourselves with it.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/jan/12/googles-research-sibling-x-shuts-down-drones-project\">Google's research sibling X shuts down drones project</a> </p> </aside>  <p>If you ask a Buddhist what time it is, their answer will be \u201cthe time is now\u201d. Like a Buddhist, the only time you have ever lived is a moment of now. You\u2019ve never lived in the past, you will never live in the future; when the future comes it will be a moment of now. Yet we never give ourselves the luxury of living in now; instead, we are constantly living inside our heads looking in the past and the future, and as you do that you constantly suffer.</p> <p><strong>Could you turn your equation into an app?</strong><br />Absolutely. I believe that the book is just the start of a very big initiative. I am trying to create a movement that doesn\u2019t depend on me or the book. I\u2019ve set myself a target of 10 million people happy, and I\u2019m hoping that everyone will set themselves a target of 25 people or 25 million happy, depending on their reach. I\u2019m not about selling books, I believe I\u2019ve been paid by life already.</p> <p><strong>In what sense was your quest to develop an equation for happiness informed by Google X\u2019s moonshot philosophy, to set audacious rather than incremental goals?</strong><br />Absolutely, our CEO Larry Page teaches us to set an audacious target but while you may miss it, what you achieve is greater than if you set a low target.</p> <p><strong>You are on a sabbatical from X?</strong><br />I have a tremendous respect for a company that does things that make the world a better place. Although public opinion sometimes attacks Google, imagine a life without search. I am one of the top execs in Google and I can tell you it is truly not a place about the money, this is a place that is truly about changing the world.</p> <p><strong>When you go back to X what will you be working on?</strong><br />I can tell you but then I\u2019d have to flash you like the <em>Men in Black</em>.</p> <p>\u2022 <em>Solve for Happy</em> by Mo Gawdat is published by Bluebird (\u00a314.99). To order a copy for \u00a312.74 go to <a href=\"https://bookshop.theguardian.com/solve-for-happy.html\">bookshop.theguardian.com</a> or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&amp;p over \u00a310, online orders only. Phone orders min p&amp;p of \u00a31.99</p>",

          "body": "<p>\u201cIf you\u2019re a super nerd, you\u2019re going to freak out in five seconds,\u201d promises Laela French, surrounded by more than 200 props, costumes, models and artwork from one of the most popular film franchises of all time.</p> <p>French is director of archives at the Lucas Museum of Narrative Arts, based at <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/jan/19/the-directors-cut-george-lucas\">George Lucas\u2019s Skywalker ranch in California</a>. The museum is not open to the public, \u201cwhich is why we do these touring exhibitions, it is the only way we can share this collection\u201d, she said.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/nov/15/star-wars-identities-exhibition-disney-george-lucas\">Star Wars Identities probes the space saga's parts that Disney cannot reach</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The O2 complex in south-east London is playing host to the UK leg of a <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/starwars\">Star Wars</a> exhibition world tour, opening to the public on Friday until September next year. The exhibition includes one of the first Darth Vader costumes, the orange jumpsuit and helmet worn by Luke Skywalker on his first rebel mission, and the metal bikini that the gangster Jabba the Hutt forced Princess Leia to wear.</p> <p>The exhibition, which hosted a preview day on Tuesday, fully expects to attract superfans. <a href=\"http://www.starwarsidentities.com/#!/faq/details\">In an FAQ section for the show</a> visitors are instructed as to whether they can wear their stormtrooper costumes (yes, but without the helmet), or bring their lightsaber (definitely not, no weapons).<br /></p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"11fa09e3ed616835b85e7801029e22f1db0fb0df\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/11fa09e3ed616835b85e7801029e22f1db0fb0df/533_17_4724_2836/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Star Wars exhibition O2.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The exhibition aims to be educational as well as fun.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: TM &amp; \u00a9 2016 Lucasfilm Ltd. All rights reserved. Used under authorisation.</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The exhibition offers greater insights into how characters were developed, some of them surprising. For example, it took a year and a half to develop the character of Jar Jar Binks, the goofball Gungan introduced because C3PO had less of a role in The Phantom Menace.<br /></p> <p>Elsewhere it is revealed that the character of Yoda had a working name of Minch and before that Buffy. He could have looked, according to some of the original concept artwork, like a jolly Christmas gnome rather than a small shrivelled Albert Einstein-based Jedi master.</p> <p>The show reveals how Lucas got the idea for Chewbacca from his experiences driving around with his faithful dog, an Alaskan malamute, by his side. The voice is based on a blend of sounds from a walrus and a cinnamon bear.</p> <p>As everybody knows, lightsabers are green, blue or red. Mace Windu\u2019s is purple because, the exhibition reveals, Samuel L Jackson personally asked Lucas for a unique weapon.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ee1266dcf401e13312e76005151c2466b31f6cba\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ee1266dcf401e13312e76005151c2466b31f6cba/0_51_3500_2100/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The exhibition is in London until September next year.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The exhibition is in London until September next year.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Joerg Koch/TM &amp; \u00a9 2016 Lucasfilm Ltd. All rights reserved. Used under authorization.</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The show is more than a collection of objects and offers visitors the chance to \u201cdiscover the hero inside yourself\u201d with a series of interactive psychological questions.</p> <p>Most have a Star Wars slant. So do you want to be a Wookiee or a Nautolan or an Ewok or one of another dozen options? Who would you choose as a mentor, Qui-Gon Jinn? Darth Vader? Yoda? Which planet do you want yourself to come from? The snowy expanses of Hoth? The desperate deserts of Tatooine? The stunning lakes of Naboo?</p> <p>French said she hoped the show would be educational as well as fun. She said: \u201cIf we can bring people in because they know and love Star Wars, and come out the other side inspired and having learned something, then it is a win-win for everybody.\u201d</p> <p>\u2022 Star Wars Identities: The Exhibition is at the O2 London from 18 November to 3 September 2017.</p>",

        "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/books/2017/jan/21/reality-is-not-what-it-seems-by-carlo-rovelli-review",

          "body": "<p>Carlo Rovelli\u2019s slim poetic meditation <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/oct/11/seven-brief-lessons-physics-carlo-rovelli-review-paean-science\" title=\"\"><em>Seven Brief Lessons on Physics</em></a> managed to clarify the troubling uncertainties of Einsteinian relativity, quantum theory and other physical exotica. Less than 80 pages long, it became one of the fastest-selling science books ever, and has now sold a million copies worldwide. Not since Stephen Hawking\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/mar/07/100-best-nonfiction-books-6-brief-history-of-time-stephen-hawking\" title=\"\"><em>A Brief History of Time</em></a> had there been such a consensual success in the science book market; in the author\u2019s native Italy the lessons even outsold <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/fifty-shades-of-grey\" title=\"\"><em>Fifty Shades of Grey</em></a>.</p> <p><em>Reality Is Not What It Seems</em> \u2013 a deeper, more intellectually challenging meditation \u2013 outlines for the general reader some of the key developments in physics from the ancient Greek philosophers and the Roman poet Lucretius to the present day. In the Italian professor\u2019s elucidation, physics goes deeper than any other science into the riddle of existence. The laws of physics \u2013 gravity, energy, motion \u2013 underpin those of chemistry, astrophysics and meteorology combined. So an understanding of the world requires some grasp of physics. This book aims to make that grasp easier for the layperson.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/oct/16/carlo-rovelli-interview-quantum-gravity-physics-science-is-where-revolutions-happen\">Carlo Rovelli: \u2018Science is where revolutions happen\u2019</a> </p> </aside>  <p>It should be noted, however, that <em>Reality</em> first came out in Italy in 2014 before <em>Seven Lessons</em>, so, with this edition translated into English by Simon Carnell and Erica Segre, we are getting Rovelli in reverse order of publication. No matter. In exquisitely written pages he seeks to bridge the divide between what CP Snow called the \u201cTwo Cultures\u201d of science and the arts. According to Rovelli, this divide widened catastrophically in\u00a0Italy after the 1923 fascist school reforms ensured that the classics provided the core curriculum, not science. He has never quite forgiven Italy\u2019s pro-Mussolini philosopher Benedetto Croce for his conviction that \u201cscientific problems are not real ones\u201d (Croce later turned against Mussolini).</p> <p>In a superb chapter on Dante and his conception of paradise and the cosmos, Rovelli writes: \u201cOur culture is foolish to\u00a0keep science and poetry separated,\u201d adding: \u201cthey are two tools to open our eyes to the complexity and beauty of the world.\u201d Like the Italian scientist-writer <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/primolevi\" title=\"\">Primo Levi</a>, Rovelli sees no incompatibility between the two cultures, only mutual attraction. In Lucretius\u2019s long philosophical poem, <em>On the Nature of Things</em>, he finds a luminous celebration of the mysteries of the natural world that anticipated a\u00a0large part of contemporary physics. Atoms are the sole \u201cbuilding blocks\u201d of\u00a0the universe, Lucretius observed. Lucretius did not know it, but he was writing about the quintessential atom of life \u2013 carbon \u2013 at\u00a0a time when atomic theory did not exist. <em>On the Nature of Things</em> only became \u201cmodern\u201d in 1417, however, when the papal scribe and humanist Poggio Bracciolini chanced on the last surviving manuscript of the poem in a German monastery. Subsequently, the poem was translated and disseminated widely. Shakespeare struck a Lucretian note in <em>Romeo and Juliet</em>, Rovelli writes, where the phantasmagoric Queen Mab is believed to have a \u201cteam of little atomies\u201d at her\u00a0command.</p> <p>Certainly Lucretius was ahead of his\u00a0time. Girolamo Savonarola, the firebrand church reformer of Renaissance Florence, fulminated against his pagan-era theory of atoms, which seemed to militate against Christian absolutism. Throughout, Rovelli repudiates religious fundamentalists of any denomination \u2013 but also rejects the idea that science is ever settled. \u201cThe search for knowledge is not nourished by certainty: it is nourished by a radical distrust in certainty,\u201d he comments in a chapter on loop quantum gravity theory. Scientists such as <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/science/dawkins\" title=\"\">Richard Dawkins</a> who pretend to atheist omniscience are, Rovelli argues, no less intolerant or prejudiced; the world is not necessarily as Dawkins thinks it is.</p> <p>Science is not and never has been about certainty. \u201cOnly by keeping in mind that our beliefs may turn out to be wrong is it possible to free ourselves from wrong ideas,\u201d Rovelli writes axiomatically. The joy of physics lies partly in its willingness to be wrong and to explore the world experimentally. Dante\u2019s Ulysses reminds his companions that we are not made \u201cto live like brutes, but to seek virtue and knowledge\u201d. Of course, curiosity-driven researchers such as Galileo Galilei incurred the wrath of the Catholic church in the 17th century by putting divine laws to test and conducting investigations. (\u201cFor in much wisdom is much grief\u201d: Ecclesiastes.) In a brilliant chapter, Rovelli extols Galileo as a proto-physicist who \u201ctasted\u201d the apple of\u00a0knowledge and was jailed by the ecclesiastical authorities for daring to\u00a0exercise his\u00a0curiosity.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/jul/05/seven-brief-lessons-on-physics-carlo-rovelli-review\">Seven Brief Lessons on Physics review \u2013 science without the detail</a> </p> </aside>  <p>A \u201ccurious\u201d person (from the Latin <em>cura</em>, \u201ccare\u201d) was originally understood to be somebody who undertook investigations with due diligence. One such was the Belgian Jesuit-educated priest Georges Lema\u00eetre, who, in 1927, developed what would become known as Big Bang theory. Nobody would claim that these ideas were easy, but Rovelli writes with bracing clarity of Lema\u00eetre\u2019s discovery that the universe is not fixed, but ever-expanding. The Catholic priest\u00a0personified the modern \u201cstruggle with curiosity\u201d and even what it means to be\u00a0human.</p> <p>Along the way, Rovelli discourses (not always clearly) on spatio-temporal continuums, the infinitude of matter, gravitational waves and other abstract ideas. The \u201creal magic\u201d of 20th-century physics begins with Einstein: his notion that time and space cannot be separated (the concept of \u201cspacetime\u201d) posed a\u00a0threat to the cosy certainties of anti-relativity scientists. Unlike the wafer-thin <em>Lessons</em>, this book by Rovelli will not fit easily into a pocket, but its lapidary integration of science and literature is a marvel. \u201cIs the world not marvellous?\u201d Rovelli asks. Yes, <em>signor professore</em>, we do believe it is.</p> <p><em>\u2022 Reality Is Not What It Seems</em> is published by Allen Lane. To order a copy for \u00a314.44 go to <a href=\"https://bookshop.theguardian.com/reality-is-not-what-it-seems.html?utm_source=editoriallink&amp;utm_medium=merch&amp;utm_campaign=article\" title=\"\">bookshop.theguardian.com</a> or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&amp;p over \u00a310, online orders only. Phone orders min p&amp;p of \u00a31.99.</p>",

        "fields": {
          "body": "<p><strong>Last week <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/gnm-press-office/2017/mar/30/guardian-bolsters-award-winning-environment-team\">the Guardian announced</a> that it was expanding its environment desk, adding three heavyweight reporters to its continent-spanning, award-winning team. Here Jonathan Watts, who will take up the new role of global environment editor in a few months\u2019 time, explains why he believes this is the most important story on the planet right now.</strong></p> <p>The environment has always been a subject close to my heart and it has become an increasing focus of my work over two decades with the Guardian. That is no doubt because the problems of climate change, biodiversity loss, pollution and over-consumption have become bigger and more apparent.</p> <p>When I started out as a cub reporter in Japan in the mid-1990s, I learned a lot collaborating with Paul Brown, then the environment correspondent, on articles about the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/1999/oct/02/paulbrown.jonathanwatts\">Tokaimura nuclear accident</a> and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2001/jul/13/globalwarming.climatechange\">Kyoto climate protocol</a>. After moving to China in 2003, I increasingly found myself writing about <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/news/2004/oct/11/france.china\">smog</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/jun/07/china-cancer-villages-industrial-pollution\">cancer villages</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2006/nov/24/china.travelnews\">species extinction</a> and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2009/nov/27/china-carbon-targets-climate-change\">carbon emissions.</a> The ramping up of environmental stories was not a deliberate strategy. China\u2019s crisis was so bad that it was impossible to ignore. This made for grim news, but it also made me hopeful that it might be a fulcrum for change. </p> <p>After the Olympics in 2008, I switched jobs to become Asia environment correspondent. In this post, I covered the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2009/dec/20/copenhagen-climate-global-warming\">Copenhagen Climate Conference</a> with <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/dec/23/john-vidal-environment-editor-greatest-job-on-earth\">John Vidal</a> and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/profile/suzannegoldenberg\">Suzanne Goldenberg</a>; the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/oct/27/biodiversity-loss-terrorism\">Nagoya biodiversity conference</a>; the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/09/fukushima-japan-nuclear-disaster-aftermath\">Fukushima tsunami </a>and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/12/japan-nuclear-meltdown-fukushima-reactor\">nuclear disaster</a>; and the rapid <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/mar/19/china-windfarms-renewable-energy\">growth of wind and solar power </a>in the deserts of China. For the past five years, I have been the Guardian\u2019s Latin America correspondent, writing on a broader range of subjects but still putting a priority on environment and development, including <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/nov/14/brazil-amazon-rangers-farmers-burning\">Amazon deforestation</a>, killings of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/15/dying-to-save-amazonian-rainforest-brazil\">conservation activists</a>, the role of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/nov/02/indigenous-rights-forests-climate-change-study\">indigenous communities</a> in <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/sep/09/amazon-tribe-protecting-forest-bows-arrows-gps-camera-traps\">forest protection</a>  and the disturbing frequency of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jan/25/chile-fire-firefighting-international-help\">forest fires</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/17/peru-floods-ocean-climate-change\">floods</a> and other extreme weather events.</p> <p>So why am I going back into full-time, specialised environmental reporting? Because it is the <a href=\"https://www.chinadialogue.net/article/show/single/en/4876--The-world-s-most-important-story-\">most important story of our age</a>. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/18/china-birth-of-superpower\">China led me to suspect</a> that global economic growth had run into an ecological wall, which is the underlying source of stress and conflict in the world. When I moved to Latin America, I hoped to find alternative, less destructive paths of development, but there was a part of me that also felt I was running away from my own conclusions. The new post will take me back.</p> <p>The responsibility is huge. The timing is crucial. Brexit was a vote against globalisation. Trump is waging war on the environment. To counter these trends, the Guardian has devoted more resources to its environment coverage. I am looking forward to being a part of an expanded team, but we have a tough act to follow. Brown, Vidal, George Monbiot, Damian Carrington and other present and former colleagues have been pioneers in this field with agenda-setting coverage and comment. Trying to maintain that quality, ambition and influence \u2013 while looking for new approaches to changing situations \u2013 will be a hard but worthwhile task.</p> <p>As to the task that humanity faces, I think the problem and the solution are environmental. The world\u2019s current concerns - rising nationalism, swelling migration, financial instability, worsening inequality and lack of confidence in governance systems - are to varying degrees caused by insecurity and fear about the future. Underlying that is an awareness (conscious or unconscious) that our current path of capital-and-carbon-driven development is wrecking our home planet, running down resources, devastating other species and building up environmental costs that are increasingly difficult to offload on distant countries and coming generations. We have to pay a bill that has been run up over centuries and it feels as if we are broke. But that is misleading. There is still plenty left if we manage it well and share it more fairly.</p> <p>We need to reconsider what is important, what is worth paying for and how decisions are being made. At a national level, why are we devoting so much public money to subsidise fossil fuels that are destroying the climate? Why are most politics determined by four-, five- or six-year electoral cycles that suit the markets but not the long-term interests of voters? Why do our economic systems make it cheaper to dump plastic in the oceans than recycle? Why do traditional beliefs of some countries encourage the slaughter of endangered animals or denial of climate science? Why are forests worth less than cropland? Why do we continue to prioritise material growth when it increasingly leads to obesity, cancer, conflict and instability?</p> <p>The key, I think, is to realise that, contrary to what Bill Clinton once said - it\u2019s not \u201cthe economy, stupid!\u201d - it is in fact the environment that is shaping everything. Which is to say that we must put our home in order before we can consider anything else. That is tough. Currently, political systems are skewed against the environment and the subject is hidden away in a media ghetto. It is a depressing page on a news website or an unpopular slot on TV channels. Most of us would prefer to pretend it didn\u2019t exist. Yet, for me the environment is not a subject, it is the prism through which everything else must be seen. It is the basis for the economy, for science, for society, for politics. Adam Smith, Albert Einstein, Karl Marx and Mao Zedong never understood this. Nor did the founders of the great religions. They didn\u2019t need to. They did not live in the Anthropocene.</p> <p>So, how to put the environment front and centre is the big challenge. Following my predecessors, I will continue to visit the frontline of humankind\u2019s impact on the natural world \u2013 the oceans, forests, mountains, deserts, poles, science labs, conference halls and affected communities \u2013 where I will continue to bear witness and record testimonies of change. But they are just symptoms. I hope I can also work with and encourage my colleagues on other news desks to consider the environment in their coverage of politics, social change, economics, psychology, art, religion and education. Those areas, close to home, perhaps inside our heads, are where we will find the cause and the cure. It\u2019s time to colonise the colonisers.</p> <p>We are all entering disconcerting new territory. Given demographic, economic and consumerist trends, the next 30 years will be difficult. But there is more than enough new knowledge and technology, as well as old philosophy and religion to make things much better. It is all about choices and action.</p> <p>\u2022 If you have any new ideas, collaborations or story suggestions for the new environmental reporting team, please email membershipeditorial@theguardian.com</p> <p><br /></p>",

          "body": "<h2><strong>Peter York\u2019s Hipster Handbook </strong></h2> <h2>9pm, BBC4</h2> <p>A welcome return for the cultural commentator \u2013 albeit a couple of years behind the curve \u2013 exploring that most ironically conventional of subcultures, the hipster, the attendant obsession with \u201cauthenticity\u201d, and its repackaging by the mainstream. En route, he meets the Mast Brothers (beards and chocolates), the owners of Shoreditch\u2019s Cereal Killer Cafe (beards and Cheerios) and eminently sensible advertising guru Sir John Hegarty (beardless). <em>Ali Catterall</em></p> <h2><strong>The Gun Shop: Cutting Edge</strong><br /></h2> <h2>9pm, Channel 4</h2> <p>This show is in the Cutting Edge strand but so light is its tone, it might easily be a new reality show. Which tells its own story, of course, about how differently guns are seen here and in the US, where there are some 65,000 gun dealers. In Battle Creek, Michigan, the likable, right-leaning Joel runs Freedom Firearms, where the answer to a customer\u2019s experience of road rage is to sell him a Glock 43 in Tiffany Blue. Subtly terrifying. <em>John Robinson</em></p> <h2><strong>Paranoid </strong><br />9pm, ITV</h2> <p>Inept policing has been one of this stuttering thriller\u2019s many frustrations: even the greenest TV sleuth should know to arrest Michael Maloney on sight. Now his smarmy shrink has finally become of interest to the cops investigating the murder of a GP, they might be on the verge of busting a global conspiracy to pump us all full of drugs. If it\u2019s not global, it at least extends to D\u00fcsseldorf, where cheerful detective Linda has been hiding something about her past. <em>Jack Seale</em></p> <h2><strong>Conspiracy Files: The Trump Dossier </strong><br />9pm, BBC2</h2> <p>It\u2019s easy \u2013 and indeed appropriate \u2013 to laugh at Donald Trump. But we should be both worried and angry, too: at his cynicism, at his opportunism, at his disregard for truth and at the ominous societal currents his rise reflects. This film explores the various conspiracy theories \u2013 from Obama\u2019s birth certificate to Ted Cruz\u2019s father \u2013 that Trump has attempted to exploit, and runs the rule over the ignoble history of conspiracy in US politics since Watergate. <em>Phil Harrison</em></p> <h2>DC\u2019s Legends of Tomorrow <br />8pm, Sky1</h2> <p>DC Comics meets Doctor Who in this time-travelling superhero show. Season two kicks off with a reshuffled squad of second-string goodies and baddies \u2013 including an Iron Man knockoff, a belligerent arsonist and a bisexual ninja \u2013 protecting the timestream from attack. Musketeer outfits, dinosaurs, a Nazi atomic bomb and a lecherous cameo from Einstein suggest Legends Of Tomorrow has lost none of its berserk, action-packed charm. <em>Graeme Virtue</em></p> <h2>The Apprentice <br />9pm, BBC1</h2> <p>Week five for the tyro tycoons, with the bedraggled contenders dragged out of bed at 5am for a rendezvous at Stratford\u2019s Lee Valley VeloPark. The task: peddling a crowdfunded gadget to ease the lot of city cyclists, with options including high-end safety gilets and traffic-aware earbuds. Will the teams concoct clickworthy content that can lure thousands of cyclists to their funding pages within an inaugural 24 hours? Or just bicker relentlessly about hashtags? <em>Mark Gibbings-Jones</em></p> <h2>The Young Pope <br />9pm, Sky Atlantic</h2> <p>Paolo Sorrentino\u2019s series is sure to get right up the robes of the Catholic establishment with its impious use of imagery. Worse for them are its central assumptions that Jude Law (AKA \u201cLenny\u201d, Pope Pius XIII) might somehow land the position of Pope and that the Vatican\u2019s cardinals are a scheming and manipulative bunch. Tonight, in the face of further plotting, Pius divides public opinion at a press conference but does gain one new follower. <em>David Stubbs</em></p> <h2>Film choice</h2> <p><strong>Hunger</strong> (Steve McQueen, 2008), 1.15am, Film4 </p> <p>New BFI fellow Steve McQueen\u2019s debut feature is an intense account of the last weeks in the life of the IRA\u2019s Bobby Sands. It\u2019s a nightmarish vision of the dirty protest \u2013 when the inmates of the Maze prison\u2019s H-block used faeces and urine to rebel against Thatcher and the authorities who refused to designate them as political prisoners \u2013 and Sands\u2019s fatal hunger strike, portrayed with stunning conviction by Michael Fassbender. <em>Paul Howlett</em></p> <h2>Live sport</h2> <p><strong>Tennis: The Paris Masters </strong>Coverage of the fourth day at the AccorHotels Arena in Paris. 10am, Sky Sports 1<br /></p> <p><strong>Europa League Football: Southampton v Inter Milan </strong>The Serie A team visit the south coast\u2019s St Mary\u2019s Stadium. 7.45pm, BT Sport 2</p> <p><strong>NFL: Tampa Bay Buccaneers v Atlanta Falcons </strong>Coverage of the NFC South clash at the Raymond James Stadium. 12.30am, Sky Sports 1</p>",
